HEADLINE: Airlines Clash in Court on Fares

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GALVESTON, Tex., July 21

 BODY:
With videotapes, flip-charts, enlargements of once-secret memos and thousands of documents, armies of lawyers in Federal District Court here are re-enacting the airline fare war of 1992.
In an elegantly restored courtroom with carved wooden panels and silk drapes, Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines are trying to draw blood, demonstrating that American Airlines engaged in "predatory pricing." That means setting fares so low that American would lose money, but so would its weaker rivals, who might be forced out of business. 
 Continental and Northwest say American's policies cost them at least $1 billion last year. American Airlines, whose executives deny they engaged in predatory pricing, say Continental and Northwest stumbled because of mismanagement.
 
Crandall Meets Jamail
 For many people at the courthouse here, the anticipated highlight of the trial will come next week, when Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines' parent, the AMR Corporation, will take the stand. Mr. Crandall is known for his outspoken views, and his grilling at the hands of Joseph D. Jamail, the folksy Houston lawyer representing Continental, is much awaited.
"Joe Jamail is no wilting flower," said the presiding judge, Samuel B. Kent, of the man best known for winning a multibillion-dollar judgment against Texaco Inc. in 1985 for his client, Pennzoil, in a fight over who would acquire Getty Oil. "I may have to eat a power bar that day."
Of the testimony so far, the highlights have been the appearance today of Robert R. Ferguson 3d, president and chief executive of Continental Airlines, and of John Dasburg, chief executive at Northwest Airlines, last week.
Mr. Ferguson testified that he believed American's pricing strategy and its half-price summer sale last year delayed Continental from emerging from bankruptcy, derailed the airline's ambitious improvement plans and thrust the airline into a fight for survival.
After Continental matched American's new and lower fares in April 1992, Mr. Ferguson said, the airline lost $30 million a month and an additional $60 million to $70 million during the summer fare war.
By July, he said, Continental had only two days' worth of cash on hand, about $29 million, but managed to win concessions from some lessors of its planes so it could continue operating.
Mr. Ferguson told the court that American's deep fare cuts were "both predatory and below cost." If Continental and Northwest had gone out of business, he said American could have raised prices by 10 to 20 percent in selected markets.
On cross-examination, Irv Terrell, a lawyer for American Airlines, produced a Continental marketing report on the airline's plans for fall 1992 that said American's pricing strategy left business customers "up for grabs" and had the effect of "leveling the playing field." Mr. Ferguson said he did not recall seeing the document.
Mr. Ferguson will be back on the stand on Thursday morning.
In testimony last week, Mr. Dasburg told the court that Mr. Crandall had put pressure on him, in a conversation in September 1991, to join in raising airline ticket prices.
Mr. Dasburg said Mr. Crandall and Donald V. Carty, an AMR executive vice president, took him aside after a dinner gathering of airline and aerospace executives and "lectured me with regard to pricing at Northwest Airlines."
Mr. Crandall, he testified, "stated that we were a discount carrier and I personally ought to make sure I was supervising pricing." Mr. Dasburg said he interpreted that to be a suggestion that Northwest raise its fares, and he said he reported the discussion to Northwest's general counsel.
American Airlines executives have disputed that the conversation ever took place.
 
'Value Pricing' at Heart
 At the heart of the case is what American Airlines called "value pricing," introduced on April 9, 1992. The airline said the approach was a way to end the confusing array of ticket prices by offering only four fares: first class, coach and two discount fares requiring advance purchase.
American hoped that other carriers would go along with plan, and many did. But a month later, Northwest fired the first shot of the summer fare war by offering a promotion of a free ticket for each adult paying a fare for a child. American volleyed back, offering 50 percent on domestic fares to all leisure passengers who could meet certain restrictions.
An all-out fare war ensued, and industry losses mounted. Continental, which at the time was operating under bankruptcy protection, and Northwest, which Mr. Dasburg said was almost out of money, say they lost a combined $1 billion as a result of American's actions.
In court documents, American has denied pricing its fares below its costs.
Lawyers for Northwest and Continental have been trying to use American's own internal documents to make their case that American slashed prices even though it would cost it hundreds of millions of dollars.
 
Economist on Stand
 On Monday and Tuesday, these lawyers questioned a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist who performed a computer analysis of American's projections for its value-pricing plan.
The economist, Franklin Fisher, said it was "preposterous" for American officials to believe the would make money under the value-pricing plan. "It's plain that unless they damaged or weakened competition, it could never pay off," he testified.
American reported a $935 million loss last year, and Dr. Fisher said hundreds of millions of those dollars came from the value-pricing plan and the summer half-price sale.
But if American succeeded in pushing weaker rivals out of business, he said, it would reap about a $500 million a year in additional profits by raising fares, recouping its losses in no more than two years.
A lawyer for American Airlines, Robert Cooper, countered that that Dr. Fisher's estimates for recoupment were based on theory and not market realities. He defended American's simplified fares as a legitimate competitive strategy and noted that in 1990, Northwest said predatory pricing "just can't happen" in the airline industry because of the competitive environment.
Northwest and Continental lawyers say they expect to finish presenting their evidence by Friday.
 
Parade of Charts
 The proceedings have been moving at a brisk pace: the jury of three women and nine men has viewed videotaped testimony by several American pricing officials and its chief financial officer, listened to testimony by a Northwest pricing executive and expert witnesses and seen a dizzying parade of air fare charts, route maps and memos on projector screens.
If the jury should conclude that American Airlines violated antitrust laws, it could assess punitive damages up to three times the amount claimed.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dun & Bradstreet President Ascends to Chief Executive

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Robert E. Weissman, would become chief executive on Jan. 1, a planned succession that was generally praised by industry analysts.
Charles W. Morris, currently the chairman and chief executive, will remain as chairman, the company said. 
 Mr. Weissman, 53, joined D.& B. in 1979 when his computer time-sharing firm was acquired. He is well regard ed by financial analysts, who say his technical expertise and charismatic presence are likely to bring new vigor to D& B, where he faces significant challenges.
In an interview, Mr. Weissman said he expected future expansion for the company in Asia and the countries in the former Soviet Union, where rudimentary economies make information-gathering a harder task. "That means we don't have a minute to lose," he said.
Through a series of acquisitions in the 80's, D.& B. became the world's largest marketer of information to business through such well-known companies as Nielsen, the television-audience and consumer-products research firm, and Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating agency.
 
Hurt by Rival and Recession
 But the company's record of rapid and consistent revenue growth during the decade, peaking at 16 percent in 1984, has slowed in recent years. With 40 percent of its revenue from foreign sources, D.& B. has been hurt by the recession, particularly in Europe, the emergence of a new domestic rival in consumer-product marketing, Information Resources Inc., and structural changes in the business of mainframe software and Yellow Pages publishing.
"It's been knocked off its pedestal as a glamour, growth stock," said James C. Goss, a media and information services analyst with Duff & Phelps.
Shares in D.& B., which also reported second-quarter results showing a 3.6 percent increase in income on flat revenue growth, rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $60.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 23, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a picture caption in Business Day yesterday about executive changes at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation referred incorrectly to the company's chairman and chief executive in some editions. He is Charles W. Moritz.

HEADLINE: Bothered and Bewildered

BYLINE: By Katha Pollitt; Katha Pollitt is an associate editor of The Nation.

 BODY:
Murphy Brown's baby apparently has a lot of real-life company. A just released Census Bureau report tells us that among white women and women with some college education, the percentage who have become mothers without marrying has more than doubled in the last decade, to 14.6 percent and 11.3 percent, respectively; among women with professional or managerial jobs, it has almost tripled, to 8.3 percent. While the numbers are small -- most unwed mothers are poor and thus disproportionately black or Hispanic -- they show that single motherhood cannot be explained by words like "inner-city," "welfare dependency" and "pathology."
Nonetheless, you can virtually hear the hum of word processors as family-values advocates labor through the hot summer nights, turning out articles and speeches bemoaning the new statistics and rounding up the usual suspects: feminism, promiscuity, the media, the 60's. 
 What if instead of trying to bully women to the altar, we ask why they're no longer running up the aisles?
Maybe marriage no longer serves women very well. Historically, lucky women married for love and still do -- I'm sure that most of today's unwed employed moms would be pleased to tie the knot with a diaper-changing Mr. Right -- but beneath the hearts and flowers, middle-class marriage was an economic bargain. He supported her; she minded the house and children.
With rare exceptions, marriage was the only path to female adulthood: a home of one's own, community standing, a sex life, children. Barred from professional training and good jobs, threatened with disgrace and the loss of her baby if she got pregnant, mocked as a spinster if she stayed unwed past her early 20's, a woman was pushed into marriage by just about every social institution: family, religion, neighbors, custom, law, school, the workplace, doctors of soul and body.
None of this is so true today. If women can support themselves, they don't need to marry for what was politely called security but was, to put it bluntly, money. If single women can have sex, their own homes, the respect of friends and interesting work, they don't need to tell themselves that any marriage is better than none. Why not have a child on one's own? Children are a joy; many men are not. To take care of a child makes sense: Children cannot cook their own meals, make their own doctor's appointments, do their own laundry. To take care of a husband after working all day makes much less sense, but most men still seem to expect it. All around them, single women see divorced women raising their kids, often with little or no child support, and hear married moms say that they might as well be single for all the help they get from their mates. If single women increasingly see marriage and motherhood as separate commitments, perhaps the reason is that they are.
The collapse of the traditional middle-class marriage bargain has left both sexes bewildered, and is a major cause of the much-discussed open hostility between men and women. But how can you make the sexes act as if they needed each other to survive when they don't? All they need each other for is love, and love is hard to find. That is the nettle the family-values proponents refuse to grasp. They keep talking as if women can be coralled into marriage by appeals to morality and self-sacrifice or punitive social policies. But the futility of their cause is shown by the feeble measures they propose: deglamorizing single motherhood, emphasizing fatherhood, stigmatizing single moms or their kids.
Critics of single motherhood cite studies showing higher rates of everything from crime to kids' visits to shrinks. What they don't tell you is that most of this results from the crushing poverty in which so many single mothers live. Among middle-class kids, the only fair comparison is between those raised by single parents and those raised by unhappily married couples. That is at best the real-life alternative that single mothers face. Here, too, the difference to the children vanishes.
There's isn't any way, in our modern, secular society, to reconnect marriage and maternity. We'd have to bring back the whole 19th century: Restore the cult of virginity and the double standard, ban birth control, restrict divorce, kick women out of decent jobs, force unwed pregnant women to put their babies up for adoption on pain of social death, make out-of-wedlock children legal nonpersons.
None of this will happen, so why not come to terms with reality? Instead of trying to make women -- and men -- adapt to an outworn institution, we should adapt our institutions to the lives people actually live. Single mothers need paid parental leave, day care, flexible schedules, child support, pediatricians with evening hours. Most of all, they need equal pay and comparable worth. What they don't need is sermons.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Near Low vs. Yen But Gains on the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar sank close to its record low against the Japanese yen yesterday as the United States renewed calls for currency rate changes to slash Japan's huge trade surplus.
But the dollar rebounded against the German mark as fresh tensions in the European Monetary System set off a flight to safer investments. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery gained $1.80 an ounce, to $391.30. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $391.75 an ounce, up $3.05 from Wednesday.
The dollar plunged as low as 105.10 yen yesterday afternoon after Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger Altman said changes in currency rates might help lower Japan's trade surplus. The level was the weakest since June 15, when the dollar hit a new postwar low of 104.82 yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.25 yen, down from 108.13 yen on Wednesday.
"It shows that the Clinton Administration believes that by manipulating dollar-yen, it's going to help reduce the United States trade deficit," said Ken Nixon, corporate foreign exchange dealer at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, of Altman's remark.
The yen had risen earlier as many fled the mark amid renewed speculation that the European Monetary System could soon collapse, leading to lower interest rates and weaker currencies in Europe.
The system, which ties several currencies to a tight trading range, came under siege as the French franc, Danish krone, Spanish peseta and Portuguese escudo plunged despite central bank intervention and Government statements to stop the selloff.
The mark, followed by sterling and the Swiss franc rose against other European currencies on safe-haven buying. The dollar was preferred over the mark, but the yen was the most favored currency.
 
 
'Bailing Out of Europe'
 "Everybody is selling marks and buying yen. Everybody's bailing out of Europe now," said Tom Moore, senior director at American Express Bank.
The dollar rose to 1.7044 German marks in late New York trading, from 1.6975 marks late Wednesday. The British pound, meanwhile, fell to $1.5120 late in New York, below $1.5150 Wednesday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.5095, from $1.5160 Wednesday.
At the height of the European selloff, the Bank of France denied rumors of a news conference to announce a sharp rise in interest rates or devaluation of the French franc.
 "The market's confused about the validity of these rumors," said Jim Blackwelder, vice president at First Union National Bank. "On one hand you say you don't think it'll happen. But on the other hand, just in case, it's better to be positioned."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Airline ticket prices have risen sharply in the last two years despite fare wars, competition from upstart carriers and attempts by the industry to simplify prices. Analysts say prices will continue to rise in small but steady increments. [Page A1.]
The Fed will abandon its traditional yardstick for steering the economy -- money supply -- because it has become unreliable. Alan Greenspan said the Fed would focus on interest rates. [D1.] 
 Personal incomes in the last two years have grown at less than half the rate of previous recoveries, the Government said. New jobless claims jumped because of seasonal variations. [D2.]
Budget conferees agreed to a steep increase in the top income tax rate and to leave the capital gains tax rate unchanged. [A11.]
 
Companies
Lawrence E. Hilibrand, who earned Salomon Brothers millions of dollars in trading for its account, will leave. His departure reflects the firm's shift from trading for itself toward the customer-account business, which produced record profits. [D1.]
Joseph R. Perella resigned as chairman of Wasserstein Perella, ending his partnership with Bruce Wasserstein and breaking up aninfluential team from the takeover battles of the 1980's. The move was said to involve compensation issues for executives. [D1.]
Long-distance companies are making fatter profits and customers are getting fewer bargains because the industry has turned surprisingly cozy after years of brutal price wars. [D1.]
American Airlines asserted that mismanagement, not American's pricing strategy, almost sank Continental. [D3.]
Sunbeam-Oster will pay $173 million to Paul B. Kazarian and two partners to settle litigation over Mr. Kazarian's ouster. [D3.]
Texaco's second-quarter earnings more than doubled because of higher natural gas prices and increased foreign production. [D3.]
Dreyfus, Franklin and Schwab were accused of deceptive advertising of mutual funds by New York City. [D4.]
A.T.& T. named a new chief financial officer and shuffled seven executives for its push into global markets and multimedia. [D4.]
Burroughs Wellcome's AZT patent was upheld by a judge in a challenge by Barr Laboratories and Novopharm. [A12.]
 
International
German prosecutors broadened their investigation of whether Volkswagen's production chief, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, took secret documents when he left General Motors. [D1.]
Nafta environmental and labor side accords should be completed by early August, the U.S. trade representative said. [D5.]
 
Markets
Stocks retreated as bond prices sank. The Dow industrials fell 30.18 points, to 3,525.22, a day after they set a new high. [D4.]
Prices of Treasury securities fell on further comments by Alan Greenspan that inflation remained a problem. [D12.]
The dollar sank near a record low against the yen but advanced against the mark. Gold rose. [D14.] Soybeans rebounded. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Lawsuits by former sales staff have put WD-40, the maker of a multipurpose lubricating spray, under fire. Market Place. [D4.]
Coca-Cola put to rest speculation that it was dissatisfied with its "Always Coca-Cola" campaign. Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Fed Abandons Policy Tied to Money Supply

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said today that the main yardstick it used in guiding the economy's growth for more than 15 years had become so unreliable that it would largely abandon it.
Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, said the Federal Reserve would stop relying on growth in the money supply -- its traditional tool -- and begin relying on interest rates, an approach more akin to the way it worked before it started relying on the money supply figures.
 
Changes in Investments
 In an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee today, Mr. Greenspan said the central bank was jettisoning the money supply approach because changes in the way Americans invest their money meant it could no longer predict how much economic growth would be produced by a certain amount of growth in the money supply. 
 "The relationship has completely broken down," Mr. Greenspan said.
Some economists predicted, however, that the new approach could present just as many problems as the one being discarded, and would make it harder for investors, economists and politicians to predict the Federal Reserve's actions.
The move comes at a time when the Fed has been criticized for keeping monetary growth so low, thus hampering economic growth. It also comes at a time when President Clinton and others are counting on low interest rates to spur the economy to greater growth.
The Federal Reserve has long sought to influence the economy through interest rates, lowering them to encourage growth and raising them to quell inflationary pressures.
How much attention to pay to the money supply in setting policy has long been a matter of disagreement among economists. Some argue that slow, steady expansion of the money supply is the key to noninflationary growth.
Since the late 1970's, the Federal Reserve has made many of its most important decisions by setting a specific target for growth in the money supply -- loosely the amount of money in circulation plus savings and checking accounts -- and often adjusted interest rates to meet them.
Federal Reserve officials said they were happy with the way money supply targets worked from the late 1970's until last year. Paul A. Volcker, the Fed's former chairman, used these targets to help bring down the double-digit inflation of the late 1970's, and then used them to help steer the record economic expansion after 1982.
Lower interest rates encourage businesses and individuals to borrow more, putting more money into the economy, some of which comes back to the banks, which then make further loans; in these circumstances, money supply grows faster. Higher rates tend to have the opposite effect.
Federal Reserve officials say the decision by millions of Americans to move their money from savings accounts into mutual funds, and particularly money market funds that many people use like savings and checking accounts, is the main factor that has damaged the relationship between money supply growth and economic growth. The reason is that M-2, the Federal Reserve's main measure of the money supply, includes money in savings and checking accounts but does not include money in mutual funds.
 
Like Carpenters Without Tools
 The central bank's predicament is akin to that of a team of carpenters who discover that their levels, plumbs and tape measures are no longer reliable and thus have to rely on the naked eye to make sure walls are vertical and floors horizontal.
"What Greenspan said in effect is he's junking M-2," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York brokerage. "That's historic."
The new tool that the central bank is turning to involves real interest rates -- which are determined by subtracting the inflation rate from nominal interest rates, which have inflation built into them. A 5 percent interest rate, for example, effectively amounts to a 2 percent "real" interest rate if inflation is running at 3 percent. The Fed said it would seek to set real interest rates at a level that creates steady growth with minimal inflation.
The plans to stop relying on monetary growth not only leave the Federal Reserve searching for new guideposts to help steer the nation to a desired level of growth but, critics say, leave the Fed steering by the stars, rather than by science, in trying to bring about steady growth with low inflation.
Mr. Greenspan said it now appeared that the Fed could produce satisfactory economic growth with far lower growth in the money supply than previously believed. In the view of many economists, the Fed's reliance on a new tool -- real interest rates -- indicates that the central bank will raise rates sooner rather than later.
 
Excuse for Raising Rates?
 Several economists interviewed said real short-term interest rates of between 1 percent and 2 percent could be expected to produce moderate growth with low inflation. Because Mr. Greenspan is concerned that real interest rates are below zero at the moment, many economists say he will use the new tool as an excuse for raising short-term interest rates soon. The Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend each other money overnight -- is 3 percent, while the inflation is running slightly above that.
As Senate Democrats badgered Mr. Greenspan to keep interest rates low to speed up job growth, Mr. Greenspan repeated the central bank's concerns about holding down inflation.
"The signal we are endeavoring to send here is at some point rates are going to have to move up," he said, giving no indication of how soon the central bank might act. The consensus among economists is that the Federal Reserve would raise rates in two months if inflation news over the next two months is bad, but that it could hold off indefinitely if inflation simmers down, as it seems to be at the moment.
 
 
End of Monetarism
 Economists said the central bank's decision to abandon the use of money supply growth as a tool was a nail in the coffin for an economic theory known as monetarism. Under this theory, central banks should keep the money supply growing at a steady, predetermined rate for many years, and that will produce a moderate rate of growth with minimal inflation.
"The Federal Reserve's move shows that the influence of pure monetarists has clearly faded," said Scott Pardee, a former senior Federal Reserve official who is chairman of Yamaichi International America, a brokerage firm. "Even the practical monetarists have found it is hard to use the different measures of the money supply for policy purposes."
Under the Humphrey Hawkins Act of 1978, the Federal Reserve must state its targets for monetary growth every six months. Mr. Greenspan's statement today means the central bank will continue to announce such targets, even though it will largely ignore them in determining monetary policy.
In interviews today, some economists said they had little idea how the Federal Reserve would set targets for real interest rates.
"We're all asking the same questions about how this will work," said John Silvia, chief economist for Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "Under one definition, the real interest rate is zero, but I pay 18 percent on my consumer interest and when you subtract 3 percent inflation doesn't that mean a 15 percent real interest rate? The Fed hasn't analyzed this very much."

HEADLINE: Summer Air Fares Are Up Sharply Despite Return of Multiple Prices

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
In a turnabout that has surprised even airline officials, the average ticket price is sharply higher this year -- not only compared with air fares last summer, when a half-price sale helped put 24 million Americans in the air, but with those in the first six months of 1991.
With money-losing carriers striving to show profits, the increase shows signs of holding, despite sporadic sales, and even though upstart regional carriers are forcing the biggest airlines to lower prices on competitive routes. 
 One consequence of the shifts: a year after the airlines abandoned efforts to simplify air fares, the fare categories are as numerous as ever, and just as confusing to passengers and as worrisome to travel agents. Moreover, while bargains can still be had on selected routes, sales and discounts are more narrowly focused than they were in the past.
 
 
Small but Steady Rises
 As a result, analysts say, if all goes according to script -- in an industry where lately very little has gone that way -- prices will continue to rise in small but steady increments.
"There have been very substantial fare increases since last year, both in leisure and business fares," said Robert Harrell, vice president of the air-fare management unit of American Express Travel Related Services. "Through a series of steadily creeping increases that began the end of last summer, and went up month after month, the carriers got the fare levels way back up."
The average domestic ticket price was $535 last month, according to Topaz Enterprises of Portland, Ore., an air-fare auditing firm. That was not only higher than the $458 average of June 1992 but was up almost 12 percent from the $479 average in June 1991.
The nation's big airlines have put through the increases in an attempt to stanch their flow of red ink, and have done so even though traffic remains sluggish. In December alone, the carriers pushed through three price increases totaling 20 percent on unrestricted coach fares, the highest-priced economy fares used mostly by business travelers. Several other increases have since been tacked on.
In fact, from June 1992 through June 1993, leisure fares rose 81 percent, according to the monthly American Express air-fare index, while full coach fares climbed 47 percent and the lowest economy fare for business travelers rose 44 percent.
From the viewpoint of the carriers, which lost $3 billion last year and almost $10 billion since 1989, higher fares are long overdue. Spokesmen argue that more revenue is necessary to finance enormous capital requirements -- including $130 billion just to replace or modify airline fleets to meet noise standards that take effect by the end of the decade.
 
 
American Posts Modest Profit
 At a news conference on Wednesday, Michael J. Durham, the chief financial officer of American Airlines, acknowledged that average ticket prices were up. But in constant dollars, he added, they are "dramatically lower" than in 1980.
This week, American reported a modest $47 million profit for the second quarter, and Delta and several other carriers have similarly crept into the black in the quarter. But profits remain razor-thin, and not since 1988 has the airline industry earned a net profit margin of as much as 3 percent.
One feature that survived the short-lived "value pricing" system introduced by American Airlines 15 months ago, and which briefly became the industry standard, is allowing leisure travelers to change their flights for a nominal fee. But many travel agents wish that most of the system had remained.
"The idea of trying to simplify fares was a great idea," said Phyllis Swiden of Village Travel in Brookings, S.D. "Now we never know what to expect from day to day -- or even during the same day."
Ms. Swiden is not alone in her complaint, or her bewilderment. "There are 17 different fares just from Phoenix to New York," Rosemary Janicki, the head of Seven Continents Travel in Phoenix, said recently.
Among those fares are unrestricted tickets, leisure fares booked 3, 7 or 14 days in advance, fares for night departures and fares for travel on Tuesday, Wednesday or Saturday, to be completed within 30 days.
Other fares that have returned on many routes, despite efforts last summer to end most of them, are special rates for students, children, members of the military, bereavement fares, negotiated fares for corporate clients and group fares for meetings and conventions. Many carriers also have vacation packages that offer air fare, hotels and ground transportation at a discount. Southwest Airlines has added a twist: one-way fares for tickets bought 14 days in advance; normally, the industry requires a round-trip purchase to qualify for special advance-purchase fares.
Despite these promotional fares, the overall trend is up. While the carriers worry that higher prices will erode traffic, most industry executives attribute the sluggish traffic to a weak economy. And almost all officials say that the carriers need to disabuse the public of the notion, as Mr. Durham of American put it, that "they need not buy a ticket until a fare promotion is announced."
This week, William R. Howard, the new chairman of Trans World Airlines, said the Government should consider reimposing some controls on fares to protect airlines against fare wars, which he called "terribly, terribly destructive." Yet before the recent reorganization of T.W.A. into an airline owned by employees and creditors, it had initiated several fare wars to raise cash as it struggled under bankruptcy protection.
Some of the fare increases, especially for leisure fares, are predictable after last summer's unprecedented and money-losing half-price sale, which began in early June.
 
 
Cut-Rate Competition
 Still, it is noteworthy that overall ticket prices have risen despite the introduction of several low-fare carriers, including Reno Air and Kiwi International, and despite the broadening impact of Southwest Airlines, which last year had more passengers than any other carrier in the 100 busiest markets.
 Fares last year in markets served by Southwest averaged $56 for distances of less than 250 miles and $58 for routes of 251 to 500 miles -- less than half of the cost of routes over equivalent distances that are not served by Southwest.
Last month, USAir cut fares an average of 28 percent on flights in the Northeast of less than 750 miles each way, on tickets requiring a 14-day advance purchase and a Saturday night stay. Industry officials viewed the move as an attempt to blunt the thrust of low-fare airlines.
 
 
Special Weekend Deals
 Hoping to stimulate business among impulse passengers "who have quite a bit of income," as one carrier put it, airlines are offering so-called weekend fares in certain markets -- requiring a three-day advance purchase, a maximum stay of four days, departure on Thursday through Saturday and a Saturday night stay. They cost about half the price of an unrestricted coach fare.
"Value pricing assumed that the market only demanded three fares," said Michael W. McCormack, director of industry relations for Rosenbluth Travel, a large Philadelphia-based agency. "But the market is more complex, and airlines are looking to fill the niches in order to maximize yield. Rather than squeeze customer demand into a few buckets, they're creating more buckets."
 The leading airlines again offer corporate discounts, and Delta Air Lines, once content merely to match its rivals, is aggressively pursuing business travelers. Business Travel News, an industry newspaper, said Delta had put together a 20-person headquarters sales staff in a quiet bid to transform itself into a leader in corporate travel.
But discounts for corporate clients differ from those of the past. "Before value pricing, some of those commitments were implied," Mr. McCormack said. "Now the carriers want explicit commitments as to how much business the corporations will deliver to them."

HEADLINE: Tax Fight Protects Lautenberg's Seat

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 22

 BODY:
Fifteen months before he comes up for re-election in New Jersey, Senator Frank Lautenberg is already running hard for a third term. His chief opponent at the moment appears to be Bill Clinton.
On one of his frequent forays onto his home turf recently, Mr. Lautenberg seemed to relish talking about how he told the Democratic President in Washington that his deficit reduction plan was no good for New Jersey. 
 "It's not pleasant to sit across from the President of the United States and say, 'It's no go,' " Mr. Lautenberg said.
And what did Mr. Clinton say?
"I think he said, 'Frank, that's not nice," said Mr. Lautenberg, one of six Senate Democrats who voted against the Clinton tax package. His reason, the Senator said, was that it did nothing to aid the Northeast's economy while making major concessions to oil and agricultural states.
 
Guarding His Own Future
 But Mr. Lautenberg may also have been looking out for something more personal than regional economics: his own political future.
He is up for election in 1994 and it is shaping up to be a tough fight. New Jerseyans are sour on taxes. Mr. Clinton won the state with only 43 percent of the vote, and Mr. Lautenberg, who will be 70 years old, may face no less formidable an opponent than former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is being urged by national Republicans to run and says he is considering it.
Republicans at both the state and national level think Mr. Lautenberg is vulnerable if they can paint him as a free-spending liberal Democrat in this tax-weary state.
If Mr. Kean does not run, the Congressman from the 12th District, Dick Zimmer, says he will, and is already sniping at Mr. Lautenberg as "a tax-and-spend Democrat" only recently converted to a "born-again fiscal conservative."
Marge Roukema, now in her seventh term in the heavily Republican Fifth District, has also said she is seriously interested but she, too, is waiting for Mr. Kean to make his plans known. Other Republicans being mentioned as possible candidates are Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian and former Attorney General Cary Edwards, who lost in the Republican primary for Governor by Christine Todd Whitman.
 
Anti-Tax Sentiment
 Mr. Lautenberg is well aware of the anti-tax sentiment that almost cost Bill Bradley, a fellow Democrat, his Senate seat in 1990. And so Mr. Lautenberg, a bootstrap multimillionaire who went to college on the G.I. Bill and leans generally liberal, has lately tilted toward fiscal conservatism.
Besides voting against the President's deficit reduction package, which includes new taxes as well as spending cuts, Mr. Lautenberg supported a Republican-sponsored measure that would have withheld assistance from states that failed to require able-bodied welfare recipients to go to work. The bill ultimately died.
Mr. Lautenberg also sided with Republicans in a successful battle to defeat a House initiative that would have allowed a $1.2 billion increase in military spending without commensurate reductions in other spending.
Although once burned, Mr. Lautenberg's colleague in the Senate, Bill Bradley, is not twice cautious. He voted for the Clinton deficit reduction package, although he did concede that it was "an easy bill to oppose and a tough one to support."
 
'Positioning Himself'
 Mr. Lautenberg's vote against it was likely a win-win decision, in the view of Thomas V. O'Neill, a former executive director of the Democratic State Committee in New Jersey.
"I think he would say he voted that way for New Jersey, but he is also positioning himself for next year, and it was very astute of him," Mr. O'Neill said. "If the deficit reduction plan does not work, he can say, 'I voted against it.' If it works, he benefits as a Democrat, and the state is likely to be better off economically."
At the same time, if Mr. Clinton is an unpopular President when Mr. Lautenberg is seeking re-election next year, he has effectively distanced himself from the White House and can run as a New Jersey Democrat, not a national Democrat.
For his own part, Mr. Lautenberg said he would concentrate on his Senate record, chiefly in the areas of environment and transportation.
 
Came Out of Nowhere
 Mr. Lautenberg is chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation and makes sure New Jersey gets its share of Federal money for roads and other transportation projects. He sponsored the laws banning smoking on airline flights and tightening airport security, and played important roles in laws banning ocean dumping and encouraging pollution control technology.
Mr. Lautenberg, a cofounder of Automatic Data Processing whose net worth has been estimated at $50 million, essentially came out of nowhere when he ran for the Senate for the first time in 1982.
He had been a Democratic campaign donor and a member of the Port Authority board with no elective experience, but he quickly demonstrated that he knew how to run for office. He won the primary over several better-known opponents, then came from behind to upset Millicent Fenwick, the Republican Congresswoman and odds-on favorite, spending $5 million of his own money in the campaign.
Republicans were convinced that the victory was a fluke, and in 1988 virtually hand-picked his opponent, Pete Dawkins, winner of the Heisman Trophy, Rhodes Scholar, Princeton Ph.D., brigadier general and a Wall Street executive.
 
'A Scholar of Roads'
 But Mr. Lautenberg ran an aggressive campaign with the help of James Carville, the political consultant who went on to advise Bill Clinton. Mr. Lautenberg's television ads on the theme, "Get Real, Pete," attacked his opponent as a fake and a carpetbagger who had moved to New Jersey in 1987 only to run for the Senate. Mr. Lautenberg won handily, 54 percent to 46 percent, and Mr. Dawkins still has not paid off his campaign debt.
"I said Pete Dawkins was a Rhodes Scholar, but I was a scholar of roads," Mr. Lautenberg recalled with a laugh, apparently relishing the possibility of a rough fight next year.
He already has $2 million in the bank for the 1994 race, and says: "I have every intention of running for re-election and have done all the things I need to do to prepare for the campaign. It is just not time yet to begin."
Does he expect an expensive race if Mr. Kean runs? He and Mr. Dawkins each spent close to $8 million in 1988, a very high figure for the time.
"Oh, Tom Kean would have to spend $25 million," Mr. Lautenberg said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I have every intention of running for re-election and have done all the things I need to do to prepare for the campaign," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. He has already told President Clinton that his deficit reduction plan is no good for New Jersey, because he knows that the state is sour on taxes. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pentagon Keeps Silent on Rejected Gay Troop Plan

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Back in April, the Defense Department commissioned two studies on how to carry out President Clinton's intention to lift the military's ban on homosexuals. One, conducted by a panel of generals and admirals, led to the new policy. But the Pentagon is refusing to make public or even talk much about the other one, a $1.3 million report by the influential Rand Corporation. 
 The Rand report concluded that gay men and lesbians could serve openly in the armed forces if its proposed policy was given strong support from the military's senior leaders, and it offered a detailed plan for carrying out the President's order.
But it was the study by the panel of generals and admirals, who maintained that open homosexuality would undermine discipline and combat readiness, that prevailed.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin said that he tried to draft a plan closer to Mr. Clinton's original promise to lift the ban entirely, but that the compromise that eventually emerged was the best he could negotiate with the Joint Chiefs, whose support was essential to win approval in Congress.
 
Lack of Chiefs' Support
 The report by Rand, a conservatively oriented research group with longstanding ties to the military, suggested that the obstacle might have been neither the lack of a practical option nor the universal opposition of those familiar with military life, but rather the resistance of the six Joint Chiefs.
Senior civilian Pentagon officials said they never seriously considered the Rand report as a basis for a new policy on gay rights because the Joint Chiefs would not support it.
Mr. Clinton's compromise, allowing homosexuals to serve but only if they keep their sexual orientation private, differs only marginally from existing policy, and bows to the chiefs' insistence that open homosexuality could never be tolerated.
The Rand report started from the assumption that the ban would be lifted entirely, as Mr. Clinton originally ordered, and set out to devise a way to carry out the policy in a way that would preserve morale and order. Rand found that a policy based on strict requirements for professional conduct could work if strongly supported by the military's senior leadership.
"While heterosexuals will be asked to tolerate the presence of known homosexuals, all personnel, including acknowledged homosexuals, must understand that the military environment is no place to flaunt one's sexual identity or orientation," a summary of the report said.
Executive summaries of the Rand report, titled "Homosexuals and U.S. Military Personnel Policy: Policy Options and Assessment," as well as briefing slides presented to Mr. Aspin last month, were provided to The New York Times by individuals who felt the study should be made public.
Rand's proposed policy was based on these principles:
*An emphasis should be placed on behavior and conduct, not on teaching tolerance or sensitivity to troops.
*Military commanders at all levels must be empowered to carry out the policy and do so forcefully, but reassuringly.
*No extensive revisions to existing military rules and regulations are necessary.
*List categories of inappropriate conduct, including personal harassment, abuse of authority, displays of affection and explicit discussion of sexuality. Such a policy "requires tolerance and restraint to foster the good of the group, but implies no endorsement of a 'homosexual life style,' " the report said.
Rand assigned more than two dozen historians, economists, sociologists, psychologists, anthropologists, doctors and lawyers to the study. The head of the study was Bernard D. Rostker, a former head of Selective Service.
Rand researchers visited Canada, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Germany, Norway and Israel, as well as fire and police departments in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Seattle, Houston and San Diego, to gain insights and lessons from analagous organizations and institutions.
"The departments visited report that, over all, the effectiveness of the organization has not been diminished by the presence of homosexuals on the force," an overview of the report said. "Morale and discipline have been maintained, and recruitment and retention rates appear to be unaffected by the presence of known homosexuals."
The report acknowledged that none of those organizations was an exact model for the military, but Rand said comparisons were instructive for assessing changes in policy toward homosexuals in the military. Military commanders argue that open homosexuals would disrupt "unit cohesion," an almost mystical bond that permits soldiers to fight effectively.
But the Rand report said, "Military leaders have many tools available to prevent this from occurring, including the existence of regulations and norms regulating conduct."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Yields Rise Again

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell again yesterday as yields rose for the third day in a row. And as on Tuesday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, was the catalyst for the rise in yields, traders and analysts said.
Mr. Greenspan testified before the Senate Banking Committee, as he gave the second installment of the central bank's semiannual report on monetary policy to Congress. He testified on Tuesday before a House banking subcommittee. 
 While Mr. Greenspan was expected to give the same general testimony, some traders and analysts suggested that many in the market appeared to be hoping that the chairman would moderate his Tuesday statement. But he did not, staying with his message of disappointment about inflation and sending again a signal that the Fed's next move on interest rates may be to push them higher.
 
Greenspan 'Held the Line'
 "What hurt the market today was that Greenspan held the line," said Alan Levinson, money market economist at UBS Securities.
The price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 fell 13/32 as the yield rose to 6.66 percent, up from 6.63 percent Wednesday. Since Friday, the yield has jumped up from 6.54 percent, a 16-year low.
But because a Fed move to dampen inflation would mean an increase in short-term interest rates, the damage this week has been more severe on short and intermediate Treasury securities. Yesterday, the price of the two-year Treasury note fell 2/32 as the yield rose to 4.18 percent, almost a full quarter of a percentage point above last Friday's close.
The discount rate on the six-month Treasury bill, which quickly reflects expectations of interest rate moves by the Fed, inched two basis points or hundredths of a percentage point higher to 3.21. It was 3.11 percent Friday.
There were several other factors that also played into the selling. One was a rumor, apparently starting in the bond futures trading pit in Chicago, that Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the House Ways and means Committee, was going to resign. His aides denied the rumor.
 
Implicated in Scandal
 Mr. Rostenkowski has been implicated in the House Post Office scandal and officials have said that he is likely to be indicted soon. He is a close ally of President Clinton and is considered crucial to the negotiations going on now as the House and the Senate try to hammer out a compromise between their two deficit reductions plans.
Both the rumor and the selling inspired by it seem to indicate an underlying concern about the entire deficit reduction process, as traders and investors wonder whether a compromise can be reached and if it is whether it will be meaningful.
Another factor was selling of Treasury securities, especially 5- and 10-year notes, to hedge against the corporate bonds that firms have bought this week.
"The market selling is overdone but that does not mean that it can not get worse until some of the uncertainties are cleared up," said Peter McTeague, a fixed income analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
Mr. Greenspan accentuated his message yesterday with more discussion of the fact that the Fed was turning to the level of real interest rates -- interest rates after adjustment for inflation -- as a guidepost for its monetary policy because its money supply data was proving so unreliable.
And he made clear the current level of real short-term interest rates -- which is zero -- is not conducive to long-term low inflation. This point was quickly taken as another sign that the next move by the Fed would be to go to higher interest rates so that real rates would be positive.
 
100 Years of Coke
 Coca-Cola joined the 100-year bond derby yesterday, following the Walt Disney Company by one day. The soft-drink maker sold $150 million of 100-year bonds at a yield of 7.455 percent.
The big difference between the Disney 100-year bond and the Coke version is that the Disney bond can be called or paid off by the company after 30 years. The Coke bond cannot.
This guarantee of keeping the 100-year bond made the Coke version much more attractive, as was reflected in the spread over the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond. The Disney deal was done at 95 basis points over the 30-year bond yield, while the Coke deal was just 80 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Robert M. Kossick, Chief Executive, 53, At New Jersey Bank

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Robert M. Kossick, chairman and chief executive officer of the National Community Bank of New Jersey, died on Tuesday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 53 years old and also had a home in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.
The cause was a heart attack, the bank's announcement said. 
 A native of New Brunswick, N.J., Mr. Kossick was an industrial-engineering graduate of the Georgia Institute of Technology and earned a master's degree in economics at St. Mary's University in San Antonio. After two years of service in the Air Force there, he started out as a systems engineer with the E.I. DuPont Company in Parkersburg, W. Va.
His banking career began in 1968 with Citicorp in New York. In the next seven years he worked in domestic and overseas departments with increasing responsibilities. His final position was in London as senior operating officer of the Citibank UK Retail Bank.
He then became executive vice president of the Bank of the Southwest in Houston and, in 1979, chairman and chief executive of Empire National Bank in New City, N.Y. The following year he joined National Community Bank as president and chief executive at its headquarters in West Paterson. He traded the presidency for the chairmanship five years ago.
During his tenure, the bank quadrupled its assets to $4.2 billion and grew from 49 to 117 branches, with nearly 2,900 employees statewide. Most recently, he negotiated the bank's pending merger with the Bank of New York.
He was a sought-after speaker for free enterprise. James Peters, the bank's current president, said with his death the "industry lost one of its most successful and colorful leaders."
Mr. Kossick is survived by his wife, the former Sherry Lynne Stamey, of Houston; two sons, Robert and Mark; and two daughters, Kristen and Alicia.

HEADLINE: The Midwest Flooding;
Like Sandbags, Flood Losses Pile Up

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, July 22

 BODY:
With heavy rains and overflowing rivers continuing to inundate the Midwest, many companies and individuals are canceling construction plans, postponing car purchases and asking creditors for deferrals of payments as they assess their losses.
The Des Moines Chamber of Commerce estimated this evening that lost sales from the flood amounted to $525 million in that city alone, and were nearly three times greater than the $182 million in damage to business property. Federal Reserve economists in St. Louis and Chicago said the figures showed the flood's extensive damage to the Midwest, although they cautioned that some of Des Moines' sales may have been diverted to neighboring towns, and that Des Moines had been particularly hard hit because the city lost its running water for 12 days. 
 Businesses and residents of downtown Des Moines were given permission by city officials today to reopen their taps, nearly two weeks after a sudden rise in the Raccoon River disabled the water treatment center here. The water may only be used at first for sprinkler systems, showers and toilets. The rest of the city will be allowed to resume using water in stages over the next several days.
 
Damage Estimates Rising
 Even as damage estimates were being revised upward, a $3 billion Congressional aid package for flood victims became mired today in a dispute over how to pay for the assistance. The current bill would call for extra Federal borrowing, whereas most Republicans and some Democrats want spending cuts to pay for the aid.
Kevin L. Kliesen, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank at St. Louis, said damage along the Mississippi for 100 miles north and south of the city had been steadily increasing as the river stayed high and more levees broke, inundating previously unharmed fields and neighborhoods. Using damage data from a 1973 flood, Mr. Kliesen said that the losses of crops, buildings and roads had reached about $1 billion and might continue rising.
Robert H. Schnorbus, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank at Chicago, said the bank was almost done with its preliminary calculation of damage in Illinois and Iowa. "The flooding has gone on longer and spread as the levees have broken, so my estimates have gone up," he said, while refusing to provide any specific figures until his calculations were complete.
Interviews across eastern Iowa suggest that many business owners and residents are cutting back on discretionary purchases while they wait to see how much the flood will cost them.
At the Front Street Brewery in Davenport, the red-brick walls and wood ceiling beams are unscathed but the hardwood floor is damp and a fetid pool of dark gray water has completely filled the 40-seat bar and brewery in the basement. Steven J. Zuidema, one of the two owners, estimates that the brewery has sustained nearly $100,000 in damage and will lose another $100,000 in sales because it cannot reopen until mid-August.
To make ends meet, Mr. Zuidema sold on Tuesday the vacant lot on which he and his wife had planned to build a house this summer. He has also laid off his 30 employees and postponed the planned purchase of a car.
"We had waited a long time, we're driving an older car and it's starting to rust and runs terrible," said Mr. Zuidema, who has a 1986 Gand Am. "Now, it looks like we're going to hold on to it for a while."
Vernon W. Eden, the 62-year-old owner of the Saylorville Marina in Polk City, estimated that the flood had caused $70,000 in damage to his docks and the loss of $450,000 in sales of boats, gasoline, food and repairs. His parking lot is now under 42 feet of water, and fishermen are staying away because the fish would rather munch on submerged grass than artificial lures.
To save money, Mr. Eden has canceled plans to build a warehouse this summer for boat storage, and has hired only two sandwich shop workers instead of the planned eight. "We've got to make sure we've survived this," he said. "We don't know what this flood is going to cost us in the end, and nobody downtown knows either."
Nobody knows how many people have been laid off because of the flood. Monfort Inc., a subsidiary of Omaha-based ConAgra Inc., has sent home without pay almost all of its 1,400 employees at its meat-packing plant in Des Moines, which needs potable water. City officials predict that such water will not be available for as much as three more weeks.
Clemente Miranda, a Monfort cattle slaughterer with eight children, was laid off more than a week ago, and the family has been trying to figure out since then how to meet their next mortgage payment.
 
Running Up Against Paperwork
 "We fall between the cracks -- we're not flood victims" according to most Federal rules, Mrs. Miranda said while fetching water for her 36-day-old infant at a Salvation Army site in southwestern Des Moines. Mrs. Miranda said that her husband was applying for unemployment but that it would take up to five weeks for checks to arrive.
Ben Dew, a community relations worker for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said that disaster unemployment assistance was the best option for Mrs. Miranda. He also said that she should explain her difficulties to the owner of her mortgage, and ask for an extension of the next payment.
"What she is running up against is not something we're going to be able to avoid and that is paperwork," Mr. Dew said.
Much of the losses estimated by the Des Moines Chamber of Commerce consisted on ripple effects from reduced spending by flood-damaged businesses. Michael Reagan, the head of the chamber, said that a survey of 298 businesses in the city had found that they had lost $175 million in sales. The chamber's statisticians had then estimated that this would result in an additional loss of $350 million through the community.
 
Benefiting From the Flood
 Yet while some families and businesses struggle, many are unaffected and a few may even benefit from the flood. Mr. Schnorbus said that carpet, wallpaper and hardware stores could gain from the flood, along with the businesses that supply them.
K & K True Value Hardware Store in Bettendorf, Iowa, has sold hoses, plastic piping and four water pumps to the Front Street Brewery. David A. Fiebich, the hardware department manager, said that sales of mops and other cleaning gear had also increased.
But the gain has been almost entirely offset by lower sales of hammers, nuts, bolts and other necessities for home improvement projects. "It definitely hurts us in the long run, because people can't afford to put up the new porch if the carpet is ruined and needs to be replaced," Mr. Fiebich said.
Mr. Eden of Saylorville Marina and Mr. Zuidema of Front Street Brewery were both hatching plans this week for how the flood might work to their advantage. Mr. Eden waxed enthusiastic about the number of baby fish that will be born this year in Saylorville Lake, and how quickly they will take lures when the lake goes back down and reduces their food supply.
Mr. Zuidema said that he was preparing to start selling bottles of Raging River Ale. "We have a lot to do with the flood, we were creamed by this flood and we have a right to take advantage of it," he said.
Yet for every optimist like Mr. Zuidema, there are other business people for whom the flood is an unmitigated disaster.
Binh Nguyen, the 42-year-old owner of the Mekong Restaurant in Coralville, had spent all day laboring with his 17-year-old son, Hieu, to erect a sandbag wall separating the restaurant from a nearby creek, so as to pump out the water. But now the creek behind the restaurant had risen a little more, and begun flowing around the new wall.
Mr. Nguyen had borrowed all the money for the restaurant earlier this year from a state program for small businesses, and now said he feared that he would never be able to raise enough additional money to replace the furnishings and reopen the eatery.
"We were only open for three months, and now what do we do," Mr. Nguyen said.

HEADLINE: Frances R. Grant, 96, Champion Of Rights in Latin America, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Frances Ruth Grant, who spent her life opposing dictatorships and promoting human rights in the Americas, died on Wednesday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 96.
Miss Grant's dedication to Latin American culture, art and human rights began in her childhood. The daughter of a pioneer of New Mexico's statehood, she was born and raised in the remote pueblo of Abiquiu in the foothills of the Valle Grande mountains. It was there that she absorbed the atmosphere of Hispanic-American culture. 
 She was educated at Barnard College and graduated from Columbia University's School of Journalism in 1918. She also received extensive tutoring in economics, political science, music and the arts.
 
A Museum Founder
 She was a founder in 1923 of the Nicholas Roerich Museum in Manhattan, under whose auspices she went to the Far East and wrote about the philosophies and cultures of India and Tibet. She served as a vice president of the museum until 1937.
Miss Grant first visited Latin America in 1929 and after that devoted most of her energy to the republics of the hemisphere. She lectured at virtually all of its universities and centers of learning and started some of the first cultural interchanges, including exhibitions, musical programs and public forums.
Her work was primarily responsible for the Roerich Pact, an inter-American agreement for the preservation of cultural sites signed at the White House by 21 republics in 1935. She founded the Pan American Women's Association in 1930 and the Inter-American Association for Democracy and Freedom in 1950 and headed both of them into her late 80's.
 
A Journal Editor
 From 1951 until the mid-1980's, she edited the English and Spanish editions of Hemispherica, a journal published by the Inter-American Association. For this she received a special citation in 1982 at Columbia University from the trustees of the annual Maria Moors Cabot prizes in inter-American journalism.
Recognized as a leader in the defense of civil and politcal liberties, she was a past chairman of the Latin American section and secretary of the International League for Human Rights. The league is a nongovernmental agency accredited by the United Nations whose predecessors date back to the Dreyfus affair in France nearly a century ago.
Jose Figueres Ferrer, then the President of Costa Rica and himself a resolute champion of democracy, paid tribute to Miss Grant in a public address in New York in 1951. He called her "the greatest fighter for democracy and human rights in the hemisphere."

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
Temporary lawyers and the price of prosperity: when a job agency puffs, the competition huffs.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Lesley Friedman would not have thought of knocking her competition six years ago, when she began her business finding temporary jobs for lawyers. There was next to no competition, to begin with. And she had more serious problems on her hands, like an opinion from the New York City bar association that her entire operation was unethical.
The bar association soon reversed itself. And a dismal economy, cost-conscious corporations and legions of disaffected or unemployed lawyers available for comparatively cheap, part-time service have made legal temping a growth industry. 
 Customers of Ms. Friedman's company, Special Counsel, now include companies like Citicorp and MCI Communications and law firms like Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon and Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn. The company's billings have increased from $800,000 in 1988 to a projected $8 million this year.
Prosperity cuts both ways, however. Ms. Friedman now has plenty of competition, with companies like Attorneys Per Diem, Lawyer's Lawyer, Valuable Consideration, Counsel Temps, Co-Counsel and Assistant Counsel chasing the same business.
Ms. Friedman even grew concerned that her staid advertising -- featuring a gauzy portrait of herself that appeared to be her graduation photograph from Mount Holyoke, circa 1975, but in fact is only six years old -- was no longer enough.
So she produced a pamphlet about Special Counsel and its rivals that was about as subtle as a sonic boom. It sounded soothing -- "If you're skeptical about temporary attorneys, Special Counsel understands," it said on the cover -- until one turned the page. "After all," it said inside, "with any other temporary attorney service, your concern would be justified."
There follows a series of superlatives, in which Special Counsel claimed to place more lawyers for temporary work than any other company and to have done so longer. The brochure went out to 9,000 members of the American Corporate Counsel Association. But copies of it soon reached the competition. And now, what might be a not-so-temporary war has broken out in the legal temp industry, one that threatens to reach the Federal Trade Commission.
The first to weigh in was Warren Hernand, a legal search consultant in San Francisco. He called the brochure "insulting," and disputed the claim that Special Counsel was either first, most or best at anything. Unless Special Counsel stopped circulating it and published a full-page apology in the newsletter of the counsel's association, he wrote, he would file a complaint with the F.T.C.
Then, a few days later, came word from Chere Estrin of the Quorum Group in Los Angeles. She called the brochure "shabby," threatened to drag in an attorney general -- she did not specify which one -- and declared that what led Ms. Friedman's father, a Los Angeles lawyer for whom Ms. Estrin once worked, to urge his daughter to start up Special Counsel was partly Ms. Estrin's own success at the same business.
"Really, Lesley, I had a much better impression of you," Ms. Estrin wrote. "You've gone over the edge on this one."
Rose Ors of Project Professionals in Santa Monica, Calif., accused Special Counsel of "mudslinging." And, in a long and legalistic "My Dear Ms. Friedman" letter, Robert Webster of the Lawsmiths in San Francisco maintained that his company long antedated hers. He further demanded that Special Counsel "abjure" claims that the competition was unqualified.
The letters sent Ms. Friedman scurrying to her dictionary (to look up "abjure") and to her trademark counsel at Darby & Darby in New York, who concluded that while the brochure contained "aggressive puffery," it did not amount to unfair competition. Nor, Ms. Friedman insists, does it contain anything untrue.
"I don't understand what all the uproar is about," she said. "I notice that the agencies that have sent me letters are all from California. Perhaps they're concerned about my plans to open a Los Angeles office." But to maintain good will in the industry, she said, she will soften some of her harsher language.
That has not mollified Mr. Hernand. He is off on a 10-day Caribbean cruise but says that if he gets no satisfaction by the time he returns, he will take his case to the F.T.C.
At that point, the parties will need some lawyers. There is no word yet on whether Special Counsel or any of its rivals will be furnishing legal temps to handle the dispute.

HEADLINE: Conferees on Budget Agree To Raise Tax Rate on Rich

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Inching toward a final deficit-reduction bill, House and Senate conferees agreed today to a steep increase in the top Federal income tax rate and to leave the capital gains tax rate unchanged.
This was one of the easiest matters for the conferees to resolve. They basically split the difference between the House and the Senate bills, which were quite similar to begin with. 
 Since members of Congress almost never make tough decisions until they are up against a deadline, issues like energy taxes and limits on Medicare spending are not likely to be settled until next week.
But the Senate conferees did send the signal that they expected some kind of energy tax to be in the final legislation. Some Democratic Senators, including Max Baucus of Montana and David Pryor of Arkansas, had argued that all energy taxes should be dropped in the interest of making the final legislation more attractive politically.
 
Taxes on Social Security
 On Social Security, the conferees accepted the Senate version of the bill. They agreed that single retirees with gross incomes above $32,000 and couples with incomes above $40,000 would have to pay income taxes on up to 85 percent of their Social Security benefits. Only 50 percent is taxable now, and that would continue to be the case for single retirees with incomes from $25,000 to $32,000 and for couples with incomes from $32,000 to $40,000.
Technically, these step-by-step decisions of the budget conferees are subject to change before the conference committee finishes its work, presumably some time next week. But in the case of the higher tax rates, what the conferees approved today will almost certainly become law if any deficit-reduction bill is enacted.
The White House continued its hard-sell approach today. Reporters from New York and New Jersey were called in for a series of briefings and news conferences on the budget, first from Treasury Department and White House officials and then, in the afternoon, by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore themselves.
They used as their text the testimony this week of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who said interest rates would rise and the markets would react unfavorably if Congress failed to enact a big deficit-reduction measure.
"There is no question that the failure to pass the budget would have a destabilizing effect on the economy," the President asserted.
 
Burden on Very Affluent
 The White House continued to stress that the increased taxes in the bill would fall overwhelmingly on the wealthy, a point the Clinton Administration believes has gotten lost in all the Republican criticism of the higher taxes. Presumably, the reason the conferees publicly locked the higher income tax rates into the bill today, while doing little else that was newsworthy, was to draw attention to how only the very affluent would be affected.
The higher tax rates on the wealthy would raise more than $112 billion over the next five years, the single biggest element of a package meant to lower the deficit by about $500 billion over the next five years.
Under the agreement of the conference committee, the top income tax rate, now 31 percent, would be increased to 35.2 percent this year and 36 percent afterward for single taxpayers with taxable incomes from $115,000 to $250,000, and for couples with taxable incomes from $140,000 to $250,000. For taxpayers with taxable incomes above $250,000, the rate would be 38.2 percent this year and 39.6 percent next year.
Taxable income is the amount left after all deductions and personal exemptions are subtracted.
 
Calculating the Impact
 According to the Treasury, a taxable income of $140,000 generally corresponds to an adjusted gross income of about $180,000, and a taxable income of $250,000 is equivalent to an adjusted gross income of more than $300,000.
The Treasury calculates that only 1 percent of the nation's taxpayers would be affected by the rate changes, and that only four-tenths of 1 percent would pay taxes at the highest rate.
The tax on capital gains, which are the profits from the sale of investments, would remain at 28 percent for all taxpayers. The Senate bill would have raised it to 30.8 percent for taxpayers with incomes above $250,000.
In a further blow to upper-income taxpayers, the legislation would require that employers and employees pay the 1.45 percent Medicare payroll tax on all earnings. Now, wages above $135,000 are not subject to the tax.
Altogether, a taxpayer with a salary of $350,000 could owe an additional $20,000 in taxes.
 
One-on-One Negotiations
 The conferees decided this afternoon that the lawmakers most expert in health care would get together to work out how to lower the expected growth in Medicare costs by about $54 billion over the next five years. They also agreed that the top conferees on tax matters, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, would try to settle the tax differences in one-on-one negotiations.
Actually, the ultimate problem is not getting Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Rostenkowski to agree. Staff members say there is hardly a whit of difference between them. Rather, the problem is finding solutions that can unite all the different elements of the Democratic Party in Congress, from conservatives like the Senators from oil-producing states to the liberal Representatives who belong to the Black Caucus.
Because every Republican in Congress plans to vote against whatever bill comes out of the conference, almost all Democrats must support it if it is to become law.

HEADLINE: 41,000 Graduates Await the Test of a Lifetime

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
"This is war," said Brad Call, who had just graduated from George Washington Law School. "It's war, man."
Still, he seemed calm for someone who had spent $1,000 on a review course and had been studying 10 hours a day since early June. 
 Next week Mr. Call, 29, and more than 41,000 others around the country will take the bar examination to become lawyers. In 12 hours over two days they will take the equivalent of 20 law school exams on everything from contracts to evidence to criminal law. And if the past is any guide, about 30 percent of them will fail.
If this were not daunting enough, recent law school graduates are hearing horror stories about the job market that awaits them even if they do pass the exam. Traditionally, law graduates are hired before they take the bar exam to begin work in the fall after passing it. But a sluggish economy has forced many firms to cut back on hiring.
A drop in job placement for 1993 graduates is affecting those of all law schools. A survey by the legal magazine Of Counsel found that the 67 largest firms employed fewer lawyers last year than in the previous year, 31,132 to 31,048.
 
Drop in Starting Pay
 Starting salaries have fallen, too. Last year the median salary for first-year associates was $47,500, almost $4,000 less than in 1991, according to the National Association for Law Placement, which does not expect any increase this year.
Some students get jobs at large firms that pay the costs of the bar review courses. But that does not make the exam any easier. Neal McCoy, managing partner in Washington for Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, said, "We would expect they would pass it the first time."
In addition, some students have not been able to afford the critical bar review courses.
Steven H. Levine, head of BAR/ BRI, the most widely used course in the country, estimates that 85 percent of this year's law school graduates are taking a bar review course, compared with more than 90 percent last year.
A review course like that given by BAR/BRI (pronounced BAR-bree) is necessary, law professors say, because it offers a thorough review of all courses the students have taken over three years and because it teaches the students how to manage their time in taking the exam.
The exam varies from state to state, and in some, like California, stringent requirements to practice law are reflected in a more difficult as well as a longer exam. Students in California will sit down to a three- day exam; for students in Texas the ordeal will last two and a half days. All other states and the District of Columbia have a two-day exam.
The test, administered by the National Conference of Bar Examiners, has been the licensing criterion for more than 100 years. The exam consists of a multistate section with 200 multiple-choice questions on contracts, torts, real property, constitutional law, criminal law and evidence. The remainder of the exam covers law in the state (or the district) in which the exam is given and includes essay questions dealing with, for example, domestic relations, taxation and wills.
Mr. Levine of BAR/BRI says pretest stress may pale in comparison with the anxiety of waiting four months to receive results. Those taking the test next week will not get their results until Thanksgiving.
"You wake up in the middle of the night," Mr. Levine said, "with a will question shooting across the ceiling and sit up sweating, screaming, 'If I only had one more week!' "
 
Scant Help for Seizure
 But for next week, taking the bar exam may be punishment enough. In Southern California, a man suffered an epileptic seizure during the February exam, which is mainly for those who failed the July exam. Only three people got up to help him. The three students were expected to finish taking the exam within the allotted period, although their scores were specially reviewed by the National Conference of Bar Examiners to take into account the time they lost in administering aid.
Those who fail can take the exam again (and continue taking it until they pass), but if the graduate has already been hired by a firm, the failure can be crippling, both to the lawyer and the firm. They are prohibited from signing documents, using the firm's letterhead or appearing in court until they have been accredited by the American Bar Association.
Bentley Saul, a recent graduate of Widener Law School in Chester, Pa., has narrowed the problem of studying for the bar exam. "The material is do-able," he said. "The other people are the problem. When you go outside of the library to get a drink of water, someone tells you how many hours a day they're studying."
No matter how much they study, there will be high anxiety. Mr. Levine says he invariably gets calls from men and women a few weeks before the exam who just need tender loving care.
