HEADLINE: Walter D. Fackler, 71, Economist Known for Accurate Predictions

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Walter D. Fackler, an economist known for the accuracy of his annual forecasts of national trends, died yesterday at a hospital in Chicago. He was 71 and lived in Chicago.
The cause was a stroke, his family said. 
 Mr. Fackler was a professor and former associate dean and acting dean of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. He had also served as director of its master's degree program for business executives.
For 31 years he made annual forecasts of the nation's economy that were widely quoted and considered among the most reliable. His expertise included industry, public finance, monetary policy and the economic effects of government actions.
He served as a senior economist for President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Cabinet Committee on Price Stability for Economic Growth in 1959-60. Before that, from 1956-59, he was the assistant director of economic research for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
As an economist, he wrote many articles, gave speeches, testified before Congressional committees and was a consultant to business, government agencies and foundations.
Mr. Fackler was born in Aitkin, Minn. A veteran of World War II, he served as a captain in the Army in Europe and won a Bronze Star.
He graduated from George Washington University and studied for his doctorate at Johns Hopkins University, where he also taught briefly. He worked for six years at George Washington as a teacher, assistant to the Dean of Faculties and director of the Foreign Service Review Program.
His survivors include his wife of 42 years, the former Hazel Shepardson; three sons, Paul, of Durham, N.C., and Mark and Neil, both of the Chicago area; a brother, James, of Minneapolis; three sisters, Charlotte Collins of King City, Ore., Joyce Pershall, of Olympia, Wash., and Rachel Rennick of British Columbia, Canada, and two granddaughters.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls From Heights, Off 30.18 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks retreated yesterday, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average set an all-time high. The average fell 30.18 points, to 3,525.22, in heavy trading.
Traders said the bond market failed to give backbone to stocks, which moved in a tight range until late afternoon, when prices fell on programmed selling. 
 Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange reached 249.6 million shares, down from 278.6 million on Wednesday. Losing issues far outnumbered gainers, 1,208 to 767. Lower oil prices again buoyed the transportation issues, with the Dow transportation index rising 2.78 points, to 1,575.99.
 
 
Link to Bond Market
 Lawrence R. Rice, market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said he was not surprised by the decline yesterday. He said the market rise on Wednesday was not as solid as it had appeared, especially on a day when bond prices were down sharply. Indeed, he said, the Dow achieved its new high on the back of only a few issues.
"The selloff of bonds continued yesterday, which by the way was due," Mr. Rice said.
He said cautious comments yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on the outlook for interest rates and inflation may represent a warning of an uptick in inflation caused by flooding in the Midwest.
But, he added, yesterday's stock market decline was orderly.
"Investors failed to panic," he said, "suggesting that we may still be within a bull market and equities still represent an attractive alternative to other investments. That's not to say the market still doesn't need a correction in the averages."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.67 points, to 444.51. The Nasdaq composite dropped 4.56 points, to 695.52, and the Big Board composite lost 1.34 points to end at 246.26. The American Stock Exchange was also down, losing 1.95 points to 431.36.
The Stant Corporation was the most actively traded issue on the Nasdaq. The company's initial public offering of 6.5 million shares was priced at $16 a share, compared with an expected range of $14 to $16 a share, according to its preliminary prospectus. Shares of the maker and distributor of auto parts closed at $17.
United International Holdings, which holds interests in overseas broadcast, radio and television operations, made an initial public offering of 3.5 million shares priced at $19. The stock closed at $22.50.
 Blockbuster Entertainment gained 1 3/4, to 24 1/8, in active trading. The video chain reported second-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share, compared with 17 cents for the period a year earlier.
Advance Circuits fell 1 5/8, to 9, as the maker of printed circuits said it was withdrawing its proposed public offering of 1.4 million shares. Citing a weak market for computers and computer products, the company said it had become more difficult to project future operating results.
Traders said that according to two studies published in the New England Journal of Medicine, Heart Technology's device to clear arteries may not be better than conventional balloon angioplasty. Shares of the medical supply company slipped 7/8, to 19 5/8.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Growth Is Laggard

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Americans' personal incomes grew at a 4.6 percent annual rate from the first quarter of 1991 to the first quarter of 1993, a Commerce Department report showed today.
That is less than half the 9.8 percent annual rate of increase in the three previous recoveries that lasted as long as the current one, the report noted. 
 In another report, the Labor Department said the number of newly laid-off people filing claims for jobless benefits jumped by 24,000 last week. Some analysts said the spike was caused by problems in adjusting for seasonal variations.
New applications for unemployment benefits totaled 352,000 during the week ended July 17, up from a revised 328,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department reported today. The July 10 number was originally estimated to be 334,000.
 
Moving Average Up
 The less volatile four-week moving average of new claims totaled 338,000, up marginally from 337,750 during the period ended July 10.
Despite the end of the recession two years ago, personal income growth in many East Coast states and California is being curbed by military spending cuts and the lingering effects of 1980's overbuilding, the department said.
The report said the 10 states with the fastest personal income growth were in the interior. Payroll increases there ranged from 8.7 percent in North Dakota and 8.4 percent in Nebraska to 6.1 percent in both Kentucky and Utah.
The 10 states with the slowest personal income growth were Connecticut, 2.3 percent; Maine and Massachusetts, 2.9 percent; California, 3.1 percent; Virginia, 3.6 percent; Maryland and Florida, 3.8 percent; New York, 3.9 percent, and New Hampshire and Vermont, 4 percent.
The department defines personal income as income received from all sources, less personal contributions for Social Security insurance. It is measured before tax deductions and is not adjusted for inflation.
The report said inflation rose at a 3.2 percent annual rate during the two years since the recession officially ended in March 1991.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation reported essentially flat results yesterday, reflecting the slow California economy.
The country's second-largest banking company earned $488 million for the quarter that ended June 30, compared with $240 million for the same period a year earlier. 
 Last year's second-quarter results were affected by merger-related expenses and a gain on the sale of BankAmerica's payroll processing business. If the nonrecurring items had been excluded, net income for the 1992 period would have been $421 million.
Delinquent loans for the most recent quarter totaled $3.44 billion, down 10 percent from $3.84 billion for the first quarter and down 25 percent from $4.62 billion for the second quarter a year earlier.
Net interest income rose, despite a drop in loans. It totaled $1.85 billion, up from $1.84 billion for the first quarter and $1.67 billion for the second quarter a year earlier. Loans amounted to $124.4 billion, compared with $124.1 billion for the first quarter and $132.5 billion for 1992's second quarter.
The bank reported moderate profitability, as measured by a return on equity of 13.3 percent, which is relatively low for the banking industry.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Haitian Leader To Appoint a New Premier

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
President Clinton urged today that Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, move swiftly toward restoring democratic institutions in his country as part of an agreement that is to return him to power on Oct. 30.
The Administration particularly wants Father Aristide to appoint a new prime minister to replace the military Government headed by Gen. Raoul Cedras. That step is part of a peace settlement reached on Governors Island on July 3 by Father Aristide and Haiti's military leadership. 
 Joining Mr. Clinton in an appearance at the White House, Father Aristide said, "We are doing our best" to carry out the provisions of the accord. He specified reforms of Haiti's army, police and judiciary, but he did not mention the naming of a Prime Minister.
The conditions of the settlement, reached under United Nations mediation, would lift an international embargo on oil shipments to Haiti upon the naming of a Prime Minister.
 
Naming of Premier a Problem
 But the nomination appears to have become a sticking point for Father Aristide. His problem is that there is not only a Prime Minister in exile, Rene Preval, who is clamoring to be restored to office, but also a two-chamber Parliament in Port-au-Prince where Father Aristide's supporters and opponents are entangled in a struggle over who legitimately represents the Haitian electorate. The new Prime Minister is to be chosen with Parliament's approval.
[In Port-au-Prince, the lower house of Haiti's Parliament chose Antoine Joseph as its speaker, defeating Pierre Canel Ridal, the candidate favored by Aristide supporters.]
One aide said today that Father Aristide's nomination of a head of government might take place next week, after consultation with Parliament.
Father Aristide said that in his view, the peace settlement and its provisions meant "having something for every single citizen of the country."
The Clinton Administration has pledged military assistance and economic aid. It has offered about 350 United States military personnel, including engineers, to assist in "modernizing the armed forces of Haiti," as Mike McCurry, the State Department spokesman, described it today.
Haiti's police force is to be supervised by foreign specialists under the United Nations agreement. In his remarks, President Clinton emphasized the importance of "getting the international police force in place." That force is to be drawn from France, Canada and possibly Caribbean countries.
The sanctions imposed on Haiti's military Government also included the freezing of financial assets of people linked with General Cedras and a bar on shipments of weapons to the nation.
Assuming that the other provisions of the 10-point agreement reached at Governors Island are carried out, Father Aristide could return to Haiti on Oct. 30, fully 25 months after he was ousted in a military coup. The agreement provides that he grant an amnesty to the military coup leaders. In addition, General Cedras is called on to resign as commander of the army, which has 7,000 troops.
Before sitting down with Father Aristide for about 30 minutes, President Clinton praised him for "the courage he showed" in signing the peace accord and said: "I'm excited about this process. There's a major potential for a victory for democracy here."

HEADLINE: Now Takeover of Canal Makes Panama Uneasy

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, July 17

 BODY:
Until recently, there was still no greater act of nationalist faith among Panamanians than to declare that the 51-mile canal that cuts through the psyche of this country as completely as it bisects its geography must revert to full local ownership and control.
But with the turnover of the canal and the 500-square-mile corridor surrounding it fast gathering momentum and due to be completed by the end of the decade, there has been a tidal shift of attitudes among Panamanians. 
 Many have begun to wonder aloud how their small country can digest its gargantuan prize.
From its completion in 1914 through the end of the cold war, the United States-controlled canal was a dependable inspiration for political appeals and popular riots, with sovereignty over it the equivalent of the American dream for most Panamanians.
The faces of Panamanian officials still often light up with enthusiasm when they are asked what they will do with the bases over which they will assume control. They speak of the huge regional universities, modern containerized ports, luxury resorts and retirement communities for affluent Americans and others that they say will ultimately match, perhaps surpass, the hundreds of millions of dollars generated nowadays from the United States military presence.
 
'The Mess of the Century'
 But contributing to the doubts now are a lack of confidence in a young and still uncertain democracy and a fear of mismanagement, readily apparent in many of the canal-related properties that have already been turned over. These quickly went from their pristine state to overgrown eyesores decaying under the tropical sun.
Foremost, however, is concern over the loss of an estimated $500 million -- about one-tenth of the gross national product -- injected into the Panamanian economy by the presence of about 10,000 American troops, 2,000 civilians and 20,000 dependents living in the country.
These anxieties were captured in a poll in May conducted for the country's leading newspaper, La Prensa, in which nearly 71 percent of the respondents said they either agreed or felt strongly that it would be better for American bases to remain in the country after the year 2000. Only 18 percent disagreed.
"We have a treaty, and that is something we cannot hide from, because once 1999 comes we'll be down to zero Americans and zero jobs," said Ray Bishop, the secretary general of the 6,000-member Panamanian Syndicate of Employees of United States Armed Forces. "The problem is that the Panamanian Government is not ready for this kind of responsibility. This is going to be the mess of the century."
The United States Southern Command, which makes its headquarters in Panama, has worked hard to convince disbelieving Panamanians that its pullout is for real. This drive began with the turnover of a 288-acre fuel storage installation, or tank farm, at the end of 1991, and a steady stream of other properties have been handed over since. Next year, American military officials say, the schedule calls for the closing of the first two of the 10 bases they operate in the country.
"Our feeling was that since nobody wants to believe that we are leaving, let's shock the system by handing over a bunch of things quickly," a senior officer said.
The tank farm was expected to be converted to a commercial fuel storage center, but since its turnover, the officer said, it has remained empty and in danger of rusting. Other properties, including officers' housing at Coco Solo, a point jutting into the sea on the Atlantic side of the canal, have been overrun by squatters.
Many see in these experiences an ominous reminder of how badly things could go.
"We paint these buildings all the time," an American official said. "We change the roofs all the time and we cut the grass all the time. The windows are sealed, and the air-conditioners are running all the time. You don't have to stop this kind of maintenance very long around here before the jungle is back."
Asked what level of preparation and planning there had been in the Panamanian Government for taking over complex properties like these, another senior American officer said: "Below line zero. Zip."
Under the treaty the American Government is not required to help maintain any properties after their transfer.
Although there are widespread expectations of the imminent decay and collapse of properties, both Panamanian and American officials said they felt confident that the Government could be counted upon to manage the canal itself properly.
Fears on this subject were raised by American opponents of the treaty negotiated by President Jimmy Carter with Panama in 1977, which sets up terms for the turnover. Panamanians have been phased in to the day-to-day running of the canal, and American and Panamanian officials alike say this change has brought few hitches.
Far more difficult, experts say, will be the profitable conversion of thousands of properties in the former Canal Zone to civilian or commercial use.
Many of the sprawling American bases appear to be monotonous versions of the planned communities on the outskirts of many American cities, except for the visible presence of thousands of soldiers barbecuing or golfing on endless, scrupulously manicured lawns, or tooling around in army vehicles, Originally, plans for the turnover foresaw the replacement of these troops by members of the Panamanian Defense Force, who, it was expected, would take over everything from the training grounds to the hundreds of spacious officers' villas.
After the arrest of the military dictator, Manuel Noriega, in 1990, however, the Panamanian Army was disbanded, replaced by a much smaller civilian police force.
Panamanian officials' plans for the bases now include universities and resorts. By early August, they say, a competition among more than 60 international consulting firms to draw up a master plan for the properties will be winnowed to six finalists, from which a winner will be chosen by late October.
"There wasn't the political will to do what we needed to do before," said Carlos Valencia, a prominent businessman who is a board member of the Regional Interoceanic Authority, which was set up to oversee the transition. "Finally, there is a will, and the ideas, and I am sure there will be the money, and we are hellbent on doing a good job."
So far, however, there is not so much as an administrator for the authority. Officials of both countries agree that, so far, Government planners have little more in hand than what one called a list of "five-word descriptives" of the 4,800 or so buildings that will become Panamanian property.
"This is something that has been built and managed by foreign powers and it is hard for us to get it in our own heads that we are soon going to be in charge of this whole enterprise," said Jorge R. Riba, a professor of city planning at the University of Panama. "In 1977, when the treaty was signed, we had 23 years ahead of us to get ready. We have done a lot of things, but mostly, we have lost a lot of time. Now it is going to be a neck-and-neck race against the clock."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the turnover of the Panama Canal and the 500-square-mile corridor surrounding it set to be completed by the end of the decade, many Panamanians have begun to wonder how their country can handle the responsibility of full ownership. Visitors looked out over the canal's locks. (Howard W. French/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins

 BODY:

'Fool Moon' to Close
True sadness is but a tear in the eye of a clown. "Fool Moon," the two-man romp at the Richard Rodgers Theater starring the clowns David Shiner and Bill Irwin, will be closing on Sept. 5.
"We hate bringing down a hit show earlier than any of us would want to," said James B. Freydberg, one of the producers. "But it's because of David Shiner's health that the producers have decided to close for now." His co-producers are Kenneth Feld, Jeffrey Ash and Dori Berinstein. 
 "I'm just exhausted, and I need a break," said the 39-year-old Mr. Shiner, who explained that he suffered a severe bout of flu at the start of the run in February but performed "because if I'd dropped out then, the show would have closed."
He never fully recovered, and he said the regimen of eight two-hour shows a week is "both physically and mentally demanding, since I'm walking the wire every night." During two acts of slapstick, mime and farcical mayhem, Mr. Shiner interacts with audience members, taking them on stage for a bout of mock movie making. "You would not believe how much energy you expend to bring that off," he said.
The producers, of course, cannot employ an understudy. Mr. Freydberg added, "It's not true that we're losing money." He said the show had netted $650,000 in its first four months and needed $100,000 more to recoup, probably in August.
Mr. Freydberg said that after a break, the show would tour the United States and Europe, "and maybe come back to New York." The new Neil Simon comedy, "Laughter on the 23d Floor," arrives at the Richard Rodgers in October.
 
'She Loves Me' Is Moving
 Rumors to the contrary, Mr. Freydberg will not be a producer of the commercial run of the Roundabout Theater's "She Loves Me," and it will not move to the Brooks Atkinson. The much-praised musical will begin previews at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Sept. 28, opening on Oct. 7; the producers are James M. Nederlander and Elliot Martin.
 
Fall at the Nonprofits
 Two of Manhattan's premier nonprofit theaters, the Manhattan Theater Club and Playwrights Horizons, are unveiling their seasonal plans. A third, the New York Shakespeare Festival, has firmed up staffing under its producer, George C. Wolfe.
First: Lynne Meadow, artistic director at M.T.C., as everyone calls it, announced that the main-stage season would open Oct. 26 with "The Loman Family Picnic," by Donald Margulies. The cast is to include Christine Baranski, Liz Larsen and Peter Friedman, with Ms. Meadow directing. The play, about a Brooklyn family, was previously produced at the theater's Stage II.
Oct. 12 is the date for the world premiere on Stage II of "Four Dogs and a Bone," a comedy about Hollywood, written and directed by John Patrick Shanley. The players include a screenwriter (Loren Dean), a starlet (Mary-Louise Parker) and a seasoned actress (Polly Draper).
The world premiere of Philip Kan Gotanda's "Knife in the Heart," directed by Oskar Eustis, is to be Dec. 20 on Stage II. And on Jan. 25, on Stage I, M.T.C. is to present Timberlake Wertenbaker's "Three Birds Alighting on a Field," which won the British Critics' Circle Award in its production at the Royal Court Theater in London. Max Stafford-Clark, that theater's artistic director, is to direct; Harriet Walter, star of the Royal Court production, will be the featured actress in the play about a woman who becomes embroiled in the art world.
Terrence McNally's "Love! Valour! Compassion!" is about three couples sharing a summer house.The debut is scheduled for April 26; director and cast are not set. The theater will announce two more shows to round out its season.
At the 5,500-subscriber Playwrights Horizons, Don Scardino, the artistic director, said "Sophistry" would begin the season on Sept. 21 at 416 West 42d Street. The play, by Jonathan Marc Sherman, is to be directed by Nicholas Martin; it shows how a sexual harassment charge triggers an uproar at a New England college.
Mr. Scardino is to direct "An Imaginary Life," a comedy by Peter Parnell opening on Oct. 29. The Pirandellian escapade examines the line between fantasy and fact in a story about a man and his midlife crisis. "Moe's Lucky Seven," by Marlene Meyer, is to begin on April 22. The drama, directed by Roberta Levitow, is a romantic comedy set in a seedy waterfront bar.
As for the Shakespeare Festival: Wiley Hausam, an agent at International Creative Management, will be director of special projects; Morgan Jenness will be director of play development; Shelby Jiggetts will be literary manager, and Carol Fineman will become general press representative.
 
Giving a Union Its Due
 That isn't just some ho-hum, garden-variety professional meeting spilling out of the ballroom and conference suites of the New York Hilton these days. The gathering, which ends today, is the 100th anniversary convocation of I.A., the name everyone uses to avoid having to invoke the organization's full title: the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators of the United States and Canada.
It has been a heady season for the union of artisans who work in theater, film and television. First, there was that centenary recognition during the Academy Awards, then an honor on the Tony Awards broadcast. At the convention, Mayor David N. Dinkins underscored the union's economic importance to the city and reminded 1,000 delegates that "it all started back in 1893 on 26th and Broadway." The union now has 73,000 members in 50 states and Canada.
Not everything has changed since the early days. In private, some producers still rail against rehearsal rules, overtime and penalties, and lay Broadway's decline to the supposed pinochle-playing idlers backstage. And some union members counter, among themselves, that it's the uncreative producers' fault they don't have more work, and that earnings haven't kept pace with inflation.
"The whole economics of the theater has changed, yet everyone blames the unions when it comes to high costs," said Alfred W. Di Tolla, the union's international president, who spent much of his life as a prop man in the theater. "But our wages haven't increased commensurate with the price of tickets."
The debate may never end. But for the delegates themselves, the convention has been a family affair because of the group's closeness and its multi-generational membership. Is there any consensus about how the rank and file views its union? "No, some love it, some criticize it, but it's all very simple," said one veteran who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If you're working, it's the greatest union in the world. And if you're not working, you say, 'What do they do with my dues, anyway?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Another Hard-Knock Life" -- Leapin' lizards, can that be Andrea McArdle? Yes, the actress who created the title role in "Annie" when she was 13 will take over the part of the ill-fated Fantine in "Les Miserables" on Aug. 16 at the Imperial Theater. In other words, Broadway's most famous orphan will become mother to the Great White Way's most famous waif, the plucky Cosette.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov

 BODY:
If security is having money in the bank or a package of chocolate chip cookies carefully stashed away, knowing of a charming and affordable little restaurant not too far from the theater district can make one feel positively smug.
Topaz, just around the block from Carnegie Hall, serves gently seasoned Thai food that is notable for its harmony and balance. The lunchtime crowd of business executives is large enough to make reservations advisable. 
 Topaz doesn't look like a Thai restaurant. The rectangular 50-seat dining room's warm brown Art Deco paneling and triangular sconces, which could have come from the interior of a 1920's yacht, are remnants of a seafood restaurant, Wharf 56, that once occupied this site. The Deco look is supplemented by wooden captain's chairs and incongruously, track lighting and worn gray industrial carpeting.
Meals start with a basket of crisp shrimp chips, addictive with the accompanying peanut sauce, just the right mixture of sweet and peppery. These are handy to have, because the menu is complex and takes time to peruse completely. For a shortcut, go directly to the soup section and try the tom kha gai ($3.50), fragrant chicken stock deliciously rich with coconut milk but still light with its layers of ginger, chili and lime. Mee krob ($5.95), the popular appetizer, was an excellent contrast to the soup, delicately crisp rice noodles served cool in a sweet tamarind sauce that packed a spicy kick.
Light, airy curry puffs ($4.25), filled with ground chicken, potato and onion, and tender chicken satay ($7.95 for five sticks) were also fine starters, but the tod mon ($4.50), cakes of minced shrimp, were rubbery.
Yum woonsen ($7.95) is a bright, aptly named salad of crystalline noodles, minced pork and shrimp, nice as a light meal. For heartier appetites, there is gai yang ($11.95), tender moist chicken pieces marinated in garlic and lime and grilled. Spareribs ($11.95) are called "giant ribs" on the menu, calling to mind all sorts of gargantuan possibilities. It was a letdown to receive ordinary-size pork ribs, even if they were terrifically meaty and tender.
The soupy curries are the spiciest dishes and are served with the meat or seafood of your choice. Jungle curry ($11.95) with scallops and green beans was delicious, but masamaan curry ($11.95), with avocado and peanuts, tasted only of chili.
The best accompaniments are the brisk Singha beer ($3.75) and iced tea ($2). There is little in the way of dessert, but take a moment to contemplate the small bar in the rear. An altar with a cigar, flowers and glasses of whisky and water pays tribute to a Siamese prince, a sort of patron saint of Thai restaurants, who opened Thailand economically.
 
Topaz
127 West 56th Street, Manhattan, (212) 957-8020.
Best dishes: Tom kha gai, mee krob, curry puffs, yum woonsen, gai yang, spareribs, jungle curry.
Price range: $10 to $20.
Credit cards: American Express, Diner's Club, Mastercard, Visa.
Hours: noon to 11 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; 4 to 11 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays.
Wheelchair access: Entrance is too narrow for a wheelchair.

HEADLINE: A Sensible Look at the Airline 'Crisis'

 BODY:
For the last three years, anyone scanning the headlines could easily have concluded that America's airline industry was on its last legs, trapped by inexorable forces it could not control. A commission appointed by President Clinton to fix the industry rightly rejects this dismal scenario.
It will recommend minor tightening of government oversight, tax cuts, some regulatory relief and increased foreign investment. But the commission's draft recommendations reject Government fare-setting and other major structural changes. These small fixes will disappoint some in Congress, but the commission has aimed well. 
 U.S. carriers have lost more than $6 billion since 1990. But as Clifford Winston and Steven Morrison of the Brookings Institution show, these losses are due largely to managerial mistakes, not deep-seated structural flaws in the industry. The industry overpredicted demand for air travel because it overpredicted the health of the economy.
Once recession hit, the airlines found themselves buried in debt from buying airplanes they could not fill. So they engaged in waves of destructive price cutting to lure travelers from competitors. Excessive investments in operations at hub airports -- a mistake that followed the quick traverse from the pre-1978 world of regulation to the unseen world of competition -- haven't helped. These losses won't recur; once the economy recovers, so will profits.
The commission did not overreach by proposing widespread structural reform. For example, it would not have the Government regulate fares -- a system that did not work well before 1978 and would not work any better now. Competition has brought sharply lower fares and more convenient schedules.
The commission wisely recommends relaxing limits on foreign investment if host countries grant U.S. carriers unfettered access to their airports. Less wise is its call for exempting airlines from some taxes; the industry does not seem overtaxed.
Some airline executives have asked Washington to regulate fares to put a stop to self-destructive price cutting. Travelers, grab your wallets. What these executives really have in mind is for government to keep the likes of Southwest Airlines at bay. Southwest is anything but self-destructive. True, it charges rock-bottom prices. But it also makes the biggest profits.
Fortunately, the commission rejected government fare-setting, thus allowing upstarts like Southwest to fly high and force competitors to catch up -- the best travel protection the commission could possibly design.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Free Trade's Fine, as Long as It's Really Free;
Pulling Workers Down

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 12 editorial on the North American Free Trade Agreement is on target. Judge Charles Richey's decision requiring en environmental impact statement is warranted. Mexico has a poor record of enforcing weaker environmental and consumer laws. United States companies could pack up and move their businesses across the border to reduce their operating costs.
Under the trade agreement, food and products from Mexico would be treated as if they were produced domestically. Thus, United States companies that want to do the right thing by way of their workers and the environment would be put at a competitive disadvantage. 
 Given the experience of Canadian workers with the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement, which saw more than 400,000 Canadian jobs migrate to the United States, where wages and benefits were only slightly lower than in Canada, one can't help believe that many United States jobs will go south across the border. If businesses moved to the United States for only slightly lower wages and benefits, the much lower wages and lax environmental and workplace regulations of Mexico will look very attractive to many businesses.
Patrick J. Lucey would have us believe, in "The Lies of Nafta's Critics" (Op-Ed, July 13), that the trade agreement would create high-tech, high-wage jobs. The implication is that low-wage jobs will move to Mexico, while United States workers will move up the ladder to the high-tech, high-paying jobs that will be created as a result of the agreement. There are no data to support such a claim.
The available data would show that United States workers displaced by trade end up moving down the job ladder, or off the ladder to permanent unemployment. The effect of this agreement would be to throw United States, Mexican and Canadian workers into competition with one another to attract investment by offering the lowest wages and the least restrictive environmental regulations.
As the consumer advocate Ralph Nader noted, "it should be the role of the world's largest economy to lift the standards of other nations around the world, instead of having our standards pulled down to the lower common denominators of other countries."
 
YOHANNES WOLDEMARIAM
Baltimore, July 14, 1993

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

A Menu of Benefits

Q I've heard "cafeteria plan" used in connection with employee benefits. What is it?
 
 GUNTER HAIMANN, Jamesburg, N.J.
A Cafeteria plans are employer-sponsored benefit plans that give tax advantages to employees by allowing them to choose between receiving taxable benefits like cash or tax-free benefits like health insurance. Its name comes from Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code, which has authorized these plans since 1978. 
 "The sole breadwinner with dependents, the single employee, the person nearing retirement all have different benefit needs," said Michael J. Langan of Towers Perrin, the consulting firm. "Some want more life insurance, others more health insurance and others more disability protection."
A cafeteria plan allows an employee to pick from a menu of benefits and pay for them with pretax salary dollars. As a result, an employee's contribution may stretch 30 to 40 percent further than if it was made after taxes were withheld -- depending on the individual's tax rate.
 But health-care changes proposed in Washington could affect cafeteria plans, especially if the tax treatment of benefits is changed to make some of them taxable to employees or nondeductible by employers.
 
Convertible Bonds
Q How can I calculate the break-even time of a convertible bond?
 
 HYMAN DUDAKOFF, Brooklyn
A The break-even period refers to the time required for the convertible's current yield advantage to recapture the conversion premium. Break-even analysis is one of several means of evaluating the relative attractiveness of convertible securities.
"Convertible security holders usually pay a premium over conversion value for the ability to participate in the appreciation in the underlying stock, while limiting downside risk," said John Georgantas, convertible securities analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company.
There are limitations to break-even analysis, though, since it assumes such factors as unchanged interest rates and a static level of common dividends over the investment period.
In addition, the analysis does not consider either the risks associated with the issuer's credit quality or the appreciation potential in the underlying stock price.
 
Credit Card Criteria
Q What criteria do banks use for evaluating credit card applications?
 
ABE DUBROWSKY, West Palm Beach, Fla.
A Every bank has its own guidelines. But a big consideration for most banks is how well the applicant has handled credit. Usually people establish credit elsewhere before applying for a credit card.
"We want to see some depth of credit experience," said Cynthia A. Graham, president of Barnett Card Services Corporation. "We expect applicants to show that they can handle several different creditors and have never filed for bankruptcy."
Banks are also interested in an applicant's current obligations, income and employment history.

HEADLINE: CAVEAT EMPTOR;
When Selling Stocks, Monday's Child Fares Less Well

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks

 BODY:
Say you're spending a quiet weekend reviewing your stock portfolio, deciding what to sell. You hope to place the order before the busy workweek begins, using the toll-free lines that so many brokerage houses operate 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
That may not be such a good idea. A number of studies have found that share prices tend to fall at the start of the week -- especially early on Monday. 
 The Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which publishes a monthly newsletter called The Mutual Fund Forecaster, recently reviewed Monday trading for 64 years ended in 1990 and concluded that the market, on average, lost 15/100 of 1 percent on Monday while making gains on other business days.
A similar pattern emerged from a study of 2,000 smaller stocks in the Nasdaq system that was conducted by Richard D. Fortin, assistant professor of finance at the University of New Mexico at Las Cruces, and O. Maurice Joy, professor of finance at the University of Kansas.
The pair's analysis, which appeared in the Journal of the American Association of Individual Investors in March, was based on stock trading for seven years beginning in 1982. The professors computed the average weekly price for a stock and then looked at the stock's price each day. One finding: stock prices rose during the week so that a $10,000 purchase typically cost $40 more on a Friday than on a Tuesday.
The fluctuations, recognized by professional investors for some time, have been dubbed "the Monday Effect." All sorts of explanations have been offered, including the general feeling of gloom that characterizes a Monday morning.
In his book "One Up on Wall Street," Peter Lynch, former manager of Fidelity's Magellan Fund, suggested that unreasonable fears and suspicions build up during the weekend. The cycle then reverses, he said, because by late Monday investors have done additional research and discovered that their fears were unfounded.
Yet the numbers speak for themselves. "My advice is to buy late on a Monday or early Tuesday and sell on a Friday," said Norman G. Fosback, editor of The Mutual Fund Forecaster. The two academics reached the same conclusion.

HEADLINE: U.S. Increases Fund To Outbid Terrorists For Afghan Missiles

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency's covert operations division will spend $55 million in a new effort to buy back more than 300 Stinger antiaircraft missiles it gave to guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan in the 1980's, Government and intelligence officials say.
The effort reflects the agency's fear that it may be outbid by terrorists and hostile governments in the black market for the Stinger, a lightweight, shoulder-carried, highly accurate antiaircraft missile considered the best weapon of its kind, the officials said. 
 They said Iranian and North Korean espionage agents and Islamic militant groups were bidding to buy Stingers from demobilized Afghan rebels starved for cash in a country shattered by years of war and privation.
 
Some Obtained by Iran
 "The Iranians have already captured or otherwise obtained some Stingers and continue to try to accumulate them," said Edward S. Juchniewicz, who was the C.I.A.'s associate director for covert operations from 1982 to 1986. "I understand why people are exercised. I wouldn't want one to hit the airplane I'm on."
The Stinger, which finds its targets with a homing sensor that locks on to the heat of an aircraft's engines, is capable of destroying aircraft at a range of seven miles or more.
The new effort to reclaim the missiles, which was first reported in The Los Angeles Times today, followed a $10 million effort that proved insufficient, the officials said. The spending increase reflected the intensity of bidding for the weapons, they said.
The fate of the Stingers is a particularly messy aftermath of one of the cold war's great struggles. The C.I.A. and the Pentagon secretly shipped nearly 1,000 Stingers to the Afghan rebels from 1986 to 1989. At least 300 are now unaccounted for, officials say. The missiles were a small but highly significant part of a $3 billion covert action program, the intelligence agency's biggest paramilitary operation since Vietnam.
The Stingers helped turn the tide in the rebels' nine-year war against the Soviet Union, which sent troops into Afghanistan in 1979. Their deployment in Afghanistan represented the only known front of the cold war in which American missiles shot down Soviet pilots.
 
Use Against U.S. Is Feared
 Now the C.I.A. fears that the missiles, gone astray, could be used against Americans.
"The Stinger problem is very complicated," said Zalmay Khalilzad, a former Pentagon and State Department official involved in the program to support the Afghan rebels. "The problem is you get in competition with Iran, and they can outbid you. A lot of different Afghans have the missiles, and they are in bad economic shape. The price can go up when Iran and others compete for buying them."
Mr. Juchniewicz said Iran might try to exchange the highly valued Stingers for military equipment it covets, including long-range ground-to-ground missiles being developed by North Korea.
Despite the threat posed by the Stingers, Mr. Juchniewicz said he had few regrets about supporting the Afghan guerrillas, known as mujahedeen, or holy warriors.
"One makes the assumption when one goes to battle that one's equipment will be captured by the enemy," he said. "So unfortunately we lost some Stingers, and now our enemy has one of our best weapons. But the Stingers turned the war in the mujahedeen's favor."
 
Blow to the Soviet Union
 Reflecting a widely held view among American intelligence officials that the Soviet loss in Afghanistan was a fatal blow to the Soviet Union, he added: "The Stingers broke the Soviets' back. Isn't the danger posed by a handful of Stingers worth the dissolution of the Soviet empire?"
The bidding for the missiles will take place in a strange international bazaar. In Afghanistan today there is little law and order, and weapons and heroin are the primary commodities. Travelers from more than 40 Islamic countries go there to learn from the rebels who stared down the Soviets.
Among them were two World Trade Center bombing suspects, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef and Ahmad M. Ajaj, and two men indicted on charges of conspiring to murder politicians and blow up Federal buildings in New York, Clement Hampton-El and Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, Federal investigators say.
Some of the Afghan rebels have turned against their former patrons. "Some of the same people who are actual or potential terrorists in this country are former guerrilla fighters in Afghanistan," said David Whipple, the C.I.A.'s former national intelligence officer for counterterrorism.
To reclaim the missiles, the agency must depend on Pakistan's intelligence service, which distributed the C.I.A.'s weaponry during the war.
The Pakistanis favored the most radical and anti-American of the Afghan rebel leaders, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. By dint of his superior arsenal, Mr. Hekmatyar became Prime Minister of Afghanistan earlier this year. He and commanders loyal to him are believed to control a significant number of the Stingers. Mr. Hekmatyar also has made alliances of convenience with Iran.
"Hekmatyar was occasionally close to the Iranians, and we were not blind to that," said Fred C. Ikle, who fiercely supported the Afghan program as Under Secretary of Defense for Policy in the Reagan Administration.

HEADLINE: Stocks Bounce Higher; Dow Up 21.52, to 3,546.74

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks bounced higher in active trading yesterday, with the market showing a resiliency that had been lacking most of the week.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 3,546.74, up 21.52 points for the day and 18.45 points for the week. 
 Not even a 1 1/8-point decline in I.B.M., which closed at 42 1/4 after falling to a new 52-week trading low of 41 1/2, could temper yesterday's rally. Traders are expecting the giant computer company to announce its turnaround strategy on Tuesday, along with a cut in its quarterly dividend and a restructuring charge, which some analysts speculate could be as much as $5 billion, to cover added layoffs.
 
 
Volume Is Lower
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange reached 222.2 million shares, down from 249.6 million on Thursday, as the composite index rose 1.20 points, to 247.46. The number of advancing issues outnumbered losers by 1,026 to 865.
Market analysts at MMS International remain bullish on stocks, given the downward trend in interest rates, moderate inflation and respectable earnings growth. As such, they say, any near-term weakness in the stock market is likely to be a result of a pullback in the bond market.
"However, the market still remains suspect," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony.
"Confusion continues over the trend of interest rates, but even so, the market could enjoy a summer rally," he said. "Looking further ahead, the second half of the year remains poor, despite the potential for that normal summer rally."
Mr. Laubscher attributed some of the gain yesterday to technical factors. "Short coverings helped firm up prices in afternoon trading, as some investors covered short positions ahead of the weekend on the chance that some positive news could come out of Washington on Saturday or Sunday regarding the budget," Mr. Laubscher said.
Among individual issues, shares of Petsmart Inc., a retail pet-supply chain, closed at $25 a share in heavy Nasdaq trading. The company had made its initial public offering of 7.2 million shares on Thursday at a price of $18 through an underwriting group led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Sunbeam-Oster rose 2 5/8 to 18 3/8. The household products company announced that it had bought back 12.4 million shares in connection with the settlement of litigation with its former chairman, Paul B. Kazarian.
Amgen rose 1 5/8, to 36 1/8. The biotechnology company reported that second-quarter earnings rose 40 percent, to 70 cents a share from 49 cents a year earlier.
In Tokyo yesterday, Japanese stocks ended sharply lower, pushed down by concerns over a higher yen and political uncertainties. The Nikkei index of 225 issues lost 381.24 points, or 1.90 percent, to 19,734.57. It was the first close below 20,000 in almost two weeks.

HEADLINE: U.S. Eases Rules Governing Telephone Links With Cuba

BYLINE: Special to The New York TimesSpecial to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
In what could be the most significant easing of the economic embargo of Cuba in years, the Clinton Administration has decided to permit American telephone companies to expand communications links to Havana and share some of their revenues with the Castro Government, officials said today.
The move is a response to a surge in calls through Canadian-based companies that relay telephone calls from the United States to Cuba, evading the embargo and charging higher rates than American companies. 
 The regulations would allow carriers in the United States like A.T.&T., MCI and Sprint to share the proceeds from telephone charges to and from Cuba with Fidel Castro's Government. State Department officials have begun briefing members of Congress about the proposal and will soon inform prominent Cuban-American leaders and officials of American companies.
 
Opposed by Cuban-Americans
 The proposal, which could net the Castro Government about $50 million to $60 million a year, is expected to generate significant opposition among Cuban-Americans.
A.T.&T. maintains limited telecommunication service to Cuba, but because of the trade embargo the company cannot split the revenues derived from that service with Cuba's state-owned telephone company. Instead, Cuba's share of the proceeds are placed in an escrow account that totals more than $80 million.
While American companies will be able to share revenues from the calls with Cuba, officials said the money in the escrow account will continue to be frozen. As a result, United States officials are not sure whether its proposal will be acceptable to Cuba.
A spokesman at the Cuban diplomatic mission here, Jose Luis Ponce, said that the escrow provision could pose a major stumbling block, The Associated Press reported.
Cuba's position is that the funds in the frozen account should be turned over in order to reach an agreement, Mr. Ponce said. He added that Cuban authorities will study the United States proposal carefully.
Officials said today that it had yet to be determined how many circuits the Administration will allow American telephone carriers to establish with Cuba. It is estimated that for every 100 circuits that American companies set up, Cuba will garner about $15 million in the first year of operation.
At the same time it has decided to expand telephone service to Cuba, the Administration has sent letters to A.T.&T., MCI and Sprint seeking information about seven Canadian-based companies that provide telephone service to Cuba via toll-free 800 numbers.
Callers to the 800 numbers are connected to switchboards in Canada that relay their calls to Cuba. The customers are then billed by the companies for the calls, though at a higher rate than for calls placed through A.T.&.T. The so-called resellers have proliferated recently because A.T.&T. service to Cuba has deteriorated due to damage to relay towers in Florida caused by Hurricane Andrew last August.
The Treasury Department has determined that these so-called telephone resellers are violating the American trade embargo because these companies share the proceeds from the calls with Cuba.

HEADLINE: Russia Aid Plan Promotes Role for U.S. Companies

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
Revising its aid proposals for the former Soviet Union, the Clinton Administration has told the Senate that it wants to get American companies more involved in efforts to build a private sector and to expand money allocated for republics other than Russia.
The new proposal came in the form of a request for $2.5 billion in appropriations sent to the Senate Thursday night and intended to carry out the Administration's aid pledges for Russia and the other former republics of the Soviet Union. 
 The Administration's request calls for allocating larger sums for loan guarantees to be administered by the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. This move would provide opportunities for American businesses as well a more direct route for help to fledgling Russian companies.
The new proposal involves a reshuffling of money after the seven wealthiest industrial nations agreed in Tokyo this month to help finance a $3 billion fund to speed privatization in Russia, down from the $4 billion fund they originally hoped to create.
 
Involving U.S. Industry
 Under that agreement, the United States pledged to provide a $125 million grant to help privatization and $250 million in export credits, much of which will be used to push American industry to get more involved in helping the former Soviet Union.
"A very heavy emphasis throughout our program is to help not just Russia but also American businesses that want to get involved there," said Strobe Talbott, the Administration's special adviser for Russia and the former Soviet republics.
The plan sent to the Senate involves $1.8 billion that the United States pledged for the former Soviet Union in April when the finance and foreign ministers from the seven wealthiest nations met in Tokyo. It also includes an additional $700 million in aid that the Administration is seeking for the fiscal year 1994.
The $1.8 billion was part of an overall $28 billion promised by the Group of Seven, which comprises the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and Italy.
One focus of the program will be to help revive Russia's worn-down oil and gas industry, which American officials say can someday be a much larger source of hard-currency exports.
"One of the biggest areas we will be involved in is in oil and gas," said Kenneth Brody, chairman of the Export-Import Bank. "They have a tremendous need to take existing fields and increase the production."
Much of the money from the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation is used to encourage American investment in Russia and to help Russian enterprises finance the purchase of American goods and services. For instance, a Russian oil drilling enterprise might purchase American oilfield equipment that will make it more efficient and more attractive to private investors.
According to Administration officials, every $1 billion in American exports to Russia might create 20,000 jobs here.
Some Administration officials say the plan's emphasis on helping the private sector should make it easier for hesitant Senators, including many Republicans, to approve the plan. Despite all the attention on President Clinton's budget package, Administration official say they still hope that the Senate will approve the aid package before the August recess. The House approved a somewhat different package in June.
Under the proposal submitted to the Senate, more than $100 million would be used to help modernize enterprises in non-Russian republics and to assist them in privatization.
The proposal also calls for $60 million in transportation funds to pay for the shipment of tens of millions of dollars of privately donated food and medicine for Russia.
"There has been a shift of emphasis away from humanitarian assistance, which you might call quick-delivery, short-term, high-impact, to a series of programs that we feel reflect our commitment to stay in for the long haul," Mr. Talbott said.

HEADLINE: Out on a Limb on Job Data

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
They say that politics runs in cycles, but these days the cycles seem to spin faster and faster.
Only last summer Bill Clinton mocked President George Bush, saying he had failed to meet his pledge to create 30 million jobs in four years. The lesson, some Democrats said, is that such a specific promise is always folly. 
 Then Mr. Clinton declared that he would create 8 million jobs by 1996. Today, the Administration went a step further, listing the number of jobs that would be created in each state by the Clinton economic package that is likely to be passed by Congress.
The precision is supposed to help lawmakers explain support for the Clinton plan and to counter opposition to the plan by business groups. But it is bound to help the President's opponents hold him to account.
Should Arizona, say, fall short of the 320,745 new jobs predicted, Mr. Clinton may find himself pilloried as a failure even if he meets his broader goal.
At the White House, however, a senior official today shrugged off the potential for political liability later.
"As long as you show progress, I think you're O.K.," the official said. "It's not as stark a target as Bush set."

HEADLINE: Moynihan Scolds the White House, Saying It Must Be Flexible to Win a Budget Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the chief Senate negotiator on the deficit-reduction legislation, accused the Clinton Administration today of inflexibility and naivete and said that if the White House did not agree to some compromises next week, he would not be able to produce a budget bill that could pass the Senate.
Mr. Moynihan's outburst came as Congressional negotiations on the budget broke for the weekend. It represented growing tension between Congress and the White House just as the differences between the Senate and House conferees were narrowing, including the emergence of the outlines of a compromise on a gasoline tax. 
 "They have absolutely no sense that they cannot have everything they want," Senator Moynihan said of Administration officials. "I'm beginning to feel they think I'm from the backwoods or something."
The Senator, a New York Democrat who until now has been circumspect when he talked about the budget negotiations, was buttonholed by a reporter in the Capitol Rotunda as he walked back to the Senate after a meeting with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is the chief House negotiator on taxes; Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, and Leon E. Panetta, President Clinton's budget director.
 
Sending a Message
 He seemed to be eager to send a public message to the White House that he had been unable to get through privately.
"There are just no negotiations going on with them," Mr. Moynihan said. "We have the President's position presented to us, and that's it."
Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta would not comment on Mr. Moynihan's complaint. Earlier, Mr. Panetta told reporters, "We've reached a sensitive stage in the negotiations."
George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to the President, said, "We just feel that the negotiations are going well, and we hope they continue to make progress."
 
Rift Expected to Close
 The rift between Democrats in Congress and the Administration seemed likely to be patched up next week, since all sides understand they must stick together if they are to pass the budget legislation over the opposition of every Republican in Congress.
In fact, after a session this afternoon, Mr. Moynihan's frustration had eased. "We had a much better meeting," he said in an interview at the end of the day. "They began to realize that you can't have all those things they want. It was a lot more collaborative."
Over the last two days, a compromise seemed to be developing on energy taxes, the issue on which the Senate and House conferees had been furthest apart. The House bill would raise $72 billion over five years with a broad tax on most forms of energy, including oil, coal, natural gas, electricity and hydroelectric and nuclear power. The Senate measure included only a 4.3-cents-a-gallon tax on gasoline, which would raise $22 billion over the five years.
On Thursday evening, Mr. Rostenkowski proposed that the Senate's tax on gasoline be combined with a new tax on utility bills. The senators rejected that, and today Mr. Rostenkowski made an offer of a 6-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax that would rise a penny each year, to 9 cents after four years.
Once an issue can be boiled down to dollar amounts, conference committees can usually reach a resolution by splitting the difference. A staff member involved in the conference put it this way: "So one side says 9 cents and the other says 4.3 cents. Where do you think they will come out?"
A gasoline tax of 6 or 7 cents a gallon would raise $30 billion to $35 billion over five years, an amount the Clinton Administration has said it could support.
The House conferees also agreed today to a gimmick in the Senate bill that can be recorded as saving $9 billion over five years, although it actually saves no money at all. The House bill would permanently extend the expiring tax credit for business expenses on research. The Senate bill would extend it for only one year, and that would save money on paper even though everyone knows it will be extended again after it expires next year.
The Administration continued to devote almost all its energy to promoting its economic plan, passing out a state-by-state breakdown showing how many jobs would be created if the economic program became law.
 
Moynihan's Frustration
 Senator Moynihan's criticism of the White House seemed to result from days of mounting frustration. He became annoyed at midweek when, just as he was trying to convince his fellow senators that they would have to accept a gasoline tax high enough to raise about $35 billion over five years, Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rostenkowski emerged from Mr. Rostenkowski's office and said the Administration wanted a gasoline tax that would raise $22 billion to $35 billion.
Mr. Moynihan complained that the only number his colleagues heard had been the lower one. What apparently set him off today was the Administration's insistence that the conferees retain generous tax breaks for investors in small businesses. Mr. Moynihan said he believed that these breaks were bad tax policy and wasted money.
The House and Senate approved provisions, called "expensing" in tax lingo, that would let small businesses deduct a sizable amount spent on equipment in the year the money is invested, instead of having to depreciate the investment over several years.
The House bill would also halve the capital gains tax on the profits from investments made in certain small businesses and held for at least five years.
Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Rostenkowski would like to cut back these tax breaks for small businesses and use the money, more than $1 billion a year, to pay for another program the Administration wants -- tax advantages for businesses in certain poor neighborhoods, called "enterprise zones."
But President Clinton has been touting the tax help for small businesses in recent speeches, even though the expensing provisions, the most costly of the tax breaks, were added by Congress and were not part of his original budget proposal.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Dry St. Louis Is Furiously Battling a Flood of Misperception

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST LOUIS, July 23

 BODY:
In this city that has been at the epicenter of the Mississippi's soggy wrath for the last week, a lot of people are desperate to get a simple message out: they're dry.
The flooding across the Midwest is likely to continue for weeks, and it could be almost a month before the Mississippi moves below flood stage here. But virtually all the city remains dry, its tourist attractions are all open and officials hope the message gets out before the natural disaster in the region turns into a bigger economic one here. 
 "There are 2.5 million people in the metropolitan area here, and I would say that less than 1 percent are truly affected," said Nancy Milton, a spokeswoman for the St. Louis Convention and Visitors Commission. "I don't want to minimize the tragedy that those people are going through, but most St. Louisans are going on about daily life without seeing any effect at all."
The dichotomy is partly a result of this city's particular geography -- its downtown located on a high bluff and protected by a 52-foot flood wall that has left attractions like the St. Louis Gateway Arch and Busch Stadium, just off the river, completely dry. And it is partly a result of the odd nature of floods, which can wreak havoc as this one has for hundreds of miles but largely spare areas that are not directly along a river.
In any case, tourism-related businesses here are desperately trying to fight off the perception that visitors need to bring scuba gear.
"We receive about 150 phone calls a day asking, 'Are you flooded?' " said Kathy Strauser, a spokeswoman for Meramec Caverns, a popular tourist attraction with an underground river where Jesse James used to hide out. "We tell them, 'We're fine. Come on out.' But it's like they don't believe us. They're afraid they're going to come out and get washed away."
Ms. Strauser said Meramec Caverns was averaging about half the 1,500 to 2,000 visitors a day it usually receives this time of year. The campground, which usually has 100 to 150 campers a night, now has about 10 or 20, she said.
Jeff Wehling, public relations director for the St. Louis Cardinals, who play their home games three blocks from the Mississippi, said the team was receiving the same kind of calls.
"We field calls daily from groups, from individuals, who are calling in and saying, 'Hey, I've got tickets for the first week of August. Is the stadium under water?' " he said. "The perception is the entire city of St. Louis is flooded."
He said it was unclear how much the fears had affected attendance. The Cardinals' attendance is up over last year, but they are contending for a pennant in a way they were not last year, and it is possible that the crowds would be even larger without the fears.
Still, Ms. Milton, the spokeswoman for the visitors commission, said there was no indication of significant cancellations at hotels. And at least one local attraction, the Gateway Arch, is benefiting. People are buying up all available tickets for the ride to the top of the arch so they can see the surging river from 630 feet above it.
She said she hoped that with the passing of time the right picture would get out.
"You really can't fault the media or the people who are watching it, but together there's an impression created that could be an economic problem at some point," she said. "It's like a game of telephone you played when you were a little kid. You start with a message that sounds perfectly clear to you, and by the time it ends up, it's totally different."

HEADLINE: Threat of Statehood in Puerto Rico Leads to a Restored Tax Break

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
Worried about reopening the debate on Puerto Rican statehood, budget negotiators agreed today to reinstate $2.6 billion in tax breaks for big American companies that do business on the island.
President Clinton had originally proposed to move quickly to phase out Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which exempts mainland companies from Federal taxes on income earned in Puerto Rico as long as it remains a commonwealth. Intended to save the Treasury $6.8 billion over five years, the provision passed the House intact as part of the President's deficit-reduction package two months ago. 
The provision attracted little debate in the House, despite opponents' predictions that it would precipitate everything from the loss of tens of thousands of jobs to a violent political reaction on the island to a new wave of Puerto Rican immigration.
 
Large Lobbying Campaign
 They were right at least about the political reaction. The issue shook the barrios of the South Bronx and San Juan as well as the boardrooms of the big New Jersey-based pharmaceutical companies that operate on the island.
Puerto Rican politicians of various political stripes united with mainland and Puerto Rican businessmen in organizing a lobbying campaign that combined a press relations blitz in the Hispanic news media, large demonstrations on the island and the mainland, and back-room cajoling on Capitol Hill.
The dispute is becoming intertwined with the political campaign preceding a nonbinding plebiscite on whether the island should remain a commonwealth or become a state or new nation. Puerto Ricans are to vote on Nov. 14.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, gave the Administration a private warning that proved to be decisive. An abrupt change in tax policy, he told President Clinton, could push Puerto Ricans to vote for statehood -- and the enhanced welfare and economic benefits that go with it -- before the Senate is prepared to accept the island as a state.
Responding to the pressure, President Clinton pledged to the Congressional Hispanic Caucus on Thursday night that he was now committed to a compromise proposal backed by Senators Moynihan and Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, to restore more than $2.6 billion in tax breaks.
 
'There Will Not Be a Shock'
 Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat who is a senior House budget conferee, said his House colleagues were ready to go along with the provision, whose main outlines were already passed by the Senate last month.
Mr. Moynihan, who as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee is a prime mover of the conference committee now working on the President's budget package, said, "It means there will not be a shock in Puerto Rico." He noted that the Administration and Congress had agreed to a gradual phase-down of Section 936 over more than a decade, so Puerto Ricans "can get ready for it and think about it."
Senator Moynihan had also argued that withdrawing the tax breaks could foster a diplomatic embarrassment that would kick up anti-American nationalistic responses throughout the third world.
By revoking Section 936, Mr. Moynihan argued, the Administration would make it more likely that Puerto Rican voters would opt for statehood. Mr. Moynihan said there was no way the Senate would approve statehood, even if Puerto Ricans vote for it, validating the charges of Fidel Castro and Puerto Rican nationalists that the island is nothing but a colony.
 
Original Plan Dropped
 Mr. Moynihan recalled his efforts as Ambassador to the United Nations during the Ford Administration to head off a resolution condemning Puerto Rico's commonwealth status as an "act of colonialism," and he predicted that the Administration would face the same diplomatic embroglio should the Senate refuse to honor a plebiscite result favoring statehood.
As Mr. Clinton pondered Mr. Moynihan's concerns, the House's three Puerto Rican members met with the President at the White House last month to urge him to reconsider his position. "We reminded the President," recalled Representative Jose E. Serrano, Democrat of the South Bronx, "that the House passed the package because of three votes, and in this room there were three Puerto Ricans."
The Administration quietly dropped its original proposal, which was to reduce the Section 936 benefits to companies like Abbott Laboratories and Bristol-Myers Squibb to a tax credit equal to 60 percent of a company's wages paid in Puerto Rico.
With the help of the Treasury Department, Senators Bradley and David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, hammered out the general outlines of the new proposal, which would allow companies operating on the island to choose between two tax credit options.
Under one, the current 100 percent income credits would be reduced to 60 percent in 1994, and reduced by an additional 5 percent each year until 1998. The second would limit tax credits to 95 percent of wages and benefits paid in Puerto Rico, along with depreciation deductions.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond's Yield Jumps to 6.70%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday for the fourth straight session as the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to its highest level in nearly a month.
The bond market has been disturbed this week by the Congressional testimony of the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan. Also, traders said, the market has been weighed down by a heavy supply of new corporate and municipal issues. 
 In trading yesterday, the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 18/32 of a point. Its yield rose to 6.70 percent, from 6.66 percent late Thursday.
Before Mr. Greenspan began his testimony, the Treasury market had been in the midst of a powerful monthlong rally. The advance was fueled in part by hopes that inflationary pressures were not strong enough to warrant an increase in short-term interest rates.
 
Rate Hopes Are Dashed
 But market expectations were dashed on Tuesday when Mr. Greenspan, delivering the central bank's report on monetary policy to a House Banking subcommittee, said the Fed was ready to raise interest rates to control inflation. On Thursday, he reiterated that message before the Senate Banking Committee.
Most traders and analysts were not surprised by the substance of Mr. Greenspan's testimony. They were, however, jolted by the central bank chairman's determined tone, which seemed to signal the Fed's intention to raise rates even if inflation pressures were not that obvious.
That prompted selling that pushed up the long bond's yield by 16 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, this week.
"The logic is that the probability of the Fed tightening has increased compared to what the market thought earlier," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Many traders saw the testimony as an excuse to cash in on the recent run-up in bond prices, said Richard Estabrook, vice president of mortgage trading at Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago.
Mr. Estabrook said he did not expect bond yields to rise much higher in the near term. But, he added, the 30-year bond's yield is unlikely to dip to the 6.50 percent level again soon, particularly with the Treasury preparing a surge of new issues over the next two weeks.
The Treasury is scheduled to sell $16 billion in five-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion in five-year notes on Wednesday. It is selling longer-term debt in the following week as part of its refunding.
In other trading yesterday, short-term Treasuries were unchanged to 1/32 point lower and intermediate maturities fell 3/16 point to 5/16 point.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills was unchanged at 3.08 percent, while the discount rate on six-month bills rose one basis point, to 3.22 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills gained four basis points, to 3.46 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10111/32 , down 7/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.81 percent, up from 5.79 percent.
