HEADLINE: Lawmakers Add to Defiance of Yeltsin

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 23

 BODY:
The Russian Parliament recessed for the summer today after rushing through an extraordinary string of measures. If put into force, they threaten to disrupt the economy, undermine the turning over of public property to private interests, fracture relations with Ukraine, jail a key Yeltsin aide and, among many other things, expand the privileges of the legislators.
The long list ranges from a budget that is twice as large as anticipated revenues to little-noticed actions like closing K.G.B. archives for an extra 20 years. It includes a declaration claiming the Crimean port of Sevastopol to be Russian, not Ukrainian -- and another condemning the United Nations Security Council for denouncing the measure. 
 It includes a bill that would give control over transferring public property to private ownership to separate ministries, another canceling President Boris N. Yeltsin's decree on accelerating such transfers, another restoring a sensitive rocket engine deal with India that was opposed by the United States, another giving Parliament full control over the Central Bank and another calling for restrictions on foreign religious organizations.
 
Yeltsin Out of Town
 Though technically many of the bills have the force of law, most commentators anticipated that President Yeltsin would veto them or that his Government would simply ignore them, as they have done with such legislation in the past.
But to the despair of his supporters, Mr. Yeltsin remained silent at his vacation retreat in central Russia.
For themselves, the legislators took over Moscow apartments they had been given as temporary residences, expanded retirement benefits and authorized travel in military planes, which Mr. Yeltsin has denied them.
At the same time, the legislators stripped parliamentary immunity from one of Mr. Yeltsin's top aides, Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir F. Shumeiko. And agents from the office of Procurator General Valentin G. Stepankov -- Russia's chief prosecutor and a political ally of Parliament -- questioned one of Mr. Yeltsin's closest friends, Mikhail N. Poltoranin, the former Minister of Information and a bitter enemy of Parliament. Both officials have been accused by Parliament of corruption.
The bills, many prepared in secret, marked the lifting of any veil from the intentions and hostility of Parliament. Since the April referendum in which a majority of voters declared their preference for Mr. Yeltsin and his program of change, the legislators have voted as if under siege, churning out measures that even six months ago would have given them pause.
 
Votes Are Nearly Unanimous
 Most votes were virtually unanimous, reflecting the fact that the liberal minority has simply stopped taking part in a legislature in which its voice and votes have no useful force. Nonetheless, as insurance, Parliament voted to require only half the members to be present for a quorum.
Liberal legislators and newspapers anxiously called on Mr. Yeltsin to return quickly to Moscow. "It is completely inadmissible that the president continues vacation during such developments," declared Lev Ponomaryov, cochairman of the Democratic Russia movement. "The tense situation demands his immediate return to Moscow."
Sergei A. Filatov, Mr. Yeltsin's chief of staff, said the President was monitoring the situation. "Any haste on the President's part would be undesirable," Mr. Filatov said in an interview. "What they want is to provoke hasty actions, to heat up the atmosphere and divide the population."
For his part, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the Speaker of Parliament, who has evolved into an inexorable foe of the President, closed the session with a warning to the members not to lower their guard.
"We are closing our session in a complex situation," he said. "Sharp turns in the political situation cannot be ruled out. Deputies themselves should be ready to resume their duties without any special notice if the situation comes to a head. They should be ready, if need be, to get together immediately to react to possible complications."
The "sharp turns" Mr. Khasbulatov evidently fears, and the ones that seemed to spur Parliament's actions, are Mr. Yeltsin's declared goal of disbanding the standing Parliament and the larger Congress of People's Deputies from which it is drawn and holding elections for a new, two-chamber Parliament.
The President has yet to declare how he would hold elections over Parliament's resistance. But his major instrument has been a constitutional conference he called in June, which has drafted a new charter. Mr. Yeltsin has said the conference can be reconvened to draft a new election law.
 
Heading for a Showdown
 These moves have effectively put the long political standoff between Mr. Yeltsin and Parliament into a showdown, with Mr. Khasbulatov openly using his threatened legislators to undermine the Government.
The measures that have most concerned liberal commentators and politicians are those that take direct aim at economic changes. The one they consider the most dangerous threatens to push Russia to hyperinflation.
On Thursday, Parliament passed a 1993 budget with projected spending of 44.7 trillion rubles ($44.7 billion at the current exchange rate), more than double the anticipated revenues of 22.3 trillion rubles ($22.3 billion). The budget included a 20 percent increase in military spending, to 8 trillion rubles ($8 billion).
"We cannot live with such a high deficit," declared Aleksandr Pochinok, chairman of the parliamentary budget commission, who had argued against it. He noted that the budget deficit was equal to 25 percent of Russia's gross national product -- far above the 5 percent target recommended by the International Monetary Fund.
The budget violated the Parliament's own resolution that inflation by the end of 1993 must be reduced to 10 percent a month, and it threatens further loans from the monetary fund.
Above all, the measure threatens to undermine a campaign by Mr. Yeltsin's tough Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, to stabilize the ruble. Monthly inflation has fallen sharply in recent months, down to 17.4 percent from 28 percent in January. The ruble has held firm against the dollar for several weeks, and Mr. Fyodorov has bet that it will remain so through September.
 
Presidential Veto Expected
 Mr. Fyodorov was conspicuously absent from the Thursday session, and it seemed likely that President Yeltsin would veto the measure. Parliament can overrule a veto with a two-thirds vote.
In other measures over the last three days, Parliament voted to restore full control over the Central Bank and its director, threatening a deal Mr. Fyodorov struck with the bank in May to tighten monetary policy.
It has also attacked the program led by Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais to transfer state-owned property to private ownership. On Tuesday they suspended Mr. Yeltsin's decree accelerating the selloff. And on Wednesday they voted to transfer control of the property from Mr. Chubais's State Property Committee to the ministries that used to control them.
Parliament also waded into Mr. Yeltsin's foreign policies. On one front, it voted to declare Sevastopol part of Russia, drawing immediate cries of rage from Ukraine. Sevastopol is the home port of the contested Black Sea Fleet, and is situated on the Crimean peninsula -- a part of Ukraine also claimed by Russian nationalists.
On another front, the legislators ruled that all agreements dealing with missile technology must be ratified by Parliament. The measure was intended to combat a decision by the Government to suspend the sale of cryogenic rockets powered by liquid nitrogen to India, a deal strongly opposed by the United States, which wants to prevent the spread of missile technology.

HEADLINE: SOUTH ASIANS SEEK A SECURITY FORUM

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 22

 BODY:
Anxious over the growing power of China and over the pullout of American armed forces from Asia, several large Southeast Asian countries are moving to create a regional security forum with the United States and Japan that will meet regularly to discuss military stability in the region with the world's fastest-growing economy.
The security forum, which is being established at the suggestion of Japan and with the blessing of the Clinton Administration, represents an important shift in strategy for the major non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia, which had long depended on Washington to keep peace in the region. 
 The creation of the forum, which does not yet have a name, is expected to be formally announced here on Saturday at the end of a two-day meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean.
Southeast Asian diplomats said the United States, China, Japan, Russia, Vietnam, Australia and several other countries with interests in Asia will be included in the forum, which for now will take the form of annual or semi-annual high-level conferences on security issues.
 
Possibility of More
 The diplomats did not rule out the possibility that the forum would someday develop into something more -- perhaps even a defense alliance.
"The nations of Southeast Asia have had the luxury for such a long time of not worrying about defense issues," a senior Asian diplomat said. "We all much prefer to focus on economic growth. But we must be logical about this. The region is changing, the United States is reducing its presence and we must be willing to discuss ways of protecting ourselves."
The Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- comprising Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- focuses on economic development and trade. Until this year, security matters were left off the agenda of Asean meetings, an understandable decision given the reliable American security umbrella.
Asian officials said the new talk of military cooperation was being driven by the departure of American troops from Southeast Asia as part of the reduction of forces worldwide, and by a distrust of China's growing economic power and recent military purchases.

HEADLINE: Alaska Governor, Once Pro-Secession, Sues Over Federal Land

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 23

 BODY:
Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska, who was elected as a candidate of a party that advocated seceding from the union, filed a lawsuit against the Federal Government today, charging that the United States has violated the terms of statehood and deprived the state of its ability to raise revenue.
The $29 billion suit, which Alaska officials say is the largest ever filed by a state against the Government, is the loudest broadside yet in Mr. Hickel's continuing battle with the Federal Government. In the last year, he has stepped up his criticism, accusing the Government of treating Alaska, the nation's biggest state, like a distant colony. 
 In the suit, filed in Federal Claims Court in Washington, Alaska officials say that the establishment of national parks and wilderness areas in their state over the last 34 years has violated the 1959 statehood pact.
Legal experts say the suit is a long shot. But the 74-year-old Mr. Hickel, perhaps the last major Alaska politician who still evokes the fervor of old territorial days, is feeding a longtime antagonism against the Federal Government among some Alaskans.
 
Fan of Development
 Mr. Hickel, 74, came to Alaska in 1940 and was the state's second Governor, serving from 1966 until 1969, when he joined President Nixon's Cabinet as Interior Secretary. Since taking office again three years ago, he has proposed a variety of schemes to open Alaska for further oil and natural gas development, to pipe Alaskan water to California and to build highways and railroads into tracts of wilderness. But the Governor has been thwarted by his own Legislature and by Federal laws that prohibit development in national parks, wilderness areas and wildlife refuges.
Now, using a legal stick to promote his political philosophy, Mr. Hickel is contending that the Federal Government owes the state at least $29 billion for all the land it has taken out of development. The statehood compact requires that 90 percent of all revenue from oil, mineral and gas leasing on Alaska's Federal land be given to the state. By withdrawing more than 100 million acres from potential development, the suit says, the Government has taken away the state's ability to derive income from those lands.
In effect, the suit asserts that Alaskans were induced to become part of the union by a Federal promise that has been repeatedly broken.
"It's a form of bait-and-switch," said Charles Cole, Alaska's Attorney General, in an interview. "No sooner had we accepted statehood than the Government started withdrawing land from revenue-producing status."
Other Alaskans say the Federal lands produce plenty of income, but in a different way. They note that the state's booming tourism industry is based on attracting visitors to the very national parks and wildlife refuges that are protected from development.
Mr. Hickel said the statehood compact had been broken on many occasions. "It cannot be legally changed without the consent of both parties, yet Congress has unilaterally amended it many times, at great cost to the people of Alaska," Mr. Hickel said.
That view was countered by John Havelock, who served as Alaska's Attorney General in the 1970's, when much of the land was protected from development. He said the lawsuit would have little chance of succeeding because the statehood compact appeared to allow the Federal Government to protect lands from development without Alaska's consent.
Mr. Havelock called the lawsuit "a political statement." But he added: "I think Governor Hickel is sincere, though. He genuinely believes all this. You might say there are a lot of old-timers here for which this is gospel, and he's one of them."
Other Western states, notably Idaho, Nevada, Montana and Wyoming, have long complained about Federal ownership of land in their state. But Mr. Cole said Alaska's situation was different because its statehood pact explicitly says how the land can be used.
When Alaska became the 49th state in 1959, it was granted 103 million acres for its use, almost 30 percent of the state. Corporations representing Alaska's Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians control 12 percent of the state's land. The Federal Government manages 59 percent, and a small percentage is in private hands.
The Federal lands in Alaska are normally open to a variety of commercial uses, like mining and oil drilling. But over the years, particularly in the 1970's, the Government has carved large national parks and wildlife refuges from the land it controls. That designation makes those lands off-limits to mining and oil development, irking pro-development forces and fueling periodic calls for secession.
 
No Longer for Secession
 The secession forces rallied behind Mr. Hickel, a multimillionaire hotel developer and entrepreneur, in 1990, when he ran as the candidate of the Alaskan Independence Party. He won with 39 percent of the vote in a three-way race. Although that party advocates secession, Mr. Hickel has disavowed that idea since the election.
Some political observers in Alaska, noting the state's high per capita income and the fact that its 550,000 residents pay no state taxes, say that Alaska has been able to prosper under current Federal regulations.
"To say that parks and wilderness discourage significant development cannot be supported by the record," said Dr. Tom Morehouse, director of the Institute of Social and Economic Research at the University of Alaska at Anchorage. "This idea that we are just a colony is old territorial rhetoric."

HEADLINE: Gang Membership Grows In Middle-Class Suburbs

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
A few of the middle-class teen-agers in baggy shorts and backwards baseball caps smoking cigarettes on the lawn behind Mark Twain Junior High School were quick to claim membership in a street gang.
"Ooh, ooh, I'm in one!" said George Clementi, a 14-year-old in a Looney Tunes T-shirt. Actually, he said, he belongs to two groups, the Crime Related Artists and the United Crime Kings. 
 His crimes? He said he paints graffiti on underpasses and drinks occasionally. Once, he said, he was arrested for trespassing. In the most serious incident he could recall, a group of Irish boys known as the Woodlawn Kidz shot up a friend's pink Geo jeep, just three days off the lot.
Suburban youth gang activity is so different from urban gang warfare that it is considered almost a separate phenomenon by police officers across the region, who say the number of youth gangs is on the rise in New York suburbs, particularly in Westchester County.
 
From Pranks to Shootings
 Generally, the police said, the activities of suburban gangs fall somewhere between youthful pranks and the drive-by shootings that have left bystanders dead in big cities around the country. There is vandalism, from graffiti to property destruction. And there is violence, though the weapon of choice is less likely to be a gun than a baseball bat and the victims are more likely to end up in the emergency room than the morgue.
"Kids go to the hospital, but nobody dies," said George Clementi's friend, Ernie Ila, 17, who took a drink of Snapple, let out a long burp then excused himself. "They get hit with golf clubs," he said with a shrug.
In fact, people have died. The police said they were concerned that two fatal shootings, including one drive-by, in Yonkers in the last year could mark the beginning of more serious problems. In any case, the police said, the proliferation of suburban gangs, with members affecting the pose of criminals and aspiring to a rap sheet, is troubling because it indicates a generalized breakdown in values.
Many of the suburban gang members do not fit the classic description of the disadvantaged youth drawn to crime as a way out of a bad neighborhood and an impoverished family.
In generally affluent Westchester County, where officials said there were 70 gangs with about 1,500 members, the police said they had cracked down on incipient middle-class gangs, including a Yorktown group known as the "Benzi Boyz," who named themselves after the Mercedes-Benz hood ornaments they steal and wear around their necks; a bunch of Peekskill middle school boys who gave themselves gang names and started fighting one another about a year ago, and the Mount Vernon Boyz, a gang of upper middle-class teen-agers, including prep school students, who have reportedly been involved in a number of assaults. In each case, the police said they were able to stop or significantly slow the gang's activities within recent months.
"They're rich kids and we contacted their parents," Ken Davis, a Yonkers police officer who sometimes works with the Mount Vernon police, said of the Mount Vernon Boyz.
Not all the gangs are equally fearsome: In Yonkers, members of the "Lawrence Street Posse" are believed to be responsible for two deaths and at least one other shooting. On the other end of the spectrum, a group of 12- and 13-year-olds in Hackensack, N.J., called themselves a gang for 48 hours, pushing around other kids in their middle school until school officials called in the police.
Indeed, short-lived alliances are one of the hallmarks of suburban gangs, which unlike city gangs do not always revolve around neighborhood groups protecting their home turf and, often, the drug business that goes with it. In the suburban sprawl, gang members are more likely to meet at school than on the block, and when trouble breaks out it is often at malls and movie theaters. Both the police and gang members said most fights in suburbia were not about territory at all, but start when a member of one group offends, or "disses," a member of another group.
 
Drive-By Beatings
 Revenge is usually less final here: Instead of drive-by shootings, there are drive-by beatings in which a group with baseball bats jumps out of a car and attacks a rival group. When guns are used, it is often for what the police call "walk-bys," in which gang members fire into the air.
As a result, the antagonisms are much more fluid. Because the disputes are often fleeting, suburban gang members are less likely to form long-term allegiances or wear gang colors that identify their affiliation. And suburban gang rosters and even gang names are constantly changing.
"Every couple of days you hear new names crop up," said Walter Young, deputy police chief in Stamford, Conn.
Many groups are gangs in name only, made up of youths who mouth "gangsta" rap lyrics and wear prison-inspired fashions like pants with no belts and boxers showing -- a look that began with inmates who are not allowed to wear belts. "There are a million wannabes," said Mr. Davis.
 
Girls Forming Gangs, Too
 Some of the wannabes "emulate themselves into jail," said Lieut. Frank Messar of the Yonkers police. At least 40 percent of the 700 arrests of 7- to 16-year-olds in Yonkers last year were gang-related, he said.
Gangs are attracting more teen-agers from all backgrounds and socio-economic groups, Mr. Davis said. Several female gangs have organized in Yonkers and Mount Vernon in recent years, too, with bad-girl names like "Bitches in Charge."
"There's no common denominator," said Karyn Addison, a detective in the youth division of the Mount Vernon Police Department. "Black, white, Hispanic -- they're all having problems. Family life is hard for all of them, and they're trying to find their way." Even teen-agers from stable homes see criminal behavior glorified on television, she said, and parents don't seem to exercise the control they once did.
"Some of these parents question what we've done instead of questioning what their kid has done," Ms. Addison said. "Instead of, 'My God, my son has a gun,' it's 'How can you prove he had a gun?' It's, 'Why did you pick up my son?' instead of, 'What was my 12-year-old doing out at 1 or 2 or 3 A.M.?' Or you try to contact a parent, and you can't find them."
 
Seeking Federal Money
 Reports of gang activity in Westchester shocked local residents earlier this summer, when County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke called a news conference to discuss the presence of gangs and to announce gang prevention programs. The Reporter Dispatch in White Plains ran a front-page story that referred to "1,500 members of 70 organized youth gangs roaming the streets of Westchester and involved in assaults, robberies, burglaries and drive-by shootings."
And while some police and school officials have argued that the problem is less serious than advertised, county officials said they did not want to wait for more drive-by shootings before addressing the problems that lead to gang violence. They are forthright about their motivation in highlighting the current problems: They want Federal money for programs that could prevent the situation from growing worse.
"You think of Los Angeles, the South Bronx or Harlem, you don't think about suburbia," said Toni Collarini, executive director of Westchester County's Youth Bureau. But she said the problem had been expanding beyond the city limits over the last five years, creating a need for more youth programs.
"In L.A. for 10 years they had cut funding for community centers and you see what happened," she said. A county task force on gangs is due to release the results of a yearlong study of gang activity within the week.
 
Danger Escalating
 In a tour of Yonkers gang hangouts with Mr. Davis and another officer, Victor Mendez, gang members said the situation was getting scarier.
Sitting on a stoop outside an apartment building with broken stained-glass windows on Elliott Avenue, a group of teen-agers known as the Elliott Troopers said they were just a bunch of guys who hung out together and got into fights with "serious gangs." These fights, they said, are steadily becoming more dangerous.
"It went from punches to razors, bats and bottles and now to guns," said Renaldo Collazo, 17, who was covered in scabs and scars that he said were the result of fights with the Lawrence Street Posse. He had 13 stitches in his head removed earlier last week after the latest run-in, he said.
His friend Damien Frank, 17, walked up then and joined in. "The last time they came over here they were wearing ski masks," he said, shaking his head at the terrorist garb favored by their rivals and lamenting the passing of the old-fashioned fistfight. "Not one of them got no knuckle game," he said derisively.
"Now it ain't nothing about fighting with their hands," said Anthony Feliciano, 17, whose face bears several prominent souvenirs of gang fights.
 
Seemingly Inescapable
 All three friends said their families had moved to Westchester from Brooklyn or the Bronx to get away from such urban problems.
But while gang violence seems inescapable, Mr. Frank said: "It's no Bloods and Crips where we're shooting at each other."
"It's just if we see each other there's going to be a little confrontation," he said, turning to his buddies and smiling. ("You like that? Con-fron-ta-tion.") "Even the little kids are fighting now."
 
From Gang to College
 On the other side of town, Sam Annabi, 19, a leader of the Arabian Knights Posse, shooed his mother back into the apartment building their family owns before speaking about his gang. When he re-emerged, he was wearing a black beret.
"Take the hat off, Sam," she called out after him, and he started to laugh in spite of himself, all the while insisting that his group's run-ins with the rival Hell Kitchen Boys, a white gang with no New York City connections, are deadly serious.
"There are fights every day," he said, bragging that he could not even go for a haircut without a bodyguard. "Just as much as they want me, we want them. They try to get my boys. It's like a routine."
Mr. Annabi, who said he planned to take a college entrance exam to attend Mercy College the next day, said guns were part of that routine, but acknowledged grudgingly: "Sometimes you miss on purpose. Sometimes you just want to scare them."
He said he had never actually shot anyone.
As Officers Davis and Mendez drove away in their unmarked black Chevy, which every school kid seemed to recognize, they said they have reason to hope that Mr. Annabi will find his way out of trouble when college starts.
But sometimes it's hard to tell the difference between the tough guys and the guys who just want to look tough, they said. And when young people commit crimes to prove themselves, the distinction hardly matters.
Roberto Rodriguez, 17, who was arrested in the death of 18-year-old Ticard Miller in a drive-by shooting on June 8, was also "a kid we'd been working with for the last couple of years," Mr. Mendez said wearily.
"I did not think he was going to be the one to get involved with this kind of thing," he said. "You never know."

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Exxon Posts A 33% Gain In Earnings

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation reported a 33 percent gain in second-quarter profits yesterday, attributing the sharp increase primarily to cost-cutting, increased demand for gasoline in Europe and lower crude oil prices.
The nation's largest oil company, based in Irving, Tex., reported a net income rise to $1.24 billion, or 98 cents a share, from $930 million, or 73 cents a share, last year. Revenues rose slightly, to $27.9 billion from $27.8 billion. 
 Despite the gains, however, earnings fell short of some analysts' expectations for the quarter, said John D. Hervey, an analyst with DLJ Securities.
Mr. Hervey said that after the quarter's $210 million in tax credits and asset sales -- up from $24 million last year -- were deducted, the earnings fell to 82 cents a share, 6 cents less than some analysts had forecast.
 
Shares Gain $1
 Still, Exxon's shares gained $1 yesterday, closing at $65.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company's American refining and marketing division posted a big increase, to $134 million from $70 million, partly because crude oil prices have dropped an average $1.97 a barrel from $20.36 last year. International refining and marketing increased to $610 million from $592 million.
"I think its a good quarter; compared to the historical range, the earnings are strong," Mr. Hervey said. "But they were negatively impacted by lower natural gas sales in Europe. Still, to be able to chart earnings against the backdrop of lower oil prices is impressive."
Mr. Hervey said Europe's recession appeared to be the cause for the less-than-expected demand for natural gas in Europe and that Exxon's operational and geographic breadth, usually an advantage, worked against it this quarter.
Lee R. Raymond, Exxon's chairman, said cost-cutting accounted for more than $200 million of the earnings. Mr. Hervey agreed that aggressive cost-cutting programs would continue to help earnings.
The company's exploration and production division, which underwent cutbacks during the quarter in the United States, posted a 9 percent earnings increase to $761 million from $698 million.
"They're painful but there have been head count reductions," Mr. Hervey said. "In general the company is making some nice moves cost-cutting-wise, and it is likely to do better in the next 12 to 18 months than the environment suggests."
Chemical operations posted a decline both in the United States and abroad at $86 million from $119 million.

HEADLINE: Ferry Promises Relief for Rockland's Weary Commuters

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

DATELINE: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 20

 BODY:
Laura McGovern's commute from her home in Rockland County to her office in Manhattan seems like it would require the conditioning of a triathlete.
To get to her job at the Social Register on Park Avenue, Ms. McGovern must drive from her family's New City home to the train station in Nanuet, board an N.J. Transit train to Hoboken, take a PATH train from Hoboken to 23d Street and then walk six blocks. Her round-trip commuting time: about three and a half hours. 
 But relief may be on the horizon -- in the form of a high-speed ferry that would whisk Ms. McGovern and hundreds of others to Manhattan along the Hudson River.
As early as next year, according to preliminary state plans, a ferry able to carry up to 500 people may originate in Rockland County -- either in Haverstraw or nearby Nyack -- and make a stop in Yonkers before traveling to midtown and lower Manhattan. Early estimates put the travel time at about 70 minutes each way.
The project might include another ferry linking Haverstraw or Nyack, on the west bank of the Hudson, to Tarrytown, on the eastern side, where commuters could board a Metro-North train to Grand Central Terminal, officials of the New York State Thruway Authority said.
 
Serenity vs. Snarls
 The proposed ferry service would provide a much-needed mass-transit alternative for some of the estimated 17,300 people who travel from Rockland to New York City each weekday and who have fewer commuting options than residents of the neighboring counties of Westchester and Bergen. It would also help to alleviate the snarl of rush-hour traffic on the Tappan Zee Bridge, which connects Rockland to Westchester, transportation officials said.
And -- last but certainly not least -- there is the potential serenity of commuting by ferry.
"It would cut out a lot of stopping-and-going, stopping-and-going," said Ms. McGovern, 23, who said she "definitely" would use the service. "Going on a boat would be a lot nicer. And a little unique."
Although plans are tentative, the project took a major step forward this month when the State Legislature approved a measure that would allow the Thruway Authority, which operates the Tappan Zee Bridge, to develop the service and to hire a private operator to run it. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who formed a High Speed Ferry Task Force two years ago to encourage such projects, is expected to sign the bill soon.
Other private ferry services, whose routes are mostly between New Jersey and Manhattan, are already realizing steady increases in passengers. The average number of riders who took private ferries to and from Manhattan on a weekday rose to 21,170 last month, compared with 1986, when ferries carried fewer than 1,000 passengers a day, according to the New York City Department of Transportation.
State and city officials have also proposed extending ferry service elsewhere in the New York metropolitan region, with new routes planned to Manhattan from Oyster Bay, L.I.; Rye, N.Y., and Hunters Point in Queens.
Although ferries once crisscrossed the Hudson between Rockland and Westchester, the boats lost their allure after the Tappan Zee Bridge opened in 1958. There is now no ferry service in either county. But with advances in technology -- new boats can reach speeds of more than 30 miles an hour -- and a more concerted public emphasis on reducing auto emissions, the ferry has made a comeback.
Peter Tufo, the chairman and chief executive of the Thruway Authority, said that the agency had yet to decide where to base the Rockland ferry, but that Haverstraw and Nyack would be strong contenders.
Haverstraw, a hilly residential town of 35,000 people that is about 28 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, is aggressively lobbying the state to base the ferry service on its waterfront. Town officials, who recently secured a Federal grant of $1.6 million for the project, said they were ready to buy an undeveloped tract that they believe would be an ideal site for a terminal and dock.
The town supervisor, Philip J. Rotella, said the town stood to gain financially from a municipal parking lot that would be built on the site and from the increase in commuter traffic through the town.
But in Nyack -- a tiny enclave of restaurants, antique shops and boutiques that lies between Haverstraw and the Tappan Zee -- there is less enthusiasm for the ferry. While Mayor Robert Capone of Nyack said he believes the ferry would aid merchants by bringing in a steady stream of tourists on weekends, other village officials said they worried that the caravan of cars driven by weekday commuters might detract from Nyack's quaintness.
"I would be opposed to the kind of use that consumes large amounts of the waterfront and gives us minimal economic return," said Kieran Quinn, a village trustee and former mayor.
 
Risky Ventures
 Besides plotting a route for the ferry and determining the number of trips per day, the Thruway Authority must decide who will build and pay for the new docks and terminals, which private operator will run the service, how much a trip will cost passengers and whether the state will provide a subsidy. Without public subsidies, ferries have proven risky ventures, and a handful in the region have failed since 1990.
To insure the ferry's success, Mr. Tufo said, the authority is considering a stop in Yonkers for Westchester commuters. Mr. Tufo estimated that 1,000 to 2,000 passengers would ride the ferry daily if Yonkers were included, compared with 500 to 700 a day without. Robert Weber, a spokesman for Mayor Terence Zaleski of Yonkers, said the city would welcome the ferry service.
Asked the likelihood of the Rockland-Westchester ferry becoming a reality, Mr. Tufo said, "I think it's better than 50-50."

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
MOBIL CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $579 million, because of higher natural gas prices, strength in its Far East markets and gains in tax-related benefits.
Allen E. Murray, Mobil's chairman, said the company was able to overcome low oil prices and recessions in industrialized markets through higher natural gas prices, $41 million in companywide restructuring efforts and an increase in worldwide production, especially in Nigeria, California and the North Sea. 
 Mobil, the second-largest American oil company, reported earnings of $475 million from its exploration and production division, $154 million higher than for second quarter a year earlier. The company said it had reduced operational costs in the division by 10 percent.
Bolstered by strong performances in Australia, Singapore and Japan, international operating earnings were $183 million, $113 million higher than last year, making up for weak earnings in Europe.
Chemical earnings declined, to $13 million, from $18 million last year, thecompany reported, as a result of industry oversupply and European economies still mired in recession.

HEADLINE: Robert M. Kossick, Chief Executive, 53, At New Jersey Bank

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Robert M. Kossick, chairman and chief executive officer of the National Community Bank of New Jersey, died on Tuesday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 53 years old and also had a home in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.
The cause was a heart attack, the bank's announcement said. 
 A native of New Brunswick, N.J., Mr. Kossick was an industrial-engineering graduate of the Georgia Institute of Technology and earned a master's degree in economics at St. Mary's University in San Antonio. After two years of service in the Air Force there, he started out as a systems engineer with the E.I. DuPont Company in Parkersburg, W. Va.
His banking career began in 1968 with Citicorp in New York. In the next seven years he worked in domestic and overseas departments with increasing responsibilities. His final position was in London as senior operating officer of the Citibank UK Retail Bank.
He then became executive vice president of the Bank of the Southwest in Houston and, in 1979, chairman and chief executive of Empire National Bank in New City, N.Y. The following year he joined National Community Bank as president and chief executive at its headquarters in West Paterson. He traded the presidency for the chairmanship five years ago.
During his tenure, the bank quadrupled its assets to $4.2 billion and grew from 49 to 117 branches, with nearly 2,900 employees statewide. Most recently, he negotiated the bank's pending merger with the Bank of New York.
He was a sought-after speaker for free enterprise. James Peters, the bank's current president, said with his death the "industry lost one of its most successful and colorful leaders."
Mr. Kossick is survived by his wife, the former Sherry Lynne Stamey, of Houston; two sons, Robert and Mark; and two daughters, Kristen and Alicia.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
The Price of Lumber Soars As Inventories Disappear

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices leaped yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on signs that the construction industry had worked through a big supply inventory that had weighed on prices since last spring.
Spruce two-by-fours for September delivery surged the permitted daily limit of $10, to $278.90 per 1,000 board feet, the highest settlement of a near-term contract since June 15. 
 Lumber futures fell sharply in the second quarter after hitting a record high of $493.50 on March 16 amid panic buying induced by logging restrictions and hopes of an economic recovery.
The expected construction boom never arrived. Lumber stockpiled by mills and distributors became a drag on the market and sent futures prices down to $223 per 1,000 board feet by June 30.
Prices are now rebounding as the huge inventories disappear.
"I think most of them are gone," said Bud Merrill, lumber analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in Eugene, Ore.
Flooding in the Midwest, which has disrupted normal transportation patterns, is also helping to lift prices, according to Mike Young, a lumber broker at the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. He said rail detours had made it difficult for Midwestern users to obtain Northwest lumber, so prices have climbed.
Mr. Merrill said demand for lumber to repair flood-damaged buildings could push up prices in the third quarter.
On other commodity markets, most cattle futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the Agriculture Department's biannual cattle inventory report, which was released after the close of trading. The report showed a 1 percent rise in the nation's cattle herd, to 110.1 million head, from July of last year to the same date this year. The herd size was near trade expectations.
August live cattle rose 0.28 cent, to 73.75 cents a pound; August feeder cattle were unchanged at 86.25 cents a pound; July hogs fell 0.07 cent, to 47.45 cents a pound; July frozen pork bellies surged 1.95 cents, to 42.50 cents a pound.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for September delivery rose 12 cents, to $17.75 a barrel; August heating oil rose 0.47 cent, to 50.19 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline rose 0.32 cent, to 52.05 cents a gallon; August natural gas rose 2.5 cents, to $2.121 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: The Dicey Game of Commodities Trading

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The floods in the Midwest have devastated many farmers and sent the prices of some agricultural products soaring.
On the commodities exchanges, where contracts for future delivery of these products are traded, business is brisk. Soybean prices alone set a four-year high on Monday. 
 Such spikes naturally attract the attention of investors. But the futures market, which extends well beyond crops and livestock into metals, currencies and oil and gas, is not for the faint of heart.
Thomas A. Russo, a managing director of Lehman Brothers and a commodities industry veteran, said, "I don't think you should be involved in the futures market unless you are willing to be a speculator."
Each week, individuals and corporations bet billions of dollars in the commodities markets on whether prices will rise or fall. Their tools are futures contracts: financial instruments that call for the future purchase or sale of a commodity at a price set when the contract is made.
Investors who buy contracts for delivery in several months know that supply and demand will likely change, causing the price to fluctuate. The investors, who have no intention of actually taking delivery of the commodity, plan to sell the contract before the delivery date. Their gain or loss will be determined by the contract's price at the time of sale.
Although small investors continue to buy futures in huge quantities, the odds against success for the Little Guy are about 10 to 1, according to the North American Securities Administrators Association and the Council of Better Business Bureaus.
"The only basis for participation is knowledge of the individual contract you wish to trade and an understanding of how the market works," said Hal T. Hansen, president of Cargill Investor Services. The market carries the potential for high returns, but also high risk, he warned.
This risk stems from volatility and a low initial margin, or the portion of a contract's price that an investor must put down as a good faith deposit. Commodity prices are volatile because they respond to many disparate factors -- inflation, politics and weather, to name a few. Crop prices for example, are affected not only by the floods, but also by the drought in the Southeast, conditions in other countries and Government policies.
Furthermore, most trades are based on a relatively small initial investment. The commodities exchanges set initial margins for their futures contracts, and brokers on these exchanges establish margins for their customers using these figures as a floor.
While investors buying stocks on margin typically must put 50 percent down, the initial margin for futures ranges from less than 5 percent to about 20 percent. Thus a small movement in a commodity's price could bring an investor a large return or wipe out his initial investment and require additional payments.
"You get more leverage with futures for the money you put down," said Morton Lane, president of Lind-Waldock & Company, a discount commodities brokerage firm. "But you have to do this with a prudent focus."
Investors are drawn to the markets for several reasons. Dr. Francis Powers, a radiation oncologist in Williamsport, Pa., recently explained why he delved into futures.
"I was looking for another way to invest profitably, as I felt that the stock market, being at the level that it is at, sooner or later is going to roll over," Dr. Powers said. "Now I trade about 13 different things, like the S.& P. stock index, the dollar index, soybeans and coffee."
The potential for huge gains certainly tugs at adventurous souls. Take an investor who bought a gold contract on May 18 for August delivery of 100 ounces at $377.90 an ounce. By holding through a monthlong downturn and waiting to sell until the price was $392.90 an ounce on July 16, he made a handsome profit.
The contract he bought for $37,790 sold for $39,290. Because the investor had to put down only 3.7 percent of the contract price, he doubled his $1,450 investment in two months.
Of course, if the price had continued to decline, his investment would have been completely wiped out -- and then some. "You can lose more than the money you put up, should the market go down greater than your earnest money," Mr. Russo of Lehman Brothers warned.
Experts advise individuals not to open accounts without substantial funds. "Some firms have minimum limits of $25,000, but I would suggest something closer to the $100,000 mark," said Leo Melamed, chairman of the Dellsher Investment Company and a former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
For those with less money to invest, professional management is available through commodity pools or funds. Organized as limited partnerships, these pools accept investments as small as $5,000 -- and even $2,000 for retirement accounts. They offer diversification and the ability to withstand short-term downswings.
"They are usually structured so that you can get monthly redemptions," said Robert G. Easton, chairman of the Managed Futures Association. "And there is typically a loss point, around 50 percent, when the fund will be dissolved and the balance returned to investors."
However you enter the fast-paced world of futures, it is usually advisable to commit no more than 5 to 10 percent of your investible assets. Establish a trading plan -- setting out how long you will tie up funds and how much you are willing to lose -- that you follow in both good times and bad.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
For New Entries, Europe Is Popular

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
New funds that invest in Europe are popping up everywhere. Many analysts say that the economic cycle in Europe is a few years behind the United States and that Europe is on the edge of a big bull market.
The Tweedy, Browne Company, an investment firm begun in 1920, specializes in classic value stock picking, or buying shares at a significant discount to what investors believe the companies are actually worth. Its first foray into mutual funds is a global stock fund, now totally invested outside the United States, mainly in Europe. It concentrates on companies with small and medium capitalization, and plans to hedge all currency risks. 
 The Skyline Europe Portfolio invests solely in Europe by policy, making it a purer play on the region. Skyline concentrates on shares of companies that have large capitalizations. The fund, which is managed out of London by Gordon House Securities Ltd., sometimes hedges currency risks.
Concerned about rising interest rates, some bond fund sponsors are slashing maturities. Share prices of funds with shorter terms will decline less if interest rates rise, as many expect late this year. Twentieth Century is waiving expenses on its new Tax-Exempt Short-Term Bond Fund through 1993. Afterward, annual expenses will equal 0.6 percent. The fund yields 3.03 percent, or 4.21 percent for investors in the 28 percent Federal tax bracket, 4.39 percent for those in the top bracket.

HEADLINE: Europe's Social Dumping

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany

 BODY:
Everybody agrees on the principle that economic growth winds up to the benefit of all, and that zero-sum games of beggar-thy-neighbor are an illusion. Eventually, all lose. But when times are hard, everybody looks to the home front and the right-now -- leave principle to the long term. What they remember about John Maynard Keynes is that he said, "In the long term, we are all dead."
The most painful new dilemma as the world feels the impact of another industrial revolution, as profound and disruptive as the 19th century's, is that growth no longer equals jobs. The demands of expansion through free trade -- productivity, competitiveness, cost-cutting -- work to reduce jobs, substituting technology or much cheaper labor somewhere else.
This is more evident in Europe than in the U.S., with unemployment in the Community at 11 percent and getting worse, although the same factors are at work in America. 
 Organized labor, with more vested interest in protecting members than in creating new jobs, is distressed by the phenomenon of "social dumping," the phrase of the day. It refers to a demand for protection not only against excess goods unloaded in a foreign market but also against genuine competition based on low wages and low or no outlays for workers' social benefits.
These were the themes of a meeting here on "America and Europe -- Old Relations, New Challenges," organized by the Hans Boeckler Foundation, which is backed by the German Federation of Trade Unions.
There was more concern about taking away too much of existing buffers than that the leaders, talking in Tokyo at the same time, would fail to cooperate in removing them. There was more concern about lack of economic stimulus than about inflation and the way it distorts and skews trade. The facts of economic interdependence weren't denied, but the questions are becoming more insistent on whether it's such a good thing or ought to be resisted.
It took Alicia Enders, representing GATT headquarters in Geneva, to put up some hard figures showing advantages to working people. U.S. consumers pay $100,000 for each $25,000 job protected against imports in the textile industry, she said. Export-related jobs provide 20 percent higher wages in services and 17 percent higher in manufacturing than for strictly domestic output.
The West European union people, trying to be supportive and hospitable to their colleagues from Eastern Europe, nonetheless worry that their welfare states will be eroded away as a consequence of concessions that desperate Eastern workers are prepared to grant management. There are quarrels in the E.C. about "dislocation" when factories move to another Community state to escape labor charges while saving market access.
The arguments are no longer about the fight between capital and labor. The leader of Poland's Solidarity union, pleading that support for infra-structure investment in the East would help Western workers, too, said, "Without capital, there is no place for labor."
But the old assumptions about labor's role in the economy have been overtaken by technology and the globalization of finance. This is the strain underneath the Tokyo disputes, the strain between the push for greater economic cooperation to promote growth by taking in each other's washing and the pull to hunker down and save what there is.
To ease it (it won't soon be resolved) requires new ideas in the industrial countries about what is a job and what should be rewarded. The economic meaning of services has to be expanded to enlarge the contributions of education, the arts, social usefulness. Unions, as they have evolved, aren't well equipped for this, but they can and should be spurred to seek ways to contribute to creation of new jobs to replace those that are migrating.
Tokyo was a reprieve in the battle between contracting political nationalisms, arising from commerce but growing more dangerously emotional in many countries, and irresistible economic aggressiveness. It won't last. If there isn't another real spurt forward in trade, on terms widely perceived as mutually beneficial, the international economic system will unravel.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Philippines Acts to Protect Environment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 13 Hinunangan Journal inaccurately presents images of the Philippines as a metaphor for the national situation. 
 In the last seven years poverty in the Philippines has fallen from 65 percent to 40 percent. Government programs, supported by the private sector, aim at reducing it to 30 percent toward the end of the decade.
The Government of the Philippines has moved aggressively to address environmental degradation. Reforms include the banning of logging in old-growth forests; establishment of forestry programs where communities take the lead in managing resources, and massive outlays for environmental protection, despite limited finances. Manila has worked out innovative debt-for-nature swaps with multilateral institutions to support such programs.
With a stabilized political climate, economic reforms have occurred at a dramatic pace. Structural changes have resulted in the resumption of economic growth, improved foreign debt ratios, a sixfold increase in international reserves and the reduction of inflation from 18.5 percent in 1991 to a manageable 6.7 percent this year.
These have a direct impact on the purchasing power and well-being of the man and woman in the street and contribute to an improved employment picture as well.
The World Bank declared last April that "the Philippines now faces its best prospect for sustained development in almost two decades." Citicorp in its emerging markets research echoes the sentiment. One manifestation: the Manila stock market has been named one of the best performing in the world, posting 110 percent returns.
 
RAUL CH. RABE
Ambassador of the Philippines
Washington, July 14, 1993

And Bear In Mind
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ALMOST PERFECT, by Alice Adams. (Knopf, $23.) Social and business pressures drive emotions in this painful, funny novel about a young woman on the rise who loves a crazy man.
ANGELS & INSECTS: Two Novellas, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $21.) Two long novellas, and very clever ones, in which insect life is an analogue of Victorian society and literary immortality is compared to the real thing.
CRUELTY AND SILENCE: War, Tyranny, Uprising, and the Arab World, by Kanan Makiya. (Norton, $22.95.) The cruelty is that of the Saddam Hussein regime in the author's native Iraq; the silence, that of the Arab intellectuals who condone or assist it.
CUERVO TALES, by Robert Roper. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) Ten interlinked stories that follow a burned-out survivor of the luminous, excessive 1960's into the downer decades that followed.
DENYING THE HOLOCAUST: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, by Deborah E. Lipstadt. (Free Press, $22.95.) A historian untangles the perverse and ingenious arguments of those who say there was no Holocaust.
DRUMS ALONG THE CONGO: On the Trail of Mokele-Mbembe, the Last Living Dinosaur, by Rory Nugent. (Houghton Mifflin, cloth, $21.95; paper, $10.95.) And was it found? Well, something was, and the trip was loads of fun.
GAME OVER: How Nintendo Zapped an American Industry, Captured Your Dollars, and Enslaved Your Children, by David Sheff. (Random House, $25.) A nuts-and-bolts history of the world-bestriding Japanese video game colossus.
IF IT BE NOT I: Collected Poems, 1959-1982, by Mona Van Duyn (Knopf, $25), and FIREFALL: Poems, by Mona Van Duyn (Knopf, $20). The first seven volumes of capacious, particular poetry by a vigorous Midwesterner, collected as one and published simultaneously with her eighth.
PICASSO AND DORA: A Personal Memoir, by James Lord. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) Life at the heart of the post-1945 artistic enterprise: what a genius, his mistress and a shrewd memoirist did and said to and about one another.
SELECTED POETRY, by John Hollander (Knopf, $27.50), and TESSERAE: And Other Poems, by John Hollander (Knopf, $20). A selection from 14 earlier books of poetry by a subtle, learned, major American master; published simultaneously with his strong-as-ever new book.
SEPARATE ROOMS, by Pier Vittorio Tondelli. (Serpent's Tail, paper, $14.99.) An Italian novel of imperfect love and urgent grief, by a young writer who died of AIDS in 1991.
TSVETAEVA, by Viktoria Schweitzer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) The life and apocalyptic times (1892-1941) of a great Russian poet, a woman whom no revolution could contain.
UNITED STATES: Essays 1952-1992, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $37.50.) In 40 years of essays and articles, the author expounds on sex, politics, literature, himself and other phenomena.

HEADLINE: The Pleasure of Their Companies

BYLINE: By Judith H. Dobrzynski; Judith H. Dobrzynski is a senior editor at Business Week magazine.

 BODY:

THE AMERICAN EAGLE
The Ascent of Bob Crandall
and American Airlines.
By Dan Reed.
Illustrated. 302 pp. New York:
A Thomas Dunne Book/St. Martin's Press. $23.95.
 
KING ICAHN
The Biography of a Renegade Capitalist.
By Mark Stevens.
Research by Carol Bloom Stevens.
326 pp. New York: Dutton. $23.
 
DANGEROUS DREAMERS
The Financial Innovators From
Charles Merrill to Michael Milken.
By Robert Sobel.
260 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $27.95.
 
CONTROL YOUR DESTINY OR SOMEONE ELSE WILL
How Jack Welch Is Making General Electric the World's Most Competitive Corporation.
By Noel M. Tichy and Stratford Sherman.
384 pp. New York: Currency/Doubleday. $24. 
 FOR all the ink spilled chronicling the corporate restructurings, takeovers, junk bonds, savings-and-loan woes and the other excesses that landed business stories on the nation's front pages during the past decade, the general reader knows far too little about the way business really works or about the (mostly) men who hold so much sway over the American economy. Powerful executives seem to inhabit a different world. They live in chic enclaves, travel in corporate jets, hobnob mainly with peers and spend their days and nights making big decisions.
Four new books examine four symbols of the 1980's. Two deal with esteemed corporate chieftains -- Robert L. Crandall, the head of American Airlines, and John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company. And two depict men regarded as rogues -- Michael R. Milken, junk bond king of the defunct investment banking firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, and Carl C. Icahn, a raider who made a killing attacking the likes of Chesebrough Pond's, Phillips Petroleum, Texaco, USX and T.W.A.
Although the four share some traits -- smarts, drive, iconoclasm -- they differ greatly in style and substance, as does the quality of the portraits. Mr. Welch comes off best: as "Control Your Destiny or Someone Else Will" tells it, he's a complicated character who learns and grows as he tries to transform a huge bureaucratic company into a world-class competitor. In "Dangerous Dreamers," Mr. Milken seems to be a charming visionary whose financial insights did more good than harm. He is neither the villain you'd expect, considering his imprisonment for securities crimes, nor (as some have said) the most important financier of the 20th century. As for "King Icahn," its protagonist comes across as the least likable of the four -- a wily, difficult, rude man, single-minded in his pursuit of the buck. And in "The American Eagle," Mr. Crandall is quick, earthy and absolutely dedicated to propelling American to the top of the airline heap.
Of the four portraits, "The American Eagle," by Dan Reed, a reporter who covers the airline industry for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, is the weakest. Using an aw-shucks style, Mr. Reed has written a formulaic book with too many digressions that take the reader nowhere. His one-sided, hagiographic account rarely goes beyond corporate sources. As Mr. Reed recounts how Mr. Crandall and his management team invented frequent-flyer programs, the hub-and-spoke route system, two-tier wages and various discount fare schemes and financing mechanisms, he provides far too little information on what American's rivals are doing and why the entire airline industry flew into turbulence. Mr. Crandall, a chain-smoking jogger whose salty outspokenness has plunged him into trouble more than once, deserves better. For all his faults, Mr. Crandall is considered in the business world to be a thoughtful industry leader, always trying something to gain a competitive edge. There must be stories that would make that Bob Crandall come alive.
On that score, Mark Stevens, author of "The Big Eight" and other books on business and finance, is far more successful. His "King Icahn" is chockablock with anecdotes that take his subject from humble beginnings in Queens, the son of a would-be opera singer who thought there was "something wrong about great wealth," to multimillionaire status, with homes on Park Avenue, in the Hamptons and in baronial Bedford, N.Y.
To please his mother, Mr. Icahn started out in medical school. But as Mr. Stevens relates Mr. Icahn's escapades since his first raids from 1978 through today, readers can't help being grateful that early on he recognized his unsuitability for the healing profession. Mr. Icahn is "a bull, snorting and pacing," in the description of a longtime assistant, "always looking for a way to get through that fence to strike a deal." Mr. Stevens shows how the man chooses his corporate targets, how he descends on management, how he'll do anything legal to get more. Consider his negotiating tactics. On the appointed day, we're told, Mr. Icahn sleeps late, catches a shower and a nap late in the day, then arrives hours after an evening session was scheduled to start -- all to outwit tired opponents as he drags out talks into the next morning. Yet for all his wealth, Mr. Icahn remains cheap -- refusing, according to a neighbor's account, to pay an extra $300 for power windows in his wife's Jeep.
Mr. Stevens has written a well-researched history of one man and his times. There's just one big problem. Who wants to know this much about Carl Icahn? Perhaps that's why Mr. Stevens strains to declare him the most important, the brightest, the very best 80's raider. Mr. Icahn's troubles with T.W.A., which he tried and failed to manage, say otherwise.
With "Dangerous Dreamers," Robert Sobel, a professor of business history at Hofstra University and the author of many books on business, treads richer territory. Although the book is billed as a history of financial innovators, the focus is on Mr. Milken, and others are brought in to put him in perspective. Walking readers down both the sunny and the shady sides of Wall Street, Mr. Sobel explains how changes in stock ownership patterns, tax laws, Federal regulation and deregulation, 1960's-style conglomeration, interest rate fluctuations, the death of traditional company-banker relationships and a host of other trends led to the financial shenanigans of the 80's.
Mr. Milken gets off lightly. As Mr. Sobel recites his background, his maniacal work habits, his intellectual breakthroughs, he seems fond of the junk bond maven. He notes, too, that Mr. Milken warned that companies were taking on too much debt as early as 1986.
In a few places, Mr. Sobel provides facts that should dispel popular misconceptions -- that there's something innately evil about junk bonds, for example, or that hostile lev eraged buyouts were the rule of the 80's. "Only 1 percent of all LBO's began and ended in an unfriendly fashion," he writes. And even at the height of the hostile takeover movement, only about 15 percent of junk bonds were issued to finance them.
Mr. Sobel has written an evenhanded recap of an era. But that's its weakness: "Dangerous Dreamers" is rather a bland synthesis of other people's reporting and research. Readers get context, not revelation.
NOEL M. TICHY, a professor at the University of Michigan School of Business and a consultant to General Electric since 1982, and Stratford Sherman, a reporter and member of Fortune magazine's board of editors who has written often about G.E., aspire to an entirely different goal. "Control Your Destiny or Someone Else Will" is a how-to book, designed to explain John Welch's management techniques and to inspire other big, stodgy American corporate leaders to follow his lead. Although the authors give readers the requisite biographical information, they are really more interested in telling stories that illustrate Mr. Welch's management ideas. He demands, for example, that each of G.E.'s businesses be No. 1 or No. 2 in market share. He talks about the need to create a "bounda ryless organization" that encourages every employee to be flexible, speedy and responsible -- and to get the job done without regard to antiquated organizational rules.
Still, Mr. Welch has his own rules, his own "unusual management ideas," and his maxims, such as a call for managers to be "hardheaded but soft-hearted." Add them all up and readers get a motivational text that teaches more about well-run organizations of the future than about Mr. Welch. Anyone familiar with management books knows much of this turf, as even Mr. Tichy, who is responsible for the book's research, admits.
That, in fact, is the disappointment in all four books. They don't tell much that readers of the business pages don't already know and do tell much that they don't want to. And they won't hold the attention of the general reader who might like -- and benefit from -- a guided tour of the business world.

HEADLINE: How We Live Now

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe's most recent book is "The Human Difference: Animals, Computers, and the Necessity of Social Science."

 BODY:

SYSTEMS OF SURVIVAL
A Dialogue on the Moral Foundations
of Commerce and Politics.
By Jane Jacobs.
236 pp. New York:
Random House. $22. 
 JANE JACOBS wrote a first book so stupendously good that a later slide downhill was all but inevitable. It has not been a dramatic slide since "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" (1961); each of her four subsequent books is intelligent, learned and original. But none has been capable, as her initial venture was, of making the everyday world seem both magical and ordered.
Ms. Jacobs's voice, in "Death and Life," spoke in the specifics of time (the present) and place (Greenwich Village). Unlike city planners, she had no utopia to impose on ordinary people. In contrast to social scientists, she rejected jargon and high theory. All you needed, she said, were eyes, a love of humanity and a feel for the real world. With them, cities, and therefore people, came alive; without them, all was sterile.
In later years, Ms. Jacobs seemed to lose that grounding. Time and space came unhinged as she moved (physically) to Toronto and (intellectually) to universals about human behavior. Mimicking the planners she once condemned, she increasingly sought to tie everything together in a convincing system that would overpower by the beauty of its design. And aping the social scientists against whose work hers once sparkled, she would do this through theory; her insights would come from books she read, not from the lives she so assiduously watched.
The latest effort is "Systems of Survival." Cast in the form of a Platonic dialogue, the book argues that there are two ways in which people organize their material world. One is through trade, which generates a moral syndrome in which individuals avoid force, act voluntarily, compete and strive for efficiency. The other she calls the guardian syndrome, which stresses loyalty, obedience, vengeance, ostentation, honor and other ways of maintaining status and protecting tradition.
Although not especially original -- Max Weber, Joseph Schumpeter, Charles Lindblom and Albert Hirschman all made similar points about states and markets -- Ms. Jacobs, with her unorthodox intelligence, often produces new insights. We learn that the military taboo against trading may have originated as a way of preventing treachery, that ecologists often see the world as military men do and that "the history of economic development is the history of men taking up women's work." Ms. Jacobs is also particularly good at untangling how commercial and guardian values are combined in hybrids like the Mafia, the military-industrial complex, agriculture, Communism and modern Japan.
But far too much of "Systems of Survival" is devoted not to an explanation of morality but to a defense of the structure used to explain it. Ms. Jacobs argues that there are no more than two moral systems, a point that is either empirically false or true only by definition. (Ethnic solidarity, altruism and paternalism are all premised on something other than trading or guardianship; Ms. Jacobs engages in mind-boggling, and ultimately pointless, thought experiments to bring such anomalies within her dichotomy.) She is at pains to insist that the two syndromes have their own moral logic, over and above the morality of the individuals whose lives are governed by them. And, most frustrating of all, she cannot make up her mind whether practices that mix elements from each syndrome are examples of monstrous corruption or necessary flexibility.
Because "Systems of Survival" seeks to justify an intellectual construct rather than to explain the behavior of real people, the stilted dialogue lacks two essential qualities associated with "The Death and Life of Great American Cities": empathy and a democratic sensibility. For reasons never fully explained, Ms. Jacobs confines herself to material realities in this book, thereby excluding love, religion, identity, rage, sacrifice and ritual. Although her characters eat -- and although two of them almost announce their engagement -- they are as wooden as the people whose history is being recounted through their dialogue.
Moreover, Ms. Jacobs's failure to treat human beings as creatures with emotions and feelings is a considered decision. "I'm sick of cant about the family being the bedrock of society," one of her characters exclaims, gratuitously, at the end of the book. "Families are fragments of their societies. The bedrocks are the ways people get their livings, and the institutions and organizations formed to that end." You get the people you imagine. If you want people trying to make moral sense out of the intimate worlds around them, try Jane Austen, not Jane Jacobs.
"Systems of Survival" is also an undemocratic book (despite Ms. Jacobs's defense of the democratization of credit). For what is modern democracy but a system that is rooted in neither trade nor protection? Democracy relies on constitutions, political parties, pluralism, individual rights and community norms. If these are used for purposes of self-interested commerce, they cannot function properly. But if they are used without competition and participation, for purposes of guardianship, they cannot be democratic. What Ms. Jacobs calls "systemic moral corruption" makes it possible for strangers to live together under conditions approximating self-rule.
Real people do not live ethical lives by following the precepts of intellectual syndromes. Their worlds are built from experience up, not from abstractions down. The younger Jane Jacobs drove this point home. The more mature one seems to have forgotten it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1083 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Streamlining the Ungainly

BYLINE: By Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
We political reporters saw it coming, the true magnitude of the health-care crisis, the way it could tongue-tie even skilled professionals like ourselves who were accustomed to turning complex issues into simple buzzwords.
It was clear as early as November 1991, when a puzzled Hal Bruno of ABC News was forced to ask the candidates in the middle of a televised debate: "Explain the Enthoven plan." Hearts sank, news disappeared in a great unstoppable wave of health policy, as the candidates rattled on about the Hawaiian approach, the virtues of broad-based community rating, managed care and managed competition (a.k.a. the Enthoven plan, named after Alain Enthoven, of Stanford University, who specializes in the economics of health care), the Canadian and the German system. 
 We were sure a health-care plan known as the German system was unlikely to be a big vote-getter. (The Hawaiian approach sounded infinitely better, particularly in New Hampshire.) But we never dreamed we would be forced to confront the dreaded Enthoven plan two years later and try to turn it into digestible news bites.
Nowadays, the health-care issue can no longer be avoided. Reform is on the move in Washington, and President Clinton's political advisers have spent much of the last few months trying to figure out how to talk about it. The wonks in the Clinton Administration have pushed it in the direction of one of the more complicated theories of health-care reform: managed competition. But the Administration's pragmatic pols are trying to turn this into a populist crusade: Just we farmers and workers and family folks standing shoulder to shoulder with Al Enthoven and the rest of the health-care economists.
One of the first things the Clintonites did was drop the term managed competition -- a distinct turnoff in focus groups. That left them with the task of describing the central structure of managed competition: the huge regional purchasing cooperatives that pool the bargaining power of individuals and small businesses to negotiate for the optimum health plans. Until recently, these entities were known as H.I.P.C.'s (or Hipics) -- for health insurance purchasing cooperatives -- but many Democratic strategists, including James Carville, felt that expression sounded like another exercise in Big Government. As a result, Hipic gave way to the Health Alliance.
Personally, I think this change was a mistake. Hip ic had a pleasant, down-home feel to it, like a chain of discount stores. "I'm gonna run on down to the Hipic, honey, and pick up some forms. You need anything?"
The Health Alliance, on the other hand, has a vaguely Orwellian tone. As in, "Good Morning, Mr. Jones, we're from the Alliance and we'd like to talk to you about how your therapy is going." Doctors are already warning darkly about the dangers of managed care under second-guessing, cost-conscious insurance companies, let alone Health Alliances.
In West Virginia this spring, Hillary Rodham Clinton, chairwoman of the health-care reform task force, took a stab at explaining the Hipic idea without giving it a name. "You'll be part of great big pools to buy insurance," she said, "and you'll get all the breaks and all the discounts the big guys are entitled to." Other times, however, she seems to be following the advice given to Willie Stark in "All the King's Men": "Just tell 'em you're gonna soak the fat boys and forget the rest of the tax stuff."
In fact, she has a wide array of potential fat boys from which to choose: insurance companies, drug manufacturers, hospitals, doctors and a variety of other health-care providers, all of whom are now scrambling in Washington to declare themselves the true friends of reform and the enemies of a flawed health-care delivery system.
Once the debate gets going on Capitol Hill, politicians will have to explain not only managed competition, but also all the rival philosophies of health-care reform. Chief among them is the single-payer system, which is also an unfortunate title. It refers to the fact that there is just one payer -- the Government -- for health care. (The money, of course, comes from taxes.) This is sometimes described as a Canadian-style system, which sounds much more appealing, as though it were the Molson ale of health care.
Still, single payer is part of the language in health politics, as in, "He's a single-payer guy" or, "The single-payer people like this bill," or even, as one single-payer supporter told me not long ago, in high pique, "They're using single-payer rhetoric to sell a managed competition plan." In the health-care debate, those are fighting words.
If the Administration is trying to simplify the language of health care in some areas, it is engaged in some rather artful embellishments in others, like financing. White House officials are more than willing to talk about the sin taxes that will be raised to support health-care reform. Who can argue against taxing sin? But they prefer a gentler term for the levy on employers and employees that would go to the Hipic/Alliances and that is expected to be an important part of the final plan. They are calling the levy a premium.
Why not call it a tax?
"If it doesn't go to the Government, it wouldn't meet one of the key definitions of a tax," Vice President Gore declared on "Meet the Press" this spring. (On the other hand, the element of coercion expected in this levy would meet one of the key definitions of a tax.)
For all the jargon, all sides in this debate will try to hit the basic emotional chords: peace of mind, security, insurance you can never lose. The Clinton forces say they are struggling to keep focused on the big picture, but as was the case on that chilly, ominous night back in New Hampshire when the debate turned to health care, they keep slipping into the abyss of wonkdom. The issue is so big, they say, the biggest domestic issue since Social Security.
Still, in pre-focus-group days, Franklin D. Roosevelt found a way to explain what he was doing.
"Today a hope of many years' standing is in large part fulfilled," he declared when he signed the Social Security Act on Aug. 14, 1935. "We can never insure 100 percent of the population against 100 percent of the hazards and vicissitudes of life, but we have tried to frame a law which will give some measure of protection to the average citizen and to his family against the loss of a job and against poverty-ridden old age."
I could write a lead off that.
