SECTION: Section 2; Page 28; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Walter Cronkite Finds It Hard to Say No

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.

 BODY:
Reassurance has always been Walter Cronkite's stock in trade, the ability to convince viewers that when he is on the air all will turn out well. And, it is in this sense reassuring to hear that the former CBS anchorman hates to see himself on camera. That's what he says. He likes to be in front of the camera, but he does not like looking at the on-screen results.
"I cringe when I see myself," Mr. Cronkite was saying the other day. He was sitting in shorts and a sun-bleached plaid shirt in his vacation house overlooking the bay here. "I don't feel I look that good. I get fat, sloppy. My suits don't fit that well. When I do interviews, my questions don't have the arrowlike quality of a Mike Wallace." 
 And so, Walter Cronkite remains modest, all too approachably human, which is reassuring as well. But that does not stop him from putting his familiar qualities to use from time to time. And lately he has been doing that often enough to seem to be devising a kind of anchorman's rebirth for himself. Mr. Cronkite never completely disappeared from the country's television screens since he stopped doing the "CBS Evening News" 12 years ago. What he did do, however, was a far cry from guiding the nation, live, through its periods of crisis. Every year, instead, he has done things like guide PBS's annual broadcasts of the New Year's concert of the Vienna Philharmonic. Once he even conducted the Hochund Deutchmeister Band in a rendition of "Stars and Stripes Forever."
Mr. Cronkite perhaps faces a dilemma common only to very famous people -- how to stay in the game and remain active even after the glory days are over. At the age of 76, he seems to have hit on a solution, which has been to become busier than ever. And the reason he is in such demand, according to those who are after his services, is that there is nobody else quite so reassuring as Walter Cronkite is, and quite as much of a draw.
Together with Jonathan Ward, one of his producers at CBS, Mr. Cronkite has created his own documentary film company and is producing television specials on some subjects generally deemed too complex for regular network treatment.
Two months ago, the Discovery Channel broadcast "Help Unwanted," a look at the changing face of unemployment in America. This Thursday night, it will show "Where Do We Fight?," which looks at American military policy abroad or, as Mr. Cronkite puts it, "at public opinion and public voices and how we decide where the U.S. should involve its military in the world."
To be sure, these are not the kinds of programs that will set the chattering classes on fire. Indeed, Mr. Cronkite is held in check by what he calls his "golden handcuffs," an agreement with CBS stipulating that he cannot work for a major network. He is therefore pretty much restricted to the smaller audiences of cable and public television.
Last year Mr. Cronkite's voice was heard on a segment of "Murphy Brown." Though he never appeared on the show, some newspapers reported that he was going to be a regular on the program. Mr. Cronkite said that was never anybody's intention.
So, the Walter Cronkite of the old days is not about to reappear in all of his former splendor. Still, the old anchorman has been in
demand. He anchored the Discovery Channel's special broadcast on the Holocaust in April, which coincided with the opening of the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington. He narrated a four-part series on dinosaurs. He was the on-camera announcer for three documentaries shown on PBS, on aging, health insurance and poor children, respectively.
Next month, rather than sail his sloop in the Virgin Islands, he is off to Scandinavia for a documentary series called "The Vikings"; then he heads for Kenya for a British documentary, "The Search for Man," about Richard Leakey and other paleoanthropologists. "We've worked with a lot of movie stars, like James Earl Jones, Meryl Streep and others," said Roger Weisberg, the producer of Mr. Cronkite's PBS documentaries. "Frankly, when we began working with Mr. Cronkite, we not only had the benefit of his experience, but we had an unusual audience draw. Stations in the PBS system were more interested; our ratings improved. He's the best investment we could make in getting publicity for our programs."
Somewhere along the line, we became a country of celebrity rather than authority, and celebrity is by its very nature evanescent. Authority is more durable, and Mr. Cronkite is one of the few people around who has it.
Certainly in his newest productions, the old Walter Cronkite of CBS days remains entirely recognizable. He is a bit grayer now, and his voice has lost just a touch of its gravelly richness, but only a touch.
He does have just a bit of the quality of the aging tenor, still mellifluous but not quite as mellifluous as before. Watching Mr. Cronkite, in all his avuncularity, tell us the way it is on the Discovery Channel is practically Proustian; like tea and Madeleines, it summons up a rich field of associations.
It is not, of course, easy to regain a top spot in one of the slots available for national attention. Watching Mr. Cronkite these days, one also realizes how much television has changed. His new productions do not, for example, have the resonance of his famous old "You Are There" programs. The world belongs to hipper types than Mr. Cronkite, to Larry King and David Letterman, and it is unlikely that he will attract the ever younger flocks who watch television. Instead, he will be the trustworthy, reassuring commentator on the old-fashioned hard stuff, like the Great Books and adventures in science.
Mr. Cronkite's rise to ultimate trustworthiness was smooth and enjoyable and tinged with elements of disappeared worlds. In Kansas City in the early days, he used to do a five-minute program of baseball scores on a tiny 100-watt radio station, clandestinely reading the scores from the Western Union wire at a nearby tobacco shop, memorizing them and then running out to write them down. Then he did reconstructed football games, graduating eventually to live football games.
Many years later he became the anchorman for the network's affiliate in Washington. Over a long career, there has been Walter Cronkite guiding a nation through the Kennedy assassination, the Vietnam War, the moon landings, Watergate and many other events.
Today, one might wonder why Mr. Cronkite works so hard. Friends say that he is basically a veteran reporter who loves to work. He explains: "It's because I can't say 'no.' I've got no facility for negatives. People call about speeches, seminars, documentaries and everything sounds interesting. My wife stands in front of me and mouths 'no,' but it seems so easy a year in advance."
That leads to another question: What, in a country that gobbles fads and personalities of the month, accounts for his considerable staying power, his capacity, even at his age, to outdraw Meryl Streep as the on-camera announcer for serious documentaries?
The answer, in part, probably has to do with that word "serious." There are still a couple of slots available for Mr. Cronkite's kind of gravitas. He can still play that role.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Paul Freireich

 BODY:

A Tuscan Garden
Q. My family would like to see the Garden of Tarot by the artist Niki de Saint Phalle near the village of Capalbio in Tuscany. When is it open? Where can one stay nearby? -- M. C. Belfiglio, New York, N.Y. 
 A. Based on the images pictured on Tarot cards, Ms. de Saint Phalle has created a fantasy world of 20 sculptures. As unpredictable as the Tarot deck used in fortune telling is the serendipitous galaxy of fanciful sculptures, some of which are building-sized. Many of the works are made of iron mesh, sprayed with cement and embellished with a mosaic of Murano glass, mirrors and ceramic tiles, and such symbols as serpents, eggs and hearts abound.
Situated in the tiny Italian village of Pescia Fiorentina, the garden is half a dozen miles from the beach resort of Capalbio. Its sculptures are a tribute to Antonio Gaudi and also recall the grotesque garden sculptures at Bomarzo, near Viterbo.
A few of the noteworthy Saint Phalle sculptures are "The Magician," crowned with a huge mirror-tiled hand; the "Empress" (or "Sphinx"), which Ms. de Saint Phalle has used as her home and studio, and "Falling Tower," which suggests the chaos at the Tower of Babel, with every window a different size and with the roof and top floor teetering.
A tour of the garden takes two hours or less, and since the garden is open in July and August, now is the time to visit. It is open 4 to 8 P.M. Monday to Saturday; admission is free. There is no phone.
Construction of the garden began in 1979 in collaboration with Miss Saint Phalle's husband, the late Swiss sculptor Jean Tinguely. Still to be completed are two sculptures.
To get to Pescia Fiorentina, which is a mile from the main road, Via Aurelia, follow a gravel road and signs for the Villa Caracciolo or those indicating "sculture." Pescia Fiorentina has but a single restaurant, Trattoria il Tortello, a mile from the garden. A meal for two, with local wine, is $34. The restaurant is open all week long during July and August. Telephone: (0564) 895133.
In nearby Capalbio, a double at the 42-room Hotel Valle del Buttero, which the Michelin Guide rates as comfortable, is $68. It is at 21 Via Silone, Capalbio 58011; telephone (0564) 896097, fax (0564) 896518. Note, though, that the hotel does not have a restaurant.
 
The Seychelles
 Q. I am interested in going to the Seychelles Islands. Where I can get travel information? I also need to know about hotels and beaches. -- Lee Kostel, Williamsburg, Va.
A. The Seychelles, a group of 100 islands in the Indian Ocean a thousand miles east of Tanzania and 700 miles northeast of Madagascar, are known for their beaches, fishing and diving as well as for their rare flora and fauna.
Discovered by the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama and under French rule until 1814, the Seychelles were later ceded to Britain. In 1976 they gained their independence.
Since there is no nonstop service from the United States, your flight is likely to stop in Europe, probably at Gatwick in England, a popular jumping-off point for Mahe, the islands' political and economic center.
To save $1,249 over the cost of a British Airways ticket for New York to Mahe Island and back (which comes to $3,280), you can buy two separate round-trip tickets on British Airways: one New York-Gatwick ($559) and one Gatwick-Mahe Island ($1,472), for a total of $2,031.
Here are some possibilities for accommodations, with rates cited being for double occupancy, including breakfast. The area code is 248.
Beau Vallon Bay Hotel, Post Office Box, 550, Mahe; telephone 46141; fax 47809. The hotel, which has a casino, also offers a pool, scuba diving and tennis. Rate: $261 a day, including breakfast.
Le Meridien Barbarons, Post Office Box 626, Mahe; telephone 78253; fax 78484. Rate: $273, including breakfast.
A 15-minute flight (or two-hour boat ride) from Mahe is the island of Praslin. There, amid flourishing trees, you will find Chateau des Feuilles, a group of 12 handsome cottages some of which overlook the ocean. Telephone 33316; fax 33916. Rate, including breakfast: $200 for a room, $240 for an apartment.
As for beaches, among the more outstanding ones on Mahe are Beau Vallon, a two-mile crescent of soft, white sand; Grand'Anse, whose six-foot waves are well suited for the body surfer, and the calm Anse a la Mouche. For an especially memorable beach, you will want to try the solitude of Anse Lazio on the northern coast of Praslin.
More information: The Seychelles Tourist Office, 820 Second Avenue, Suite 900F, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 687-9766, fax (212) 922-9177.
 
A.T.M.'s Abroad
 Q. During a recent trip to London, I tried to use my automatic teller machine card to withdraw cash, but could not. I understand there is a special code for electronic banking transactions. -- Bette Kirschstein, Ossining, N.Y.
A. Actually, there is no special code needed for banking abroad, but there are a number of reasons a machine may not deliver the goods.
Most A.T.M.'s outside of the United States and Canada are set up for a four-digit personal identification number. While you explained that you had one, some card users may not be aware of this requirement. Anyone with a code exceeding four digits should get a new number through the card issuer and test that number before leaving. Travelers with an access code of four letters should be sure to translate those letters into numbers. It's also important to know one's daily withdrawal limit.
Remember, too, that most international A.T.M.'s do not offer a choice as to which account money should be withdrawn from. Typically, withdrawals are deducted from a checking account, even though the teller machine or receipt might not say so.
Be sure the logo on the back of your card matches the one displayed. The logos you are likely to encounter are Plus and Cirrus, which have a total of 200,000 A.T.M.'s, but some of them may be open only during regular business hours.
Even though there may be a transaction charge, A.T.M.'s still offer a favorable rate: withdrawals are debited at the rate that banks use for transactions in the $1 million range.

LENGTH: 1255 words

HEADLINE: A Philosopher's Perch on Main Street in Ridgefield

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
IT is approaching noon in Ridgefield and a queue is starting to form on Main Street at a little establishment that may be the most recession-proof business of all in these economically troubled times.
In other communities, the business would be described as a hot dog vendor's cart. But in Ridgefield, in keeping with the upscale image of Fairfield County, the awning over the cart describes it as Chez Lenard, the Sidewalk Cafe de Ridgefield. 
 The fare dispensed under the awning is described in a menu as Les Delices Culinaires de la Voiture, Selected Delicacies from the Sidewalk Cafe. The true specialty of the cart is le hot dog facon Mexicain et garniture Suisse. That's a hot dog with chili con carne and fondue created on the premises with cheese, wine and cherry brandy. At $3.25, it is also the most expensive item on the menu.
The cart's proprietor, 57-year-old Michael Soetbeer, sports a whitish beard and deep tan and is attired in a sports shirt, Bermuda shorts, moccasins and occasionally the tall, floppy chef's toque.
Mr. Soetbeer also brings to the job an enthusiasm almost akin to joy. As the queue starts to lengthen at the noon hour, his hands fly in synchronized patterns, getting a hot dog, putting it into the bun, lathering on the mustard or sauerkraut or relish or chopped Bermuda onions, at the same time talking to everyone who is buying or even passing by.
 
Part of the Town's Charm
 "How's the family? I'm glad it's a nice day. I see you've come back to visit." The last is directed at a young mother who arrived at the cart with her 4-year-old daughter. They once lived in Ridgefield but now live in another town. When they come back for a doctor's appointment, the daughter insists they eat at the hot dog stand, the mother said. The stand and its proprietor are part of the charm of the town, she said.
After customers get their hot dogs, some eat while sitting on a wooden planter that the town allowed Mr. Soetbeer to build around a nearby tree. Others drift over to a municipal bench and eat there, or take the hot dogs to a park diagonally across the street. Mr. Soetbeer remains at the stand, serving up more or, when there's a break, simply watching people go by, which he dearly loves to do.
"When I was a kid in a little town on Long Island, my friend and I would sit on the curb and watch the world go by," he said. "I loved it. I still love watching people and here I can do it all the time. I love this job."
Mr. Soetbeer is a man of philosophical bent, conscious that the present economy has hurt some people he has come to know from his perch on Main Street. A declining economy is no respecter of social rank or who works for which Fortune 500 company or how many BMW's or Mercedes are parked in the driveway. When the crunch comes, it comes, and some of the people he knows are now out of jobs. In such a climate, the philosophy of Michael Soetbeer could come in handy. What newly unemployed people might do, he said, is to reflect on what they really want to do in life, what kind of work would make them "really happy and at ease and then see if they can make a buck doing it."
That might sound simplistic, particularly in a town such as Ridgefield, populated by corporate people who wear suits to work, not shorts and moccasins with no socks.
Mr. Soetbeer's opinions, however, should carry some weight. He knows from personal experience what many executives are now going through. He was once one of them. He too lost his job. It was in 1980. He was the personnel director of a large psychiatric center in White Plains, commuting each day from Ridgefield. He was 43 years old, had been involved in personnel work nearly all his adult life, had a wife and three children and suddenly had no job because the center had been sold and the new owners brought in their own management team.
 
No More Endless Details
 He knew he had to work but really didn't want to go back into personnel work. He liked the contact with people but not the endless details that tied him to a desk. One day, almost as a joke, he said, his wife pointed out a little newspaper advertisement. A man who had operated a hot dog cart known as Chez Lenard in warm weather in the center of Ridgefield wanted to sell it. For $5,000, Michael Soetbeer had found his destiny.
Thirteen years later, he can look back and say they have been the most joyful years of his business life. And proud years. "Some people might think this is not upscale work," he said, smiling. "But it is."
He and his cart have also gained a measure of fame, in town and out. Yankee Magazine once designated the cart as the "Best Hot Dog Stand in New England." A local calendar once used a pen and ink drawing of Mr. Soetbeer and his cart as the illustration for the month of June. A mural at Norwalk Hospital that shows the communities the hospital serves uses the hot dog cart to illustrate Ridgefield.
 
A Lot of Hard Work
 Although the hot dog cart represents so much fun, Mr. Soetbeer will also admit that it represents a lot of hard work. He has made it into a year-round enterprise, which takes some tenacity considering Connecticut's weather. Standing under an umbrella on a dreary New England winter day, jumping up and down to keep warm, would not be considered a life-enhancing experience by most people. And in the fast food business you have to keep regular hours, in all seasons, because customers expect it.
"I'm a creature of habit," said Mr. Soetbeer. "By 8, I'm in the center, by 9 I'm setting up, I'm open at 11 and I close at 5." That's seven days a week. In his spare time, he also caters parties, using a spare hot dog cart, mostly for children but sometimes for adults. "I did an adult party in New Canaan the other night. It's the trendy thing to do lately."
After 13 years at the cart, Mr. Soetbeer has been described as an institution in Ridgefield. First Selectwoman Sue W. Manning, who occasionally drops over from her office a block away, agrees that is an apt description.
"He's viewed as an institution," she said. "He's a very friendly sidewalk ambassador. He's always cheery, even in bad weather."
 
Civic Suggestions
 Occasionally, the ambassador will show up at her office to relate some problem that needs attention, and she takes the suggestions seriously. "He dropped in today to tell me the benches in the park are too close to the trash receptacles," she said, "and the seniors who go to the park are complaining."
The only time Mr. Soetbeer parted from his cart in recent years was in February, absolute low point of the hot dog season in Connecticut. He and his wife, Jane, an executive at Norwalk Hospital, take a short vacation, usually to visit their three children, one of whom lives on Maui.
This summer is different, though. For the first time, he is taking some time off, not to smell the roses but to smell the salt water. He now has a boat, an old 31-foot wooden sloop he has renamed With Relish, and plans to get in some sailing time. But the cart will continue in operation, run by students carefully selected by Mr. Soetbeer. He does not want anyone to think this is an indication he is retiring or even semi-retiring from the hot dog business. When the students go back to school, he goes back to work full time. "This is fun," he said. "I'll do it forever."
A legitimate question is what would have happened if Mr. Soetbeer had not lost his job 13 years ago. With no hesitation he responded, "I'd be a basket case by now."

HEADLINE: Your Home: Salability;
A Slovenly House Is A Turn-Off

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
COOKIE crumbs hang from the upholstery in the family room. The beds have been left unmade. Dirty dishes sit for days in the kitchen sink. The living room carpet is stained and frayed. And underwear is scattered all over an upstairs bedroom.
What's so surprising about all of this? The fact that the home in question may be on the market. Indeed, buyers and brokers complain that an ever-increasing number of homes currently up for sale -- even expensive homes -- are being offered in a condition that is almost an embarrassment. 
 "We were appalled by what we saw," said Ken Hall, a salesman, who recently moved with his wife, Stacey, from Milford, Conn., to Atlanta. "Three out of four houses were in such a messy condition that it felt like a distress sale, even if it wasn't."
Not only was it a turn-off, he said, but it also implied they could knock down the price because the sellers must surely be desperate or downtrodden, or both.
The decline in housekeeping standards nationwide, widely reported in the media earlier this year, is beginning to affect the salability and value of even the best of homes.
Lack of time is a prime culprit, according to Dr. Juliet Schorr, a professor of economics at Harvard University and the author of "The Overworked American," (Basic Books). Subsequent studies on the shrinking amount of hours now being spent on regular housekeeping confirm that assumption.
Another catalyst, say the experts, is a deterioration in the level of acceptable standards that make the unkempt home more acceptable than in June Cleaver's day. Back in the days of "Leave It to Beaver," slovenly housekeeping would have been viewed as a sin. Today, however, cleanliness has ceased to be so close to godliness.
Brokers report that a messy home has become so commonplace and acceptable in our society that even the sellers may not appreciate how unappealing their homes appear to others.
"It's hard to tell people they're slobs," said Jim Whittemore, a partner with Burbank/ Whittemore, a real estate agency in Larchmont, N.Y., who has been selling homes for 18 years.
Susan Spetrini, a broker with the Beazley Company of Hamden, Conn., agreed. "It's easier to say the house needs painting than the house needs cleaning," she said.
And when there's trouble in the family the situation can be grim. "You see the worst conditions when there's a divorce," said Kathy Burke, a broker with Weichert Realtors of Upper Montclair, N.J.
What the sellers overlook, said Mr. Whittemore, is that sloppy housekeeping can become a deterrent for the brokers too.
He said this was one reason why certain homes are not shown as frequently as others offering similar amenities in the same price range. Animal hair on the furniture, he said, is one of the worst offenders.
"If you only have an hour or two with a customer," he explained, "you find yourself automatically excluding the homes you know will be in a mess." Thus, he concludes, "It's the cleanest, neatest houses that tend to make a broker's short list."
Ms. Spetrini, for example, keeps a mental inventory of homes she subconsciously puts on the back burner. They include those where there is the likelihood of finding half-eaten pizza slices on a kitchen table, jelly on the chairs, dirty kitty litter, unflushed toilets, underwear left on the floor, mold in a swimming pool or bathroom.
What can be done? Even before scheduling an "open house" to acquaint brokers in the area with the listing, it might be best to call in a heavy-duty cleaning service. Such a service will have the mechanized equipment to tackle long-neglected jobs like shampooing rugs, polishing the floors and washing walls. These services are listed under "House Cleaning" in the Yellow Pages.
Expect to pay $100 to $400, depending upon the size of the home. It tends to be worthwhile having the windows washed, too, to enhance an atmosphere of light and airiness.
IF feasible, arrange for weekly maid service while the listing is active because it's not going to be easy to keep that home tidy and clean over the long haul. "It is money well spent because you will get so much more for your home and will sell faster," said Mary Ellen Pinkham, author of "Mary Ellen's Clean House" (Crown).
If not, Ms. Pinkham recommends at least creating an "illusion of cleanliness." Among her 10-minute tips: keep boxes around the house that be quickly stuffed with items left out; spray the air with a cleanser; wash, paint or polish the front door ("It's the first thing they notice").
Brighten up a bathroom with a new shower curtain if the existing one is beyond redemption, suggest Martin M. Shenkman and Warren Boroson, co-authors of the 1990 book "How to Sell Your House in a Buyer's Market," (Wiley).
The authors also recommend going through the house, room by room, compiling a checklist of all the items that need attention, even calling in a friend (or the broker) if a more critical eye is required. The exterior and landscaping need equal care, they say.
Among the authors' other suggestions: oiling a squeaky gate or door, stuffing those extra clothes in boxes under the beds and being ruthless about getting rid of excess furniture and other assorted clutter. "Most buyers are looking for space," they note. "Or at least the impression of it."
Bare floors, added Barbara Webski, manager of a Stamford office of William Pitt Real Estate, can look far better than worn or soiled carpeting. "Take up those old carpets," she said.
It may therefore be better to hold the inevitable tag sale prior to placing the home on the market -- not leaving it until a few days before moving out, which is customary.
If drapes are worn, faded or out-of-style they might also be best removed, said Ms. Septrini. Yellowed venetian blinds are also best taken down. Smokers should leave windows open.
"IF nothing else, clean up the bathroom and the kitchen every day," said Don Gurry, a sales associate with the Ridgewood, N.J., office of Coldwell Banker Schlott Realtors. "Clear off those counter tops. Be sure the laundry room is presentable. There's no reason to have things thrown all over the place even if it's in use. Make the beds. Wipe the stove after every meal."
Finally, he warned: "You'd be surprised how many buyers look inside the oven and the closets as well. All this stuff really does have an impact of price."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Manhattan Office Assessments;
Weaker Shoulders for the Property Tax

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
DON'T talk assessments to Peter S. Duncan. It is true that the building he runs as executive vice president of George Comfort & Sons -- 200 Madison Avenue, at 35th Street -- is down in value from past years.
But what matters to him is that he is in a leasing mode again. The 550,000-square-foot office building is out from limbo after having been purchased by George Comfort and a partner, Loeb Realty and Development Corporation, of Manhattan. It was one of the properties that was forced into receivership when the Government froze the assets of the late President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines. 
 "We could not be aggressive going after outside tenants during the period of court ownership," said Mr. Duncan, whose company has managed the building since 1976. "Our hands were tied on spending money."
Assessments enter the picture only because New York City has completed its final assessment roll for the 1994 fiscal year, which began July 1. It shows a marked drop in commercial and office property values. There are few sales in the current sluggish market that would demonstrate the slide in actual transactions. The 200 Madison Avenue sale is only a straw in the wind.
But 10 years ago the Philippine investors paid $50 million for their long-term leasehold (another party owns the land). This year the buyers paid $25 million, getting a building that is 83 percent occupied.
The sale serves to underscore the downward trend of values reflected in the assessment roll. The roll itself again calls into question the policies that have let homeowners pay far less than their fair share of property taxes, and lightened the burden on rental property by holding rents below market levels through regulation.
The final assessment for all classes of property turned out to be $79.2 billion, the third year in a row of decline. The 1991 roll (an aberration, in some minds) was a record $91.5 billion.
In the last few years Manhattan office buildings have accounted for about 28 percent of total assessed value. In the latest year the fraction is down to 26 percent. The drop in value has been 20 percent since 1991.
Every $1 billion drop in value of Class 4 property under current tax rates means a loss in revenue of $107 million.
IN the early 80's, when foreign investors were stepping up their interest in real-estate investment in New York, there was talk that office rents in Manhattan might eventually reach $100 a square foot a year. In that environment both city and state government proceeded to place a heavier share of taxes on commercial property. The expectations of rising rents also inflated the prices foreign buyers were willing to pay for office buildings. Assessments of properties that sold were promptly lifted to 45 percent of sale price.
In fact, after exceeding $40 and sometimes even $50 a square foot a year in midtown in the mid-80's, midtown office rents have settled back to the low-$30's and mid-$20's. Downtown rents on the whole are lower.
Rents have apparently stabilized in the last year and a half. Real-estate brokers usually place the low point of activity in the market at the last quarter of 1991. "Just before Labor Day that year there was a depression in real estate," said Vincent Tuminelli, senior financial consultant at Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage firm. There were only seven midtown transactions of more than 100,000 square feet the entire year, he said.
In 1992 there were 17 midtown transactions over 100,000 square feet. And in the leasing range of 25,000 to 50,000 square feet, midtown activity rose over 100 percent, he said.
Another sign of the leasing pick-up has been the moderation in concession packages given by owners. These are made up of their contribution toward space improvements for the tenant and rent waivers for some of the early months of the lease. Brokers say that free-rent periods have shortened, and the payments for tenant work have declined. Overall, concessions such as contributions to space improvements for tenants, which make effective rents lower than nominal rents, are down about 15 percent from the "depression," Mr. Tuminelli says. On larger leases owners had been paying about $50 a square foot a year toward tenant work.
The decline in the tax base that the weakened market has set in motion is by no means restricted to New York City.
A paper called "The Impact of Declining Property Values on Local Government Finances" was published in March by the Urban Land Institute, a nonprofit education and research institute in Washington. The report found an over-all decline of 21 percent in commercial values for the three years from 1989 to 1992. The impact varies from area to area, but the institute nevertheless said it anticipated a "massive shift in the burden of paying for local government services from the commercial sector to the residential sector."
RELATIVE to commercial values, residential values have held their own. The Urban Land Institute paper predicted that nationally there will be an upward shift in the proportion of the local tax base represented by residential property -- to 72.8 percent from 65 percent.
In New York City as well residential values over all have held up better than commercial values. The final assessment of rentals, co-ops and larger condominiums (Class 2) for fiscal 1994 was $24.4 billion, down $1 billion from a year ago but almost unchanged from the $24.3 billion roll of 1990. Since 1990 commercial assessments have dropped $6.6 billion.
The fraction of market value at which the various classes are to be assessed was frozen in 1981 by state law at the unequal levels that then prevailed. The idea was to preserve the favoritism the New York City system shows to Class 1 property against legal challenge. The favoritism was locked in against a market upturn by limiting annual increases in assessments to 6 percent a year and a maximum of 20 percent over five years.
THE result was that during the period of market-value escalation in the 80's houses paid an ever-lower share of the tax burden. In 1993 they paid 11.2 percent of the total tax levy although they represented 42.7 percent of the market value of the city's taxable property.
During most of the 80's the City Council was also helping homeowners by regularly shifting a fraction of their tax burden onto Class 4 property.
By 1993 commercial property was paying 53 percent of the tax burden though it represented only 31 percent of total market value.
The latest assessment roll is driving home the point that commercial property can no longer be relied on to underpin the tax base. The assessments are based on actual income and expense statements.
SINCE there is a five-year phase-in period for taxes to be based on actual assessments, there is a lag time in which city tax payments do not fully reflect the decline in values. But the gap between billable and actual assessments has all but disappeared as the flat market has persisted. The Manhattan office sector is expected to produce $2.2 billion in tax revenue in the current fiscal year. That is down almost $300 million from 1992.
The city is relying on property taxes as a whole to contribute $7.67 billion toward the expense budget of $31.3 billion approved by the City Council this year. Local taxes of all kinds make up $18 billion of that budget.
As time passes and office leases are renewed at prevailing market rents, Class 4 assessments should continue to decline.
"We believe that as more leases come due there is still a significant decline in value that will be reflected in total assessed values," said Jonathan Adams, chief economist of the Real Estate Board of New York. Without a near-term market turnaround, the decline may be an additional 10 percent, he said.

HEADLINE: Foreclosure Evictions Disputed

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IMAGINE living quietly in an apartment, faithfully paying your rent and obeying the landlord's rules. Now imagine that the landlord stops making his mortgage payments, and the bank that holds the mortgage forecloses. And suddenly you are evicted so the bank can sell the property unencumbered.
Tenant advocates and some state legislators say that because of a loophole in the state's anti-eviction statute, such a situation is not uncommon. In fact, they say, thousands of tenants have already been evicted while tens of thousands more may face similar fates. 
 "This is a problem of immense proportions," said Assemblyman Raul Garcia, Democrat of Union City.
The loophole, Mr. Garcia said, allows lenders who have taken back properties in foreclosure to avoid the requirements of the state's Eviction for Cause Act. The act prohibits the eviction of tenants without a showing of "good cause," like nonpayment of rent.
But a bill sponsored by Mr. Garcia and now poised for a vote by the Assembly would close the loophole. The bill would amend the Eviction for Cause Act and extend its protection to people living in buildings that lenders take back in foreclosures.
A 1986 amendment to the 1974 act was thought by tenant advocates to have accomplished the same goal, but recent court interpretations of the law have allowed lenders to evict tenants living in buildings they have foreclosed on, even if the tenants are paying their rents.
Banking officials have lobbied against the proposed amendment, saying it will make it difficult for lenders to sell foreclosed properties. And that, they say, could result in lenders' being unwilling to make mortgage loans on rental property.
"What this bill does is make landlords of the lenders, and lenders are not equipped to be landlords," said Edmond V. Lawlor, spokesman for the New Jersey Savings League, a Cranford-based trade organization of 94 savings banks.
The debate comes as lenders, facing a real-estate market weakened by the recession, struggle to sell the thousands of properties they have taken back in foreclosures over the last few years.
"Tenants should not lose their homes because the building's owner did not fulfill his mortgage obligations," Mr. Garcia said. He represents part of Hudson County, where he said banks foreclosed on 246 rental properties last year, resulting in the eviction of more than 1,000 families. "It's horrible to think that innocent people who are faithfully paying their rents are being put out on the street just to make it easier for the banks to sell their buildings," he said.
The impact extends beyond just the people who are evicted, Mr. Garcia said. "Very often, after these people lose their homes, they require public assistance and rent subsidies," he said. "And that ends up costing taxpayers money."
Mr. Garcia said that more than 20,000 foreclosure complaints were filed statewide in 1992. It takes about one year for a foreclosure action to run its course. And while many of those will be resolved without an actual foreclosure, he said, even a single foreclosure can affect scores of residents.
Mr. Lawlor of the Savings League said passage of the bill would make it difficult for lenders to sell buildings they have taken back in foreclosures. "What will happen is they'll wind up getting more and more properties that they won't be able to sell," he said, adding that it is much more difficult to interest prospective buyers in a building that has existing tenants, particularly if the rents they are paying are low.
"If the owner went belly up, the main reason he went belly up is usually because he's not getting the rent," he said. "Why else would an owner default?"
But what about tenants who are paying rent and have done nothing wrong?
"The lender hasn't done anything wrong either," Mr. Lawlor said. "The person who's done something wrong is the owner. But you're punishing the lender by saying, 'You can't sell this building.' "
 
'Catastrophic Results' Feared
Last month, at a hearing of the Assembly Housing Committee, Stu Cameron of the New Jersey Bankers Association said the bill would have "catastrophic results" for both mortgage lenders and for those seeking loans.
If lenders cannot evict tenants from the buildings they foreclose on, he said, "the supposed security of a mortgage loan in New Jersey could become an illusion." As a result, he said, banks would be less willing to make mortgage loans.
The Housing Committee voted unanimously to release the bill, which
awaits posting for a full Assembly vote.
Robert Levy, executive director of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New Jersey in Springfield, agreed with Mr. Cameron's comments. "If New Jersey becomes a state that is known to be anti-lender, you lose a tremendous amount of available mortgage financing," Mr. Levy said. "Lenders have a lot of alternatives for where they can put their money, and they will avoid those areas where they have a concern that they can't recoup their funds in the event of a default."
Mr. Levy emphasized that the banking industry is sensitive to tenants' concerns. "We are very much in favor of consumer rights, and we obviously don't like to see tenants evicted," he said. "But by the same token, if you remove mortgage financing from our state, prospective tenants won't have places to live because the housing won't be built."
 
Couple Face Eviction
 That, however, offers little solace to Seymour and Marion Josephson, a retired couple in West Orange who are fighting to remain in the house they have rented for the last 21 years.
"I'm 70 and my wife is 71, we both have health problems, and we've never missed paying rent to anybody," Mr. Josephson said.
The couple have lived in the house through a succession of owners, but the current owner declared bankruptcy. As a result, Mr. Josephson said, the bank that held the mortgage on the property became the owner.
"The next thing we knew, out of the blue we got an order to vacate within 30 days," Mr. Josephson said. "Just figure how that felt to two elderly people who thought that this was their home."
Mr. Josephson said that he tried to pay rent on the house, but that the bank would not accept any payments. "For a year we put the rent aside," he said, adding that he and his wife continue to live in the house because his lawyer has been able to hold off the eviction.
"We want to stay here," Mr. Josephson said. "This is our home. But they have no interest in that at all. They just want us out."
 
Case Being Appealed
 The Josephsons are represented by Susan Oxford, a lawyer with the State Public Advocate's office. Ms. Oxford said the case was now on appeal before the State Supreme Court.
She said the basis for the appeal is a 1986 amendment to the Eviction for Cause Act that extended the protections afforded by the act to tenants in foreclosed properties. Some courts, however, have ruled that the 1986 amendment did not extend the protection. And that, she said, is why passage of the new bill is important.
"It's really important to have clarification," she said. "And the best way to have it is to have the Legislature say it more explicitly."
Ms. Oxford said the foreclosure exception "defeats the purpose of the act if an innocent tenant who is paying their rent can be uprooted just because the property has changed hands in this manner."
She said the banking industry has offered only "bald assertions" that extending the protection would cause problems for lenders.
 
'It Enhances Their Assets'
 "In fact, it enhances their assets to have tenants producing rents," she said. And if the rents in a particular building are artificially low, she said, local rent-control ordinances all have a "hardship" provision allowing landlords -- including banks that have become landlords through foreclosure -- to raise rents if they can prove a need.
And, Ms. Oxford said, in the case of single-family rental homes like the Josephsons', the existing law allows an owner to evict a tenant if a prospective buyer intends to live in the property.
"If the banks are saying, 'We can't evict them as fast as we'd like to,' well, that's exactly what the Legislature intended," she said.
Joan Pransky, a Montclair lawyer who represents the New Jersey Tenants Organization, agreed. "Those amendments were absolutely intended to bring foreclosures under the anti-eviction statutes," Ms. Pransky said. "I know, because I sat in a room when we hammered out those amendments with the sponsors of the bill."
 
'In Their Economic Interest'
 Ms. Pransky said that increasing numbers of foreclosures and a weak real-estate market have prompted banks to push for an interpretation of the amendment that exempts them from the amended law.
"The banks decided that it was in their economic interest to get rid of the tenants," Ms. Pransky said.
In fact, she said, by being able to evict tenants after a foreclosure, a lender might be able to enhance the value of the property beyond what it was worth to the original landlords.
"If you have a building that's filled with tenants paying $300 a month and can empty out the building and bring in tenants paying $600 a month, then you have a building that's worth more," she said.
In addition, she said, allowing a lender to empty a building completely might make that building more valuable to a prospective buyer hoping to convert the apartments to condominiums. That option, she said, would not have been available to the original owner because of laws that prevent the eviction of tenants during condominium conversions.
"But this is not about the law," Ms. Pransky said. "This is about economics."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 11; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1509 words

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins

DATELINE: UPPER MONTCLAIR

 BODY:
WHERE there's a town, there's a hardware store, but there is only one Thompson's. Never will there be another. For six decades, Thompson's Hardware has always been "the store that has everything," as its motto boasts. Everything, yes. But now, hour by hour, it's an everything that there's less and less of.
These days, the nondescript little two-story building at Park Street near Watchung Avenue in Upper Montclair is flying red distress flags that scream "Sale." Thompson's is blacking out its windows with red, green and ultrapink signs proclaiming "Retirement Sale" and "Quitting Business." 
 Customers who enter this hushed shrine to the glory of hardware have a worried look, as they scout the inventory for 30-percent discount gems and eye an ever-increasing acreage of shelf space that was last devoid of gadgets during the Great Depression. To those who love the smell and look and swagger of an honest, how-can-we-help-you-sir American hardware store, the very spectacle is a catastrophe.
It's the Dodgers leaving Brooklyn. It's George Steinbrenner thumbing his nose at the Bronx. It's as if a public utility, open seven days a week, has announced the abrogation of its civic franchise.
"A couple of people are pretty angry at us," said William P. Rust, the store's 58-year-old proprietor. "They're really mad. They say, 'How dare you do this to me?' They take it personally."
After Aug. 21, Thompson's liquidation sale will have completed its dastardly work and the store will be no more, unless the garish disaster signs intrigue some brave white knight who has a hardware habit and a determination to carry on.
The foundering of the S.S. Thompson reflects the retail ecology of most towns in New Jersey. Thompson's has been on the market for more than a year now, and there is still no buyer. "They don't want to fight chain stores," Mr. Rust said. "They think there is no future in a quality hardware store that -- well, that has everything."
Mr. Rust is hardly the average hardware guy. A Princeton graduate and Wall Street dropout, he left Smith Barney in Manhattan in the mid-1970's, where he was a first vice president. Before that, from 1956 to 1961, he was an Army pilot -- rated for helicopters and fixed-wings -- and left as a captain when he went into the Reserves.
The store is a celebration of the owner's concept of retailing as an omnium-gatherum. Treasure-bearing stained-oak cabinets line the walls with close to 500 small drawers full of hinges, bolts, screws, nails and assorted stuff. Lurking in secret recesses are those essential replacement items that local homeowners, in their Victorians and Tudors, know have not been machined, cast or extruded in the last five decades.
There are handmade garage-door springs. There are 60-year-old boxes full of Stanley door pivot hinges, crayoned with the original pricing. Bins of nails. Rolls of screening. There are brass corners for steamer trunks, brass door pulls and suitcase catches. A nest of copper staples sits patiently in a John Ruskin cigar box, near dusty one-inch-diameter lag bolts.
Arching above the crowded aisles is the cathedral vault of the original stamped tin ceiling. Dark fan belts of every size swing from above like dangling prosciutto in Zabar's. Thompson's creaky, unvarnished oak floors are oiled once a year; they make the most routine hunt for roofing nails or Teflon tape an auditory experience.
Downstairs, in the inner sanctum of hardware, reside 12-foot-long apple-pickers, long-handled brick-oven bakers' shovels and even hogs' rings. "You know, the rings that go in the noses of hogs," Mr. Rust said. "For some reason we keep selling them, and we don't know who's buying them. Or why."
In a world of highway hardware merchandising, Thompson's is a place where you can buy five tenpenny nails or even find a replacement for a worn crutch tip. Home Depot this definitely is not. Nor a Rickel nor a Channel, nor any of the blister-package palaces.
For small retailers in every town, the agita of marketing these days is that recession-squeezed customers are hot to get the most for their dollar. And they're willing to forgo service to get it. Just try shouting up a clerk next time you head over to Megahardware-by-the-Highway.
For the big-ticket buy, customers are increasingly outta town. When Home Depot opened a few years ago in Clifton, the town next door, "the head count in our store was the same, and so was the number of transactions," said Mr. Rust, whose computerized inventory system tracks every purchase. "But the dollars per transaction were down. People thought they could get a better price on the $400 charcoal grill and the $300 rotary mower out on the highway."
Paradoxically, though, the mass merchandisers are experts on variable pricing; dozens of items are featured at prices that are actually below Mr. Rust's costs. "Yet much of our own inventory is priced lower than in the stores on the highway," he said. "But somehow people don't notice that."
He sighed. "Here's what's going to happen when the recession is over," said Mr. Rust, holding forth in his air-conditioned office. "Local folks will realize they're tired of the inconvenience and hassle of going to the highway to buy things. They'll come back to town for service. And when they do, all their favorite stores will have disappeared. Ultimately that will affect the tenor and tone of the community. And that will affect property values."
The mall stores are even invading Montclair, which now has a Gap and a Talbots. "But I don't think that's hurting the local merchants," Mr. Rust said. "It's helping them. The big names attract shoppers from out of town."
A tall, tan, solid man clothed in a plaid shirt and an aura of implacable calm, Mr. Rust studies the world with some bemusement behind his wire rims, a decidely low-key philosopher of merchandising. He has the look of a friendly banker, if only bankers were given to deliver long, thoughtful lectures on how to rewire your Tiffany lamps.
The store was built in 1930, Mr. Rust said, by one A. Thompson, a contractor who wanted to supplement his building business with retail sales. Mr. Rust kept the name.
"It wouldn't make any sense to change it in a town where everyone says, 'I'm going over to Thompson's,' " Mr. Rust said. "Also, the name Rust wouldn't be too great on a hardware store."
Originally, a dentist and a real-estate office occupied the second floor; now Mr. Rust has turned the 12,000-square-foot space into Thompson Executive Services, a suite of six rental offices with an office manager and two secretaries. They minister to tenants ranging from lawyers to the headquarters staff of the American Platform Tennis Association.
Also operating out of Thompson's is Mr. Rust's flag and customized banner business, which he began pretty much by accident in 1986 and which now brings in nearly $500,000 in revenue a year. Mr. Rust intends to keep the office business and the flag merchandising going, but he wants to sell the building and the hardware store with it.
The profitable Thompson's isn't closing its doors for lack of customers; Mr. Rust is tired of giving seven-day attention to the store. He wants to focus on building his flag business. He hopes to play more golf, more tennis. There is much more flying to do.
It is a labor-intensive endeavor, this local hardware business. "Our goal is to encounter everyone who comes into the store with a 'how can I help you?' " Mr. Rust said. "Whether it's a request for a 19-cent washer or a $190 lawnmower, we try to give the same service to all."
The three full-time clerks at Thompson's and their part-time helpers have become adept at sign language. "The hands start going as soon as people try to describe whatever it is they need," Mr. Rust said. "They'll say, 'It's the thing that goes up like this and it's shaped like that.' "
Mr. Rust has always been a hopeless hardware junkie; that's one of the reasons he bought the store in 1985, after six years as a developer and contractor converting deteriorating buildings into gleaming medical condominiums and rehabilitated apartment residences. "I was in Thompson's two or three times a day, at least," he said. "When the previous owner asked me if I'd like to buy, it wasn't exactly a surprise. I satisfied a dream, buying in."
After a year of trying to sell the store and the building in a season of lingering economic stagnation, there are no takers. "People are so concerned about the mass marketers, they're intimidated," he said. "But I'm convinced that a young couple could come in and make a lot of money if they think creatively."
He always has. Just notice where the copying machine is. And the United Parcel Service weighing station. They're at the back of the store, so customers have to navigate aisle after aisle just to get to them.
In fact, you might as well pick up some batteries and a light bulb on the way to get that 15-cent Xerox copy. And don't you need some duct tape? You have until Aug. 21 to buy it.

HEADLINE: Baby Boomer Blues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a member of the post-baby boomer generation now struggling in the workplace and also coming to the realization that a declining living standard is to be expected, I have little empathy with the plight of the baby boomers. 
 They have nothing to complain about; they experienced an America of abundance after World War II, and expected such wealth to continue despite their malaise and snide rejection of their parents' values. Now that opportunities are harder to come by and job security is less assured, these baby boomers should look at themselves as mostly to blame. After enjoying affluent childhoods in the 1950's, they grew up to reject those values in the protest movements of the 60's and the profligacy of the 70's and 80's.
If, as Robin Toner says in reviewing Katherine S. Newman's "Declining Fortunes: The Withering of the American Dream" (June 20), baby boomers are now bemoaning their inability to compete with their parents' opportunities, then maybe they should have striven to match their parents' achievements with equally impressive ones of their own. Indeed, the baby boomer generation should be singled out more for its inherent selfishness and social irresponsibility than for its economic difficulties.
Ms. Toner is correct: Ms. Newman does give a far more sympathetic portrayal of the baby boomers than they usually get. Unfortunately, it is also a portrayal far more sympathetic than they deserve.
 
KEVIN CALLINAN
Arlington, Va.

HEADLINE: When Robert Rubin Talks . . .

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Three days before President Clinton introduced his economic plan, his economic inner circle huddled for a debate: Should we settle for cutting the deficit by less than our goal of $140 billion in 1997 to avoid more politically unpopular spending cuts?
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and George Stephanopoulos, the White House spokesman, argued that it wouldn't be so bad to fall short. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Leon Panetta, the Budget Director, pressed for sticking with the goal. Then Robert E. Rubin, the Administration's point man on economic policy as director of the new National Economic Council, threw his weight behind the bigger cuts. 
"What we do here will send a signal of how serious we are about fighting the deficit," Mr. Rubin said at the meeting. "We've set this goal, and it's important to stick with it to remain credible with the financial markets."
The President stuck with $140 billion.
When Bob Rubin left his position as co-chairman of Wall Street's most prestigious investment banking firm, Goldman Sachs, to coordinate economic policy for the President, it was widely thought that he would serve as the quintessential "honest broker," directing traffic while others made the recommendations. In fact, the 54-year-old Mr. Rubin is quietly playing a major role in shaping policy, and in the process putting a subtle pro-business stamp on Administration policies.
Whether he is campaigning against cutting off China's preferred trading status or pushing for health-care-reform options that would cost employers less, Mr. Rubin is reminding those around him that paying attention to business is a key to getting the American economy back on track -- Mr. Clinton's No. 1 campaign pledge.
In recent days, he has also pressed for relaxing the alternative minimum tax that squeezes heavy industry. And in the trade talks in Tokyo two weeks ago, he played the role of tough cop in pressing Japan to do more to reduce its trade surplus.
 
Business Is Skeptical
 Within weeks of coming to Washington, Mr. Rubin established himself as a major player. He briefs the President several times a week, offering his own counsel as well as funneling policy advice to the President from Secretary Bentsen, Ms. Tyson and others.
"What the President values in Bob is experience, honest, dispassionate analysis, the ability to weigh arguments and broker them in an honest way, and a deep but practical understanding of how the economy works," said Mr. Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to the President.
Interviews with more than a dozen Administration officials suggest that Mr. Rubin gets high marks for shepherding many new economic policies from brainstorming session to concrete proposal, all the while soothing delicate egos and preventing Cabinet secretaries from rampaging.
If there has been a failure, it is that Congress and the American people have not embraced the embattled budget package and the already defeated stimulus plan, which were forged by the National Economic Council. Secretary Bentsen, Ms. Tyson and Mr. Rubin attribute these problems to poor communications and Republicans out to score political points.
Despite Mr. Rubin's pro-business bent, many business people do not see him as their champion, and criticize the policies he and the President are embracing.
Some executives ask why Mr. Rubin, long lionized as one of the shrewdest executives on Wall Street, is shilling for Bill Clinton, a man they see as hopelessly liberal and disorganized. Why, many ask, is Mr. Rubin, who earned more than $15 million in 1991 and has a net worth estimated at more than $50 million, defending an economic plan they see as long on tax increases and short on spending cuts?
If anything has surprised Mr. Rubin since joining the Administration, it is the avalanche of criticism, especially from the business community. In interviews in his modest West Wing office, a room largely devoid of decorations and mementos, he asserted that business badly misunderstands what he -- and President Clinton -- are about.
"Some business people seem to think the President hasn't made one dollar in spending cuts," said Mr. Rubin, a self-effacing man with sad eyes and a soft, often-tired voice. "When you're outside the process, it's much easier to advocate that certain things be done, like a lot more spending cuts, than when you're inside, and see the political realities. Spending cuts make up half of the President's $500 billion in deficit reduction."
 
The Day He Growled
 At one speech to the Business Roundtable, Mr. Rubin lost his cool after executives complained about energy taxes and higher corporate taxes and attacked the President for not having courage to make serious spending cuts.
"President Clinton has made a vast number of courageous decisions about spending cuts that Presidents haven't wanted to deal with in the past 12 years," he told the group. "That's a testament to political courage."
Several weeks later, in a reflective mood in his office, he said: "For years, business people have told me that the Government has to address two big problems: the budget deficit and underinvestment. The President is doing what most business executives said should be done. Many executives have attached much higher weight to the specific things they object to than to the larger good of what he's doing."
On Wall Street, Mr. Rubin was long a prominent member of a rare species: the unabashed Democrat. He said his Democratic genes come from his grandfather, who was the No. 2 man in a machine-style Brooklyn political club.
He describes himself as a centrist, although his conversation makes clear that he is moderate to conservative on economic issues, and liberal on social and urban issues.
"If I were to stick a label on Bob, I'd call him pragmatic," said Stephen Friedman, Goldman Sachs's chairman and formerly co-chairman with Mr. Rubin. "His approach is: 'What are the problems and the opportunities and how do we achieve what we want to achieve?' "
He might also be described as a pro-growth Democrat. Carefully measuring each word, he said: "I believe very strongly that the country has to have a vibrant economy, because if you have that, then you can do a lot of things, including many social programs. But if all you focus on is redistributing the pie, you end up with a smaller pie -- and tremendous social tensions. You have to find some balance between growing the pie and helping those most in need."
 
An Affinity for Clinton
 Mr. Rubin enlisted in the Clinton camp several months after he co-hosted a small dinner for Mr. Clinton in 1991. Hearing the Arkansas Governor talk about the need to cut the deficit, increase investment, make the cities bloom again and improve job training and infrastructure, Mr. Rubin said, he came away astonished at how "congruent" Mr. Clinton's thinking was with his own.
That still seems to be the case. Mr. Rubin sees eye to eye with the President on the importance of attacking two deficits at once: the budget deficit and the investment deficit. When Congress passed tough caps on spending that forced Mr. Clinton to scale back his ambitious investment plans, it was Mr. Rubin who played field marshal to preserve as many investments in training, new technologies, the Head Start program and infrastructure as possible.
"He as much as anyone helped maintain the economic plan's pro-investment orientation," said Gene Sperling, one of Mr. Rubin's two deputies and the economic-issues coordinator for the Clinton campaign.
Mr. Rubin sees no instant fixes for the nation's economy. In his view, Mr. Clinton's plan is the best long-term medicine for the economy, combining deficit reduction with incentives for private investment as well as government investment in training, infrastructure and new technologies. He is worried, however, that in a nation eager for short-term results, Americans will grow impatient if there is no payoff soon.
 
The Crossroads

 "I believe we are at a historical crossroads," he said. "Until Bill Clinton came along, I felt there was a high probability that the United States would continue on a trail in which we underperformed the rest of the industrialized world."
With the earnestness of an Eagle Scout, he added, "If we can accomplish a substantial part of the things we hope to do, I think it will have a historic impact on putting the economy back on the right track."
Increasingly in recent weeks, Mr. Rubin has flexed his muscles by saying what he thinks, often asserting that what's best for the economy is usually the best politics.
At a meeting in May, he teamed up with Ms. Tyson to challenge health-care advisers who were pushing the President to embrace a generous basic health-care plan for all Americans. Mr. Rubin favors a more modest plan because it would mean smaller tax increases and less upset for business. He also thinks a modest plan would be more conducive to economic growth.
Last spring, he campaigned against stripping away China's preferred trading status over human-rights violations. He argued that American businesses need to build their presence in China now because that country might someday have the world's largest economy.
That view largely prevailed: the President extended China's "most favored nation" trading status for a year, although he based any additional extension on human-rights improvements.
Or take the July 12 meeting of the Administration's Reconciliation Committee -- a group of senior economic, political and communications people whose goal is to get the President's package through Congress.
There Mr. Rubin went to bat for slashing the alternative minimum tax -- a levy placed on companies when their income, by standard measures, is too low to pay the normal corporate income tax. He argued that this tax, which involves stingier depreciation provisions, undermined the President's hopes of promoting investment because it punishes industries, like paper and airlines, that invest heavily in equipment.
Mr. Rubin argued that the group should support the House version, which called for bigger reductions in alternative-minimum-tax revenues than the Senate version, saying this would demonstrate that the President recognizes business's needs.
 
Noblesse Oblige
 In at least one area, Mr. Rubin and the President part. It is Mr. Clinton's "soak the rich" rhetoric. "Bob very much believes that those who are well off should pay the most in taxes," said Mr. Sperling, his deputy. "But in his view, the message should be a noble calling, rather than a populist slam."
That sense of noblesse oblige is often evident in Mr. Rubin, a thin man whose suits always seem rumpled and whose shirt is often out. This financial aristocrat has made his mint and, corny as it may sound, he now wants to help turn the nation around.
No one ever said Bob Rubin's new job would be easy. When he was asked to set up the economic council, and superimpose it on an existing bureaucracy, it was as if he were being asked to land an alien spacecraft atop the White House without shattering the fine china.
Essentially, the council's role is to put together information and policy recommendations from different departments involved in economic issues and prepare memos to help the President make a decision. He often assembles officials from half a dozen agencies to discuss policy. In some previous Administrations, there was no formal process for channeling economic ideas to the President, and in the Bush Administration, Richard Darman, the Budget Director, took charge of developing economic policy mainly through force of personality.
So far, Mr. Rubin has tiptoed through the forest of big egos without making enemies. "If a different personality, a Brzezinski or a Kissinger, had this job, it wouldn't work," said Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger Altman. Agencies like the Office of Management and Budget and the Treasury "would block it from working," Mr. Altman said. "They'd try to take back control of recommendations to the President."
 
A Dearth of Ego
 The secret of Mr. Rubin's success, Administration officials say, is that he is a good listener, makes sure everyone is heard and has a small ego. One White House official said Mr. Rubin has the smallest ratio of ego to accomplishment of anyone he has ever met.
"He's exceedingly well equipped for this job," said Robert Strauss, the former Democratic Party chairman. "He has no ego."
This is not to say that Mr. Rubin walks on water, although the criticisms one hears tend toward the gentle. He is known for running meetings with Prussian efficiency, but one complaint is that he sometimes lets discussion drag on for too many weeks before pushing the President to make a decision.
In addition, Mr. Rubin doesn't have the decades of policy background of, say, a Henry Kissinger. He tries to compensate through judgment, hard work and asking thousands of questions. He can often be seen lugging accordion folders stuffed with files, and many nights he takes them back to his suite at the Jefferson Hotel, his Washington residence.
"I've never seen him work so hard," said Kenneth Brody, a former Goldman Sachs partner who is chairman of the Export-Import Bank. "He's never worked like this before."

 
 
THE ROOTS OF ROBERT RUBIN

AT the end of his long days, Robert E. Rubin sometimes seems to miss Goldman Sachs. Talking about his life in Washington, he said: "It's very wearing. It's very job-focused, but at least it's multidimensional because you get involved in so many issues."
Life in New York was "broader," he said, because it wasn't totally focused on work. He spends much more of his time in his office nowadays than he did at Goldman Sachs, where he often traveled.
Mr. Rubin said "the single biggest upside" of his current job is the "quality of the people and the interaction with them," adding that they are "in the same category of exceedingly capable and effective people you find at the top of any profession."
Twenty-eight years at Goldman Sachs was good preparation for his job, he said, because that firm was managed through discussion and consensus: "It was much closer to my experience here than life in a typical corporate hierarchy would be."
Mr. Rubin was born in New York City in 1938 and grew up in Miami Beach, the son of a lawyer. He was graduated from Harvard College (summa cum laude in economics), then spent three days at Harvard Law School before dropping out to see the world. He later studied at the London School of Economics and was graduated from Yale Law School. After Yale, he spent two years at the New York law firm Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.
He joined Goldman as a trader in 1966, and became a young star in risk arbitrage -- speculating on the stocks of companies subject to takeover attempts. He later ran the firm's stock and bond trading departments, and revived its commodities subsidiary. He became co-chairman in 1990.
He and his wife, Judy, who is New York City's chief of protocol, keep an apartment on Park Avenue and a weekend home in Pound Ridge, N.Y., a suburb north of the city. They have two sons, both in their 20's.
Might he return to Goldman Sachs after his White House job? "I've said to myself it's very unlikely I'd go back into the commercial world," he said. He wouldn't elaborate.

HEADLINE: In Mississippi, Riverboat Gambling Rides Rougher Waters

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
MOST folks think of saturation on the Mississippi River these days in terms of the Midwestern floods. But for investors in gambling stocks, it is more likely to refer to the overflow of riverboat casinos in the state of Mississippi.
Companies with riverboat casinos in Mississippi, such as Grand Casinos and Casino Magic, have been among the biggest winners in the market this year, with investors speculating that the hunt by states for new tax dollars will lead many to license casinos. 
 And that is why the stock of Casino Magic, for instance, more than quadrupled this year, closing Friday at $18.25. The company opened its first casino in Mississippi last fall. The company reported first-quarter income of $13.5 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenue of $38.7 million, a profit margin that would make any investor drool.
Of course, by the market's logic, when growth starts to slow, investors should get spooked. That's why the recent monthly revenue numbers from the state and the city of Biloxi, Miss., where most of the riverboat casinos are located, are an investor's equivalent to a Stephen King novel.
The new state and local figures give the first indication that the results could be disappointing. For Biloxi, the gaming revenues climbed an anemic $154,382 in June over May, according to figures from the city's controller's office. But even that was some $850,000 less than April's take.
Even with the gross numbers headed back up, the June report is bad news for investors. Why? Because, as in any bubble market, the growth of casinos continued long after demand was met. In June, the number of slot machines in Biloxi increased by more than 50 percent, growing to 3,500 slots, from about 2,300, according to figures from industry experts and Wall Street analysts.
In other words, revenues are at best flat even as capacity has continued to boom. With more mouths around to divide up the pie, everybody will get a smaller piece. So investors could be seeing the earnings growth in the Biloxi casinos start to stabilize, or even fall.
THINGS are not much better statewide. According to numbers put together by the Mississippi state tax commission, gaming revenue grew by less than $3 million in June from May, to about $61.4 million. But over that time, casino capacity climbed significantly, with the number of slot machines in operation hitting more than 8,000 at the end of June, up from about 6,850 in May.
Air started seeping out of the casino stock bubble last month, with the relatively insignificant news that Casino Magic was shutting its Biloxi operation for two days to allow for an audit. Suddenly, investors who days before could not scoop up enough casino shares started dumping them.
All of the Mississippi riverboat stocks were hit hard. Casino Magic, which had been trading as high as $28 a share in May, dropped to as low as about $20. Grand Casinos, whose shares had traded as high as the $50 range, plummeted in a few trading sessions into the $40 range. President Riverboat Casinos, which had flirted with the $50 range, also fell.
After a couple of weeks of volatile movement, the stocks have been holding relatively stable, as investors await second-quarter results. On Friday, Casino Magic closed at $18.25, Grand Casinos closed at $31.125 and President, at $31.875.
Each of those companies has a different exposure to the vagaries of the Mississippi marketplace. While Grand Casinos has significant operations in the state, its vulnerability to a Mississippi downturn is limited by its other operations, including on Indian reservations. President and Casino Magic both have only one casino each outside the state.
WHILE those three casinos are perhaps the best known in Mississippi, many others, including a number of private operators, have or are planning to set up shop there. In Biloxi alone, one city official said, as many as 30 companies have applied for gambling licenses and at least two are in the initial phases of development. All that means, of course, is even more competition down the line.
Some investors might think the slowdown has something to do with the Mississippi floods. But the damage is not even in the state, and most casinos have announced the catastrophe had no effect on their business.
Of course, the figures do not take into account the fact that every machine was not in operation throughout the entire month. But even when that factor is figured into the equation, the results are ugly.
For example, when the number of slots available in Biloxi on each day of the month are added up for May, there were some 73,000 slot days. That would give the casinos revenue of about $267 per slot day. In June, there were 90,000 slot days available, meaning revenue per slot day dropped to only about $218.
The same holds true for the whole state, where the number of slot days was more than 225,000, compared with about 176,000 in the previous month. That means the total revenue per slot day dropped from about $332 in May, to about $272 in June.
This just foreshadows a consolidation in which some of these players fold, while others rake in more of the pot. Which companies will end up being which is anybody's bet.
