HEADLINE: Profile: Anne K. Bingaman;
Rousing Antitrust Law from Its 12-Year Nap

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
"COULDN'T you publish in September?" says Anne K. Bingaman as she greets a reporter in her new office on the third floor of the Justice Department. "By then things are really going to be happening."
Barely a month in office as the nation's top antitrust cop, Ms. Bingaman has already begun to turn on the lights in an area of law enforcement left in the dark for much of the last 12 laissez-faire years. With her background as a plaintiff's lawyer added to the Administration's expressed commitment to more aggressive enforcement, 1993 could well mark the beginning of a new era in antitrust law -- an era that will find it in a prominent role in international trade policy and the domestic economy. 
 "She's going to bring a more activist approach, there's no question of that," said Robert Pitofsky, a professor at Georgetown University Law Center, who was considered for the antitrust position and who advised the Administration during the transition. "Closer calls are going to be decided in favor of action rather than inaction," distinguishing her era from the Reagan years.
The new assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, who is 50, brings a solid background litigating big cases on behalf of consumers who say they have been forced to pay unreasonable prices and companies victimized by cartels.
Before she came to Washington, Ms. Bingaman's main political interest had been the adoption of laws to protect women's rights, and she notes that she wrote one of the only books about the Equal Rights Amendment.
Her other political cause has been her husband, who is in his second term as a Democratic Senator from New Mexico. Jeff Bingaman is known in Washington as a taciturn and thoughtful politician, a master of detail not known for colorful oratory. While his colleagues may spend many an afternoon brokering deals and attending to the needs of constituents, Mr. Bingaman will often walk the two blocks from his office to the Supreme Court, where he will find a secluded corner of the library to sit and think.
His wife, by contrast, works a room as well as the most seasoned of pols. She has raised millions of dollars for his campaigns, played host at his parties, and is as well known as he is to lawmakers and lobbyists.
"She's sort of supercharged in a positive way; she's a walking series of anecdotes, the kind of person who would slap you on the back," says her old law partner Stuart E. Eizenstat, the former Carter aide just appointed ambassador to the European Community. "You sometimes think she's the politician and Jeff's the lawyer."
Jack H. Friedenthal, a friend of the Bingamans since he taught her at Stanford Law School more than 20 years ago, agrees.
"She's encouraging and enthusiastic and knows how to make people feel good about themselves," said Professor Friedenthal, who is now the dean at the George Washington University National Law Center. The drop in law enforcement "has accompanied a general depression in the antitrust division. She will invigorate that office."
Her political connections, though, at first made some officials skeptical. "When I first heard that the White House was pushing Anne Bingaman, I said, 'Hmmm. Now the White House is pushing a senator's wife on me,' " recalled Attorney General Janet Reno. But Ms. Reno said she called around to some mutual friends, who solidly endorsed the appointment, and in a matter of weeks Ms. Bingaman has become a trusted adviser in an area of law in which the former Florida prosecutor has had virtually no experience. "What she has done in her brief time here is exciting," Ms. Reno says.
THE resumes of Anne Kovacovich Bingaman and Hillary Rodham Clinton look remarkably similar. Both met their future husbands at law school. Both had flourishing law practices as their husbands moved up in state politics. And both have been actively involved in women's and children's causes; they met three years ago working for the Children's Defense Fund.
Ms. Bingaman was born in the mining town of Jerome, Ariz., and grew up in Phoenix, the daughter of a grocer, who, like everyone else in his family, never went to college. There were no professional sports teams within hundreds of miles, so the family passion was talking politics. She decided to become a lawyer, she recalled, because her childhood hero, Adlai Stevenson, was a lawyer.
"Honest to God, I was 9 years old when he lost and cried for three days," she said. "I didn't know what a lawyer even did, but I knew Adlai Stevenson was a lawyer so I wanted to be a lawyer."
After graduating from Stanford, she went to its law school, where she studied antitrust law with William Baxter, the intellectual father of the Reagan Administration's antitrust policy and head of the department during its first three years. After she and Jeff Bingaman graduated, they married and moved back to his home state of New Mexico. They have one son, who is now 13.
When Jeff Bingaman became state Attorney General, she got a job teaching at the University of New Mexico School of Law in Albuquerque after the dean said the school badly needed a woman professor.
SHE led a coalition that successfully pushed for the adoption of New Mexico's Equal Rights Amendment and won an effort to open the New Mexico Military Institute to female cadets. She also served as general counsel to Planned Parenthood, lobbying to ease abortion restrictions.
In 1975, she became involved in a huge and complex lawsuit that was to become well known in antitrust circles. As a lawyer in private practice, she represented a uranium processing company, the United Nuclear Corporation, that alleged the existence of an international uranium cartel. After the defendants failed to produce witnesses and documents that were hidden abroad, a Federal judge entered a judgment in favor of Ms. Bingaman's clients that was valued at the time at about $1 billion.
She has also worked to defend companies against antitrust accusations. In one case, she settled claims against the Supron Energy Company, which was one of several gas companies sued in a class action by residential consumers and the State of New Mexico for alleged price fixing.
Ms. Bingaman began her tenure at the Justice Department by drafting a law to make it easier to bring antitrust cases, particularly against cartels that involve foreign companies and their American counterparts. Officials say she will be leading an effort to sign agreements with the European Community and other countries to make it easier to challenge cross-border transactions. Similar international agreements were used successfully by securities prosecutors to crack large and complex securities-fraud and insider-trading schemes throughout the last decade.
She also vows tougher scrutiny of proposed mergers and better coordination of prosecuting efforts both among Federal agencies and with the states. To husband the division's shrinking resources, she expects to return to the states many nickel-and-dime price-fixing investigations left from the Republicans.
But while the path of antitrust enforcement is changing, it is hard to say just where it is heading. Although Ms. Bingaman has been urged to bring new life to the department, there are some calls for restraint.
There are urgent cries for antitrust exemptions from military companies, which have seen their orders dry up along with the cold war. Executives and policymakers involved in health care say they need to be free of vigorous antitrust enforcement to consolidate the industry and bring down prices. And high-technology companies say they must be allowed to collaborate in research and development to take on foreign rivals.
"She will be under enormous pressure to hold off on enforcement domestically to save jobs, and might be under pressure to enforce antitrust laws against foreigners to save jobs," said Eleanor Fox, an antitrust scholar at New York University School of Law.
Ms. Bingaman has given little hint of her views on the exemptions, other than to say the law generally frowns on exceptions.
"Any exemption to the antitrust laws is unusual," she said during her Senate confirmation hearing in a way that disclosed little of her thinking but seemed to please the panel. "The antitrust laws are very general. Exemptions are not common, and generally the proponents of exemptions bear a heavy burden in justifying their special status."
She also faces a new round of budget cuts. The Administration's proposed budget recommends that an already bare-bones operation be cut by an additional 2 percent, to 635 employees. It now has 310 lawyers in Washington, compared with 411 in 1980.
But she insists the smaller staff will not mean any cuts in the number of lawyers and will not prevent the reemergence of the antitrust division. "We're going to have to do more with less," she said.
 
 
 
A BACKLOG OF LAISSEZ FAIRE
 ANNE BINGAMAN's antitrust approach is likely to mark a sharp departure from the last 12 years. Republican Administrations, putting unquestioned faith in the marketplace, all but abandoned whole areas of antitrust law, cutting the division's resources in half to devote more Federal money and prosecutors to routine drug cases and street crime. Critics said Ronald Reagan did not have to try to repeal antitrust laws because they were simply ignored.
Huge mergers involving rivals in steel and chemicals, oil and airlines, all breezed through unchallenged. The regulators sat on the sidelines as more than $1 trillion in assets changed hands in more than 31,000 deals.
All told, the merger boom meant there were about six times as many corporate combinations each year as in the late 1970's, but the frenzied activity could barely be heard in the halls of the Justice Department. Restraint-of-trade cases fell from 225 in 1979 to 77 in 1991, monopoly investigations from 20 to 5, and merger investigations from 152 to 82. About the only thing the department did was go after price-fixing conspiracies, usually in the electrical and highway construction industries.
"Too much effort has been put on small criminal cases and not enough on larger-concentration issues," Ms. Bingaman said on the day she was appointed. She said the staff reduction and the failure to pursue mergers vigorously was "just appalling."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Washington's Airline Answer: Keep Oil Cheap

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WHAT this country needs is oil price controls. So suggests the Government commission formed to save airlines from the problems brought on by debt, recession and price wars.
Virtually unnoticed in last week's preliminary report of the National Commission to Ensure a Strong Competitive Airline Industry was a recommendation that "when jet fuel prices rise more than 10 percent in any 12-month period, then the U.S. Government shall release crude oil from the [Strategic Petroleum] Reserve to the extent necessary to reduce such prices to the level of a 5 percent increase, provided that such action is not inimical to the national defense or security." 
 Given the historic volatility of oil prices, such a trigger would be reached virtually every year. But that is not the point. Were no lessons learned from the experience of the 1960's, when the Government intervened to support domestic oil prices, and the 1970's, when efforts to hold down oil prices saved consumers little but enriched those who evaded the controls?
Of course, no one asked this commission to worry about the health of the nation. Just that of a bunch of overleveraged airlines, many with inflated expenses, that have reacted to a continued weak economy by cutting fares. The commission recommendations that actually may get accepted involve cutting taxes on the airlines, as if such taxes were the real problem.
In fact, as is often the case by the time the Government lumbers into action, there are indications that the airline crisis, if that is what it is, is passing. The leveraged cripples, with the exception of Northwest, have passed through bankruptcy reorganization or disappeared. Stock prices are rising, fare wars are less severe and the airline unions are discussing concessions.
Wall Street even smiled when the unions demanded majority ownership of airlines in return for allowing the carriers to pay market wages. Shareholders would "end up owning a smaller part of a better company," said Rose Ann Tortora, the airline analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Another factor helping airline shares is that oil prices, far from threatening to rise out of control, are tumbling. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting this week to try to cut production, but, as Bear Stearns oil watcher Fred Leuffer notes, there is scant indication they can reach agreement. Iraq is so desperate for cash that it may actually comply with United Nations requirements to be allowed to sell some oil. And weak European economies are buying less oil than anyone forecast. The futures market price for crude oil to be delivered in September has fallen below $18 a barrel.
Oil prices will rise someday, pushing air fares up and airline profits down. Does the commission really believe that should trigger automatic Government intervention? Or is this recommendation just another case of special interest pleading that, in Washington, seems so natural as to pass almost unnoticed?

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Divining the Market With the Advance-Decline Line

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE advance-decline line is one of the most watched technical indicators of the stock market, and lately some analysts have said it is sending a positive signal. The line, which records the cumulative number of stocks advancing on the New York Stock Exchange, less the number declining, rose to a new high for the current bull market early this month, breaking out of a narrow range that had lasted several months. 
 But that rise has come about largely because many nonstocks traded on the Big Board, ranging from preferred stocks to closed-end bond funds, have risen as interest rates have declined. Paul Desmond, the president of Lowry's Reports Inc., a technical advisory service in North Palm Beach, Fla., notes that the advance-decline line calculated from the stocks of operating companies only hit its 1993 high in March. He notes that the advance-decline lines for Nasdaq and American Stock Exchange issues are also weak. "That kind of deterioration has often led to at least an intermediate market decline," he said.

HEADLINE: Health Care's 'Gang of Five'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Leonard Orland ("Health Reform Runs Antitrust Risk," Viewpoints, July 11) clearly cautions all of us about the importance of antitrust laws. The economic incentives that allowed the "Gang of Five" large national insurance companies -- Aetna, Cigna, Metropolitan Life, Prudential and Travelers -- to gain wealth and power during the last 30 years are precisely those that have placed many of our citizens at unacceptable financial risk when seeking health care today. 
 When health care costs were 3 percent of wages or less, individuals and businesses did not pay attention to the way benefits were designed or paid for by insurance companies. Health insurance traditionally consisted of two parts: the retention and the cost of claims. The retention, in insurance language, is the amount needed to administer the program and to provide profit. The claims are the amounts paid out in benefits.
The retention, for the most part, has been based on the amount of claims paid. If the retention is 10 percent of paid claims, and paid claims increase, the insurer collects more money and makes more profit. The clear incentive of the Gang of Five and others, then, was to write policies that would stimulate employers and patients to spend more.
Think back to when insurance programs insisted that the patient go to the hospital to receive benefits for simple tests like upper GI series, barium enemas and gall bladder X-rays. The hospital, insurers and doctors all benefited. The percentage of wages spent on health care increased. The insurers made more money.
The Gang of Five paid doctors so generously that it was common for physicians to accept whatever they were offered, frequently forgoing co-insurance or deductibles because the payment schedules were so rich. Physicians were not told what fees would be paid. They were told only to keep billing until the fees hit the top. Then the insurer would revise fees upward to "keep pace with inflation." The percentage of wages devoted to health care continued to grow.
Certain large employers began to balk, asking for preferential treatment. The insurers saw one more opportunity -- they would move from community rating to experience rating of premiums. This meant breaking up the large insurance pools. Bigger employers would pay less, smaller employers would pay more. Eventually, everyone would pay their own actual cost and the insurer would avoid all risk. The insurance companies became very expensive administrators and cash managers, no longer willing or able to provide insurance.
H.M.O.'s then came along, skimmed the healthier employees, and shifted the real cost of health care to the sicker patients who remained in the now-fragmented traditional "insurance" programs, making costs rise for everyone.
President Clinton and his advisers now seek to reward these thieves by turning over to them the management of our health. What a terrible proposal! It could permit the Gang of Five to seal the tragic demise of the finest health system in the world in only 30 short years.
 
STEPHEN A. KARDOS
Monmouth Beach, N.J., July 13
 
Dr. Kardos is chief executive of Health Network America Inc., a health management firm.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Taxing and Spending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Thrashing out a Congressional compromise on President Clinton's five-year, $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts, a job that only recently seemed impossible, now looks to be merely Herculean. After the requisite threat displays, House and Senate Democrats moved behind doors last week and made surprising progress toward resolving the $60 billion difference between their separate versions of the economic package. By week's end, about half that gap had been made up, and what once seemed the single prickliest issue on the agenda -- the size of a proposed energy tax -- seemed almost a done deal.
The biggest remaining task is making peace between party conservatives who want more spending cuts and liberals who want more spending, period. So far, House and Senate bargainers have sidestepped that dispute, making speedy progress by splitting the difference on a handful of simple, but big-money, tax items. 
 The energy tax is one. The House once envisioned a broad energy levy that would net $72 billion through 1998; the Senate backs a 4.3-cent-a-gallon, $24 billion gasoline tax. By week's end, the House had scaled back its ambitions to a 9 cent-a-gallon gas tax, and an agreement to meet halfway seemed imminent.
But on spending for Federal benefits to the poor and elderly, an area dear to Mr. Clinton and House liberals, compromise is not so easy. The Senate wants to spend $30 billion less through 1998 on key programs -- $9 billion less for Medicare, $7 billion less for food stamps, some $9 billion less for an expanded tax credit for the working poor. Additionally, Mr. Clinton and the House want to spend $5.3 billion on "empowerment zones," a stew of tax breaks and credits for businesses that move to the inner city. The Senate bill omits the idea.
House and Senate bargainers tried last week to hash out those differences, but the House side left fuming. Representative Charles Rangel, the powerful New York Democrat, complained that the empowerment zones were being gutted of any real incentives to business and suggested that Mr. Clinton would regret it when the time comes to vote on a compromise package.
Much of this is posturing -- staking out positions for the final battles. The truth is that this dispute is largely over whether the Democrats are still Hubert Humphrey's party or the new creature of more pragmatic, not to say hard-hearted, pols. The actual dollar differences are niggling in the context of the $7 trillion the Government will spend through 1998.
The President allowed, in a Tuesday speech before House and Senate negotiators, that his Republican foes have succeeded in persuading the public that the plan is a veiled middle-class tax increase, when in fact, he said, its impact on the average Joe amounts to "a buck a week." Belatedly, Mr. Clinton has set about making speeches and radio talk-show appearances and sending his top aides to schmooze with the press in nonstop briefings.
The President has about two weeks to make his case before Congress's scheduled vote, and lawmakers who heard his speech expressed relief that he is warming to the task. But it remains an uphill battle. "The easy things have been done," Mr. Clinton said last week, referring to Congressional schemes to rein in the deficit in the 1980's. But he could just as easily have been talking about the job of bolting together an economic package that can mollify both Congress and the American people.

HEADLINE: JULY 18-24;
Business Losses and Personal Anguish

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
This spring, Binh Nguyen realized his dream of opening a Vietnamese restaurant in the small town of Coralville, Iowa. But his 70-seat restaurant had been open only a couple of months when the Clear Creek overflowed behind the one-story wood building, drenching the carpet.
Mr. Nguyen closed the restaurant. He and his 17-year-old son, Hieu, cleaned the carpet, dried the building out and reopened on July 6. Later the same day, the creek overflowed again, this time rising until it reached the window sills. The water has not receded since then, and is not expected to do so for another two weeks because it flows into the swollen Iowa River. Mr. Nguyen has laid off both his waitresses and is worrying about who will lend the additional $12,000 he needs to reopen yet again. 
 Many Midwestern businesses are struggling to survive this summer's epic floods, laying off thousands of workers. When the Labor Department on Thursday announced a jump in new claims for unemployment, part of the blame was placed on the floods.
The Des Moines Chamber of Commerce last week estimated lost sales in the city at $525 million, compared with $182 million in physical damage to businesses. City water began flowing again on Thursday, 12 days after a rise in the Raccoon River disabled the water-treatment plant.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why Politics, as Usual, Is Not Helping the Mentally Ill

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
BY Albany standards, the recent jockeying between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature over mental health financing has made for an exceptional game of political chess. But the debate at the heart of the maneuvering -- how to shift money away from costly psychiatric hospitals and into community mental health services -- has been played out in virtually every state capital, and rarely with resounding success.
The tragic result has been a big imbalance between supply and demand for community mental health services in most states. Because of the nexus between mental illness, homelessness, substance abuse and crime, the costs to society and government have been immense. 
 In New York, at least, the dilemma takes on the feel of a crisis every few years when the case of a disturbed homeless person like Larry Hogue captivates the public. But in reality, the quiet crisis caused by inadequate community care has persisted since the mid-1950's, when states began to empty their pscyhiatric hospitals.
What makes the predicament so exasperating is the virtual consensus among psychiatrists and policy makers that community mental health programs work, not necessarily to cure patients but to allow large numbers of them to live meaningfully outside of institutions. Their success has been frustrated not by medicine, but by the interrelated obstacles of politics and money.
Those obstacles always loom larger during bad economic times. But the situation is fast becoming more urgent because the number of American adults with mental disorders is expected to increase by 14 percent between 1990 and 2010, to nearly 32.8 million.
Mental health advocates argue that change must come quickly before the system is utterly overwhelmed. "The system is crazier than the people it's trying to serve," said Laurie Flynn, executive director of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill.
 
New Medication and Patient Rights
 Since its peak in 1955, the population of state psychiatric hospitals around the nation has declined from 559,000 to fewer than 100,000. New York's dropped from about 90,000 to about 10,500. Psychotropic medication, court decisions expanding patients' rights, and Federal programs that paid for the care of elderly patients in nursing homes led to a wave of deinstitutionalization.
But because hospitals have proved to be powerful constituents and the mentally ill are not, money has not always followed patients into the community. States now are struggling to make it do so.
Small states like New Hampshire, Vermont and Rhode Island, which carry less of a burden, have had the most success. Larger states have had more difficulty. Mental health officials in Los Angeles County, for instance, estimate that they can meet only half the need for community services. Two years ago, California tied mental health financing to its sales tax, just in time for the recession.
Wisconsin, on the other hand, is considered a model among larger states. In 1974, it decentralized its system so that counties took primary responsibility for deciding how to spend state money, which was allocated by formula. That provided incentives for counties to reduce their use of expensive hospital beds and expand community programs.
In Dane County, home of Madison, psychiatrists created a program in which caseworkers provide intensive support and monitoring for patients in the community. Only about 50 of the 1,300 patients in the county system require long-term inpatient care.
"If you don't have to keep people in places that cost $500 a day, you can do an awful lot," said Dr. Leonard I. Stein, a University of Wisconsin professor of psychiatry and a founder of the program.
Since 1988, Ohio has tried to replicate the Wisconsin model with mixed success. It has cut its hospital population from 3,800 to 2,000, said Michael F. Hogan, the state mental health director. "But the redistribution of funding has eroded the purchasing power of the mental health department within the state budget," he said. "About 39 cents of every dollar saved by hospital downsizing is being lost to the mental health system."
The situation is similar in New York, and has given rise to an unprecedented, and politically nettlesome, proposed solution.
Hours before recessing on July 8, New York's Legislature passed a bill that would require the state to take a set amount of money each time a bed is closed in a hospital and funnel it to community mental health programs.
Advocates hailed the bill as a godsend. But Mr. Cuomo has threatened to veto it, saying the bill would tie his hands in the budget-making process, would not require closing of any of the state's 22 psychiatric hospitals, and would not earmark spending for the mentally ill homeless.
From the 1988-89 fiscal year to the 1993-94 fiscal year, annual state spending on New York's psychiatric hospitals decreased by $184.4 million, according to the Office of Mental Health. But spending from the state general fund on community mental health programs increased during that period by only $86 million.
In a 1986 speech, Mr. Cuomo paid tribute to "reducing the size of our psychiatric centers to finance much of the cost of community expansion."
But the mid-1980's were fat years, and recession turned tribute into temptation. With little confidence in Albany, or Sacramento or Columbus, that the future will be better, there may be insufficient will to pay what even Mr. Cuomo admits is a growing debt to the mentally ill.

HEADLINE: A Rare Tern Sets the Blood Racing for Birders

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE MAY, N.J., July 22

 BODY:
The bulletin, on telephone hot lines in all 50 states and an international computer network, arrived like a thunderclap.
"It made the blood race with excitement," said Paul Kerlinger, director of the Cape May Bird Observatory, who helped spread the word. 
 Within hours, hundreds of people around the nation dropped what they were doing and raced off in cars or headed for airports, praying they could get to Cape May before it was too late.
"It was the most electrifying news in years," said Macklin Smith, a professor of medieval literature at the University of Michigan, who hopped a jet to New Jersey.
The object of all the attention was a 10-inch-long blur of gray and white feathers beneath a black cap, listed in bird directories as a whiskered tern (Chlidonias hybridus).
Flitting about in a marshy meadow near the Cape May lighthouse, it closely resembled terns familiar to the region. But the whiskered tern, common in Europe, Africa and Asia, had never been seen in North America. A birdwatcher from Britain who caught the tern in his binoculars before sundown on July 11 couldn't believe his eyes.
It was as if climbers ascending Mount Everest had come across a Central Park pigeon panhandling peanuts.
For most of the 20 million or so Americans whose interest in birds goes beyond stocking a backyard feeder, the pleasures of identifying wildfowl by sight and sound are enough of a payoff. In recent years, however, what was once seen as a lonely but serene pursuit has increasingly set competitive juices flowing.
Those who have the time and money to roam the continent to track down rarely seen species are gaining star quality. Winging It, a publication of the American Birdwatching Association, now ranks the most accomplished birders in the nation by the numbers they claim to have seen or heard.
Among birders, the yearly ratings are anticipated like the Oscars, with a mix of admiration, envy and dismissiveness.
North America has about 850 of the 8,700 bird species in the world, and spotting 700 on this continent puts a birdwatcher into a very exclusive club. Topping 800 is a feat accomplished only by the Babe Ruths and Hank Aarons of birddom.
Professor Smith, currently ranked No. 4 among the top spotters of North American birds, at present has 801 species on his lifetime list, the most recent being a spot-billed duck he spied in the Aleutian Islands of Alaska this spring.
 
Moving Up in the Rankings
 Seeing the whiskered tern in Cape May gives Professor Smith a chance to move ahead of the current No. 3 in the ranks -- also listing 801 sightings -- once the sighting is officially confirmed, which he said was almost a certainty.
Adding to his pleasure was word that Benton Basham, a Kentucky anesthesiologist who currently ranks No. 1 with 810 sightings, arrived in Cape May too late to see the whiskered tern and when last heard from was slogging after it in a Delaware coastal marsh.
Professor Smith, who took up birding as a graduate student at Princeton 20 years ago, cheerfully describes himself "as one of the ones most obsessed with birding."
He at first ignored the published rankings, uncomfortable at calling attention to himself. "It seems ostentatious, but on the other hand, why hide your accomplishment?" he rationalized.
Cheating is not unheard of, but those who comes up with repeated claims of very rare birds not seen by anyone else quickly lose credibility and are ignored, said several experts.
"What more often happens is that people are mistaken about what they've seen or heard," said Joan Walsh, a biologist at the Cape May Bird Observatory, which operates the refuge where the whiskered tern was first spotted.
 
Sometimes, a 'Goofy' Sighting
 "But strange things happen," she added. "A while back, a man with a very good reputation was fishing alone on the Manasquan Inlet jetty when he looked up and spotted an albatross in front of him.
"No one would ever suspect him of making up a goofy story of seeing an albatross on the other side of the world where it's supposed to be. He has no camera, no binoculars and has no one with him to verify a North American first. But his good reputation, plus the unmistakable size of the albatross, left no doubt in anyone's mind that he had seen it."
Competition in birding reaches its height in several states every spring when teams fan out to see who can count the most species in 24 hours. These events help raise money for conservation by getting nonparticipants to pledge donations for each kind of bird a team finds.
In New Jersey the annual event is called the World Series of Birding. The winning team this year had a score of 215 species, counted in an exhausting dash across the state that required complex logistical planning to get the team to prime viewing locations ranging from mountains to cities to seashore.
Given a bird's ability to relocate with a few wing beats, reaching the scene of a sighting quickly is crucial. Most ardent birders carry lists of friends or other bird enthusiasts they will immediately telephone with news of a special bird in their area; some even carry beepers.
 
Hot Lines and Networks
 Now there are bird hot lines in every state operated by volunteers of organizations like the Audubon Society, with tape-recorded messages reporting recent sightings updated every week. Moreover, the North American Rare Bird Alert hot line puts out bulletins over an 800 number (1-800-458-BIRD), and a computer network called BirdChat, which has subscribers as far away as Moscow, enables birders to communicate with one another and to flash important messages.
"BirdChat is closely monitored by lots of people who chase birds," said Norman Saunders, a Federal Department of Labor economist who helped set up the network two years ago. "When they get back from their conquest, the message board is filled with bragging."
Word of the whiskered tern began spreading the evening it was sighted, and by the next morning was carried by the Rare Bird Alert and state hot lines, in addition to BirdChat.
Not since a rare Arctic bird, a Ross's gull, showed up at a Baltimore sewage treatment plant a few years back had the world of birdwatching been so jolted.
Cape May is one of the hottest birdwatching sites in the nation, thanks to its location at the end of a peninsula that about this time of year begins to funnel millions of birds in a southward migration from northern nesting areas.
Just how the solitary whiskered tern managed to cross the Atlantic to reach these shores is something of a mystery. Mr. Kerlinger, speculates it may have become addled by "an aberrant compass," and presumably crossed the entire width of the ocean, pausing to rest on its surface.
Unfortunately, he said, it is as unlikely to recross the ocean as it is to find a mate here, and a lonely and uncharted future lies before it.

HEADLINE: Immigrants Forgoing Citizenship While Pursuing American Dream

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
For most of his 12 years in this country, Armando Espinosa, an immigrant from Ecuador, had absolutely no intention of becoming a United States citizen. What would be the purpose? he asked himself. With a green card in his wallet, he led a comfortable life in Queens, working as an industrial mechanic while his two children flourished in public schools. He certainly did not consider himself American.
"I am Ecuadorean in my blood and my gut," he said. "I do not even like apple pie." 
 Mr. Espinosa was hardly alone in his thinking. Unlike 50 years ago, when the majority of immigrants routinely sought to naturalize, only slightly more than a third of legal permanent residents now apply to become citizens. Although advocates for immigrants believe that the tide is turning, most immigrants now exist in a state of legal limbo, many nourished by the dream, often an illusion, that they will someday return home.
 
'Not Healthy for Democracy'
 Numbering up to 10 million nationally, these immigrants form a growing population of tax-paying residents without the right to vote or to serve on juries, police forces or in many Federal jobs. At a time when ethnic and racial tensions are fracturing the harmony of many cities, the immigrants' status -- seen by some as an unfair disenfranchisement and by others as a failure to integrate -- has become a cause of concern.
"You don't want a city composed of isolated pockets of immigrants who belong to a subculture and not to the larger society," said Sean R. Benson, executive director of the nonprofit Emerald Isle Immigration Center in Queens and the Bronx. "It's not healthy for them or for democracy."
Legal immigrants are eligible for citizenship after five years in the country, or after three years if they are married to a citizen. The reasons that most do not naturalize are complex, ranging from their close ties to home in the age of jet travel and long-distance telephone calls to their fear of the citizenship interview -- in which immigration officials may challenge them to "Name the order in which the 13 colonies came into the union" or "Explain the stripes on the American flag."
"It's easier to exist in limbo between two worlds," said Margie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigration Coalition. "Because people can come and go more easily, they are not forced to make the ultimate choice of where they want to pledge their allegiance."
With the help of officials in cities like New York, however, advocates like Ms. McHugh are aggressively selling the advantages of citizenship on the radio and in community workshops -- just as New York City textbooks used to promote Americanization in the early part of the century.
Already, owing as well to changes in the application process, more New York immigrants are applying for citizenship than at any point in the recent past. Over the last year applications to the New York office of the immigration service have increased by 70 percent. At the same time a small industry catering to, and sometimes exploiting, applicants has arisen, with nonprofit groups offering free civics classes while for-profit stores charge exorbitant rates to help immigrants fill out the forms.
Starting in November the number of applicants is expected to swell as the three million immigrants granted amnesty under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 become eligible for citizenship. In a recent, typical month, about 8,000 of them called the National Association of Latino Elected Officials to inquire about the process.
"I think we will see a very dynamic citizenship movement build in the next decade, with millions of people coming forward, spurred by the folks who received amnesty," said Frank Sharry, executive director of the National Immigration, Refugee and Citizenship Forum.
 
Attitude Changes Slowly
 Mr. Espinosa's attitude toward citizenship slowly evolved. As his children -- one born in the United States -- became Americanized, he found himself increasingly interested in the laws and politics of his new country. He could no longer vote in Ecuador and he could not vote in the United States. He began to feel like a man without a nation, he said.
Slowly angered by what he saw as the political weakness of Hispanic residents, Mr. Espinosa said he felt guilty. "If people like me retain our allegiances to home and refuse to participate in electoral politics here," he said, "the lot of our race will never improve."
Just as Mr. Espinosa changed his thinking with time, so too have immigrant groups, particularly as inner-city ethnic tensions flared and anti-immigrant sentiment intensified. In the last few years it has become a priority for Hispanic and Asian groups, as well as for politicians in newly created minority districts, to convert immigrants to citizens and then register them to vote.
"Our political power will be thwarted if we don't transform into citizens the immigrants who right now, technically, don't count," said Luis Miranda, director of the Hispanic Federation of New York City.
 
National Identity
 Because immigration is at peak levels, the numbers of legal immigrants who apply for citizenship are still substantial, about 300,000 a year. But the proportions are low. About 37 percent apply for citizenship, compared with about 67 percent in 1946, according to Immigration and Naturalization Service statistics.
Immigrants who find it harder to return home for visits -- political refugees and those who come from farther away -- are likeliest to become citizens. Vietnamese refugees are eight times as likely to naturalize than economic migrants from Canada, for instance.
And while slightly more than half the immigrants from the former Soviet Union and China become citizens, only 18 percent of Dominicans and 28 percent of Jamaicans do so, according to the New York City Planning Department. (Those four places sent the most immigrants to New York City in 1992.)
"You have to understand that many immigrants feel lost and diminished when they come to this country," said Saramaria Archila, a Colombian immigrant and executive director of the Latin American Integration Center. "What they have left is their national identity, and they are loathe to give that up."
 
Photos and Fingerprints
 Only about 20 percent of the immigrants from Mr. Espinosa's homeland renounce their official ties to Ecuador and swear allegiance to the United States. And that low percentage worries him.
So after learning on Spanish-language radio about a citizenship campaign in Queens, Mr. Espinosa ventured out on a recent weekend to the storefront headquarters of the Latin American Integration Center, a nonprofit community group, in Woodside. Volunteers fingerprinted and photographed him.
They also helped him fill out the Immigration and Naturalization Service application, which asks a dizzying array of questions, some personal, some political, some arcane.
They include: "Have you ever knowingly committed a crime for which you have not been arrested? Have you ever been a habitual drunkard? Have you ever advocated or practiced polygamy? During the period March 23, 1933, to May 8, 1945, did you serve in, or were you in any way affiliated with the Nazi Government of Germany?"
 
Eight-Month Wait
 Because the New York offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn have a backlog of applicants, Mr. Espinosa will have to wait about eight months for his interview with one of the 25 examiners who each conduct up to 40 interviews a day. The examiner will ask him civics questions, evaluate his spoken English and dictate a sentence for him to write as a test of his written English.
Over the decades, the interview for citizenship has achieved notoriety based on the experiences of immigrants who have encountered hostile or arbitrary examiners. Immigrant groups say that fear of the interview -- especially the English proficiency component -- keeps many people from applying.
A survey of Hispanic immigrants by the National Association of Latino Elected Officials showed that 56 percent had started the application process, but only 33 percent completed it.
"We have eliminated voter literacy exams in the South, but we still retain the tradition of arbitrariness in testing for the citizenship exams," said Harry Pachon, executive director of the Latino officials' organization. "Examiners can make the process a living hell. They can obviously overstep their discretionary authority, as in one instance where someone was asked if they ever had sex before marriage. Or they can perversely ask the kind of civics questions that most Americans could not answer."
 
A Standardized Exam
 To counter complaints of arbitrariness, the Immigration and Naturalization Service began last year to offer immigrants the option of taking a standardized citizenship exam created by the Educational Testing Service, which administers college entrance exams. The citizenship exams are administered and graded by community groups, and immigrants who pass are only briefly interviewed by Immigration and Naturalization Service examiners.
Some problems have arisen at the community test sites, particularly those based in for-profit offices, said Rose Chapman, the chief of naturalization for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York. One group in the Bronx is under investigation for charging immigrants $400 for the $16 test and promising a passing grade. Another in Queens passed almost all its test takers, but the dictation responses on the exams were all written in the same handwriting.
Some 60,000 immigrants nationally have taken the exam in the last 17 months. About 15 percent of the applicants in New York City opt for the exam, accounting for a significant increase in the citizenship applications.
Another increase resulted when the immigration service required longtime legal immigrants to exchange their dated green cards for new ones at a cost of $70. Many -- about 7,000 people in New York City -- decided to pay $20 more and become a citizen as long as they had to face the Immigration and Naturalization Service once more. And about 3,500 immigrants indicated that they were moved to come forward so they could qualify to become a New York City police officer, Ms. Chapman said.
 
Feeling Torn
 Lucia Alvarez, a Guatemalan immigrant who works for the city's Human Resources Administration, said that after 13 years in this country the decision was a troubling one despite her gratitude toward the United States.
"I feel bad, torn, toward my country, as if I'm abandoning it," Ms. Alvarez said. "It's like denying something about yourself."
Still, as a citizen, Ms. Alvarez will be able to sponsor her mother to join her in this country without the difficulties she has experienced for years.
"There's no turning back now, I guess," Ms. Alvarez said, as she sealed the envelope with her photos, her fingerprints and the details of her life and character.

HEADLINE: Japan's Leadership Fight Sets Off Difficult Shifts

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 24

 BODY:
By the time Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa left a crucial meeting of the Liberal Democratic Party on Thursday, this aging strategist in Japan's postwar economic miracle had resigned and suffered a humiliating verbal assault that left him looking sadly out of touch.
He had been beaten in a vast power play, but perhaps more important to the political shifts under way here, Mr. Miyazawa's fall symbolized a deep philosophical change slowly gaining momentum, which some believe could affect Japan more than the next choice of prime minister. 
 In this chaotic encounter between the old guard and a newer generation, a number of politicians, historians and economists agree, Japan was bidding a tortured farewell to its last postwar Prime Minister -- and, just maybe, to the rigid adherence to a set of principles that have left Japan an oddly unbalanced economic superpower.
The new leaders are generally more comfortable with at least discussing the idea of Japan's accepting all of the burdens of membership in the global community, and of changing the Japanese economy's emphasis on producers at the expense of consumers.
As a young bureaucrat in the late 1950's, Mr. Miyazawa helped formulate -- and then as a longtime politician embodied -- the policies that lifted Japan spectacularly from the ashes of World War II. Japan built a military of modest proportions and agreed to follow the lead of the United States on all issues of security and international politics, focusing instead on economic development under the firm guidance of well-trained bureaucrats.
This is often referred to as the Yoshida doctrine, after the pre-eminent figure of the late 1940's and early 1950's, Prime Minister Shigeru Yoshida.
Those policies eventually left Japan deeply mistrusted because of its yawning trade imbalances, and still struggling 48 years after World War II to articulate an independent security and foreign policy. The Yoshida doctrine also left Japan increasingly at odds with the United States, particularly under the more aggressive economic policies of President Clinton.
"Miyazawa is the last of the generation that came up under the direct influence of Yoshida," said John W. Dower, a professor of Japanese history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and author of a definitive study of the Yoshida era. "It was a policy of economic nationalism under the eagle's wing. It worked. But psychologically it has been hard to break from the subordinate independence that policy created."
 
Unchallenged Orthodoxy
 While it was clear even before the end of the cold war that the ambiguous Yoshida legacy was starting to work against Japanese interests -- with growing trade frictions and Japan's halting response to international crises like the Persian Gulf war -- the doctrine became a kind of orthodoxy that, many politicians and other experts say, few politicians could question openly.
It was just a few years ago, for instance, that a leading political scientist, Yonosuke Nagai, wrote, "The Yoshida doctrine will be permanent."
For the most part, the leaders vying to replace Mr. Miyazawa, many of whom are defectors from the Liberal Democratic Party, endorse only incremental changes in the policies. Because of public distrust of the military, there is a powerful strain of pacifism that still runs through the new generation, and an unwillingness to bend to every American demand on trade. Of course, the current battle to choose a new prime minister is being waged not in terms of philosophies, but power alignments and personalities.
Some of the new leaders have been willing to discuss directly issues that were all but taboo during the four decades of Liberal Democratic rule.
Morihiro Hosokawa, head of the Japan New Party and a strong candidate to become prime minister in a coalition government, has said he would consider opening Japan's rice market. Tsutomu Hata, head of the Japan Renewal Party, has promised that he would extend full apologies to Japan's Asian neighbors for World War II, something the postwar leaders refused to do. The Harbinger Party has said it would review the constitutional limits on Japan's taking part in collective security arrangements.
 
Some Want Deregulation
 There are even some younger members of the Liberal Democratic Party who have said they are committed to pushing for full economic deregulation.
"Our position is that there is no need for the bureaucracy to play this paternalistic role over business," said Seiichi Ota, 47, a Liberal Democrat who delivered some of the most fiery lines against Mr. Miyazawa at the meeting on Thursday. "They should just watch out to make sure there is fair competition."
Because Mr. Yoshida has cast such a long shadow over policy making here, some of the new leaders have sought to reinterpret his philosophy rather than discard it.
"Some have the opinion that we should not change the doctrine because Prime Minister Yoshida established the policies of giving priority to the economy, and they were successful," wrote Ichiro Ozawa, co-founder of Mr. Hata's party and the most aggressive of those wanting to alter the security and economic agendas. "But this is wrong. Prime Minister Yoshida was only making a political choice of giving priority to the economy as a cold war strategy. It is not based on his political philosophy, nor is it an unchanging political principle."
Even some of those who helped make the Yoshida doctrine a success are starting to argue that the legacy may be doing more harm than good.
 
'At a Loss What to Do'
 "The successors to the Yoshida era are at a loss about what to do and where to go," said Naohiro Amaya, a former top official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry who was instrumental in designing Japan's successful industrial policies. "I think we are in for a long period of trial and error. But I do know that sticking to the status quo means suicide."
He added: "The Yoshida doctrine was a response to a particular situation. But the situation has changed."
Another source of pressure for change is big business. Many industrialists who are active internationally now say the Japanese economy discriminates against foreigners and should be strengthened by introducing more competition and lifting the heavy hand of the bureaucracy. Akio Morita, the chairman of Sony, argued recently that the Japanese markets were a sort of fortress, and that the walls had to be torn down.
The Liberal Democratic Party has been depicted for so long as little more than a corrupt money machine that many have forgotten that it was built in 1955 with a firm intellectual anchor in the principles set out under the conservative Mr. Yoshida.
Under his tenure, which came to an end in 1954, Japan regained its sovereignty from the United States under the San Francisco peace treaty and ended the American occupation. But its independence was still limited by a series of compromises and bargains that Mr. Yoshida drove with the Washington.
 
Forced to Rearm
 After the outbreak of the cold war, and then the Korean War, the United States forced Japan to abandon its pacifism and rearm. Japan reluctantly agreed, but on condition that its military would have no offensive ability and that military spending would remain modest. The United States maintained huge bases on Japanese soil, and Japan agreed to follow the American lead on security and political issues.
In return, Mr. Yoshida sought to rebuild the economy swiftly by tilting toward producers, not consumers. This one-sided pursuit of economic gain led to the adoption by many economists and historians of the phrase "neo-mercantilism" to describe Japan's efforts to increase its wealth through exports.
"Yoshida himself was denying at the time that this was a long-term strategy," said Kenneth B. Pyle, an historian at the University of Washington and the author of a book published last year evaluating the Yoshida legacy. "He was just responding to the circumstances and wanted to help with economic recovery."
He added: "As long as the cold war was on, it worked beautifully. They had this sort of cocoon the United States built for them. But it led to a loss of self-respect."
To be sure, there have been some important steps away from the most extreme interpretations of the Yoshida doctrine in recent years. Japan has sought and received an assurance that the United States will back its bid for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, for instance. The Government has taken a variety of steps to loosen protection of the domestic market, opening up to products ranging from computer chips to oranges.
Parliament also passed the emotionally charged bill permitting Japan to send troops abroad for the first time since World War II and take part in United Nations peacekeeping operations.
But the real drive for this bill was said to have come from Mr. Ozawa, who has since left the party, not Mr. Miyazawa. Against the resistance of the old guard, Mr. Ozawa began a discussion group several years ago to debate the merits of Japan's so-called Peace Constitution and the country's stunted security and military policies.
"Until recently, we couldn't even discuss this issue," Mr. Ota said.
Finally, with the last of those who personally remember Mr. Yoshida now stepping off the political stage, one-party rule ending for the first time in 38 years, corporate Japan pressing for a more open economy and the Clinton Administration serving notice that it will be unrelenting in attacking what it sees as unfair trade practices, the debate over a new set of policy principles has begun in earnest.

Mr. Yoshida, second from left, led supporters at a rally in 1950. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pathologist Says Police Blows Didn't Cause Death

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 24

 BODY:
Blows to the head could not have been the sole cause of a motorist's death, despite an autopsy that says the man was fatally beaten by police officers, a pathologist has testified.
The chief medical examiner for Oakland County, Dr. Ljubisa Dragovic, testified Thursday at the officers' trial that his review of the autopsy materials showed that there was no swelling of the motorist's brain, a finding that he said would be essential to show that the man, Malice Green, had died of trauma from being struck by blunt objects. 
 "If there is no such thing, then that mechanism of death is out," Dr. Dragovic testified. He added that Mr. Green's death was caused by a combination of cocaine and alcohol use and bruising of the brain. Dr. Dragovic, testifying for the defense, was to return to the stand on Monday for cross-examination.
 
Autopsy Report Is Faulted
 Mr. Green, 35, died on Nov. 5 after a confrontation with Officers Larry Nevers and Walter Budzyn, both of whom have since been dismissed.
The autopsy, prepared by the Wayne County assistant medical examiner, Kalil Jiraki, showed that Mr. Green had died of at least 14 blows to the head in a beating that tore off part of his scalp.
Photographs and tissue showed that Mr. Green's brain was bruised, Dr. Dragovic said, but he concluded that Dr. Jiraki's autopsy was incomplete and his conclusion wrong.
The death, Dr. Dragovic said, was caused by the combined effects of cocaine, alcohol and the bruising, which together brought on a fatal seizure.
Dr. Dragovic, who works in suburban Detroit, said the beating alone would not have been enough to cause death. A toxicology report showed that Mr. Green had both alcohol and cocaine in his blood.
Mr. Budzyn, 47, and Mr. Nevers, 52, are charged with second-degree murder. A third former officer, Robert Lessnau, 33, is accused of assault.
The three defendants, who were dismissed from the department after Mr. Green's death, are white. Mr. Green, an unemployed steelworker, was black. His death raised racial tensions in Detroit, but there has been no testimony that race was a motive in the beating.
 
Evidence Is Examined
 The three defendants are being tried together. But Mr. Budzyn and Mr. Nevers have separate juries, and Mr. Lessnau's case will be decided by Judge George Crockett 3d of Detroit Recorder's Court.
Dr. Dragovic said he first became aware that there were problems with the autopsy after a reporter faxed him parts of the reports. In April, Dr. Dragovic and a defense lawyer, Fred Walker, went to the Wayne County Medical Examiner's office in Detroit to look at photographs and samples of brain tissue, the doctor said.
Those reports, Dr. Dragovic testified, showed that there was no fracture of Mr. Green's skull and no fluid in his lungs. He said those findings would also be needed to show that Mr. Green died of blunt-force trauma.
"There is a simple gap between what was seen in the photographs, what was described in the reports and the conclusion that was reached," he said.
"I found, there and then, upon reviewing the photos of the brain itself and the tissue that blunt-force trauma could not and cannot be taken as the sole cause of death in the case," Dr. Dragovic said.

HEADLINE: FILIBUSTER DELAYS SERVICE MEASURE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
Senate Republicans have mounted their fourth major filibuster of the year, refusing to agree to schedule a vote on the $394 million-a-year national service bill, which they attack as a case of tax and spend.
By warring against the bill, whose concept of offering educational grants in exchange for public service is generally popular in the country, the Republicans stepped up their general delaying and harassment campaign against Democratic legislation. The tactic risks being labeled obstructionism but offers the hope of rendering the new Democratic Administration legislatively impotent. 
 The national service measure would authorize educational grants of up to $5,000 a year to as many as 150,000 Americans in exchange for their agreement to tutor grade school students, help senior citizens or perform other public services. The concept was emphasized in President Clinton's campaign last fall and, although it has been significantly scaled back since then, it is a priority for Congressional Democrats.
Eli Segal, a White House aide who is heading the effort for the program, said yesterday, "This is about something other than national service." He said that many Republican senators favored the measure and that small changes could be made to meet their objections but he would not speculate further as to why Republicans were actually filibustering.
 
With Increasing Vigor
 The bill has been debated since Tuesday, and Republicans have fought with increasing vigor. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said the amendments they demanded as a price for allowing the final vote would gut the bill.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said Friday in an interview that his party was filibustering this bill because it clearly fit within their attack on Democrats as a tax-and-spend party.
He called the national service bill an example of "willy-nilly mortgaging our future" and of "increasing spending over here while raising taxes over there" in a House-Senate budget conference. But Senator Mitchell said in an interview in Portland, Me., yesterday, "It's another example of Republican obstructionism, of trying to prevent action even though a majority of Americans, a majority of Congress and a majority of the Senate want action."
It takes 60 votes to shut off debate in the Senate, and a vote on a motion to do that is scheduled for Tuesday morning. But Mr. Dole said he had the 41 votes he needed to block that action from among the 44 Republicans in the Senate. Mr. Mitchell said he did not know how the vote would come out.
 
3 Other Targets
 There have been three other major filibusters earlier this year. Republicans killed the $19.3 billion economic-stimulus bill in April. They forced major changes in the campaign-finance bill and in the measure easing voter registration rules before allowing those measures to come to a vote. But they made a strategic decision not to filibuster the highly popular family-leave bill in February.
Senator Mitchell said that by filibustering now the Republicans were trying to take advantage of the Senate's need to spend some time on appropriations bills before the August recess. He said this bill should have "nothing to do with partisan politics."
Full-fledged filibusters are not the only Republican delaying tactics on Capital Hill. Senate Republicans threatened a filibuster and refused to let amendments to the Hatch Act allowing greater political activity by Federal workers go to a House Senate conference.
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, invoked rarely used Senate rules on Friday to delay a hearing on the nomination of Joycelyn Elders to be Surgeon General, although the hearing was later concluded.
 
Flood-Relief Bill Blocked
 And House Republicans on Friday blocked action on a flood-relief bill, complaining that treating the measure as an emergency bill, thus exempting it from Federal budget limits, would lead to higher Federal deficits.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, floor manager of the national-service bill, insisted Friday that "a fair compromise is certainly possible. It would produce additional support needed to pass the bill in spite of the threat of a filibuster." Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, the senior Republican on Mr. Kennedy's Labor and Human Resources Committee, said she did not favor a filibuster. But it is not clear whether she will vote against it, and if she abstains, the effect will be the same as a vote backing the filibuster.
The bill's $394 million price tag is for the program's first year, and Mr. Segal said that is expected to pay for 20,000 to 25,000 participants. The bill puts no limits on future spending, but Mr. Clinton has spoken of a goal of 150,000 volunteers by 1997, which might cost about $3 billion.
The bill is greatly scaled down, for budget reasons, from the measure Mr. Clinton described in the fall campaign. He hoped to involve millions of participants and to provide larger grants than the $5,000 in this bill and in a companion bill the House is debating.
Under the Senate bill, participants would also get living allowances pegged to the minimum wage, health care and child care, if necessary. The $5,000 grants would be available for up to two years. Many programs would be financed through grants to state agencies.

HEADLINE: Town Rallies Behind Boys Who Killed Father

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RUSH SPRINGS, Okla., July 22

 BODY:
Rush Springs is the kind of place, as people say about countless small towns across America, where people know about it when you're born and care about it when you die.
Except when Lonnie Dutton died last week. People here seem to care a lot more about gaining freedom for his accused killers -- his son Herman, who just finished the eighth grade here, and his son Druie, who finished the fifth. 
 There are blue ribbons tied to every lamp post on Main Street and to countless mailboxes in this farm town of 1,400 people in southwestern Oklahoma, all stitched by a group of mothers who want the authorites to drop murder charges against the boys.
Just after dawn today, dozens of cars and pickup trucks sporting blue bumper stickers reading "Friends of Herman and Druie Dutton -- We Support You!" formed a caravan and drove 18 miles to Chickasha, where the occupants rallied outside a closed court hearing for the boys.
The two slight, blond-haired youths shot their father with a deer rifle on July 12, when he was four days short of his 40th birthday, as he lay dozing on a sofa in the family trailer at the edge of town. After calling for an ambulance and reporting that someone had shot their father, the boys quickly broke down and told neighbors that they had done it because they were tired of his beatings and of watching him sexually molest their 10-year-old sister, Alicia.
 
Authorities Are Faulted
 While there have been a growing number of cases of children killing parents who they say abused them, what makes the Dutton case so unusual is the town's extraordinary show of support for the boys.
Many residents say the boys were simply too frightened to tell the authorities what was happening. At the same time, family counselors and the school principal say the boys' action points up a failure of the authorities to provide them with a way to free themselves from abuse.
Mr. Dutton, who had been known as a bully since his high school days here, had long been suspected of beating the children.
"One of the things that needs to be brought out is that a lot of people were very afraid of my brother, including me," said Linda Munn, Mr. Dutton's sister, to thunderous applause at a town meeting several days ago at which 200 people turned out to vent their feelings about the incident.
She said that nobody should blame the boys for all the times they had denied that their father was hurting them, even when teachers asked about their bruises or agents of the State Department of Human Services came to investigate.
"They learned, 'If I cry, I get hurt,' " Mrs. Munn said. "They dared not tell. They knew better than to say anything to anybody."
 
6 Official Visits to Home
 On at least six occasions, officials said, investigators with the county sheriff's office or the human services agency went to the Dutton trailer but did not find sufficient evidence of abuse to remove any of the children.
"How could the boys expect a fair shake from D.H.S. if they kept getting thrown back," one man shouted at the recent town meeting.
But a Grady County deputy sheriff responded: "It all comes down to the child has to be willing to talk. We have gone out and investigated calls, but when we get out there and they won't tell us anything, there's nothing we can do. Many times when you talk to children, they're afraid you'll separate them from their family, people won't believe them, or when they get back they'll get smacked around even harder for telling."
An official with the human services agency in Oklahoma City, Winston Barton, said townspeople were trying to make a scapegoat of the agency. He said the agency's records showed there had been no formal report of abuse at the Dutton home since 1990, when a report was investigated and dismissed because the children gave no indication that they were being abused.
The temperament of Herman, 15, and Druie, 12, whom nobody calls by his given name of James, was totally different from their father's. "These were good kids," said Karen Goodwin, the editor and publisher of the weekly newspaper, The Rush Springs Gazette. "If these were thugs or troublemakers, the whole town wouldn't be supporting them like this."
They lived a confined existence, with their father and their sister and a younger brother Jake, 8, in a trailer without electricity, running water or a telephone. The father, an unemployed roofer, would not let them go anywhere but school. Their schoolmates could never come to the trailer, which is still surrounded by a pungent and cacophonous collection of chickens, turkeys, quail, pigeons and a goat.
As the police officers drove the two boys to Lawton, where they are confined in a juvenile detention center, they stopped at a McDonald's for a meal. The boys asked them how to order. They had never eaten at a McDonald's.
 
Mother Departed Scene
 Their mother, who lives in Texas, has not lived with the children since she and Mr. Dutton divorced several years ago. Several people here said that Mr. Dutton got custody of the children after telling the authorities that his wife had abused them.
For years, residents have noticed that Herman and Druie were extraordinarily protective of their sister and their younger brother, both of whom have been sent to live with a relative.
"Every day when those kids got on the school bus, they all got in the same seat," said Mary Smith, who lives down the gravel road from the Duttons. "First Sissy, right up against the window, then Jake, then the two other boys would squeeze right in and all four would sit together just like that."
Mr. Dutton, who received public assistance and food stamps, rarely went into town. When he did, he was often in a foul mood, the neighbors said, and he sometimes got into arguments in which he threatened to hurt people or even to kill them. In a dispute with a neighbor, he repeatedly drove his pickup truck through the neighbor's picket fence, destroying it. The neighbor, fearful of him becoming even more violent, declined to press charges with the police, residents said.
"He was basically always a bully," said Becky Fitzgerald, a first-grade teacher here, who had known Mr. Dutton since he was 4 years old.
 
Making a Baby Cry
 Mrs. Smith, whose 21-month old granddaughter was Mr. Dutton's great niece, told of the aggressive way he played with the baby. Saying he was playing a game called plinky, Mr. Dutton would flick his index figure against the baby's skull until it cried, Mrs. Smith said. She said that when she rescued the child, Mr. Dutton would laugh and protest he was not seriously hurting her.
Yet Mr. Dutton was never convicted of hurting anybody, and since he was shot while he was asleep, the notion of self-defense on his boys' part is arguable.
But about the only comment in a score of interviews here that could possibly be interpreted as a show of support for Mr. Dutton was an observation by Melvin Brumley, the owner of Melvin's Barber Shop. "I don't think most people here really know for sure what went on," he said. "We don't have all that facts and figures yet."
The principal at the boys' school, Bill Chambers, said they were "scared silent" by their father. He said he intends to press for changes in the law to make it easier for the authorities to act on allegations of child abuse.
 
A Yearning for Normal
 For now, some people here are hoping things will return to normal. Indeed, in some ways they already are. The Main Street remains a partly beautiful, partly haunting tableau out of the "Last Picture Show," complete with a large sign in the middle of town: "Help the economy of Rush Springs -- Buy Something -- Anything! Local merchants will love ya!!"
Next month is the annual Watermelon Festival. Rush Springs likes to call itself the watermelon capital of the world, a mantle for which it competes with President Clinton's hometown of Hope, Ark. And townspeople note proudly that Winston Churchill once ate a slice of watermelon from Rush Springs.
"That's what we need to focus our attention on now, is watermelons," said Justin Jones, a watermelon farmer. "It's time to move on."
But most people here say they will not move on until Herman and Druie come home and are reunited with their younger sister and brother. "They all really do love each other," said Haylee Golden, a 14-year-old who was a classmate of Herman's. "That's one thing I know for sure."
