HEADLINE: Private School, Public Need

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J.

 BODY:
The stunning news last month that Peddie, a small private secondary school here, had just received a $100 million gift provoked two responses from this tiny, tax-weary borough of 5,000 people: First, congratulations. Second, can you help us out?
"When they received the money, I called them up the following day to congratulate them," said Mayor Ernest Turp, a Peddie graduate. "Then a couple of weeks later, I said I'd like to sit down with the headmaster and review their relationship with the borough. The people are very concerned. They would like to see Peddie make a good-sized contribution." 
 Because Peddie is a nonprofit educational institution, its lush 245-acre campus goes untaxed. That deprives the borough -- which collects about $2 million a year in property taxes -- of an estimated $1.1 million annually.
Instead, like many similar schools, Peddie voluntarily contributes a sum in lieu of taxes -- in Peddie's case, $25,000 -- to help pay for the municipal services it uses. But with roughly 30 percent of Hightstown's property off the tax rolls -- including Peddie, six churches and three public schools -- borough officials say the property tax burden has fallen unevenly on the private homeowner.
So far, relations between the town and the school have been upbeat. The borough wants more money, but has broached negotiations without appearing like a ragged mendicant, cup in hand, at the gate. Peddie wants to appear understanding. It has said it would like to contribute more than it already does -- and that it has an obligation to do so -- but that there are limits, because an enriched endowment does not necessarily translate into mad money.
Peddie's windfall, which came in June from Walter H. Annenberg (class of 1927), the billionaire publishing executive, places the school in a unique position with obvious public relations implications: it feels obliged to act graciously toward the town it has inhabited since 1866, but its primary interest and its fiduciary responsibility are to the students and the institution.
In the world of town and gown, the Peddie-Hightstown relationship reflects an increasingly common clash over how much schools -- sometimes richly endowed but revenue-poor -- can contribute to communities that are struggling with greater costs, reduced state aid and large amounts of property they cannot tax. Some schools contribute little or nothing, while others, like Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, pay a great deal. Phillips Exeter said it pays $500,000 a year in taxes on holdings deemed unrelated to education.
 
More From Hotchkiss
 Like Peddie, the Hotchkiss School in Salisbury, Conn., makes contributions to the town in lieu of taxes. But recently, Salisbury officials have been asking for more.
"We're trying to be fair, not trying to gouge anybody," said Bud Trotta, the First Selectman there. "We've gotten them to increase it over the years, but it's still not enough."
Mr. Trotta said that nearly 30 children of faculty members at Hotchkiss and two other private schools in the area attend Salisbury's public schools. But because faculty residences owned by the schools are tax exempt, the town absorbs the educational costs, about $250,000 a year.
John Virden, the provost at Hotchkiss, said the school believed in paying its fair share. Its contribution last year to fire and ambulance service and several other projects was $50,000. In addition, he said, the school made its athletic facilities available for little or no cost.
Such arrangements are typical. Peddie has increasingly made its campus available to the town for athletics -- its golf course is open to the public, for example -- and it maintains a busy schedule of concerts and art exhibits, many of them free or at reduced rates.
Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass., pays $60,000 to the town. But the headmaster, Robert Kaufman, said: "It's important to remember, schools cannot be in the position to be the financial saviors, to ride into the town budget meetings on a white horse. It is a mutually dependent relationship."
 
Commercial Gains
 All the schools make the point that their communities gain direct advantages from the buying power of the students, faculty members and visiting parents who patronize local motels and restaurants.
In Hightstown, Peddie has paid an annual sum in lieu of taxes since 1989, when Mayor Turp negotiated the school's first contribution. Its current donation is $15,000 to the general fund and $5,000 each to the fire department and ambulance corps.
But in a town with only one major tax-paying industry, a Minute Maid orange juice plant owned by Coca-Cola, homeowners provide most of the $6.9 million in property taxes that goes for municipal and county services and the public schools.
What more Peddie might now contribute, and how much the borough wants, are subjects still under discussion. But from the start, the school has recognized that its sudden wealth -- the endowment rose from $17 million to $117 million overnight -- made it more of a target.
"We feel a real responsibility to Hightstown," said Anne L. Seltzer, the director of development.
 
'A Citizen of the Town'
 Morton Goldfein, a laywer who graduated from Peddie in 1959 and is on its board, said he believed that the school had a "natural responsibility to enhance" its relationship with the town. "The school is a citizen of the town, and has been for a long time, and the school recognizes the importance of citizenship," he said.
Mr. Goldfein said he had floated proposals that would involve Peddie in some unspecified economic development in or around the downtown area, which amounts to perhaps two dozen shops on heavily trafficked Route 33, also known as Main Street.
Once a prime 19th-century rail hub for the shipment of potatoes and grain, Hightstown saw its prominence gradually erode, becoming a small town of small homes, a declining tax base and a retail and commercial afterthought to Princeton, about 10 miles away, and the many stores that line Route 130.
The board chairman at Peddie, Finn M. W. Caspersen, the chairman of the Beneficial Corporation and a classmate of Mr. Goldfein, cited urban decay in New Haven, home of Yale University, and said: "The town has not proved to be an asset to the university. That's not what we want in Hightstown."
 
Revenue Is Spoken For
 But he also pointed out that the endowment leaves little room for maneuvering. Annual interest on the endowment, in the current market, is expected to produce relatively little beyond the $5 million that Peddie hopes to use for scholarships and teacher salaries under the terms of the gift. The rest would be rolled back into the fund to keep up with inflation.
Charles Galbraith, the school's business adminstrator, said the school's annual operating expenses usually exceed revenue, and the difference must be made up by donations, a situation typical at many small schools and colleges.
But practically speaking, it is hard for some in town to look at the perfectly groomed Peddie campus and the Victorian houses on its periphery that were bought for faculty members without feeling that Hightstown is unfairly divided by privilege.
"I love Peddie," said Kathryn S. Dennis, who publishes the Hightstown Gazette, a 144-year-old weekly newspaper that her family has owned since 1912. "But with the exemption, it's hard for young families and for some of the older people who feel that they have to move out."
Setting a tone for the town's reaction four days after the gift was announced, Ms. Dennis wrote a front-page editorial on June 24, saying, "We are very happy for the Peddie School. but concluded:
"We mean you no harm, but the town has been carrying Peddie and other tax-exempt properties for years. Now it is time for the Peddie School to help the taxpayers."

HEADLINE: After 8 Years, Coliseum May Be More Than Issue

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
It has been eight years since Mortimer B. Zuckerman won the right to demolish the New York Coliseum and build something else on its site. But finally, the next few days or weeks may reveal the shape of the building that will be built -- if anything is to be built there at all.
The coming week is likely to see a flurry of negotiations over the fate of the Coliseum site, at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, a prime location that makes it probably the best development site left in the city. 
 The fresh impetus to the negotiations came about a week ago when Mayor David N. Dinkins, in response to a request from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum, indicated his willingness to force a mid-August deadline on Mr. Zuckerman to negotiate a deal.
Previously, Mr. Dinkins avoided taking a stand on the M.T.A.'s dealings with Mr. Zuckerman, who wants to cut the negotiated price of the land and reduce the scale of the planned development.
 
Best Thing, Worst Thing
 The talks over the Coliseum, one of the longest-running public policy soap operas in New York, feature the tug and pull of elected and appointed officials from the city and the M.T.A., as well as Mr. Zuckerman and an array of civic groups. All say they are doing the best thing for New York, but the deadlock resulting from their actions has done exactly what all agree is the wrong thing: left the Coliseum exhibition hall and office building under-used and deteriorating.
"This is one of the premiere sites in the city of New York," said Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan. "It is an embarrassment to all of us that Columbus Circle, the gateway entrance to the park, the Theater District and a major residential neighborhood, has been allowed to lie fallow and become a center for drug-dealing, street-sleeping and shoddiness."
Mr. Zuckerman's original 1985 plan to build a 2.1-million-square-foot project on the 3.4-acre site was scaled back twice after widespread criticism, court challenges and the pullout of the main tenant, Salomon Brothers.
Now, with court challenges over project's size and other issues exhausted and the city's office-space market suffering from the biggest glut in memory, Mr. Zuckerman has sought to cut his offering price from its market-peak 1985 level to something more like what the land would bring in today's depressed market. He also wants to reduce his building plans again, to a project that would be built in stages, people close to the talks say.
 
'Major Law Firm' Lined Up
 Mr. Zuckerman said in a telephone interview that he planned to make a formal proposal to the M.T.A. and to the city soon. The proposal would probably involve building 150,000 square feet of retail space and 700,000 square feet of office space, he said. He added that most of it would be occupied by a "major New York law firm" that he declined to name but is said by people close to the talks to be Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
"You can't build these things on spec any more," Mr. Zuckerman said. "We have great confidence that we can put together a tenancy if given the time for complex legal and financing arrangements."
That would create new jobs in the construction industry, Mr. Zuckerman said, and leave room for more development on the Coliseum site.
The current price tag on the site is $338.6 million. People familiar with the talks said Mr. Zuckerman now hoped to buy an unspecified amount of land for the first building for $62 million, and leave the price of the rest of the land to be negotiated later.
The perennially cash-strapped transportation authority, which owns the Coliseum and other buildings on the site through a subsidiary, has been trying to close the Zuckerman sale or get money from the property through other, interim uses since the last lawsuit over Mr. Zuckerman's development plan was settled last autumn. The M.T.A. has been reluctant to cut the price of the land or to sign on to a staged development plan.
 
'Doesn't Sound Like a Sale'
 Robert Bergen, general counsel for the M.T.A., declined to comment on the current negotiations but said: "We have said we're not interested in phased developments, where we have to continue to hold the property for him at our expense while he's getting ready to develop it. That doesn't sound like a sale to me."
City officials including Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, are also known to be taking an active role in the talks with Mr. Zuckerman. Mr. Dinkins, in his response to the M.T.A., called for Mr. Zuckerman to negotiate an acceptable deal for the sale by Aug. 16 and to close the sale by Nov. 15.
Because of the complicated sales agreement for the site, the city and the M.T.A. -- which is not a city agency -- both must sign on to any plan, and their interests do not necessarily coincide.
While city officials declined to comment publicly on the talks, a senior city official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the city believed that it and the M.T.A. should look hard at Mr. Zuckerman's new offer when it is made formal. Further, the official said, the city wants to make sure that issues other than immediate cash rewards are considered in any decision.

 
Looking at Larger Impact
 The official said: "The city has an interest in the larger economic impact of the project. There might be a use that brings in more direct revenue to the city but has a very limited secondary economic impact, or there might be one that would bring in a limited amount of direct revenue but have a much more significant economic impact."
A retail user, for example, might bring a high rent, but another proposal -- like studio or exhibition space -- could pack a punch with secondary income from hotel and restaurant traffic. In any case, the official said, "We would be wary of encouraging speculative office space."
Meanwhile, people close to the talks said tempers were wearing thin. These people said that Mr. Zuckerman thought that the M.T.A. was trying to force his hand in a weak market and get a 1985 price for the land, and that it seems clear he could benefit from continuing delay that would grant time for talks with Weil, Gotshal or for a stronger market.
These people also said that city officials were miffed that the M.T.A. gave no warning this month when it sent Mayor Dinkins its letter calling for the city to join the agency in setting a closing date and that M.T.A. officials suspect that Mr. Zuckerman is negotiating in the hopes of a delay.
Finally, despite the apparent deadline Mr. Dinkins set in his letter to Peter E. Stangl, the authority's chairman, careful readers noted that further delay was not impossible. Mr. Dinkins wrote that "should the parties, acting reasonably and responsibly, be unable to reach an agreement by Aug. 16, 1993, I would be prepared on that date to concur" if the M.T.A. issued a closing notice -- suggesting that this deadline, too, is an elastic one.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
DAMAGE ESTIMATES OF MIDWEST FLOOD CLIMBING SHARPLY

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As the rain keeps falling and the water keeps rising, it is becoming clear that the terrible flooding of 1993 will have a considerably bigger effect on the nation's economy than seemed likely just a short time ago.
"Seems like we get bombarded with heavy rain and heavy rain; in between, we get light rain," said Roy R. Arends, a farmer in Alexander, Iowa. "It's been hard to get the crops in, it's hard on equipment, it's hard on nerves. The financial impact is yet to be seen, but right now it really looks bleak." 
 As they survey bankers, farmers, businesses and state officials, analysts at four Federal Reserve banks in the Midwest have been raising their damage estimates, in some cases doubling and tripling recent numbers.
 
'Hurricane Andrew Range'
 "Two weeks ago I said you weren't going to see discernible impacts" on the gross domestic product, said Edward Lotterman, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. "That was before Iowa, Missouri and Illinois. Now I think we're getting into the Hurricane Andrew range in terms of losses."
The dollar figure that economists are putting on crop losses, property damage and lost production and sales -- for now at least -- is $10 billion to $12 billion, roughly two-thirds of the losses from Hurricane Andrew last year. As the figures climb, they include losses not only from areas under water, but also from adjacent areas where people and businesses are suffering.
Heavy rain fell yesterday along the Missouri River in Nebraska, expanding the flooded area north and west and raising the specter of more trouble ahead. [Article, page 16.]
 
A Parched Southeast
 And while the Midwest is reeling from the flood, parts of the southeastern United States -- without a major rainfall since June 1 -- are feeling the bite of a drought. In South Carolina, the worst-hit state, the state Agriculture Commissioner said 95 percent of the corn crop had been lost, 70 percent of soybeans, 50 percent of wheat and 25 percent of tobacco. Parts of North Carolina and Georgia are also suffering.
"There's going to be crop loss and poultry suffocation," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University. The damage is likely to be measured in hundreds of millions of dollars.
Eventually, consumers around the nation are likely to see higher prices for some foods as a result of the current damage, but the changes are likely to be moderate, far less than the sharp increases produced by the devastating drought of 1988.
Laura d'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said Friday that she thought the flooding and drought would add no more than three-tenths of 1 percent to the inflation rate this year. She said she expected "a serious effect on spending" this summer and suggested that a lack of resources for rebuilding could limit the economic stimulus after the flood waters recede.
For all the tremendous losses to property and people's well-being, most natural disasters eventually provide a shot in the arm for the national economy, because the tremendous sums of money invested in repairs show up in gross domestic product.
"A guy whose home was wiped away and a community whose major road was destroyed doesn't show up as G.D.P. loss," said one Administration economist who would speak only on anonymity. "In fact, that diminution of assets shows up as a G.D.P. gain, because we'll send a road crew out to repair the road. But that gain is a measure of what was lost."
 
Stalled Midwest Growth
 Economists expect the negative impact of the Midwest floods to be measured in tenths of 1 percent of the nation's $6 trillion gross domestic output -- the amount of goods and services Americans turn out a year. But the blow is still enough, said Sara Johnson, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, to temporarily stall the economic expansion of the Midwest, a region that has been doing better than the rest of the nation for several years.
And statistics about the nation's economy are scant comfort to people watching their homes being swept away, or to those on dry land who have also suffered.
Dwayne Crook is the sales manager at Buford Ward Chevrolet in Quincy, Ill., a dealership that sits on a bluff hundreds of feet above the swollen Mississippi River. "A lot of our business comes from Missouri," he said. "They just can't get here. The bridges are down. There's water over the roads." The dealership's sales, which were very strong earlier in the year, have been down 30 percent since the flooding started.
Such disruption of everyday economic life is continuing throughout the flood area, where water now covers millions of acres in eight states.
"This thing has been going on and on and on," said Wesley Ooms, an assistant vice president at State Farm Insurance, in Bloomington, Ill. "You really can't do anything until water's receded."
Crop losses from the flood could reach $5 billion. Iowa's farmers, for example, may end up losing a third of their corn crop, taking a $1.1 billion loss, said Evan Stadlman, executive director of the Iowa Corn Growers Association.
"There's the crop that should have been harvested in the fall that never got planted," he said. "There's the crop that was lost due to flooding. We're also talking about the crop continuing to be reduced if don't get more favorable weather. Plus we may see the crop that can get harvested can't get to market."
 
Impact on Business
 The rains and flooding have kept buyers out of stores, and some factories have been shut. The loss of business in Des Moines, where flooding of the waterworks disrupted the city's water supply, has been estimated at $200 million by the Des Moines Chamber of Commerce and at $500 million by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
The flooding has halted home building in some areas, and the rain has delayed it in others. Housing starts in the Midwest, which had already dipped in June, are likely to remain at below-normal levels all summer.
"The water has to go down," said Betty Hardle, chief executive of Good Value Homes in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. "The ground has to dry somewhat. The approach to the property has to be suitable for heavy trucks. The constant rains added time, cost and aggravation."
While rebuilding after the flood will provide some economic stimulus later this year, it is likely to fall short of what occurred after Hurricane Andrew in South Florida and Louisiana. While the hurricane demolished homes and businesses which were often rebuilt, the biggest damages from the flooding have been to crops. And lost crops are simply never made up.
There is another major difference: even with aid from Washington, the proportion of losses that will be compensated from the flood and drought will be much lower than from Hurricane Andrew.
 
A Lack of Insurance
 After the hurricane, insurers paid more than $16.5 billion in claims within a few months. Among the many homes flooded in the Midwest, relatively few are insured against flood damage. State Farm, for example, said it had received fewer than 400 claims for flooded homes and fewer than 400 for autos damaged by the water.
Few private homeowner policies provide flood protection, and Donald Collins, assistant administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said only about 15 percent of the 30,000 to 40,000 homes damaged by flooding have Federal flood insurance. "Not enough people bought the insurance," he said. "That's just tragic."
And many farmers do not buy Federal crop insurance which, as a rule, does not pay for the first third of the loss. "People with damaged homes or crops aren't going to have an Allstate man drive up to door and write a check," said Mr. Lotterman of the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis. "So you don't get an immediate infusion of cash that you got after Andrew."
For now, all the numbers attached to flood damage are rough estimates at best. The numbers cannot be confirmed or contradicted until people can inspect all the damage and the fall harvest is completed.

HEADLINE: Long Hearings on Ireland's Beef Scandal End

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, July 24

 BODY:
As only the 25th richest country in the world, Ireland can hardly be expected to produce corruption scandals on the scale of those in the United States, Japan or Italy.
But accusations of fraud involving more than $300 million in the beef industry -- one of the country's most important -- have portrayed Ireland as the bad butcher of Europe in the longest, costliest public investigation in the country's 71 years of independence. 
 The Tribunal of Inquiry into the Beef Processing Industry, sitting in Dublin Castle, produced charges of audacious short-weighting, deliberate mislabeling to fake quality and the sending of rotten beef hearts to Russia and of tons of meat to Iraq from cattle that was supposed to have been slaughtered according to Islamic law but was not.
The Tribunal, which ended its hearings last week, was also told that ranking Government officials gave favored treatment to companies run by an entrepreneur, Larry Goodman, who had friends in high places, made hefty contributions to political parties and won preferential treatment in getting government credit and insurance. His companies were also accused of evading millions of dollars in taxes.
The accusers included politicians and Government agriculture inspectors, who generally charged that fraud was carried out by workers with the connivance of company officials.
The hearings alternately shocked and bored the Irish for a year and half as people learned that the lawyers involved were earning $2,500 a day, that the cost to the state would probably be about $5 million and that the final report of the single judge presiding over the inquiry, High Court Justice Liam Hamilton, will not come until the end of the year. He may recommend that the Government press criminal charges against industry and Government officials. If the beef charges are serious enough, they could provoke a general election for the second time.
In November, a dispute growing out of the inquiry forced an election that resulted in the coalition Government between the Fianna Fail party of Prime Minister Albert Reynolds and the Labor Party. Labor replaced the Progressive Democrats, whose leader, Desmond O'Malley, had a bitter dispute with Mr. Reynolds over the beef accusations.
But whatever Justice Hamilton recommends, the tribunal has underscored how important beef is to Ireland, a country already suffering heavily from recession, with an unemployment rate of about 20 percent, twice the European rate, and factories closing almost daily.
The place of cattle, in Irish mythology as well as contemporary economic life, is clear here. On the national television crime-stoppers program, pictures of stolen tractors and mowers are regularly shown and cattle medicines are advertised in prime-time slots along with beer and detergents.
The beef scandal grew out of the shipment in the late 1980's of several hundred millions of dollars worth of beef to Iraq, which failed to pay its bill, and the Goodman companies then demanded that the Government pay the insurance of about $250 million. A British television company, Granada, produced a program alleging dishonesty and payoffs. Government ministers denounced the program, but refused to answer important questions in Parliament, appointing the tribunal instead.
"The whole point was not to rock the boat," said Douglas McLernon, a lecturer in economics at Trinity College. "No matter what, we have to sell our meat. We're worried about jobs, about the image of the Irish farming community, not about the morality of it."
He said that sending improperly slaughtered beef to a Muslim country was "like putting chocolate chips in the Communion wafers." He added, "But here in Holy Ireland there was not a word about the morality."
Statistics show why beef is so important. Cattle account for 73 percent of Ireland's agricultural exports, which in turn make up 13.7 of all exports. About 15 percent of Irish employment is in agriculture, far above the European average. Ireland has about 8 million head of cattle, with a human population of 3.5 million. Britain, with a population of 58 million, has 12 million head of cattle.

HEADLINE: Loggers Listen to What Michigan Forests Say

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMASA, Mich.

 BODY:
Midway between Lake Michigan and Lake Superior, the Fence River cuts a silvery path across a lush landscape of maple, poplar and pine. The woods on both sides of the river are owned by the Mead Corporation, and no one knows the landscape here better than Dr. Dean Premo, a 38-year-old zoologist hired by the paper and lumber company to conduct some of the most important wildlife studies in the timber industry.
For more than 50 years, the nation's timber industry has focused most of its scientific work on one challenge: how to grow more trees in less time. But mindful of the public's new interest in forests as well as Federal and state laws protecting endangered species, the industry is rapidly expanding its biological research to understand more thoroughly how plants and animals are affected by logging. 
 The desire of timber executives is twofold. First they hope to develop timber- cutting practices that meet the demand for trees while providing greater environmental safeguards. Second, they hope to avoid the kind of political and legal stalemate that has paralyzed the industry in the Pacific Northwest. As a result, they are compiling more complete scientific data with which to argue their case.
 
Information Needed
 "The public needs accurate information and we need accurate information," said John R. Johnson, the technical services manager of Mead. "The ability to pre-empt legislation is secondary. What we want is policy and regulations that make good biological sense. What we're having a problem with in the natural resources area is that we need better quality information."
That is where Dr. Premo fits in.
For three winters, Dr. Premo, who was reared in this logging town, has strapped on snowshoes and hiked to a stretch of river to count the tracks of wolves, red foxes, otters, minks, coyotes and a dozen more kinds of mammals. In the same area during the spring and summer, Dr. Premo and his staff have studied the density of 90 species of breeding songbirds by listening to their calls and spotting nests.
Their research has shown that mammals use the river to migrate and that wide corridors of standing timber are necessary to their survival. Dr. Premo has also found that logging to within 50 feet of streams, which is the standard in Michigan and other states, causes breeding songbird populations to plummet by 90 percent. He recommends buffers of 250 to 400 feet.
 
Environmentalists Split
 The timber industry's new research has attracted the attention of environmentalists and left them divided over it. Some view the research as a legitimate effort to sustain compatible economic and ecological goals.
"What's going on up there may be a leading edge of what could turn out to be a more constructive, mature relationship between the environmental community and the timber industry," said Michael McCloskey, the chairman of the Sierra Club in Washington. "You are operating in a part of the country where environmental sensitivities are somewhat greater. There is still a fair amount of native flora that has survived into second- and third-growth forests."
But the local environmental groups in the upper Middle West, which are more strident, view the research as a public relations ploy. "These companies are not worried about biodiversity," said Dr. Bill Willers, a professor of biology at the University of Wisconsin at Oshkosh, who is executive director of the Superior Wilderness Action Network. "What they are interested in is getting the right image. It's a cover. They are afraid of an impending citizen backlash."
Mr. Johnson and other timber industry executives readily acknowledge that such a backlash is a concern. They said there is ample evidence in the Pacific Northwest of how a political clash over the value of trees, endangered animals and logging jobs can sharply reduce cutting. On July 1, President Clinton tried to settle that fight by proposing to reduce sharply the amount of timber in the Northwest that can be cut over the next decade, to provide economic aid to displaced timber workers and to turn about seven million acres of virgin forest into reserves that are open only to limited logging.
 
No Virgin Forest Left
 Here in the upper Midwest, the debate is not nearly as ferocious, and there are differences in the two regions that are likely to keep it that way. No great stands of virgin forests remain as they do in the Northwest. The forests of Michigan's Upper Peninsula have been cut for more a century.
In addition, much of the timber land on this thinly populated peninsula bounded by three Great Lakes is privately owned. Timber company executives and scientists like Dr. Premo have been successful in arguing that sustaining commercial logging in the region, which is larger than Massachusetts and New Hampshire combined, gives the forests enough economic value to fend off housing subdivisions, shopping centers and four-lane highways that they contend are considerably more damaging to the environment. The paper and lumber industry in the state last year had total revenues of about $6 billion and employed 63,000 people.
"It's in all our interests -- the timber companies, the foresters, the state, the environmentalists and the tourism industry -- to keep this a healthy forested landscape," said Dr. Premo, who was educated at Michigan State University and moved back here with his wife, Bette, a specialist in aquatic biology and chemistry, in 1985 to open an environmental consulting company.
 
70 Million Acres of Forest
 The nation's $200-billion-a-year timber industry owns 70 million acres of forest land in the United States, an area roughly the size of Arizona. Almost every important forest-products company has started broad ecological research programs.
In the South, the Georgia Pacific Company is conducting a joint project with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to protect the endangered red cockaded woodpecker. Earlier this year, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt approved a plan for preserving the species that called for Georgia Pacific to limit logging on 500 acres surrounding each of about 100 colonies of woodpeckers found on the company's four million acres of woodlands in the region.
In Maine, Bowater Inc., the Scott Paper Company and the Champion International Corporation are studying how timber cutting affects populations of tropical songbirds that migrate from Central and South America to breed in the Maine woods. More than 250 species of tropical songbirds migrate to the United States and Canada and their numbers are said by some scientists to be declining rapidly because logging is fragmenting forests.
Forest scientists in Michigan and elsewhere say few projects are more advanced than the one Dean and Bette Premo designed for Mead, which is based in Dayton, Ohio, and had sales last year of $4.7 billion.
 
Bigger Migration Corridors
 By tracking animals as they moved among logged areas, the Premos persuaded the company to leave much broader patches of timber standing for migration corridors. They have showed Mead foresters where the corridors should be.
Their research on wetlands and on the ecological importance of the temporary vernal ponds that form in the forest after the spring melt also led to new management practices. Mead's foresters, unaware of the importance the ponds played as resting and feeding areas for wildlife, used to cut up to the edge of the ponds and then fill them with the brush and slash from logging. Now the ponds are ringed by uncut forest.
And their research on the value to wildlife, especially to birds, of leaving unlogged corridors along the Fence River has led the company to establish much wider buffers along streams.
"I argued that by doing this they can maintain populations of birds to keep insects in check that are devouring their young trees," Dean Premo said. "I make a legitimate economic and ecological argument to them. I tell them you wipe out the birds, then you have to use pesticides to control the bugs."

HEADLINE: Tallying Crown Heights Toll, in Votes

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Savoring the respite from the hammering sun, Sal Margolis plopped into a swivel chair inside the Margolis Stationery Store in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where he meditated with some melancholy on his possible political defection.
"I'm a lifetime Democrat, but I may change my voting habits for the first time," he said. "For 40 years I voted Democratic, but the string may be ending." 
 The 68-year-old Mr. Margolis was discussing the prospects of his not voting for Mayor David N. Dinkins in the upcoming election after hearing about the Crown Heights report that harshly criticized his handling of the racial disturbances. "After the report, my opinion of him went down considerably," he said. "Before that, I thought he was doing fair and I was thinking I would vote for him again. I didn't think the report would be that negative. It was all negative. The report told me he might be inept."
In recent days, people throughout the city have fumbled to fit the disquieting conclusions of the Crown Heights report into their thinking about who should be the next Mayor. Some 50 conversations in a scattering of neighborhoods whose voters are considered critical to the outcome of the election suggest that the report has jarred or even fully eroded the faith of many Dinkins backers. For many others, it has fortified already established voting convictions.
 
Months Remain
 Of course, it is important to note that the election is still more than three months away. As many voters themselves emphasized, their allegiances are far from settled, and the efforts of the candidates or the shifting tide of news events could eclipse the Crown Heights issue before the ballots are cast on Nov. 2.
But at least in the immediate wake of the report, a substantial number of people once inclined to vote for Mr. Dinkins said that they have slid into the murky realm of the undecided. A few said that they have marched all the way into the camp of his opponent, the Republican-Liberal candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani.
On the other hand, many other voters said that they had already squarely settled on their candidate before the release of the report and have not wavered. Indeed, the staunchest Dinkins backers, especially black voters, expressed deep indignation over the report and said that they were more resolved than ever to rally support for the Mayor. Unsurprisingly, none of the 50 people interviewed said that they have migrated from Mr. Giuliani to Mr. Dinkins since the report's release on Tuesday.
The report was also highly critical of police officials and prosecutors. But the Mayor was the most visible and significant target, and news accounts focused heavily on the report's conclusion that Mr. Dinkins was slow to recognize and respond to the violence that erupted in August 1991 after a black child was struck and killed by a car driven by a Hasidic Jew. A Hasidic scholar was killed in the ensuing unrest.
Indeed, many people seem to have seized on the report as a summation of the Dinkins years rather than solely a commentary on the four days of violence.
 
'It Disturbs Me'
 Three women who had just completed some avid shopping at rackety Zabar's on the Upper West Side illustrated the perplexed emotions that have transfigured some voters.
"I was for Dinkins, and I think what he did there was terrible," said Evelyn Kalish, 71. "Now I doubt I'll vote for Dinkins. It disturbs me."
Pam Edel, a 42-year-old part-time teacher, chipped in: "I can't make up my mind. I don't like either of them. Last time, I voted for Dinkins, though I wasn't happy with him."
She said that the report did not surprise her and that she had been undecided for a while.
What will she do?
"I think there's a chance Giuliani can convince me to vote for him," she said. "His image as the D.A. is too strict for me. To be honest, I want Lindsay back."
The third woman, Nancy Beha, a 42-year-old special education teacher, was of a different mind. She felt the report was unduly harsh. "I think this is an almost ungovernable city," she said. "You need a superhuman person. I think Dinkins has been O.K."
Ms. Kalish had a final word: "Actually, I'd love Koch back."
 
Weakened Support
 Among more than 15 interviews with people on the Upper West Side, home to many white liberals who went strongly for Mr. Dinkins last time, there was little unadulterated support for the Mayor.
Quite a few Jewish voters said they had already aligned themselves with Mr. Giuliani, and the report has more firmly rooted them there. "I was 90 percent for Giuliani, and now I'm 100 percent," said Akiva Goldfarb, a 21-year-old student lugging some dry cleaning down Broadway. "The report made me feel more secure in my vote."
He underscored that he and his friends did not feel Mr. Dinkins was unresponsive to Jews. "It's not a Jewish thing," he said. "I think he generally wavers and is indecisive. I feel in general he doesn't want to take strong action."
Around the corner on Amsterdam Avenue, Scott Bodie, 41, was standing outside Avventura, a glassware shop he manages. "I usually vote a straight Democratic ticket," he said. "I always felt a black Mayor was good for the city, but his laissez-faire attitude is not what we're used to. Up to the Crown Heights report, I was going to vote for Dinkins. The report made me totally undecided. When the report said he didn't do anything, to some extent it makes it hard for me to imagine voting for Dinkins."
 
Hispanic Voters Waver
 Four years ago Hispanic voters constituted an important swing constituency that helped put Mr. Dinkins in office. In Sunset Park, Brooklyn, home to a sizable Hispanic population, the Crown Heights report intensified an already palpable disenchantment.
Frank Castillo, a 45-year-old freight elevator worker, who was walking his dog, Tita, through the park, said: "I was for Dinkins but when I heard about that report on TV -- well! The report has changed my mind. He doesn't make me feel too good anymore. Now I don't know. I have to play it by ear."
Marlene Vazquez, a 24-year-old mother of three, was cheerily strolling through the park with her children and her father, Miguel Vazquez, a butcher. "I thought the report was true," she said. "It's given me a lot to think about. I was going to vote for Dinkins, but now I'm undecided. I've been up and down with him. Like a relationship."
She said other issues were also important. "More has to be done for the kids. They see their parents at home, and they wonder, Why aren't they going to work? Why are they eating the same stuff?"
Her father had already resolved his vote. "I like Giuliani," he said. "He talks from the heart. Dinkins always has mixed-up opinions. He contradicts himself too much."
 
Catalyst for Defenders
 Conversations with a diverse group of black voters offered a different perspective, one infused with anger at the report and suggesting a freshly energized desire to defend the Mayor.
John A. Coleman, the president of Blackstone Enterprise, a construction company in Queens Village, felt the report was very unfair to Mr. Dinkins. "There were some mistakes, but I don't think they should tar and feather him," said Mr. Coleman, who is black. He said that the sizable middle-class black community of southeastern Queens felt extremely protective of the Mayor and would continue to rally around him. "If anything," he said, the report "will make me support him stronger."
In Hollis, Queens, Andre Whitfield, a black 26-year-old janitor for the Transit Authority, was washing his Jeep in front of a friend's house. "I really think the Mayor didn't have anything to do with it," he said. "He did what he could do. The tension in Crown Heights is in that neighborhood, not outside it. There's nothing you can do if the people there don't want to live together."
As he routed a stream of water over his Jeep, he said that exploitation of the report would inflame racial tensions. "A lot of people just want to see him out of power. They should just leave it alone. This is going to start another riot."
Several black voters and steadfast Dinkins backers in Cambria Heights, Queens, echoed these thoughts. "People make mistakes," said John Bryant, 40, a control room operator for Consolidated Edison. "Even Koch, Abe Beame and Lindsay. They all made mistakes. But this is the first black mayor, so he's under the microscope. They all made mistakes but were they penalized this bad?"
 
Anxiety Among Koreans
 Along Union Street in Flushing, Queens, a cultural and commercial hub for Koreans, reaction was far more mixed. Several Koreans said they felt the Mayor had been excessively attacked, though they singled out racial tension as an uppermost concern of theirs.
"Right now, we're anxious," said Bruce Lee, 39, a fruit and vegetable wholesaler in the Bronx who was doing business at the Korean Commercial Bank. "The Mayor I wish would pay more attention to our community."
A number of voters felt that Crown Heights was just a blip in the Dinkins years, and too much was being made of it. "I'm undecided," said Lois Karakis, who owns KB Dry Cleaners in Sunset Park and voted for Mr. Dinkins in 1989. "The Crown Heights episode won't affect my vote. It's the drug problem, the unemployment, taxes, breaks for the small business person. Take the sidewalk. I'm here alone most of the time. I have to watch the sidewalk for litter or get a $50 fine. I sweep twice a day and I'm trying to run a business. These are the things that affect my vote."
Quite a number of past Dinkins supporters said they had turned away even before the report's release. Vincent Marciari, a 69-year-old Italian who owns Blenderman's Meat Market in Kew Gardens, Queens, said the report didn't surprise him but merely affirmed his fraying opinion of the Mayor. "I always voted Democratic before," he said. "Now I'm voting for Giuliani. My wife, my son and my daughter, too."
Many of his customers, he said, feel likewise. "I've had four or five customers come in today and tell me they're not going to vote for Dinkins now," he said.
Mitchell Borstein, a 41-year-old butcher who had stopped by the store, said he voted for Mr. Giuliani last time and was going to again. "The man came into office on a platform of bringing the races together," he said of Mr. Dinkins. "It's gotten worse."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Old-Time Yank Advice And Opinion

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
THEY remembered Bucky Dent's playoff homer off Mike Torrez and they remembered Graig Nettles's glove at third base in the World Series, but they also remembered what Sparky Lyle fondly called "the rip sessions" on the team bus after a game.
At their Old-Timers Day reunion yesterday, many of the 1978 Yankees, the last Yankee team to win a World Series, were surveyed informally for an uncle's advice to the current Yankee players, many of whom are suddenly in a divisional pennant race for the first time. 
 "Be patient," Reggie Jackson replied. "Trust your ability. Don't force it. Let it happen."
"You got to get your unity together," Mickey Rivers said. "You got to help each other."
One way the 1978 Yankees accomplished that was to pounce verbally on a teammate who had made a costly error or who had struck out in the clutch. From the back of the team bus Catfish Hunter, Lou Piniella, Dick Tidrow and Sparky Lyle, among others, would ambush their victims.
"Nobody was immune," Lyle recalled. "Chris Chambliss once made an error that cost us a ball game in Texas and he told me later, 'The one thing I dreaded the most was getting on the bus.' But by the time we got back to the hotel, we were all laughing about whatever happened."

 
 Maybe that's the best advice of all for this Yankee team, but it takes characters to do that and it takes character to accept it.
"The closer you get in the race, people tend to put more emphasis on a particular game," Lyle said. "You just got to play solid baseball."
Jim Spencer, the backup first baseman and d.h., remembered losing the first two games of that World Series in Los Angeles.
"On the plane coming back," Spencer said, "I remember Nettles saying, 'Don't worry, the Dodgers are a different team in New York.' "
Those Yankees swept the next four games, completing a surge that began in July after they fell 14 1/2 games behind the Red Sox.
"Going into our four-game series in September in Boston, we were just hoping to close the gap, but we swept 'em to tie for first place," Nettles said. "In a pennant race, the idea is to believe in yourself. Don't let people tell you that you don't belong in the race."
That divisional race ended with the Yankees defeating the Red Sox, 5-4, in a one-game playoff at Fenway Park on homers by Bucky Dent and Jackson.
"In a pennant race," said Roy White, the Yankee left fielder that year, "you try to win every series: two out of three or three out of four."
But the 1978 Yankees were brimming with the confidence of having won the 1977 World Series after also winning the 1976 American League pennant.
"We had the feeling we were the best," Willie Randolph said. "You rely on each other. You rally around each other. You're going to have ups and downs. It's how you handle it. If you're in a slump, push another guy to pick you up. And when he's in a slump, you pick him up."

 
 This year's Yankees can't lean on the confidence that permeated the 1978 Yankees or the Yankees of Joe DiMaggio's era.
"I'd tell 'em, just keep playing as they're playing," said DiMaggio, the ultimate Yankee, "and hope they get good pitching."
But these Yankees hope to win while George Steinbrenner shills for a new stadium, another topic of conversation.
"He can do anything he wants, that man," DiMaggio said when asked about the stadium situation. "I can't help him one way or another."
Reggie Jackson, now a Yankee special adviser, acknowledged "not being caught up in the tradition" of the Bronx ball park because "the game has changed economically" since the free-agent era began.
In mentioning the need for as many as three million customers annually, Mr. October added that "the only way to do that" is with a new ball park.
Another Yankee employee, Willie Randolph, now the assistant general manager, and Nettles disagreed.
"I can't imagine a new Yankee Stadium," Randolph said. "To me, Yankee Stadium is in the Bronx."
"I think they belong here," Nettles said. "But if they go, I hope they rebuild Yankee Stadium somewhere else. I'd hate to see the Yankees playing in another type ball park."
But no matter where other Yankees play eventually, these Yankees must try to win the pennant in this Yankee Stadium.

HEADLINE: Demythologizing the Trade Pact

 BODY:
Debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement has been overheated. Critics proclaim the pact -- which would eliminate most tariffs and trade barriers with Mexico and Canada over the next 15 years -- a national catastrophe, threatening jobs, wages and the environment. Proponents claim Nafta will boost employment and that its environmental provisions are a lovely shade of green.
The truth is more mundane. Nafta would have a modest economic impact in Mexico but a trivial impact on the U.S. economy. Mexico is too small to threaten U.S. firms, and U.S. tariffs are already so low that elimination couldn't possibly lead to a flood of Mexican imports. Nafta spells neither economic salvation nor ruin. 
 Will jobs disappear? Ross Perot warns that Nafta will take jobs away from up to six million Americans -- based on the absurd calculation that the agreement threatens every worker in industries that use a lot of labor. The Administration says that Nafta will boost employment. Neither is correct.
Trade pacts affect where people work, not how many people work. Under Nafta, more Americans would find work in service industries (like insurance) and high-tech manufacturing (computers) for export to Mexico; fewer Americans would work in glass-blowing and apparel industries that would lose out to Mexican imports. But overall employment would not change. With or without Nafta, the U.S. employment rate will again hover around 6 percent once the economy recovers.
Unfortunately, the workers displaced by Mexican imports won't be the ones who find the extra work in export industries. Fortunately, the number of displaced workers would be small. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that, over 10 years, Nafta would add fewer than 500,000 to the 20 million workers who'll be displaced for other reasons.
Will wages shrink? Mr. Perot warns that U.S. firms will flee to Mexico to hire low-paid workers; employers who stay will drive down wages to Mexican levels. Some employers will relocate, but Mr. Perot's numbers are cockamamie. Most studies predict foreign investment in Mexico, an economy only one-twentieth the size of the U.S., would rise by no more than about $15 billion a year -- a tiny fraction of the $500 billion investment in plant and equipment that takes place every year in the U.S.
Besides, low wages primarily reflect low productivity, giving companies little reason to relocate -- otherwise Haiti would rule the corporate world. And because Nafta is expected to increase U.S. exports, it is as likely to raise U.S. wages as lower them -- though in neither case by very much.
Will the environment suffer? Critics charge that Nafta will encourage U.S. firms to relocate to take advantage of Mexico's notoriously lax enforcement of environmental laws. The threat is real but small. Few firms face compliance costs larger than 1 percent of total costs, which is too small to warrant the journey.
There are legitimate questions about Nafta's environmental impact: Does Nafta adequately protect U.S. health and safety standards; will it protect the environment along the border? And critics have rightly pointed to the agreement's weak environmental dispute resolution and enforcement mechanisms. But there's still time to make Nafta better when the Clinton Administration negotiates a supplemental accord on the environment.
Regional trade accords like Nafta raise troubling questions because they break with the honorable U.S. tradition of treating all trade partners alike. But Canada and Mexico are special cases because they are neighbors. And Nafta would help Mexico lock in recent market reforms that the U.S. supports. Nafta isn't an economic magic bullet, but it does some good and no great harm.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
City Opera Turns 50, But Who's Counting?

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Who can blame the New York City Opera for keeping its 50th-anniversary celebration low-key? The company opens its season on Wednesday evening not with an attention-grabbing gala or a trendy premiere but with plain old "Carmen," followed by a few weeks of standard repertory and operettas. There will be no exhibitions, picture books, film compilations, collaborations with other New York institutions or glittery evenings of self-congratulation.
 "No, we aren't doing that," said Christopher Keene, the company's general director. "After the 150th anniversary of the Philharmonic, the 100th of Carnegie Hall and the 100th of the Met, 50 doesn't really have that much resonance. And for me, at the tender age of 46, 50 seems younger every day." 
But the current mood of sobriety runs deeper. Mr. Keene, having in his four seasons as director raised the company's performance standards to their highest level since the mid-70's, is fighting to hold his ground in the face of a recession that has eaten into ticket sales and contributions. Attendance dropped last season from about 80 percent of capacity to 72 percent, with each point representing about $100,000 in potential revenue. Anniversary or not, the last thing Mr. Keene wants is to appear to be fiddling while Rome burns.
 True, City Opera is in good company. At the Metropolitan Opera, attendance declined 5 percent last season, to 89 percent, for a loss of almost $3 million in potential revenue. But the Met's economy is better cushioned than City Opera's, with interest from a $100 million endowment helping to cover expenses.
 City Opera has always been too busy keeping its head above water to start an endowment. It does have a small cash reserve fund, which Mr. Keene used to cover a $1 million deficit for the fiscal year just ended and a $2.9 million shortfall for the previous one. The fund now stands at $4.5 million, and Mr. Keene does not expect to have to draw on it this season, thanks largely to a $1 million challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. But he sees no similar grants on the horizon.
 To cope with these financial stresses, he has tightened administrative belts and chiseled away at the production budget. And having weathered an orchestra strike during his first season, in 1989, he found himself futilely begging the union to accept a wage freeze just as negotiations on the next contract were about to begin.
At the same time, Mr. Keene has been trying to keep an uneasy peace between his administration and the company's board, which is understandably concerned about the deficits. The board's main frustration has been the difficulty of finding new donors willing to fork over significant sums. At least one board member has suggested that the changing demographics of the city and the increased demands on both private and public funds augur poorly for the notion of "opera for the masses," the original dream of the company's founders.
 For all of that, Mr. Keene projects an air of confidence and control. The desk in his office at the New York State Theater is bare but for a few neatly stacked scores and a telephone, and his bookshelves are equally free of the trappings of administrative chaos. Although he concedes that the problems never seem to let up, nothing in his manner suggests desperation. To the contrary.
 "We are far from being in dire straits," he insisted. "We are in a tight spot. But this company always has been in a tight spot. I have a chart of famous shipwreck years in City Opera's history. In the worst of them, the deficit accounted for about 20 percent of the total budget. Our 1992 deficit was closer to 10 percent." During the tenure of his predecessor, Beverly Sills, Mr. Keene added, the deficit approached $6 million. If she could cope with that, he reasons, he can handle his current problems.
 His optimism obscures a few details. For one, Miss Sills, a famously persuasive fund-raiser, is a resource the company no longer has. She served briefly on the board after resigning as director but came to feel that Mr. Keene would not have autonomy until she left the company completely. Last year, to the chagrin of former City Opera colleagues, she joined the board of the Met. She insists that she is not raising money there and argues that her reputation for effortlessly attracting vast sums is overstated.
 "Look," she said, "it's true that I had connections. There were people who were fishing buddies of my husband's, who only gave money to the company because he called and said: 'Beverly is coming to see you. Be nice.' And when I was singing, just about every C.E.O. in the country knew that I was good for a free performance if they put on a concert to benefit handicapped children. So there was a lot that was owed to me, and when I ran City Opera, I called in the chits."
 Miss Sills had other help in clearing the $6 million debt that may not be available to Mr. Keene. "Beverly was able to wipe out that deficit," said Robert Wilson, who resigned as chairman of the board in April after a 12-year term, "because at the time, Lloyd Rigler loaned the company $3 million and then forgave part of the loan, and I gave the company $1 million. But there were special circumstances then. We felt that before Beverly the company had not been well managed. Julius Rudel was conducting rather than minding the store, and the finances were a mess. We thought that Beverly's arrival was the start of a new era, that she would manage the company well, and therefore it should be saved. Beverly did manage it well, and so did Christopher. And now my feeling is that if it can't hack it under good management, why pour more money into it?"
 Mr. Rigler could not be reached to discuss future contributions, but he was just elected co-chairman of the board with Irwin Schneiderman, who said that accepting the position implied a commitment to keeping the company alive.
 Mr. Wilson, who remains on the board, pledged in 1989 to give the company $2.5 million in installments through 1995. When asked whether he expected to contribute after 1995, he said, "I hope to continue to be generous." Mr. Wilson has lately become a voice in the wilderness at board meetings, arguing that if the company does not change its ways, it will run out of money before the end of next season.
 "In the early 1980's," he said, "the critics were excoriating our performances, and not without reason. Artistically, they were appalling. So we decided to do what we could to improve the quality. Doing that has been expensive. But I think in recent years it has been universally conceded that the quality is up. Unfortunately, our box office is exactly what it was when we were a second-rate company, and our contributor base has not grown either. So the question I raised was, 'If the audience doesn't appreciate the difference, why should we keep spending money to make this a first-rate company?' "
 Mr. Wilson's argument has found little support at City Opera or elsewhere. "I disagree with him," said Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Met. "It could be that if they had not improved the quality, the audience would have dropped another 20 percent."
 Mr. Schneiderman also dismisses Mr. Wilson's theory, while agreeing that expenses must be trimmed. "Our budget is around $22 million," he said, "but based on our public support, maybe we really should be a $20 million company. We're trying hard to get ourselves working within our means. But if you look at what we're doing, you'll see the difficulty. Christopher is not spending a lot of money on productions."
 Indeed not. Mr. Keene says he will not approve a budget of more than $250,000 for a production that will stay in the repertory. (Met productions can top $1 million.) For specialist productions his ceiling is $120,000. Often, the costs are well under those limits. Bernd Alois Zimmermann's notoriously difficult "Die Soldaten" cost $65,000 two seasons ago, and Schoenberg's "Moses und Aron" was bought from the Cologne Opera for only $35,000 in 1990.
 Not much money is wasted on performers, either. The top fee for singers and conductors is $1,750 a night -- "with no exceptions," Mr. Keene said --compared with a $12,000 limit at the Met and even higher fees in Europe. The fee structure makes for a transient roster and for even more artistic and commercial frustration.
 Great singers have passed through City Opera: Placido Domingo, Jennie Tourel, Mignon Dunn, Tatiana Troyanos, Jose Carreras, Norman Triegle. A few, like Miss Sills and Samuel Ramey, formed an attachment to the company and continued to sing with it long after their earning power outpaced City Opera's pay scale. But with the best singers being snapped up by other companies, long-term casting is impossible, and the company cannot rely on stars to lure its audience.
 THIS PROBLEM CAN BE TRACED back to City Opera's earliest days, as in fact can most of its current problems. Debates over repertory have been almost continuous. The company's founding music director, Laszlo Halasz, clashed with the board over his desire to conduct contemporary works. He won the battle, establishing contemporary music as part of the company's mandate. During Mr. Rudel's tenure as general director, from 1957 to 1979, the company stepped up its commitment to new music, a commitment Mr. Keene has fought to uphold. Significantly, 20th-century music makes up the heart of the anniversary season, with a new production of Sir Michael Tippett's "Midsummer Marriage" in September, and a weeklong premiere festival of works by Ezra Laderman, Lukas Foss and Hugo Weisgall in October.
 In the face of mounting costs and dangerous deficits, Mr. Wilson wonders whether it makes sense for the company to be adventurous, even though he finds its contemporary productions the most appealing. "Very few people are interested in adventure," he observed. "When we present something unusual, or when I go to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, I see the same old crowd. They can fill the hall for three or four performances, but that's it. And we can't afford that."
 Yet it is mainly when City Opera presents unusual repertory that Mr. Wilson's dream of luring the Met's audience comes true. Mr. Volpe of the Met said: "How many Met patrons went to hear 'Moses und Aron'? I know that when I went, I saw a lot of people I normally see at the Met."
 Of the 226 works City Opera will have presented by the end of this season, 76 are by 20th-century American composers. The list includes musicals and theater pieces, which multiplied during Miss Sills's tenure. Miss Sills accepted a $5 million grant from Lawrence Wien to produce musicals every year for five seasons and saw them as a way to provide the extra performance weeks required by the orchestra players' contracts. But since those who control the rights to the best musicals tend to hold out for Broadway revivals, City Opera is left with second-rate properties like "110 in the Shade" and "The Pajama Game." Many operagoers -- and not only critics -- have questioned the appropriateness of these works as opera house fare.
 "Some of our board members feel that doing these musicals is a mistake," Mr. Schneiderman volunteered. "We don't do them all that well. They don't fit the company's image. The only reason we're doing them is to provide work for the orchestra, and we can't keep doing that."
 Budgets and ticket sales have always been headaches, too. In the 1950's, attendance sometimes fluctuated between 55 and 65 percent. (In those years, the company played at City Center, about the same size as the New York State Theater, which seats 3,000.) And insolvency has always lurked in the wings. Newspaper articles have repeatedly warned of the company's demise.
 But Mr. Keene and the board recognize that survival takes more than faith, and in their more realistic moments, they admit that they are facing problems peculiar to the 90's. Corporate sponsors think twice about contributing to the arts when social welfare programs are also demanding their support. And as a New York culture shaped by European immigrants gives way to one with strong third-world strains, the company will have to work harder to renew its audience.
 Some changes are afoot. The board is trying to start an endowment campaign. And Mr. Keene has decided to revert to a spring-fall season, abandoning the summer weeks in 1995. Miss Sills moved the spring weeks to summer in 1984, thinking that without competition from the Met, City Opera would have the opera audience, including tourists, to itself. The summer season worked for a season or two but has since been a liability.
 The shift to the spring, of course, will put City Opera back into direct competition with the Met, but neither company seems worried. Mr. Keene cited some business-world folk wisdom: "The best place to put a gas station is on a street that already has one." At the Met, which in the early 1960's objected vehemently to Lincoln Center's plan to put City Opera on its doorstep, disdain for the smaller company has apparently evaporated.
 "My view of the City Opera is very positive," said Mr. Volpe. "If you look at opera companies in the United States, you see that the more companies there are, the better aware the public is, and that helps all companies. We know that many of our patrons go to the City Opera, and some of theirs come here. We don't see it as a problem."
 Miss Sills takes Mr. Volpe's observation a step further, offering the cheerful view that the half-empty glass is actually half full. "Let me point out," she said, "that if the City Opera is playing to a 72 percent capacity, that means that there are more than 2,000 people there, night after night. That's more than can be accommodated in a normal-size opera house in Europe, where the capacities are more like 1,500. And it's in addition to another 3,500 at the Met, 25 yards away. That's an enormous number of people coming to hear opera.
 "So here's City Opera, a repertory company fighting a rival that's one of the world's great houses, and still drawing a crowd that would sell out a European house. It's ridiculous, if you think about it. And that's why I think that whatever its problems, the company will survive."
FIVE DECADES ON AN OPERATIC ROLLER COASTER
 1943 -- Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, and Morton Baum, a lawyer, outline a plan for City Center, a venue for reasonably priced theater, opera, ballet and concerts at the Mecca Temple on West 55th Street. 1944 -- Mayor Fiorello La Guardia sells the first ticket for New York City Opera's first production, "Tosca," led by Laszlo Halasz, the music director. Reviews are enthusiastic.
1946 -- City Opera presents Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos," the first of its many American premieres.
1949 -- The company presents William Grant Still's "Troubled Island," the first of its many world premieres.
1951 -- The board objects to Halasz's presentation of the premiere of David Tamkin's "Dybbuk"; Halasz objects to budgetary constraints and is replaced by Joseph Rosenstock.
1954 -- "Showboat" draws jeers from the press, which considers it inappropriate operatic fare, while a bona fide operatic rarity, Donizetti's "Don Pasquale," fills only 35 percent of the house.
1955 -- Erich Leinsdorf takes over as director, proposes more contemporary music, hires drama coaches to spiff up the acting, and is fired within a year.
1957 -- Facing financial difficulties, the company cancels its spring season. Julius Rudel is appointed general director, and initiates a golden age of adventurous programming.
1966 -- The company inaugurates its new home, the New York State Theater, with the North American premiere of Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo," starring Placido Domingo.
1978 -- After a succession of failures, Mr. Rudel is replaced as general director by Beverly Sills. 1979 -- Rudolf Nureyev appears in "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme" on an opera/ballet double bill.
1981 -- After years of complaints about the sound in the State Theater, Lincoln Center performs an acoustical makeover.
1983 -- The company's first summer season is wiped out by a 54-day strike; the season finally opens in September with a new toy: a supertitle screen to provide English translations.
1985 -- Teen-agers with cigarettes start a fire that destroys the Passaic, N.J., warehouse complex in which City Opera's costumes are stored.
1988 -- Miss Sills resigns as general director, and Christopher Keene succeeds her. 1989 -- A two-month strike wipes out the fall season.
1990 -- A low-cost production of Schoenberg's "Moses und Aron" imported from Germany proves a critical triumph.
1992 -- After five years of surpluses, the company posts a $2.9 million deficit; a production of Janacek's "Excursions of Mr. Broucek" is canceled to save money.

An article in the Arts and Leisure section on July 25 about the New York City Opera misstated the percentage of decline in ticket sales last season at the Metropolitan Opera. It was 3 percent, not 5. The Met reported the error shortly after the article appeared; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Sea Grass, Tidal Creeks and New Homes

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, GA.

 BODY:
Not too many years ago, the grassy wetlands between this picturesque island and the mainland was considered wasteland, good only for filling in so it could be built upon.
Some islanders, like the novelist Eugenia Price, have lived on large tracts beside the marshes here for decades. 
 But now dozens of housing developments have been built on the mainland sides of the long string of barrier islands on the nation's Southern shore.
Four housing developments are under way beside the marshes here, testifying to what brokers say is the steadily increasing interest in the quiet landscape of sea grass and tidal creeks.
Georgia has only 100 miles of oceanfront, and most of the land that is not permanently protected -- 7 of its 14 barrier islands are owned by either the state or Federal government -- has already been developed.
That scarcity has increased the cost of oceanfront property to $6,000 a foot, and consequently, marshfront land has increased in value, too, said Vernon Mims, a broker with Island Realty here. He estimates the value has grown by at least 35 percent in the past few years.
On St. Simons, an island of 12,000 residents about 290 miles southeast of Atlanta and just 45 miles north of Florida, marshfront lots of 0.75 acre cost about $100,000, Mr. Mims said. Marshfront homes now on the market range in price from $180,000 to $675,000.
St. Simons and the neighboring Jekyll and Sea Islands -- collectively called the Golden Isles -- have long been popular vacation and second-home resorts.
Jekyll, now owned by the state, once was an exclusive retreat for the Rockefeller, Vanderbilt and Morgan families, and later served as a vacation retreat for Jimmy Carter while he was President.
Just east of St. Simons, Sea Island is the location of The Cloister, a well-known resort popular for honeymoons. George and Barbara Bush spent theirs there.
St. Simons, home to Spanish monks in the 1500's, looks like what it is: a town first, resort area second. It has numerous neighborhoods, a few condominiums, and a small downtown with a drugstore, shops and restaurants. After the English drove out the Spanish in the 1700's, St. Simons fostered a thriving timber industry.
In fact, timbers from the island's live oaks were used in building the Brooklyn Bridge in 1874. The Atlantic lies to the east, and the Marshes of Glynn, dramatized in the poem by that name by Sidney Lanier, to the west.
Duane Harris, the director of the coastal resources division of the state's Department of Natural Resources, said Georgia was one of the first states to protect marshland. in 1970, the Legislature outlawed altering its 450,000 acres of wetlands for any purpose other than a water-related activity.
The law was passed after a University of Georgia professor conducting research on nearby Sapalo Island found that as the smooth cord grass in the marshes died, the decaying plants provided food for fish for 30 to 40 miles off shore. He set the value of the marshes themselves at $80,000 an acre, Mr. Harris said.
But the land beside the marshes has some restrictions. Houses must be built at least 13 feet above ground, 25 feet away from the marsh and cannot be taller than 25 feet above the platform. If the property owner owns the marshland adjacent to his house, he can build a walkway across it without a permit from the state.
The attraction to the marshes is simple, brokers and people who live there say: No one can build behind you.
"It's a natural buffer," said Lee Davenport, the executive director of the St. Simons Chamber of Commerce, who is building a house in West Point Lake subdivision, one of the new marshfront developments. "You won't ever have any neighbors on that side."
Also, the marshes offer an array of wildlife, from otters and alligators in the creeks to deer and 200-pound wild black pigs.
Miss Price, the writer, has lived on a four-acre tract beside the marshes since 1967. In "St. Simons Memoir," a book recalling how she came to live on St. Simons, she wrote: "I am so captivated by the dear, dark woods that I now find the ocean almost dull."
Doris Green, who moved from Pennsylvania to a marshfront home when her late husband, Wilson, retired a decade ago, said, "It is very peaceful. Beautiful sunsets, colors change. It's very golden at times." The drawbacks, though, are pesky, persistent deer flies and deer, which ate nearly all her husband's prize rose bushes before he built an electric fence around them.
Mrs. Green's neighbor, Joe Adams, a Delta Airlines captain, said deer had eaten $600 worth of shrubbery at his 3,800-square-foot house, which is on the market for $675,000. Mr. Adams owns about an acre of highland and two acres of marsh up to the Frederica River, which is accessible via a 1,000-foot walkway across the marsh. He said he was selling because his children were grown and the house is too big for just him and his wife.
Most of the people building in the West Point Lake subdivision are professionals, like Dr. James Grooms, a local dermatologist, who is building a large home beside the marsh. A few are buying lots to build retirement homes in the future. About a third of the 36 lots in the subdivision have marsh views; the rest border on a small lake.
The other subdivisions are Hampton Plantation, Hampton Point and Oglethorpe Landing. The 290-acre Hampton Plantation has 75 of its 290 lots on the marsh. Marshfront lots range in price from $69,000 to $175,000, said Nick Joseph, the vice president of sales and marketing.
The development's 18-hole golf course has four holes built on hummocks in the marsh and connected by 800 feet of bridges,
The smaller Oglethorpe Plantation, comprising 18 acres, has 5 marshfront lots ranging in price from $63,000 to $139,000, said Linda Morton, a broker with Parker-Kaufman Realty in St. Simons.
Hampton Plantation's riverfront lots sold within 20 minutes for $75,000 apiece when the project was begun in the 80's, Mr. Harris said. The marshfront lots were not as popular, but interest has increased in recent years.
All of the developments are on the northern, largely undeveloped, end of the island.
At the center of the island is Sea Palms, 800 acres where development began about 20 years ago. Larry Singleton bought the three nine-hole golf courses, convention center, hotel and tennis center in December from the Chase Manhattan Bank, which had foreclosed on the previous owners. He said the purchase price was $10 million.
Mr. Singleton said that about 100 acres of undeveloped land included in the sale would be used for single-family homes.
The development has some riverfront property, but most of the "waterfront" is actually marshfront. The 180-room Sea Palms Golf & Tennis Resort hotel is beside the marsh.
"People probably thought the original developers were crazy," Mr. Singleton said. "People didn't want anything to do with it, worrying that they're going to go underwater every time the tide comes in."
But Mr. Singleton said he and his staff, all local residents, had managed to turn the development around in the last six months. He pared the staff by 100, including 20 managers, and now has about 140 employees.
"This place is making money," he said, "because every single person grew up here and the support is unbelievable from the community."
Last year, he said, the average occupancy rate was 45 percent. Now he said, it is 65 percent.
Mr. Singleton said the stigma of the marshes just doesn't exist any longer.
"You look out our hotel windows and that's what you see," he said. "Down here, marsh is second only to the ocean."
