HEADLINE: Focus: St. Simons Island, Ga.;
Sea Grass, Tidal Creeks and New Homes

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, GA.

 BODY:
NOT too many years ago, the grassy wetlands between this picturesque island and the mainland was considered wasteland, good only for filling in so it could be built upon.
Some islanders, like the novelist Eugenia Price, have lived on large tracts beside the marshes here for decades. But now dozens of housing developments have been built on the mainland sides of the long string of barrier islands on the nation's Southern shore. 
 Four housing developments are under way beside the marshes here, testifying to what brokers say is the steadily increasing interest in the quiet landscape of sea grass and tidal creeks.
Georgia has only 100 miles of oceanfront, and most of the land that is not permanently protected -- 7 of its 14 barrier islands are owned by either the state or Federal government -- has already been developed.
That scarcity has increased the cost of oceanfront property to $6,000 a foot, and consequently, marshfront land has increased in value, too, said Vernon Mims, a broker with Island Realty here. He estimates the value has grown by at least 35 percent in the past few years.
On St. Simons, an island of 12,000 residents about 290 miles southeast of Atlanta and just 45 miles north of Florida, marshfront lots of 0.75 acre cost about $100,000, Mr. Mims said. Marshfront homes now on the market range in price from $180,000 to $675,000.
St. Simons and the neighboring Jekyll and Sea Islands -- collectively called the Golden Isles -- have long been popular vacation and second-home resorts. Jekyll, now owned by the state, once was an exclusive retreat for the Rockefeller, Vanderbilt and Morgan families, and later served as a vacation retreat for Jimmy Carter while he was President.
Just east of St. Simons, Sea Island is the location of The Cloister, a well-known resort popular for honeymoons. George and Barbara Bush spent theirs there.
St. Simons, home to Spanish monks in the 1500's, looks like what it is: a town first, resort area second. It has numerous neighborhoods, a few condominiums, and a small downtown with a drugstore, shops and restaurants. After the English drove out the Spanish in the 1700's, St. Simons fostered a thriving timber industry.
In fact, timbers from the island's live oaks were used in building the Brooklyn Bridge in 1874. The Atlantic lies to the east, and the Marshes of Glynn, dramatized in the poem by that name by Sidney Lanier, to the west.
Duane Harris, the director of the coastal resources division of the state's Department of Natural Resources, said Georgia was one of the first states to protect marshland. in 1970, the Legislature outlawed altering its 450,000 acres of wetlands for any purpose other than a water-related activity.
The law was passed after a University of Georgia professor conducting research on nearby Sapalo Island found that as the smooth cord grass in the marshes died, the decaying plants provided food for fish for 30 to 40 miles off shore. He set the value of the marshes themselves at $80,000 an acre, Mr. Harris said. But the land beside the marshes has some restrictions.
Houses must be built at least 13 feet above ground, 25 feet away from the marsh and cannot be taller than 25 feet above the platform. If the property owner owns the marshland adjacent to his house, he can build a walkway across it without a permit from the state.
THE attraction to the marshes is simple, brokers and people who live there say: No one can build behind you.
"It's a natural buffer," said Lee Davenport, the executive director of the St. Simons Chamber of Commerce, who is building a house in West Point Lake subdivision, one of the new marshfront developments. "You won't ever have any neighbors on that side."
Also, the marshes offer an array of wildlife, from otters and alligators in the creeks to deer and 200-pound wild black pigs.
Miss Price, the writer, has lived on a four-acre tract beside the marshes since 1967. In "St. Simons Memoir," a book recalling how she came to live on St. Simons, she wrote: "I am so captivated by the dear, dark woods that I now find the ocean almost dull."
Doris Green, who moved from Pennsylvania to a marshfront home when her late husband, Wilson, retired a decade ago, said, "It is very peaceful. Beautiful sunsets, colors change. It's very golden at times." The drawbacks, though, are pesky, persistent deer flies and deer, which ate nearly all her husband's prize rose bushes before he built an electric fence around them.
Mrs. Green's neighbor, Joe Adams, a Delta Airlines captain, said deer had eaten $600 worth of shrubbery at his 3,800-square-foot house, which is on the market for $675,000. Mr. Adams owns about an acre of highland and two acres of marsh up to the Frederica River, which is accessible via a 1,000-foot walkway across the marsh. He said he was selling because his children were grown and the house is too big for just him and his wife.
Most of the people building in the West Point Lake subdivision are professionals, like Dr. James Grooms, a local dermatologist, who is building a large home beside the marsh. A few are buying lots to build retirement homes in the future. About a third of the 36 lots in the subdivision have marsh views; the rest border on a small lake.
The other subdivisions are Hampton Plantation, Hampton Point and Oglethorpe Landing. The 290-acre Hampton Plantation has 75 of its 290 lots on the marsh. Marshfront lots range in price from $69,000 to $175,000, said Nick Joseph, the vice president of sales and marketing.
The development's 18-hole golf course has four holes built on hummocks in the marsh and connected by 800 feet of bridges,
The smaller Oglethorpe Plantation, comprising 18 acres, has 5 marshfront lots ranging in price from $63,000 to $139,000, said Linda Morton, a broker with Parker-Kaufman Realty in St. Simons.
Hampton Plantation's riverfront lots sold within 20 minutes for $75,000 apiece when the project was begun in the 80's, Mr. Harris said. The marshfront lots were not as popular, but interest has increased in recent years.
All of the developments are on the northern, largely undeveloped, end of the island.
AT the center of the island is Sea Palms, 800 acres where development began about 20 years ago. Larry Singleton bought the three nine-hole golf courses, convention center, hotel and tennis center in December from the Chase Manhattan Bank, which had foreclosed on the property. He said the purchase price was $10 million.
Mr. Singleton said that about 100 acres of undeveloped land included in the sale would be used for single-family homes.
The development has some riverfront property, but most of the "waterfront" is actually marshfront. The 180-room Sea Palms Golf & Tennis Resort hotel is beside the marsh.
"People probably thought the original developers were crazy," Mr. Singleton said. "People didn't want anything to do with it, worrying that they're going to go underwater every time the tide comes in."
But Mr. Singleton said he and his staff, all local residents, had managed to turn the development around in the last six months. He pared the staff by 100, including 20 managers, and now has about 140 employees.
"This place is making money," he said, "because every single person grew up here and the support is unbelievable from the community."
Last year, he said, the average occupancy rate was 45 percent. Now he said, it is 65 percent.
Mr. Singleton said the stigma of the marshes just doesn't exist any longer.
"You look out our hotel windows and that's what you see," he said. "Down here, marsh is second only to the ocean."

HEADLINE: Thousands of Missing-Persons Cases

BYLINE: By LISA BETH PULITZER

 BODY:
WHEN Florence Orvieto of Stony Brook learned the fate of her daughter Lorraine, whose death was linked to Joel Rifkin, the reported serial killer, this month, she was shocked by more than the circumstances surrounding the case. The body of her daughter, she learned, was found, but not identified, exactly one year ago and had been lying in a morgue in New York City despite a missing person's report filed in Suffolk County in January 1992.
Lorraine Orvieto, 29, was one of nearly 5,000 people reported missing last year on Long Island. But the police said her case was extremely uncommon. 
 "We handle between 2,500 to 3,000 missing persons cases a year," said Officer John Gmelch of the Suffolk County missing persons unit and a member of the team that investigated the Orvieto case. "The totals seem to stay roughly the same. I think only one-10th of 1 percent are murdered or meet with foul play."
That statistic offered little solace to the Orvieto family, who spent more than 18 months searching for their daughter.
An investigator for the state police office in Farmingdale, Edward Lloyd, said that at least five of the victims identified in the Rifkin case were the subjects of missing persons reports,but that just Anna Lopez of the Bronx had been identified through a missing person's report.
 
'Part of Tracking Problem'
 "I think it is part of the tracking problem," said Craig McCrary of the Federal Bureau of Investigation Behavioral Science Center in Quantico, Va. The center, which studies serial killers, was portrayed in "Silence of the Lambs," the movie released in 1991, the year that Mr. Rifkin reportedly began his spree.
"Right now in the United States," Mr. McCrary added, "there is no one place to report homicides. We have over 17,000 different police agencies. That means missing persons and homicides get reported and are spread out over 17,000 different agencies."
He said his agency had set up the Violent Criminal Apprehension Program. "The idea is to get as many homicides in this computer system and then look for matches and similarities to begin to identify patterns early on where we may be having a serial killer," he said.
 
Arrested on Parkway
 In the case of Mr. Rifkin, a self-described unemployed landscaper, who lived with his mother and sister in a quiet middle-class neighborhood in East Meadow, the police did not learn of his activities until he was apprehended in a traffic case. He was arrested on June 28, after two state troopers had tried to stop him on the Southern State Parkway because his pickup had no license plates and found the decomposing body of Tiffany Bresciani, 22, wrapped in a blue tarpaulin in the back of his truck.
They said Mr. Rifkin later told them that he was on his way to Republic Airport, where he intended to dispose of the body, but no shovel was found in his truck, just some tools.
In 12 hours of questioning by investigators at the state police office in Farmingdale, Mr. Rifkin admitted to killing 17 women, all of whom he said where prostitutes from New York City, according to the police.
"One reason prostitutes are favored victims of serial killers is they lead a very transient life style," Mr. McCrary said. "They come and they go. This is a common problem, especially in a large metropolitan area like New York. After all, who if anybody tracks missing prostitutes?"
The police can accept a missing person's report on people over the age of 18 only if there is evidence of foul play or the subject has a history of mental illness or requires medication.
In the report filed by the family of Lorraine Orvieto, whose body was found on July 11, 1992, by a fisherman in a drum in Coney Island Creek in Brooklyn, relatives described her as manic depressive, a cocaine abuser and a former psychiatric patient.
Although the Suffolk police did conduct a search, her body was not identified until her driver's license was found in Mr. Rifkin's bedroom.
"Why there wasn't a match I couldn't tell you," Officer Gmelch said. "The condition of the body possibly. But in most cases where a person has been dead for a long time the only way to identify the body is through dental records. But you have to have something to match the dental records up with."
 
Juveniles Among Missing
 Of the cases filed in Suffolk last year almost two-thirds were juveniles. For the group 15 and younger, most were runaways. In Nassau the number of juveniles among those reported missing was a little more than half.
"Youngsters get into a fight with their parents and they take off," said Lieut. Robert Reed, commander of the juvenile and missing persons unit in Nassau.
Fifty-seven percent of the juvenile cases reported involve females under 17, but for those younger than 12 most reports involve boys.
"They generally don't like the rules at home," the head of the missing persons unit in Suffolk, Sgt. Paul Schiefke, said. "They feel the parents are too strict."
The police said although most youngsters returned home on their own, sometimes the police obtain a lead or other clues about the youngsters' whereabouts from friends. The police may also learn that the youngsters' friends are "hiding them out."
"It is very rare that they don't turn up," Sergeant Schiefke said. "I don't think we have any active cases where a child under the age of 16 has been abducted or not returned."
Nationwide nearly 31,000 children were reported missing from 1984 to 1992, according to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Of those 20,594 were located alive, 304 were found dead and 9,000 remain missing.
According to police statistics 65 percent of missing people voluntarily return home or are found in 48 hours, 82 percent in seven days, 87 percent in 14 days, 94 percent in 30 days and 99.9 percent in six months to a year.
There are about 10 classifications for missing people, including endangered, runaway, mentally or physically affected, suicidal and possible drowning victim.
For missing adults, the police said, 99 percent leave voluntarily, usually because of domestic or employment problems. "Adults who are missing usually do not want to be found," Sergeant Schiefke said. "They are always a mystery. There's always something else involved."
 
In Another Life
 One man in Suffolk whose wife reported him missing was found by the police almost eight years later in Massachusetts selling aluminum siding and living with a different family.
In another case, a man from Long Island reportedly drove his car onto the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, parked it, and disappeared. No one witnessed his jumping, but his body was never recovered.
The police follow certain guidelines when filing a missing person's report. "We follow any leads the person reporting the person tells us," Sergeant Schiefke said.
After 30 days a more detailed report that includes dental records is registered with the State Division of Criminal Justice computer system. The information -- body descriptions, including tattoos, dental work and other characteristics -- is matched to people missing statewide and nationwide.
"Let's say someone finds a body, a skeleton in the woods of Ohio," Officer Gmelch said. "They would take it to the Medical Examiner's office. He may estimate that it is a female, age 20-40, about 5 feet 5 inches. The computer will then match every female that is around 5 feet 5 inches."
"These are done on all cases," Sergeant Schiefke said. "If there is any hit any place in the country, any kind of match, two or three descriptive characters that might pop up, we follow that lead. The information stays in an active file for years and years. We have some cases from 1937."
The police said that in his confession Mr. Rifkin had described how he had bought sex from his victims, all petite, strangled or suffocated them, and disposed of their bodies throughout the region. He took one break, said Lieut. Eugene Corcoran of the state police in Farmingdale, to telephone his mother. Lieutenant Corcoran said that was the only time that Mr. Rifkin became emotional in the interrogation.
As investigators were questioning her son, Mrs. Rifkin was meeting with the police, who spent at least four hours in her house.
Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Robert Sale, said the police had told her that her son was being detained because of traffic violations. "I'm the one who told her of what we later learned to be the allegations," he said.
In an interview at his office in Hempstead, Mr. Sale, an associate of Eric W. Naiburg, Amy Fisher's lawyer, indicated that he was displeased with how the police conducted their investigation.
The other day the Westchester County police identified an 18th victim and linked the body to Mr. Rifkin, who was in the Nassau County jail.
"I can say that if Amelia Erhardt's body washed up on shore, it would not surprise me if they tried to link Joel Rifkin to her disappearance," said Mr. Sale, former bureau chief of county and district court for the Nassau County Legal Aid Society, where he worked from 1968 to 1976.
"I would guess that first of all, most of these bodies were not found until the perpetrator literally took the police to them," said Jim Omohundro of the uniform crime-reporting program of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. "So if they don't have a body they don't know a murder has been committed. Without a body, it's just a missing person's report, and a missing person is simply not a criminal matter.
"In terms of linking them to a single guy the question is even if they uncover isolated bodies in different jurisdictions, how are they going to know they are dealing with a serial killer unless there is some sort of a database linking homicide victims."
When a person is missing, or murdered, but no missing person's report has been filed, it is nearly impossible to identify the body. "Who knows who they are if nobody reports them missing?" Sergeant Schiefke said.
 
Timne-Consuming Process
 Looking for a missing person is not as glamorous as it appears on television. Officer Gmelch said in many cases identifications were made through hundreds of telephone calls in a time-consuming process.
One problem is that all information must be obtained through official channels, he said, adding, "Everything has to be done on official letterhead," to check mental institutions, drug-rehabilitation centers and hospitals. "Once a letter is sent the check may not come back right away. It could take months."

HEADLINE: Toward Broader Ambulance Coverage

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
SHOULD you be stricken suddenly with a heart attack or a stroke, geography can determine whether you live or die, contends Lenore A. Minerva, owner of Empress Ambulance Service in Yonkers.
"If you're stricken in New Rochelle, Mount Vernon or Yonkers, you will have a good chance of surviving, but if you happen to be in Hastings or Dobbs Ferry, for example, you are going to have a real problem," Ms. Minerva said, explaining that those communities, unlike New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and Yonkers, don't have advance-life-support emergency medical-service systems with paramedics on call 24 hours a day. 
 What Ms. Minerva would like to see is an around-the-clock uniform system of emergency care in Westchester to make sure that everyone in the county has access to emergency medical services.
"Right now, emergency service is patchwork," she said. "Some communities have good systems; others have spotty, infrequent service. My goal is to convince everyone that medical emergency service is so important that it should be put on a par with fire and police departments."
 
Started in 1976
 She continued, "Service could be integrated into the volunteer emergency medical ambulance corps that now exist in many Westchester communities simply by adding 24-hour advance-life-support paramedic systems."
Ms. Minerva added, "In all five boroughs of New York City, they have advance-life-support systems in operation around the clock, and they are saving lives every day."
Ms. Minerva's company, Empress Ambulance Service, is the largest provider of medical services in the Hudson Valley region, responding to approximately 165 calls for immediate medical help a day, 60,000 calls a year with a fleet of 45 ambulances backed by 200 employees.
"The company has come a long way since my husband, Daniel, started in business in 1976," Ms. Minerva said. "All we had was an idea, a bank loan and one van."
 
Mobility for the Handicapped
 The company started by the Minervas was American Ambulette, a medical-transportation business that Ms. Minerva still owns, and the van was used to take physically impaired people back and forth to their appointments or for medical treatment or to their jobs.
"That type of service, which made it possible for physically challenged people to go on normal errands, didn't exist at the time," Ms. Minerva said. "We found a niche in the market.".
By 1983, American Ambulette, in conjunction with the county, developed a pilot program to provide transportation to physically handicapped residents.
In two years' time, the Paratransit program was operating countywide, and it now provides transportation for 350 people a day in a fleet of 100 ambulettes.
"The county, namely County Executive Andrew O'Rourke, were really farsighted when they initiated this program," Ms. Minerva said. "It gives people who never had it before mobility."
She continued, "Now they will be able to get to work, go to school and, in joining the mainstream, they are also able to pay taxes and return something to society."
She added that the Americans with Disabilities Act will only increase the need for transportation for many more people in the near future.
Empress Ambulance Service -- which was a three-ambulance concern in Yonkers when the Minervas acquired it in 1985 to "protect our position in the industry and give us a base to enter the emergency-services segment of it" -- has now grown to a fleet of 45 ambulances.
"Later in the year after we bought Empress," Ms. Minerva added, "we got approval to become the sole provider of emergency medical services for the city of Yonkers, and the next year we became the advance-life-support-system emergency medical service provider for New Rochelle and Mount Vernon."
In 1988, Empress introduced what is called a paramedic fly-car system, which is integrated into the ambulance service to shorten response time.
"With fly car, we are on the scene in 4 to 10 minutes," Ms. Minerva said. "A fly car, which has one or two paramedics and is fitted out with all the necessary advance-support equipment, is always the first vehicle on the scene."
The paramedics assess the patient's condition and begin treatment. "Our paramedics are certified by the New York State Department of Health, which requires 1,800 hours of both clinical and classroom work," Ms. Minerva said.
 
A Life-and-Death Business
 She added, "Paramedics represent the highest level of pre-hospital technicians, trained to carry out a variety of lifesaving procedures on patients."
Two-way radio equipment enables the paramedics to follow the orders of a doctor who is on call at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers to advise them on standard operating procedures, Ms. Minerva said.
"I only wish my husband had had such prompt lifesaving treatment when he had what turned out to be a fatal heart attack in 1988," she said. "The ambulance that we called didn't arrive for 20 minutes. I gave him CPR, but it was not enough. I never forget for one day that we are in a life-and-death business."
Since her husband died, Ms. Minerva, who is 50, has been the company's chief executive officer and chairwoman. Robert H. Pontbriand is president, and the three Minerva sons, Michael, Daniel and Matthew, are an integral part of the company.
 
A Separate Company Established
 "They love the business and have been involved in it ever since they were old enough to work in the company during the summers," Ms. Minerva said. "The boys have a lot of energy, and we are planning expansions. For instance, two years ago we started providing high-risk transport for the Westchester County Medical Center and a year later contracted with the medical center to supply them with A.L.S.-staffed ambulances at the center."
More recently, she added, the company has expanded into other municipalities in the county, signing contracts to handle emergency medical services in a joint effort with the volunteer corps of Harrison and Yorktown.
Despite the sluggish economy, Empress grossed $11 million in sales last year, and American Ambulette grossed $5 million.
Those figures, Ms. Minerva said, are a result of "watching spending and costs like a hawk."
She added: "This is a business that requires a large capital outlay -- a fully equipped ambulance costs $65,000, and our payroll is large. Although there are always sick people who need our services, our cash flow is slow and profit margins thin.
"We deal with so many hundreds of claims that some years ago I developed a computer program to handle the billing and the administration. It grew into a free-standing company that we run called Medical Billing Systems, which markets electronic billing systems for all phases of the medical transportation industry."
Small wonder, then, that last month Ms. Minerva was selected as one of 11 business owners in southern New England and suburban New York to be named Entrepreneur of the Year in a program started by the accounting firm of Ernst & Young to recognize and honor outstanding business owners and founders. Ms. Minerva is now entered in the national competition for the Entrepreneur of the Year Award to be announced later this year.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Ruth Pierson Churchill;
Years of Elegance, a Life of Good Works

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY HORNER

DATELINE: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
"I REMEMBER every detail," Ruth Pierson Churchill said. She was recalling the time -- almost a century ago -- when the communities of Chatham, Madison and Florham Park were known for their manor houses, landed estates and world-famous rose nurseries. And well she might, for Mrs. Churchill is the granddaughter of Louis Mulford Noe, whose rose greenhouses and dairy farms once ranged over several hundred acres of this area.
Mrs. Churchill will celebrate her 97th birthday on Aug. 22, but her age seems to have barely reduced her schedule. 
 In recent months, she received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at the Drew University commencement, in recognition of the 30 years of research she devoted to placing the university's Mead Hall on the National Register of Historic Places. (The award spoke of her long connection with Drew and of the fact that she had "dated one of our most noted seminarians.")
She was honorary chairwoman of Centenary College Alumni Association Day. And her book of personal essays, "Memories Entwined With Roses," first published in 1984, went into its third printing.
In some ways, for a well-to-do woman of that day, Mrs. Churchill was a pioneer. She attended a local private school, Centenary Collegiate Institute (which became Centenary College) and then a finishing school in Washington before going on to Smith College and a Phi Beta Kappa key. But then she joined the Overseas Relief Service in Chateau-Thierry, France, where she assisted war-torn families. And in 1921 she was living in Greenwich Village and working on an atlas for the Rockefeller Foundation.
And yet, in other ways, she resembled her contemporaries. "I am very domestic," she said, describing her pride in Arthur Burdett Churchill, an advertising executive, whom she married in 1923, and the achievements of her three children, Emily, Martha and John, and their offspring.
Q. What is the question you're most often asked?
A. How do you have so much energy at this time of your life? I do what I have to do and take it as it comes. But I can boil it up. Recently -- one after the other -- there was the Centenary College event; next, I autographed 100 of my books in a reception given me by the Historical Society of Chatham Township. The week before, there was the Drew award, followed by a family reunion with 30 kids here.
When I was 88, I was quoted as saying that I take no vitamins, but now I take six pills -- some for I don't know what. I've always been athletic, love gardening and eat a great deal of fruits and vegetables, but nowhere near the red meat I once did.
Q. You had a special way of life -- being driven to church in a coach, enjoying shopping excursions to New York City to the Ladies' Mile and then lunch at the Waldorf. Did you ever have contact with the economically deprived?
A. When we were children, often tramps would stop by our home. Mother couldn't say no, and they were always fed on the back porch -- -- probably knowing that ours was a hospitable home because of marks they put on the telephone poles. She'd also invite poor children to come up from Newark for picnics.
There was no welfare then, but we had those wonderful gardens, and Mother would have big baskets of fruits and vegetables sent to sick and poor people.
Q. For 25 years you served on the board of the Morris County Welfare Board. To what do you attribute your concern?
A. Again, to my mother, who taught us that we were privileged children who had to do things for others.
We were Protestants, but there was a Catholic nun who visited. We'd get culls -- that what they called greenhouse roses without straight stems -- and give them to her for the altar.
The club I belonged to as a child -- we called ourselves the Busy Bees -- held fairs to give a little black girl an artifical limb. Mother regularly gave dinners in Madison for some black boys; they were only about 10 years old and weren't permitted to use the Y.M.C.A.
Q. The rose industry then employed hundreds of newly arrived immigrants.
A. In a way, Grandfather's estate was like a Southern plantation. Grandfather was always called "the Big Boss" and Grandmother, "Mother Noe." Several of the hired men lived in small rooms in the potting sheds and had their meals at the Boarding House located at the top of the hill on Noe Avenue. There was no place for families to gather until the 1920's, when the Neighborhood House was built; it had running water and cooking facilities, but the outhouse was nearby.
All those people working -- Irish, Italians, German -- were poor people. The Italians had to walk all the way from Madison; there was a big Italian colony there. They came in by the day to plow the field, and their social life also depended on the Neighborhood House. But those were happy times, and Noe Farm was considered a big family working together -- before suburbia took over the area.
Q. Have you kept in touch with any of those workers?
A. Yes, because at one time many people in Madison could say that some member of their family worked on the Noe farm.
Q. What problems did you observe in the early years of the 20th century?
A. Alcoholism was a problem. There was a lot more drunkenness on the streets. When I was a youngster, the famous Battle Hill Tavern on the corner of Waverly Place and Main Street was really a saloon, and often drunks would stagger out through its swinging doors into the arms of Captain Johnson, Madison's only police officer. "Walk on the other side of the street," Mother would warn.
We had pollution and didn't know it. The soft coal that caused it was essential to the greenhouses, and Grandfather Noe purchased property near the Chatham railroad station, where he had his own private siding to receive it. A large farm wagon pulled by horses delivered coal to our house, and the careful driver would sprinkle it with cold water to control the dust.
Q. Much of your time has been on behalf of historical preservation of landmarks. Do you think the newer immigrants entering Morris County -- and the rest of New Jersey -- have the potential for such devotion?
A. I listened the other night to a debate on television about whether America can become a melting pot or whether the way will be diversity, and I think diversity will win out. This is going to be a whole different world, and historic preservation may not be a major concern.
But I'm not worried; the world has changed so much in my lifetime. It's better to think of what immigration brings. There are brilliant people who are going to come out of this, to lead us on to something else.
When I look back, my grandmother was so prejudiced against Catholics. My son married a Catholic; I have three grandchildren baptized in the Catholic church and a granddaughter married to a wonderful Jewish man. My family was Methodist, and I'm Unitarian. And I just don't think of race. I would rather my child be married to a fine man of another race rather than to someone who didn't love her. I've changed; I've really changed a lot.
Q. You mention having been a widow for more than 26 years. What has helped sustain you?
A. I could never go into a group to be helped. I'm a person who is strong in my individuality because I realize that everything has to die -- even trees die. The night my husband died, I was in the room with him and he was suffering so, I couldn't stand it. I stood out in the corridor, and a nurse said, "Hello, dearie, how do you feel?" and I said, "Awful, I'm just praying that my husband will die."
When the doctor called and said he had died, my son was there. He cried, and I cried.
I don't mourn. I just think of the wonderful life I had with him. Of course, it's different when you're a widow and you don't have a fine husband to go with, but I made it on my own. I've traveled worldwide. I've had beaus. Two wonderful men wanted to marry me, but I didn't want to get married.
Q. You say you were a maverick growing up, and yet there were social rules you obeyed. What do you mean?
A. When I was in finishing school, a young man had to buy tickets for the chaperone when he took me out. It's so much better now that things are out in the open. Living together shocked me at first, but then I went off to Hawaii with a man who wanted to marry me.
Q. You make it sound as if you've made a very successful transition from the formal world that you knew so well.
A. I enjoy being free, dressing in jeans and a sweater, still being able to drive, to shop and cook for myself. I don't miss the fussiness, and yet sometimes I yearn for the elegance of the old days -- the coachman in high hat and gloves, the flowers, the beautiful serving, finger bowls and butter balls, the planned things versus helter-skelter and our managing to eat meals together. It was lovely, and sometimes I still make butter balls.

HEADLINE: Yonkers Fighting To Save Rail-Car Jobs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE last three subway cars bound for Taiwan stood on test tracks awaiting a final run at the once-busy Union Rail Car plant here. Alan Suarez, an assembly-line technician, removed his baseball cap to mop his brow and wondered where he would turn next for work.
Union Rail Car, which over the last year manufactured 132 subway cars for Taipei's rapidly growing transit system, recently lost a bid to build 216 more cars for the capital of Taiwan. The contract was instead awarded in early May to a German company whose bid was lower because, according to United States officials, it subcontracted part of the deal to a company subsidized by the South African Government. Officials in Washington are investigating the matter and hope to convince Taipei's Department of Rapid Transit Systems to reverse its decision on the ground that South Africa violated United States and international trade laws. The South African manufacturer, however, denied that any Government subsidy was involved, and Taiwan claimed that the Yonkers company was a front for a Japanese conglomerate. 
 While all sides quarrel about international trade practices, Mr. Suarez and other employees at Union Rail Car are worried about more immediate concerns -- like how they will pay their bills and provide for their families if their company no longer has a job for them.
"I'm bracing myself," said Mr. Suarez, who is 32 years old and has been at Union Rail Car for seven years. "For now, everything in my life is on hold -- even my plans to get married."
At its peak two years ago, there were 220 workers at this company, which is in a sprawling industrial park, originally the home of the Otis Elevator Company, along the Hudson River. Fifty employees remain today, as work on the Taipei contract winds down and only a small order of eight cars from New York City's Transit Authority waits to be filled.
As it is for many blue-collar workers in the country who depend on a dwindling supply of manufacturing jobs for their living, Union Rail Car's workers face not only layoffs but also few prospects for future employment.
Highly paid production workers are fading fast in America as domestic companies lose contracts to global competitors and fight to keep up with advances in technology, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Department of Labor.
The hard facts are that the state had only 981,800 manufacturing jobs in May, the lowest number since 1958, when figures were first recorded. There were 1.8 million manufacturing jobs then.
Westchester has also been hard hit. In May, the county recorded only 46,600 manufacturing jobs, its lowest count ever for the month. And more job losses in the manufacturing sector are expected in coming years -- especially two years from now when General Motors lays off more than 2,000 workers at its North Tarrytown plant.
Typically, production workers earn about $12 an hour, and those like Mr. Suarez in the transportation industry who build autos, buses and subways, earn up to $20 an hour, Mr. Surdey said. "Maybe I'll have to move to find work," said Mr. Suarez, who was born in Ecuador and became a United States citizen when he was 7. "Maybe I'll have to retrain. But it's not like I'm a waiter and can go anywhere to get a job." He said that there were only a few major rolling- stock manufacturers in the United States. Officials -- including Mayor Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers, Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from Harrison, and negotiators from the United States Trade Representative's Office -- are concerned that workers in this city may find themselves on the unemployment line because of South Africa's engaging in what they call unfair trade practices.
"Yonkers wasn't given a level playing field," Ms. Lowey said. "South Africa and Taiwan should abide by the rules if they want to play in the international arena."
The new contract, which would have meant $345.6 million for the Yonkers company, was awarded instead to Siemens, a major electronics and electrical manufacturer based in Erlangen, Germany, with subsidiaries in 131 countries. Part of the deal was subcontracted to the Union Carriage and Wagon Company, a large rolling-stock producer outside of Johannesburg.
Ms. Lowey said that the 4 percent difference between the two bids was made up by the South African Government, a situation the Representative called "actionable under Section 301 of the United States Trade Act of 1974."
Some government subsidies to private industries that bid internationally also violate the principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Ms. Lowey, who is on the Subcommittee on Foreign Operations of the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee, has written to Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, asking his office "to take action to protect hundreds of jobs in Yonkers."
That office confirmed that trade officials were aware of the problem and had had discussions with authorities in Taiwan about alleged subsidies.
Meanwhile, Maria H. Kibby, a spokeswoman for Siemens in Manhattan, said her company had no knowledge of any Government subsidy, but she did say that Siemens was negotiating with representatives of Kawasaki Heavy Industries in Japan (one of the parent companies of Union Rail Car) to give part of this new contract to Union Rail Car.
Alf Lyle, a marketing executive for Union Carriage and Wagon of South Africa, said that the Yonkers company "got beaten fairly and squarely in competition on the open market." He said there was no Government subsidy involved.
Robert Bingham, chief executive officer of the South African company, said subsidies have existed in his country in the past "as they have in most other countries but they have begun to fall away as South Africa is integrated into the international market."
 
A Three-Company Partnership
 Albert Lin, a spokesman for Taiwan's Coordinating Council for North American Affairs in Washington, said Taiwan's Department of Rapid Transit Systems was concerned that Union Rail Car may be just a front for a Japanese company.
If that is true, then the argument that American jobs were being lost because of unfair trade practices does not hold water, Mr. Lin said.
The Yonkers company is a partnership of Yonkers-based Kawasaki Rail Car (a subsidiary of Kawasaki Heavy Industries of Japan) and two other companies -- Nissho Iwai American Corporation (a subsidiary of Nissho Iwai of Japan) and North American Transit Corporation, a subsidiary of Nissho Iwai American. Nissho Iwai American and North American Transit are Manhattan based, said David W. Rose, manager of administration and human resources for Kawasaki Rail Car.
Mayor Zaleski, who called Mr. Lin's comments "nonsense," said: "No way is Union Rail Car a showcase for a Japanese company. These are American jobs we're talking about."
Yonkers had a 7.5 percent unemployment rate in May and cannot afford to see more of its workers on the unemployment rolls, Mr. Zaleski said.
 
A Six-Year Program
 The Mayor, who went to Taiwan last year on behalf of Union Rail Car, said, "It looks like we've become a victim of a misinformation campaign."
He said that other vendors who had been vying for the contract planted doubts in the minds of officials in Taipei about whether Union Rail Car was an American company.
Also, Ms. Lowey, calling the argument that Union Rail Car was a front for a Japanese company "irrelevant," said, "All lines of company ownership are blurred in today's global market."
Union Rail Car has installed the brakes, propulsion and air-conditioning systems, along with the seats, vertical poles and other interior equipment for Taiwan, which is in the third year of a six-year program to expand public transportation. They also assemble the wheel-and-axle carriage.
Taiwan is a 14,000-square-mile island off China's mainland with a population of 20 million. Its cities and roads are "very crowded, just like New York," Mr. Lin said.
 
A 90-Day Interim
 The subway-car shells for the Taipei order were shipped from a Kawasaki Heavy Industries plant in Kobe, Japan, and arrived in Port Elizabeth, N.J. They were then taken by truck to Yonkers. A representative of Taiwan's Department of Rapid Transit Systems inspects the work there.
Union Rail Car, established in 1986, has supplied cars for the A and D Lines of the New York City subway, the PATH system of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and for Philadelphia, among other cities.
Because the new contract does not take effect until 90 days after it is signed, United States officials say they have until the end of month, and perhaps beyond, to convince Taipei officials to reverse their decision.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Baseball Comes to a Resounding Sigh

BYLINE: By THAD MUMFORD; Thad Mumford is a writer and co-executive producer for the television series "Roc" and is a former Yankee batboy.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
While driving to work the morning after the All-Star Game, I was listening to the local all-sports call-in show. The host announced that the topics of concern to him were whether or not Cito Gaston was guilty of pouting in the first degree by not bringing in Mike Mussina; fears that a strike could jeopardize the playoffs and the World Series, and whether fans were pleased with the selection process of the All-Star squad.
After a string of testosterone-intensive commercials, the first caller, Dan from Mar Vista, chose to talk not about baseball but about whether the Lakers were making a serious effort to re-sign A. C. Green. The next caller, John from Northridge, was deeply distressed that the Clippers were no closer to naming a head coach than they had been a month ago. And so on, and so on, and so on. When Paul from Long Beach called to discuss the trade of Eric Dickerson to the Falcons, the exasperated host asked him why he seemed so disinterested in baseball. "It's a dead game, man," came the reply. 
 Whether or not baseball has become a dead game is not really the issue. The unfortunate yet inescapable truth is that baseball, once the game that best articulated the nobilities of American culture, is being soundly defeated in a bloody battle of reality versus perception, especially in the hearts and minds of America's young.
In many ways, baseball's trouble has less to do with the game itself than with the turbulence of a society trying to make sense of its own redefinition. Fathers, once the primary passers of the torch of the game and its idiosyncratic language, today are either nonexistent or unable to find the discretionary time or income to nourish the passion in the next generation of fans. So how did this happen? Here are some possible reasons:

 
 
Television

 
 The great trivializer. In so many areas of modern life there is a causal linkage between television and cultural erosion, and baseball is hardly exempt. Before the television era, the only way to see the game was to see it live. If you were fortunate enough to live in proximity to professional baseball of any level, you were able to see up close and personal the carefully honed artistry of its participants. In those days, you left the park firmly convinced that a player was someone supremely bestowed with magic.
In today's world, where the vast majority of people have the enormous complexities of life explained to them in a half-hour newscast with pictures, baseball as interpreted by television and its tremendous reduction capacity, has become a game that looks easy to play. A game that in person is a sensory, participatory experience on television becomes just so much white noise. Victims of overexposure, great stars who in other times appeared larger than life are now reduced to a kind of cozy familiarity. They fit as comfortably in our living rooms as our local weather people. Can you imagine feeling that way about Ruth, Gehrig or DiMaggio?

 
 
Pop Culture and Video Games
 A generation of young men and women weaned on the helter skelter of music videos and remote control are hardly in sync with a sport that celebrates the amiable meanderings of timeless grace. Our bottom-line pop culture exalts product but has lost patience with process. Feelings of youthful alienation that in previous times expressed themselves in turgid, melodramatic ballads are now nurtured by the often myopic hopelessness and cyncism of today's music and language.
This translates into a kind of generational restlessness that lends itself more to the primordial violence of football or the in-your-face machismo of basketball. The vernacular of the pop culture, once peppered with baseball terminology, is now liberally sprinkled with words like "slam dunk" and "blitz."
Aiding and abetting the cultural estrangement from baseball is the video game. Instead of taking their boundless energy outdoors, playing sports and developing athletic skills, kids now plant themselves in front of computer screens, becoming passively seduced in the process. Can you imagine Mantle, Mays or Snider saying, "I can't come out right now, I'm playing Mindsweeper?"

 
 
The Media
 The sports section, once the playground of myth, fantasy and romance, now regularly features stories of run-amok greed and the failure of the human spirit. Sportswriters, imbued with the self-righteousness of Woodward and Bernstein, have redefined the role of the Fourth Estate. Once a public relations arm for professional athletes, writers seem to have appointed themselves the custodians of morality and candor and with a Geraldo-like scrutiny have put the game and its participants on a par with lawyers and Woody Allen.
While it is important for people to know that an athlete's imported loafers are sometimes filled with clay, it need not be the driving inspiration for reportage. Meanwhile, the hype and exaggeration in our culture have soared to such dizzying heights that Hornsby, Ott and Hubbell would have difficulty satisfying today's expectations. The end result is a population of fans that primarily views athletes as a socially stunted, malcontented, underachieving, princely rewarded aggregate. In the current economic climate, who wants to take anybody out to the old ball game to watch that?

 
 
Nostalgia
 Comparisons to bygone eras and players are usually negative and uninformed (sports journalists play a huge role in this.) Arguments about the superiority of players in other generations rarely take into account the advent of larger gloves, the rampant use of the bullpen by committee, the burgeoning arsenal of two-story pitches, the increased size and athleticism in the modern athlete or the effect of fatigue created by cross-continental flights. Could any of the great players of the golden age produce the same numbers in the company of Dibble, Charlton or Gossage in his prime?
Certainly expansion and the increased popularity of other sports have drained the game's talent pool, but those who insist that the best baseball exists only in black-and-white footage don't know what they are missing.
Baseball can survive its current spate of distractions and continue to thrive if it meets its problems head on. The same television that minimizes is also the world's most powerful marketing tool. Taking its lead from other sports, principally football and basketball, baseball can make better use of its players in giving lie to the notion that life has passed the game by.
As the medium moves into its own brave new world of unlimited channels and program selections, the presentation of the game will evolve to satisfy a new global audience. The music video, the method du jour of gaining entry to a child's imagination, should be used to sell the sport to the modern generation. Instead of running "Catch the fever" commercials that are more or less pop Muzak and play to those already converted, baseball videos directed and produced by the same people that have turned Madonna and Sting into four-dimensional pop icons should saturate MTV and VH1. Wouldn't it be nice to hear baseball referred to as "Cool like dat."
The reverence for tradition that comes with nostalgia should be used not to denigrate the current condition of the game but to provide a historical perspective for fans and players alike. Once again the music videos could be an effective teaching tool.
Above all, baseball must have enough faith in itself to resist the current scurrying to put out its fires with quick-fix solutions. It should believe in the inexorable cyclical nature of life and trust that this, too, shall pass.

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Railroads Threading Freight Around the Midwest's Floods

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 24

 BODY:
Widespread Midwestern flooding is costing the country's railroads tens of millions of dollars, punishing train crews and maintenance workers and taxing the ingenuity and patience of railroad operations employees and their customers. But the freight is getting through.
The railroads account for more than a third of all freight moving through American commerce -- more than any other form of transport -- and their success in getting into and out of the heartland has prevented an economic headache from escalating into a stroke.
 
'War Rooms' and Bufferin
 Total intercity rail freight traffic is down 1.5 percent nationwide from a year ago, according to the most recent weekly tabulations of the Association of American Railroads, which represents the country's 70 largest railroads. But the strikes hobbling Eastern coal production appear to be a more important factor than the flooding, the group said. 
 Auto companies and other leading manufacturers that rely on railroads say factories that are not under water are getting the supplies they need to operate normally.
The tensions of recent days are evident in temporary "war rooms" like that of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway in Schaumburg, Ill., a suburb just west of here, where operations managers spend hours on the telephone, coordinating detours of their trains onto the tracks of other railroads and of other lines' trains onto Santa Fe tracks. Squeezed in among the maps plastered to the walls is a Bufferin dispenser.
More than a quarter of the country's rail freight traffic normally runs through the flood zone. Some critical shipments, like perishable food or products needed immediately to keep individual customers' manufacturing plants running, have been shifted to trucks. But the majority appears to be wiggling through by rail with tolerable delays of up to several days on an ever-changing crazy quilt of detours.
"We have had six railroads use our lines and we've diverted on to four ourselves," said Bob Auman, a spokesman for the Norfolk Southern Railway Company, which is based in Norfolk, Va., and has a network of track that stretches into flood-stricken areas of Illinois, Iowa and Missouri.
 
Truckers Hurt As Well
 The trucking industry, which accounts for less freight than the railroads by weight but more when measured by value, has also run into delays and detours and, like the railroads, has been forced to absorb most of the costs. Although the most heavily traveled routes have remained open, including interstate highway crossings of the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers, some transcontinental trips have been lengthened by as much as 500 miles, said Ferdinand P. Serpe, the executive director of the Illinois Transportation Association, an industry trade group.
Recent improvements have helped the rail system to cope. "The railroad network going into this was in the best shape it had been in modern history, thanks to billions of dollars in investment since deregulation in 1980," Edwin Harper, the president of the railroad association, said. "There's been stress on the system, but the system has been able to handle it."
A big part of that investment has been large, centralized dispatch centers, like the one in Schaumburg. Operations managers can see the exact status of every train on any stretch of the line from a glance at a computer screen. Marketing specialists can use the same computers to tell customers the location of a shipment.
These electronic hubs have made it far easier for railroads to coordinate their activities. And the closer relationships that many railroads have forged with the trucking industry in recent years have also helped.
For the railroads, the challenges of the flood are greater than any that executives can recall. "There have been hurricanes where there was more damage in a particular area, but no one can recall a situation where so much railroad property has been under water for so long," said Mr. Auman of Norfolk Southern.
 
A Detour to Montana
 The Santa Fe sticks as close to its main Chicago-Kansas City-Los Angeles artery as possible. At one point, with track flooded on the Illinois side of its Mississippi River crossing at Niota, Ill., and problems in Missouri as well, the detours sometimes entailed what was called a "North Pole" route, using Burlington Northern tracks to Minneapolis, then to Billings, Mont., and on to Denver.
Now, with the Mississippi crossing restored, a preferred detour involves switching to Burlington Northern lines at Bucklin, Mo., a detour of less than 100 miles, before returning to Santa Fe tracks in Kansas City, Mo.
The Bucklin line, a single track weakened by the weather, cannot handle much traffic, so other routes are used. One alternative follows CSX track to Memphis, then Southern Pacific track to Fort Worth, where the Santa Fe is rejoined.
Each detour adds to fuel costs and running time. In addition, crew arrangements become vastly more complicated. On many detours, railroads must hire crews from the company whose line they are using or, at the least, a pilot to accompany their crew over the unfamiliar track. Even then, complications pop up.
On Thursday, for example, Santa Fe had to send an engine to help a Burlington Northern train stranded on the Santa Fe line through Missouri. The Burlington locomotive turned out to be under-powered to deal with the grade of the unfamiliar track.
Detours also wreak havoc on the precisely scheduled distribution of engines and freight cars to points where they can immediately be put back into service. The Chicago, Central and Pacific Railroad has been sending grain cars that normally shuttle between Iowa and Illinois to Dubuque, Iowa, where they are unloaded onto barges on rail trips as far as New Orleans.
"That results in far fewer loadings, which will have a major impact on our profits," said Paul Anderson, a superintendent of transportation for the line, which is based in Waterloo, Iowa.
While streamlining increased railroad profitability during the 1980's, the railroads are now finding it has impeded their options in dealing with the floods. Over the years, the Santa Fe had become so much more efficient in distributing crews that it closed a personnel center in central Missouri. Now the railroad needs to have crews there to replace those who must leave the trains, under Federal rules that limit consecutive hours of duty.
"We found that the few hotel rooms in the area were already filled with our maintenance people, who have been working round the clock to repair a bridge and track washed out east of the Grand River," Russell Hagberg, the vice president in charge of transportation for Santa Fe, said. The solution, for now, has been to send restored Pullman dining and sleeping cars that the railroad normally uses to entertain its most important clients.
 
One Carrier's Nightmare
 Although some short lines in the region have been severely hurt by the flooding, the only intercity carrier facing potential disaster so far is the Gateway Western Railway, which carries freight from Chicago to Springfield, Ill., on Southern Pacific track, then to Kansas City on its own line. The three-year-old company was hurt when it was forced to abandon a stretch of its route near Louisiana, Mo., after local officials feared that its efforts to raise its flooded track were weakening a levee. Then the rampaging Missouri River blew out and buried a broad stretch of raised track west of Glasgow, Mo.
"It's flowing at 10 knots through there," said Reilly McCarren, the president of the privately owned railroad, which is based in the St. Louis suburb of Fairview Heights, Ill. "There's a danger it will become an alternate course for the river."
Gateway is still operating its normal two trains a day each way between Chicago and Kansas City, but its heavy reliance on Union Pacific and Burlington Northern tracks means that it is losing money every day just when it needs resources for repairs that could cost $7 million or more.
R. L. Banks & Associates, a Washington consulting firm, estimates that the flooding to date is likely to cost the railroad industry $235 million to $275 million.
Most of the big railroads say it is too soon to project their losses. The Burlington Northern, one of the harder-hit lines, said flooding had added up to $10 million to operating costs by June 30.
Some lines have benefited. The Illinois Central, with tracks running from Chicago to New Orleans east of the Mississippi River, has enjoyed a 4 percent jump in its business as grain owners and millers transfer products normally sent by barge.
Railroad executives say the flood experience may lead to maintenance adjustments and new cooperative arrangements among railroads and with truckers, but few foresee any lasting impact. Mr. Auman said Norfolk Southern was unlikely to change plans to tear up part of its track between Moberly, Mo., and Des Moines, even though the availability of that line is now saving it money.
"We've only been running 60 cars of freight a year on that 41-mile stretch," he said. "It's too expensive to maintain as a contingency against a 500-year flood."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1545 words

HEADLINE: STRONG COMPANIES ARE JOINING TREND TO ELIMINATE JOBS

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
It is no longer news that troubled companies are eliminating jobs by the tens of thousands. But the recent announcement by Procter & Gamble that it, too, will shrink its work force called attention to a surprising aspect of America's jobs crisis: profitable companies with booming sales are also shedding jobs, insisting that to survive the 1990's, they must prepare for the worst.
Successful companies once felt free to raise prices to fatten profits. Now, unable to raise prices in a weak economy, the mind-set is to focus on cutting labor costs to maintain profit margins. 
 Explaining Procter & Gamble's decision to eliminate 13,000 jobs during a year of record earnings, Edwin L. Artzt, the company's chairman, told a story with themes that are now standard in American business. He said customer surveys had increasingly found that while shoppers considered the company's soaps, detergents, diapers, shampoos and other brand-name products good quality, they also considered them overpriced. To maintain sales, discounts would be needed, but if profits were to be maintained, costs would have to be cut.
 
'Hitting the Wall' a Concern
 "Our costs had gotten too high because the work process was too complex," Mr. Artzt said in an interview. "I became convinced that if we did not reverse this situation, we would end up two or three years from now hitting the wall, as other companies have."
Thus, Procter & Gamble embraced a practice that has quietly become the daily regimen at such profitable companies as General Electric, A.T.& T. Johnson & Johnson, the Chubb Group of insurance companies, Raytheon and many others. Even a hugely successful and rapidly expanding discounter like Wal-Mart Stores embraces job cutbacks as a basic strategy.
As it opened stores and added more than 100,000 employees in the last year, Wal-Mart simultaneously eliminated some existing jobs. Most stores, for example, had an employee assigned to insure that the electronic scanners at check-out counters were up-to-date with the numerous price changes pasted on products. Now this chore has been added to the duties of store clerks.
"You have to go along regularly cutting a few jobs, or you will get layers of fat and bureaucracy," said Donald Shinkel, a vice president of Wal-Mart. "And when that builds up, you get the sort of crisis that is happening at I.B.M."
Several trends that have gathered steam over the last decade have made job cutbacks almost as popular in corporate America today as takeovers and mergers were in the 1980's. The jobs lost at hundreds of companies feed the country's economic weakness, making a strong economic recovery harder to achieve, some economists say.
"If you can let someone go without affecting your sales, you reduce your wages and increase your profits," said Albert Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a research organization supported by corporations. "That's O.K. at a few companies, but a lot of this is going on and if it continues then there might eventually not be enough wages for people to buy things, and the economy gets hurt."
The Clinton Administration prefers to focus on the jobs created since Mr. Clinton took office -- like those at Wal-Mart or at a new Johnson & Johnson factory in Cincinnati that makes instruments for camera-guided surgery -- rather than those that are being constantly eliminated.
"On net, the economy has generated in the range of 800,000 jobs in the private sector since January, so there is more job growth than job elimination," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said, citing a level of job growth that many economists have considered inadequate to bring down the nation's 7 percent unemployment rate.
"But that still leaves us with two questions," he added. "Are they good jobs? The evidence so far is that they are mostly part time. And secondly, even though jobs are being created, does the conspicuous loss of jobs at many companies create the sort of anxieties among workers that may deter them from spending as much as they otherwise would?"
 
Weak Growth Prompts Cutbacks
 Yet if job cutbacks are hard on the economy, many corporate executives say the weak economic growth since 1989 is a major reason the cutbacks are needed. The weak economy has helped turn millions of Americans into discount shoppers, forcing companies to cut prices, and then labor costs.
Expensive health insurance is advanced as another major reason for holding down payrolls, as is global competition. In nearly a dozen interviews with corporate executives, they frequently held up the International Business Machines Corporation as a frightening example of a company that had ignored competition for too long and must now engage in emergency job shedding. Finally, many executives have depicted the job reductions as a belated correction to the overhiring that took place in a more prosperous America in the 1960's and 1970's -- particularly the hiring of middle-level managers and other white-collar workers.
"Our work force simply grew over time," Mr. Artzt said. "There were too many layers of people, and so we went back and said, 'If we were recreating Procter & Gamble today, how would it look?' "
Adopting a procedure already practiced by many companies in one form or another, Procter & Gamble late last year set up 11 teams, each with 100 managers. They fanned out to the company's 147 factories in the United States and abroad, examining practices and soliciting suggestions from workers who might eventually find their own jobs phased out.
 
Conflicting Views
 "The suggestions bubbled out of the organization," Mr. Artzt said. That view is somewhat at odds with a Conference Board survey, released this month, of 55 companies, each with 10,000 employees or more: 64 percent reported that job-cutting at their companies had "lowered morale among employees who have survived," even when the job-cutting was through attrition or buyouts rather than layoffs.
If you do it once, "you can get back on track," said Helen Axel, the Conference Board researcher who conducted the survey. "But if you keep on downsizing, as many companies are doing, then you keep people on tenterhooks and perhaps in the long run reduce their efficiency. No one knows yet."
The Procter & Gamble teams concluded that 65 computer systems around the world could be consolidated into 3, reducing the need for programmers and other support personnel. The shampoos sold in Europe will now have the same packaging in every country, simplifying production. And there were nearly 150 other proposals.
The bottom line was Mr. Artzt's announcement that 12 percent of the work force, a third in the United States, would be eliminated over three years, mostly through attrition. Thirty factories are to be closed. The cuts will reduce overhead costs to 12 cents of every sales dollar from 14.5 cents, leaving more room to cut prices without shrinking profits.
 
Wages Fall, Profits Rise
 The growing impact of job-cutting is increasingly evident in national statistics. Wages are falling as a percentage of national income, while profits are rising. Among the country's unemployed, the percentage reporting permanent job losses, rather than temporary layoffs, resignations and the like, has risen to more than 40 percent today from less than 30 percent in the mid-1970's, the Labor Department reported. Analyzing an index of help-wanted ads, James Medoff, a Harvard labor economist, found that the number of job openings available to an unemployed worker has declined by 37 percent since 1984.
Finally, white-collar workers without jobs constitute a much bigger percentage of total unemployment than they did in the mid-1970's, recent studies have found. That might reflect the elimination of middle managers and administrators, people often described by corporate executives as secondary to the production process.
"White-collar employment growth stopped during the last recession and remains halted," said Erica L. Groshen, a labor economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who conducted one of the studies. The recession ended in March 1991.
No issue is more troublesome to managers and workers than the impact of job-cutting on the employees who survive. A.T.& T. and many others offer transfers and retraining to dislocated workers. Wal-Mart offers promotions to workers who find ways to eliminate their own jobs, Mr. Shinkel, the Wal-Mart vice president, said. But that is easy at a company that is expanding.
General Electric, which has reduced worldwide employment to 230,000 people from 400,000 in 1981 -- while nearly tripling sales -- takes a different approach: a rapid and wholesale cutback with handsome severance packages, followed by slower and more methodical job shrinkage thereafter, mostly through attrition.
"It was mostly the fat middle management that lost jobs during that initial cutback in the mid-1980's," said Prof. Noel Tichy of the University of Michigan's Business School and a G.E. consultant in those years. "G.E. had the money to do it right, paying a lot of money to the people who left. I.B.M., General Motors and other troubled companies shedding people now don't have the money to be so generous, and that hurts corporate morale."

PUB-DATE: July 26, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1382 words

HEADLINE: EXPANSION OF AID FOR WORKING POOR IS TIED TO BUDGET

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 25

 BODY:
Overshadowed by the fight over raising taxes and cutting the Federal deficit are plans by both houses of Congress to add billions of dollars to a Government antipoverty program, a move that the Clinton Administration casts as a "pay raise for the working poor."
The House has already passed Mr. Clinton's proposal for an expansion of the program, known as the earned-income tax credit. The House bill provides for a $28.3-billion rise over the next five years in what is now an $11 billion-a-year program. That would represent the largest antipoverty measure taken by the Federal Govern ment since the mid-1970's. It would both increase current benefits and expand the number of workers eligible, to 20 million from 14 million now. 
 The Senate bill, though smaller -- an $18.2 billion increase over five years -- would still raise spending on the program by more than a third.
 
From Right and Left
 The 18-year-old tax credit is a program favored not just by liberals but by many moderates and conservatives, largely because it is the primary antipoverty measure that specifically rewards poor people for working. Under the Clinton plan, minimum-wage workers with two or more children would receive nearly $4 in Government payments for every $10 of the first $8,500 they earn working, up from a maximum of $2.50 now.
The question now is not so much whether the House and Senate versions can be reconciled -- Congressional negotiators agree they can and should be -- but whether the compromise expansion being thrashed out in the Capitol will be held hostage to an overall budget agreement. Without the larger plan, the expansion of the tax credit would be in jeopardy.
 
'A Big Difference'
 Veronica Martinez, a 23-year-old Houston mother of three, is one of 14 million people who claimed the credit on her tax form this year. Ms. Martinez earns $4.50 an hour as a checkout clerk in a Fiesta Grocery Mart. Her pay (25 cents over minimum wage) makes her eligible now for a $2.15 credit for every $10 she earns. Under the Clinton plan, she would become eligible for $3.60 for every $10.
"Yes, it made a big difference to me and to them," Ms. Martinez said of the credit she got this year, which she used to buy clothes for her children and a new washer-dryer for her apartment. "And if somebody in Washington's going to come up with some more money, if they're trying to say, 'Keep working, don't give up and go on welfare,' well that's great."
Like the vast majority of people who claim the credit, now available only to people with children, Ms. Martinez receives the benefit in the form of a once-a-year check from the Government, which she received after attaching a one-page form,a Schedule EIC, to her 1040 tax form.
Devised about 20 years ago by former Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, the tax credit has thrived and been expanded over the years in the service of a remarkably diverse set of goals, though all of them still aim at helping the poor.
It has been portrayed as a means to offset an increase in Social Security payroll taxes and to help poor families with child-care costs. It has been expanded twice to make up for Congress's inability to agree on an increase in the minimum wage. Now President Clinton specifically wants to use it, in his words, to "make work pay."
As broad as Mr. Clinton's proposal is, it would stop short of the campaign pledge he made that all families with a full-time worker be guaranteed enough money to live above the poverty line, now defined as a yearly income of $11,500 for a family of three, $14,750 for a family of four. About five million Americans work 40-hour-a-week jobs but remain below the line, the Census Bureau reports.
And many advocates of the program, even as they urge its expansion, argue that the health-care overhaul Mr. Clinton is to unveil may be at least as important as the tax credit in encouraging people to work. Right now, many people who qualify for the federally financed Medicaid program lose their benefits as soon as they start working -- typically in jobs that have no health insurance.
"If today you are a family on welfare, you can simply wind up being worse off working," said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group. "You lose your health-care coverage when you get a job. It undermines the work ethic. But if you can go to work and get your low wages supplemented, and if you do not lose your coverage, the incentives to work become sharply stronger."
 
Not Without Faults
 The tax-credit program has faults. For one thing, it is so complex that hundreds of thousands of people who are eligible for it now do not apply, while many others who are not supposed to receive the credit do claim it, often without prompting an audit.
Nonetheless, there appears to be a consensus among the President and the houses of Congress that the credit is inherently a good idea and should be expanded, which is certainly not the case with other measures designed to help the poor. (The House has backed the President's proposal for a five-year, $7 billion increase in the Federal food-stamp program, for instance, while the Senate's budget bill provides for no increase.)
"The earned-income tax credit is a bad name for a great policy," said David T. Ellwood, an Assistant Secretary for Health and Human Services who is co-chairman of the Administration's task force on overhauling the welfare system. "What it is, basically, is a pay raise for the working poor."
What is still to be worked out, however, is not just the size of the increase, but the degree to which it can be devised to move tax law toward the President's vow in his State of the Union Message: "If you work 40 hours a week and you've got a child in the house, you will no longer be in poverty."
 
Would Help the Childless
 White House aides concede that even the Clinton proposal, let alone the Senate version, will not accomplish this for workers supporting several children.
Mr. Clinton's proposal, approved virtually intact in the House, would expand the maximum credit to $3,371 and would, for the first time, include a much smaller credit, up to $306 yearly, for about 7.5 million childless workers.
The Senate version would include a maximum credit of $3,315 and would not be extended to childless workers, partly because proponents in the Senate argued that lower energy taxes than in the House budget plan would make up for the extra tax credits those workers would enjoy in the House version.
The maximum tax credit now is $1,513, applying to families with two or more children and incomes from about $8,000 to $12,000. There are supplemental credits, amounting to up to about $800, for people who have infants and who pay health-insurance premiums. These would be simplified and folded into the basic grant under the Clinton plan.
At $11 billion annually, the credit is the second-largest Government program for contributing money or food to the poor, just behind Aid to Families with Dependent Children, and would become the largest if the President's plan becomes law.
 
A Bizarre Side Effect
 As popular as the program is, some features have come under heavy criticism. Some economists are even warning that current proposals could actually aggravate a bizarre side effect of the code that can encourage people to overstate their income on their tax forms, since the value of the additional credit they would receive would exceed the amount of extra tax they would pay.
Moreover, current law and Mr. Clinton's proposal can both work as a disincentive for a second person in a poor family to get a job, since some of the extra income would be canceled out by a decrease in the credit the family would receive. It can also amount to a disincentive for marriage, for much the same reason.
Some conservative scholars also argue that Mr. Clinton may be pushing the tax credit away from its purely antipoverty roots. Under the Clinton proposal, families with two or more children and incomes up to $28,000 would be eligible for a credit, up from the current maximum of $23,760. (The benefit at such levels is small, since it decreases from a peak at around the $12,000 income level.)
