HEADLINE: MOVE BY MOSCOW DEPLORED IN WEST

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Western officials and economists today criticized the decision by Russia's Central Bank to withdraw old bank notes from circulation, saying it could unfairly confiscate currency from many Russians and severely hurt small businesses, a group that the West is eager to help.
The move to reduce the number of rubles in circulation is officially aimed at controlling the money supply and reducing inflation, but some officials and economists interviewed said the move might ultimately help drive up prices by undermining faith in Russia's currency and Central Bank. 
 "It seems like a pretty ham-handed way of trying to reduce inflation and of trying to increase confidence in the currency," said Stanley Fischer, a former chief economist for the World Bank who is a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "The most likely thing it will do is encourage Russians to use the dollar more, and that's the last thing you want to do if you want to discourage inflation."
Under the plan, Russians will have 14 days to exchange up to 35,000 rubles -- equal to $34 -- for new bank notes. Any other older currency that Russians hold may be deposited in saving banks, where it must be held for six months before it can be exchanged for new ruble notes. Those holdings are expected to be significantly eroded because the interest rate those deposits receive will be far lower than the inflation rate.
 
Some Praise for Plan
 Since big Russian companies often work in dollars while small businesses work in rubles, several officials and economists said the move would particularly hurt the most dynamic part of Russia's economy: small business.
Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, declined to comment on the move, saying he was trying to obtain further details about the decision. Officials of the International Monetary Fund, which is working closely with Russia on its reform program, also said they were studying the plan.
In interviews, Western officials and economists praised one aspect of the plan, saying it would make it easier for Russia to run its monetary policy independent of other former Soviet republics that still use rubles.
Russian officials have long complained that it is hard to bring down inflation when other republics are dumping rubles into the Russian market. By withdrawing all rubles printed before 1993, the Central Bank's plan would greatly reduce the amount of rubles that other republics control.
 
Came as a Surprise
 But the move could also increase tensions between Russia and the other republics.
"The Central Bank's decision will certainly have an effect on people and businesses in republics other than Russia, but it should help Russia get control of its money supply," said Herbert S. Levine, an economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
Western officials said the plan was a surprise, and that it was not even discussed with an International Monetary Fund delegation that left Moscow last Thursday.
Several economists said the move could reduce confidence in the Central Bank because it had promised not to make any drastic moves regarding bank notes until the end of the year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Profitable companies are shedding jobs, insisting that to survive in the 1990's, they must prepare for the worst. Procter & Gamble's recent announcement that it, too, will shrink its work force called attention to this surprising aspect of America's jobs crisis. Unable to raise prices in a weak economy, the mind-set is to focus on cutting labor costs to maintain profit margins. [Page A1.]
How deep I.B.M. may cut this time can say a lot about how quickly and forcefully its new chief executive intends to leave his mark. Analysts expect the board to take a big additional charge against earnings, perhaps more than $4 billion. [D1.] 
 Overshadowed by the fight over raising taxes and cutting the Federal budget deficit are plans in both houses of Congress to add billions of dollars to a Government antipoverty program, the earned-income tax credit. [A1.]
Rail freight is still getting through, despite widespread Midwestern flooding that is costing the country's railroads tens of millions of dollars. [A1.]
New machine tool orders dipped 2.3 percent in June, a sign that plant managers are growing more wary about the future. [D3.]
Some members of Congress strongly oppose the new Los Angeles Mayor's idea to lease the city's international airport to a private company and use the income to pay for services. [A9.]
Fractured city, state and Federal policies have encouraged New York to spend far more on temporary shelter for homeless people than on permanent housing. [B1.]
 
The Media Business
Alan Ladd Jr. was dismissed as chairman and chief executive of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and replaced by Frank Mancuso, the former Paramount Pictures chairman. M-G-M's owner, Credit Lyonnais, also said it would revive the United Artists studio and take steps to improve M-G-M's basic financial condition. [D1.]
W will arrive on newsstands this week looking like a bona fide magazine for the first time in its 21-year history. [D1.]

A serious split emerged in Russia over the central bank's decision to declare all pre-1993 ruble bank notes invalid. Finance Ministry officials protested to President Yeltsin. [A8.]
There is a growing conviction in the Basque region of Spain that a futuristic auto factory, the brainchild of a native son, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, will never be built. Mr. Lopez is enmeshed in a dispute over possible industrial espionage. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Butte Journal;
Faith's Anchor in a Western Diaspora

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUTTE, Mont.

 BODY:
This brick and clapboard city in southwestern Montana dusty, stark and eroding now in its perch alongside the Continental Divide -- was built by a rough and bawdy sort, miners who carved out this state's once-largest city in a rush for copper, silver and gold.
A hard-living city with bars in almost every block, Butte was as close to urban as the Wild West got, luring fortune-seekers from every corner of Asia and Europe a century ago. Among them came Montana's largest population of Jews. 
 This year, Butte's Congregation B'nai Israel, the last of three synagogues remaining in this city, celebrates its 90th anniversary, though its congregation is down to 30 families from a high of 500 in the 1940's.
"What's remarkable is the tenacity with which it has hung in there," said 72-year-old Stan Gronfein, a Butte native and member of the congregation whose family ran a men's clothing store for many years. "I've always wondered how we managed that."
Mr. Gronfein's grandparents, who arrived from Germany in the 1890's, were among B'nai Israel's founders. Mr. Gronfein remembers the city's glory days when there was a kosher market and so many businessmen were Jews that half the city closed down on Jewish holidays.
Butte's first Mayor was Jewish, Henry Jacobs, elected in 1879, and his house has been restored as part of the national landmark district of Butte, which gained that status for its mining history.
Elders remember when B'nai Israel had a full-time rabbi (the last moved on in the 1960's), as well as the years when they had none, when laymen conducted services and passed on their traditions to the children.
For four years now, the congregation has participated in a student rabbi program with Hebrew Union College in Los Angeles. The student flies in monthly for services and to teach the children. It is all the community can afford, and for its size, members said it is all they need.
"It's difficult to be Jewish there," said Scott Meltzer, one of the student rabbis. "It's a small segment of a multicultural town and there's little Jewish culture left."
The city of Butte declined as demand for copper, its main source of income, plummeted in the 1960's and 70's. The last big production was a decade ago, but residents had long since begun their exodus.
The population now is about a third of what it was at its peak of 100,000 in the 1940's, when the Anaconda Company wielded huge power in the state and processed more copper than any other company in the nation. Its smelter in Anaconda, 35 miles west of here, belched toxic-laden smoke that killed foliage for miles around and polluted the ground and water. The area around Anaconda now makes up the largest Federal Superfund cleanup site in the country, and the mines in the hillsides here are inactive.
Through it all, B'nai Israel has survived as the only continually functioning synagogue in Montana. Congregations have formed in more cosmopolitan Billings and Missoula, but their meeting places are informal. In a sense, B'nai Israel has been benefited from hard times. With three synagogues merged into one, it has an enviable five torahs on its altar, affluent by even Eastern standards.
And when a special occasion is observed, the entire city takes notice. Bar mitzvahs, which take place about every five years, are almost as big as the St. Patrick's Day Parade. In 1988, Leo Rosenthal's bar mitzvah received a two-page spread in the local daily newspaper.
For Leo's family, which moved here from New York, the attraction of Butte was a thriving Jewish community in a Western state. His mother, Barbara, grew up in Far Rockaway in Queens, and his father, Paul, in Brooklyn. A visit West nearly 20 years ago changed their lives.
"We wanted to leave New York," Ms. Rosenthal said. "I knew I wanted children, and that I wanted religion in my family. So I got out the Yellow Pages and started looking for a congregation. It had to be a place with a synagogue that needed a dentist, so we picked Butte."
The future is less certain than when the Rosenthals arrived in the 1970's; Butte has not shared in Montana's population boom.
"You just wouldn't come here to try to establish yourself," said Rand Rafish, a third-generation congregant. "We don't have that kind of economic environment. People are leaving because there are no jobs."
But those who remain believe that far from drifting, their fate has been strengthened because their congregation is small.
"As long as there is one family, there will always be a temple in Butte," said Mel Rafish. "It will never bite the dust."

HEADLINE: Ukraine May Ask Special Status in Atom Pact

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, July 24

 BODY:
As sentiment in Ukraine strengthens for keeping nuclear weapons on its territory and delaying ratification of disarmament treaties, the Defense Minister has suggested that the country may try to join the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty with the special status of a "transition country" with nuclear weapons.
The Defense Minister, Col. Gen. Konstantin Morozov, spoke in an interview Friday on the eve of a five-day trip to Washington, where he is to meet with Defense Secretary Les Aspin. General Morozov appeared to be searching for middle ground between the position of hard-liners in the Ukrainian Parliament, who have threatened to reject the 1970 nonproliferation treaty, and appeals from Washington that Ukraine keep its pledge to join the treaty as a country without nuclear arms. 
 When the Soviet Union broke up in late 1991, Ukraine officially became the world's third largest nuclear power. Today a total of 176 former Soviet long-range missiles and 30 bombers carrying 1,656 nuclear warheads remain on its territory.
"We can join the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and support all the provisions, but as a state that has temporary status of a country with nuclear armaments on its territory that are being destroyed," General Morozov said. "We are now in a transition period. And I think theoretically it is possible for Ukraine to get the status of a transition country."
 
1992 Pledge to Sign
 President Leonid M. Kravchuk and his Government had pledged last year that Ukraine would unequivocally ratify both the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, a 1991 agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union on reducing nuclear warheads, and the 1970 treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
Western experts here say that for Ukraine to sign the nonproliferation treaty it must do so as a non-nuclear nation, like other new signers. But General Morozov seemed to suggest that Ukraine would not threaten the legitimacy of the treaty if it was viewed as a nuclear heir in transition instead of a proliferator.
In offering a new position, which Western experts here said had not previously been described by senior Ukrainian officials, General Morozov seemed to be heeding nationalist sentiment in the Ukrainian Parliament, where euphoria over the independence gained in December 1991 has given way to mistrust of Russia's intentions.
Apart from the dispute on stewardship over nuclear arms, the two countries have sparred over control of the strategic Black Sea fleet and the port of Sevastopol, a navy base on Ukrainian territory.
 
Up to Parliament
 General Morozov repeatedly emphasized in the interview that the decision on whether Ukraine would declare itself a nuclear power or not was up to the Ukrainian Parliament. "It is very difficult for me to predict what the Parliament will decide," he said.
Ukraine's stance on the nuclear weapons is important because its failure to ratify the nonproliferation treaty and the 1991 strategic arms treaty, called Start I, would result in the scuttling of the follow-up Start II treaty and could increase regional tensions.
Two weeks ago the Parliament's influential Foreign Affairs Committee released a document declaring for the first time that the nuclear weapons inherited from the Soviet Union and stationed on Ukrainian soil were the sole property of Ukraine.
Ukraine's top leaders have meanwhile wavered on the commitments they made last year. Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma, who headed Ukraine's biggest missile factory until he entered politics last year, said in a private meeting with lawmakers in May that Ukraine should declare itself a nuclear nation and temporarily keep part of the former Soviet arsenal.
In a separate interview on Friday, Environment Minister Yuri Kostenko, a lawmaker who leads a parliamentary group analyzing the nuclear treaties, said the United States should understand that Russia's policies of "political and economic pressure" were "without any doubt whatsoever a threat against Ukraine's territorial integrity."
Mr. Kostenko -- who is also visiting the United States in the coming week, on a mission to inspect safety at nuclear power plants -- said Ukraine was being singled out for unfair treatment. "Instead of helping us decide these complex issues, we are accused of being a nuclear power because we're not giving these weapons to Russia tomorrow," he said.
General Morozov's trip comes a month after a visit to Kiev by Mr. Aspin, who suggested a compromise under which warheads on Ukraine's missiles would be removed and placed under international supervision on Ukrainian soil.
Mr. Aspin's proposal was well received here at the time because it seemed to signal respect for Ukraine's sovereignty and because he suggested regular high-level meetings between American and Ukrainian military officials. It has since been criticized in Parliament as a "facade" for lack of follow-up.
Control over any use of the weapons remains in Russia's hands, and the Ukrainian authorities have repeatedly told Washington that they are not trying to seize operational control over the weapons. But there has been speculation in the West, based on reports from Moscow, that Ukraine is already trying to develop the ability to operate the weapons. American intelligence agencies have estimated that Ukraine could acquire technological ability to fire the missiles in 12 to 18 months.
 
Operational Efforts Denied
 In the interview, General Morozov repeated Ukraine's assurances that his country was making no such efforts. Asked if Ukraine had started to work on circumventing the locks placed on the air-delivered weapons by Moscow, he said, "No."
Asked how long it would take for Ukraine to acquire independent control if they decided to take this step, General Morozov said: "It's not really important how long it would take. You have my 'no.' "
The Defense Minister prefaced his "no" by saying that Ukraine had the scientific expertise to take control if it wanted to do so.
"Despite the economic crisis we now live in, this is a very technologically developed country," he said. "We have a very developed industrial military complex. We have high technological industries for the production of missiles and in the field of radio electronics. So this question is not the most complex question for Ukraine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We are now in a transition period," said Konstantin Morozov, the Defense Minister of Ukraine. "And I think theoretically it is possible for Ukraine to get the status of a transition country." (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS EXPECT TIGHT BUDGET VOTE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
After weeks of labeling the Clinton Administration's $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts too miserly or too spendthrift, Democratic liberals and conservatives alike took to television today to concede the increasingly obvious: like it or not, they will probably pass a compromise version of the plan next month.
"I think the President will be able to get the votes when the time comes," said Senator Sam Nunn, a conservative Georgian who was one of six Democrats to vote against the Senate version of the package last month. "He's very persuasive." 
 A prominent liberal Democrat, Representative Kweisi Mfume of Maryland, predicted, "It's going to pass by the tightest of margins."
He added, "Many people in this particular party that I'm a member of realize that we really don't have a choice."
 
Pressure From 2 Extremes
 Mr. Mfume is the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, whose 38 members have grudgingly supported the House version of President Clinton's economic plan despite their conviction that it does not spend enough on social needs. By contrast, Mr. Nunn voted against the far more frugal Senate version of the plan, arguing that it needed to cut spending even more.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen also predicted that the economic package would pass Congress, but not without difficulty.
Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Mfume were interviewed on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." Mr. Nunn appeared on the CBS News counterpart, "Face the Nation."
They spoke as scores of House and Senate lawmakers prepared for a second and probably final week of negotiations to meld the House and Senate models of the economic package into a single measure that could pass both houses of Congress.
The crucial talks over taxes and spending on Federal benefits, involving negotiators from the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee, will not resume until Tuesday. Democratic leaders have committed themselves to passing some form of compromise by the time Congress leaves on Aug. 9 for its monthlong summer recess.
 
Reining In Defectors
 Today, Mr. Bentsen suggested that the most difficult task remaining was to hold on to conservative Democrats who supported either the House or Senate version of the package earlier this year. It is feared that they might vote against any compromise package if it does not sufficiently cut both the growth of the deficit and spending.
Mr. Clinton's plan includes about $250 billion in new taxes and another $250 billion in spending and interest reductions through 1998. That would cut the growth of the Federal deficit by $500 billion over five years, to about $200 billion in the last year of Mr. Clinton's term in office, according to the Administration.
Even so, the total Federal debt would still rise by $1 trillion during the period, a figure conservatives like Mr. Nunn say is too high. On the other hand, Mr. Clinton is under pressure from liberals like Mr. Mfume and moderates to spend more, something Mr. Bentsen said today would be resisted.
"The biggest problem at the present time, it seems to me, is being sure that we get the $500 billion" in deficit reduction, Mr. Bentsen said, "and, in addition, that we keep more spending cuts than we do revenue increases. And we're committed to that."
 
Little to Tempt Conservatives
 Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Clinton cannot afford to lose any more conservatives in the Senate, where Vice President Al Gore had to cast a tie-breaking vote last month to keep the economic proposal from failing. The House passed the measure by a six-vote margin.
Virtually all the six Senate Democrats who opposed the package then are conservatives, and there is little indication they will support the more liberal package now being drafted.
Mr. Nunn said he had seen little so far in the compromise talks that would tempt him to switch his vote.
"I'm keeping an open mind until I see the conference results," he said today. "But I felt and still feel that we needed to bear down more on spending cuts."
He also said the White House should have prepared a 10-year economic recovery plan instead of a five-year plan.
"You can't come to grips with this long-term problem in a five-year plan," he said.

HEADLINE: Move to Withdraw Rubles Splits Russian Government

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 25

 BODY:
A serious split emerged in the Russian Government today over the sudden decision by the Russian Central Bank to declare all pre-1993 ruble bank notes invalid as of midnight tonight, with senior Finance Ministry officials making a personal protest to President Boris N. Yeltsin at a Kremlin meeting.
The decision, which has thrown Russians into panic as they scurry to unload old bank notes, was made on Saturday without consultation with the Finance Ministry, which was only notified at the last minute, a senior economic adviser to the Government said. 
 "The Ministry of Finance has lodged its protest and regards this as a completely inappropriate policy," said the adviser, Jeffrey D. Sachs, a professor of economics at Harvard, who said he had spoken with senior Finance Ministry officials today and had cleared his comments with them. "The ministry is in ongoing discussions with the Government, the President and the Central Bank about these actions," Mr. Sachs said.
Although Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin issued a statement on Saturday expressing Government support for the Central Bank's decision, the Finance Ministry's protest showed that a bitter dispute continues over monetary and fiscal policy within the Russian leadership. The dispute also underlined the fragility of Western-style economic reform in Russia.
 
Slowing Inflation Unlikely
 While the officially stated goals of the Central Bank's action -- to slow inflation and insure tighter control over Russia's money supply -- are also goals of the reformers, Western diplomats and economists said the invalidation of older bank notes would not effectively accomplish those goals.
By causing more economic pain to individual Russians, they said, the move could erode what support exists for the Government, for Mr. Yeltsin and for the very idea of reform, which many Russians already associate with chaos and difficulty.
Other officials and Western diplomats said it was believed that Mr. Yeltsin, who returned to Moscow today after breaking off his vacation, had made no immediate decision at the meeting with Finance Ministry officials on whether to seek a reversal of the Central Bank's decision.
Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman had said that the President was returning to deal with the threat to the economic reforms posed by the Russian Parliament, which before recessing on Friday passed a series of laws and resolutions that would swell the budget deficit, hobble privatization of state enterprises and cancel the licenses of foreign banks.
The Minister of Finance, Boris G. Fyodorov, who is the main architect and spokesman for Russia's market reforms, is believed to be on vacation in the United States, and could not be reached for comment.
 
Timed for a Long Weekend
 Diplomats suggested that the Central Bank's move, which is deeply unpopular and will discredit the Government, may have been coordinated with the lawmakers involved in the parliamentary session and was timed for a long summer weekend when few officials would be at their desks.
Protests also came today from other former Soviet republics that still use the ruble or maintain large ruble reserves, like Armenia, Moldova and Georgia.
Under the order issued Saturday, Russians may exchange up to 35,000 rubles each of older notes -- only $34 -- at banks before Aug. 7, a deadline that is likely to create long lines. Any further amounts must be put on deposit and frozen for six months at an interest rate significantly below the current inflation rate.
Foreigners may change only 15,000 rubles and may do so only on Monday, with no possibility of banking the rest.
Mr. Sachs said he saw "a real possibility" that the Central Bank acted "in coordination with the Supreme Soviet in an overt attempt to destroy the economic reform by stopping privatization and stabilization."
 
'Soviet-Style Thinking'
 He called the Central Bank's actions clumsy and "cruel" and said they showed "Soviet-style thinking." He said he hoped that Mr. Yeltsin would come down firmly on the side of reformers planning genuine free-market strategies and that the acting director of the Central Bank, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, who has been feuding with Mr. Fyodorov and other reformers, would be dismissed.
Under Russia's much-criticized Soviet-era Constitution, the Central Bank reports directly to the Parliament.
Mr. Fyodorov has recounted severe battles within the Government of Prime Minister Chernomyrdin between those who favor Western-style reforms, including tighter credits to try to control Russia's high inflation, and the Soviet holdovers who control most of the bureaucracy.
Even in his own Finance Ministry, Mr. Fyodorov has said, there are many officials who do not understand the principles or benefits of a market economy. Mr. Chernomyrdin himself is a former manager of state industry who was imposed on Mr. Yeltsin by the Parliament after the acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, was forced to resign late last year.
Supported by Western Governments, international institutions and advisers like Mr. Sachs, Mr. Fyodorov and the young reformers in the Government have had good access to Mr. Yeltsin and have won many of the arguments over economic and financial policy.
But diplomats suggest that the bureaucrats and conservative-minded industrialists concentrated in the Parliament and in the Central Bank have been working to undermine any transition to a real market by seeking to control and limit privatization and maintain a large state sector.
Mr. Yeltsin is trying to get rid of the Parliament, which was elected in March 1990 and nearly succeeded in ousting him from his post last spring. He has been trying to get a new, democratic constitution approved that would reorganize the legislature and require new elections. But the current parliamentary leadership insists that it alone may adopt a new constitution.
On Saturday, the Central Bank shocked Russians and other countries of the former Soviet Union by announcing that all bank notes printed before 1993 would be withdrawn from circulation by Monday.
Today, a number of newly independent countries of the former Soviet Union criticized the Central Bank's decision. The Finance Minister of Armenia, Levon Barkhudarian, called it an "unexpected and a gross violation of multilateral and intergovernmental agreements linking the former union republics." He said Armenia would ignore Russia's decision and continue to accept older bank notes.
Officials of Moldova said the measure was a "complete surprise" and would cause hardship; Georgian officials said they would introduce their own currency by Aug. 2; officials of Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan said they would have to go along with the Russian decision.
 
Last-Minute Spending Sprees
 But ordinary Russians, who are paid in cash and use it for nearly all purchases, are the most likely to be hurt. Though Central Bank officials said that on average, Russians would have less than 35,000 rubles of old notes on hand, anyone planning to make a major purchase soon would have stockpiled many more. One Russian, who had saved 400,000 rubles to buy air tickets for a holiday in Bulgaria, discovered today that 150,000 of those rubles -- or about $150 -- were outdated.
Other Russians struggled today to spend old rubles at a few open state stores, buying televisions and other goods, while others tried to fill up on gasoline, causing long lines at gas stations. Private gas stations doubled their prices and refused to take older notes, as did nearly all private kiosks checked in central Moscow and in Istra, a small town some 25 miles away. The traders in Moscow's private central market also refused to take old notes, though some were happy to exchange dollars for new notes.
Almost all official money exchanges were closed today, but one private company near the Central Bank offered to sell dollars at a rate of 1,250 new rubles to the dollar and 1,750 old rubles to the dollar. Street traders sold dollars for up to 1,900 old rubles. On Friday, before the announcement, the official exchange rate was 1,004 rubles to the dollar.
The announcement has created speculators in old rubles, who obviously will find a way to exchange them. Long lines are expected on Monday at savings banks as Russians try to exchange and deposit old rubles.
The Central Bank action was criticized by many Russians. An old woman at the central market said her pension was now worthless; a factory manager called the Government actions "deceitful and cruel." He said bitterly, "They act like Communists."
Western diplomats said the Central Bank would probably not achieve its stated goal of rapid control over the money supply. Businessmen will find ways around the restrictions, these officials said.
Some officials also said that corruption among bank officials could not be ruled out after an audit of the bank by Coopers & Lybrand. In an audit partially released to Parliament on July 9, the American accounting firm said the bank's books were impossible to reconcile because of error, possible fraud and incomplete records.
Mr. Sachs said that the audit and the decision on Saturday, when viewed together, showed "gross mismanagement or worse, and the incapacity of the Central Bank to support reform measures."

People wired money to themselves yesterday at the Central Telegraph office in Moscow, in a bid to exchange their old bank notes. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Team of Individuals;
Almost 10, New Jersey Quintuplets Vie to Stand on Own

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA GIRT, N.J.

 BODY:
Christopher is the oldest. Lauren is the tallest. Megan is the youngest. Ryan is the most energetic. Kevin is the best all-around in sports.
The superlatives translate into ammunition when the siblings compete with one another to be first, last, best -- anything to make them stand out as individuals. It's part of a campaign that has been going on for almost 10 years since Jenifer and Jerry Joyce became parents for the first time on Aug. 18, 1983. They emerged from the hospital into a flurry of publicity about the armsful of babies they would be raising. 
 Five babies, to be exact -- a rarity even in a world where fertility drugs have made multiple births more common. (In 1990, the National Center for Health Statistics counted 13 sets of quintuplets born in this country.)
Inevitably, of course, the headlines tapered off and the television cameras went away, leaving the Joyces with being chauffeurs, cooks, referees, counselors and parents to the quintuplets, their only children.
They do not say it has been easy. But they do say it has been worthwhile. And for all seven Joyces, it is, of course, the only family life they have known.
Like all children, the Joyce quintuplets ask a lot of questions. For instance, they wanted to know how a boy and a girl who do not have the same birthday could be brother and sister.
Then there was the time when Lauren told her mother that she had decided to have quadruplets. Mrs. Joyce told her that people cannot choose the number of children they have at one time.
For Mrs. Joyce, 37 years old, and Mr. Joyce, 40, clearing up their children's misinterpretations of life has been relatively easy.
"Trying not to compare is probably the hard part," Mr. Joyce said. "From report cards to baseball games to their tennis ability to whatever, you're constantly comparing. Some are going to excel in some areas and some aren't going to excel in some areas. You always have that instant barometer of comparison."
Mrs. Joyce said: "When they were younger, we used to dress them alike to keep track of them. In a populated place, it was easy to identify them if they all had on orange sweat shirts."
Mr. Joyce added, "It was cute then, but they got sick of the cute stuff." His wife said: "You have to treat them as individuals. It takes a lot more work. When one of them has a real special interest, we try to develop that interest. That's very important."
 
Rules of Their Own
 From oldest to youngest, Christopher likes baseball, Ryan hockey, Lauren soccer and basketball, Kevin basketball, and Megan softball.
None of the quintuplets look confusingly alike, except for maybe Kevin and Ryan, who, like Lauren and Mrs. Joyce, have red hair and freckles. Christopher has blond hair and Megan has brown, with a few freckles sprinkled on her nose.
Each has a different best friend, hobby and career goal. "Everyone likes to do their own thing," Kevin said.
And there are the sibling rules that the quintuplets determined themselves: The boys don't let the girls play Nintendo. The girls don't let the boys in their room. The girls take a different route than the boys when they walk to school, even though the school is about a block from their house.
And the most important credo: "We never play with the girls," Christopher said.
Asked why, he answered: "Because they're girls."
While the quintuplets denied having any common denominator beyond sharing the same parents and birth date, Mr. and Mrs. Joyce know the advantages of having five children the same age.
"They're never bored, and it's nice to know they're never alone," said Mrs. Joyce, a computer analyst at Continental Insurance Corporation in Neptune.
The quintuplets were in the same third-grade class at Sea Girt Elementary School in this town of 2,500. Being in the same class sometimes worked to their advantage. The teacher did not punish the quintuplets if they fought among themselves. "She would say 'Go tell your mother,' " Lauren said.
And if a schoolmate picked a fight with one quintuplet, the others quickly interceded.
Having quintuplets is also efficient, noted Mr. Joyce, an economics teacher and tennis coach at St. Rose High School in Belmar.
"One good thing is that they are involved in the same activities," he said. "If they go to tennis, they all go at the same time."
The quintuplets play on the same soccer, tennis and swim teams. But they constantly compete with one another: the first bowl of cereal, the last piece of bread. Sometimes there are only four beach towels or three rafts. The girls share a bedroom, the boys another, and they all share one bathroom. They never get separate birthday parties, although they seem to have set a neighborhood trend of joint birthday parties.
But they do get two birthday parties. One is a small party with their godparents. Each quintuplet has his or her own pair of godparents, one of the few things they do not have to share. The other party is a big one for classmates, friends and family.
 
Minute-to-Minute Schedule
 The financial costs of having quintuplets is hard for most parents to fathom. In 1992, the United States Department of Agriculture estimated that the cost of raising one child from birth until age 17 was $92,000 to $180,000.
How will the Joyces pay for college? Who is going to teach the quintuplets how to drive? "I just try to handle each day as it comes," Mrs. Joyce said. What about their grocery bill? "I don't keep track of that," she said, but added that the children can eat two boxes of cereal and a bag of bagels each day. "And that's just a snack."
In the Joyce household, time is considered a far more precious resource than money. A schedule is kept on the kitchen counter next to the phone.
Mrs. Joyce gets up at 5 A.M. to do the laundry, exercise and get ready for work. She leaves for work by 7:15, and Mr. Joyce gives the children breakfast and sees them off to school or summer day camp.
By 3:30 P.M., the quintuplets are back at home and Mr. Joyce, too, is usually home by then. About 4 P.M., Mrs. Joyce gets in from work and finishes the laundry, makes dinner, lunches and snacks for the next day.
Evening activities vary from bicycle riding to Rollerblading, but 30 minutes is devoted to reading a book, and the parents require the quintuplets to prepare weekly book reports. By 10 or 11 P.M., everyone is ready for bed.
Every minute of each day is accounted for three weeks in advance, Mr. Joyce said, but their schedule is lighter now than it was nine years ago. He recounted the quintuplets' round-the-clock feedings, and the dozens of volunteers who helped change diapers. Even though Mr. and Mrs. Joyce get more sleep at night now, they still do not have much time to spend alone. But that's not a priority.
"Every minute I have is for them," Mrs. Joyce said. "I just enjoy talking to them. When I'm at work, I miss them. They're my best friends now."

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Dropped 2.3% Last Month

BYLINE: ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
In a sign that plant managers are more wary about the future than they were just a few months ago, machine-tool orders dipped 2.3 percent in June, after a 9.4 percent decline the previous month, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday.
New orders fell to $308.65 million in June from $315.75 million in May and $348.30 million in April. The association, based in Washington, represents 340 makers of machine tools. 
 But orders in June still topped June 1992's $208.6 million by 48 percent. And orders for the year are up 39.2 percent, largely because of an unusually strong February, March and April. Analysts traced much of the year-to-date surge to American auto makers, which have accelerated the pace at which they are introducing models. Their appetite for new tools has been strong enough to offset a large decline from the aerospace industry.
 
Increase Termed 'Impressive'
 The increase is "fairly impressive," said William Potter, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder. "Clearly, it is slowing, however."
He said the aerospace industry's caution was a result of the poor health of the airline business. "There's just not the money there to spend on new planes, and there was a lot of buying last year," he said.
This year is also shaping up as a notable one, analysts say, because the bulk of new orders is coming from, of all places, American manufacturers. Of the $1.76 billion in new orders recorded in the first half of 1993, only $165.3 million, or 9.4 percent, were placed by foreign companies.
"About two years ago, the export orders were the only ones causing any growth, and our economy was in the doldrums," said Robert W. Gardner, an association spokesman. However, partly because of the sluggishness of certain European economies, particularly Germany's, he explained, "that's no longer true."
Machine tools are the myriad items found on factory floors that create many of the manufactured products that Americans buy, from refrigerators to car chassis.
 
Viewed as Leading Indicator
 Because machine tools can take as long as 18 months to customize so they can perform their specialized tasks, the monthly statistic is viewed by some analysts as a leading indicator of economic activity. By that logic, the year-to-date surge means that the domestic manufacturing sector is in a slow recovery.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Amy H. Linsky and Roy B. Oser

 BODY:
Amy Hallen Linsky, a daughter of Bettie Hallen of Springfield, Mass., and Leo J. Linsky of East Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Roy Bennett Oser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Oser of St. George, S.I. Judge Norma L. HEADLINE: PULSE;
Public Assistance

 BODY:
Recession-related layoffs and homelessness in the region helped drive up the number of people receiving public assistance 22.5 percent since 1988, to more than 2 million last year. Of the two principal aid programs, General Assistance and Aid to Families with Dependent Children, A.F.D.C. has remained the larger, accounting for 79 percent of all recipients and 70 percent of spending. A family of three generally receives $577 a month in New York, $581 in Connecticut and $424 in New Jersey. A.F.D.C. benefits have risen 6.6 percent in New York in the last five years, and less in New Jersey and Connecticut. General Assistance, which normally goes to individuals, has expanded sharply - total recipients increased 66 percent and spending 96 percent. New Jersey pays a montly average of $504 per person; New York pays $352; and Connecticut pays $306.

HEADLINE: A Budget Worthy of Mr. Bush

 BODY:
If the conferees who will meet this week to finish a budget stick to their present path, they'll likely hand President Clinton a package much like the one George Bush signed three years ago. Is that what America voted for?
The conferees are about to recommend chopping deficits by about $500 billion over five years, primarily by cutting defense, trimming Medicare, raising income taxes and imposing a gasoline tax. But that's exactly what Congress did under President Bush three years ago. 
 Mr. Clinton promised voters more than a rehash. He pledged to end the consumption frenzy of the 1980's by turning the Federal budget toward investments in infrastructure, children and training. But Congress is veering in a different direction. Unless it turns around, and fast, Mr. Clinton's victory in getting a deficit-reduction package through Congress will be hollow.
There's nothing wrong with the overall target. The conferees appear headed for a package that would reduce the deficit by the fifth year to about $200 billion -- a prudent target because at that level the nation's debt would grow no faster than the economy. And the mix of taxes is about right. Following Mr. Clinton's lead, Congress would raise taxes on the rich by about $100 billion and impose a gas tax that would likely cost a middle-class family less than $50 a year.
But what about investment? Congress knocked tens of billions from discretionary spending that Mr. Clinton proposed. And it seems unprepared to prune old programs to make way for Mr. Clinton's initiatives. That probably means that most of his plans to hike spending on worker training, education, mass transit and technological research will be slashed. He'll be lucky to save a third of his investment program.
This week the budget conferees will turn to energy taxes and entitlements. The disagreements are narrowing, but still important. The Senate would impose a $20 billion gas tax; the House would raise $70 billion from an energy tax. The House would use the extra revenue to subsidize low-paid workers, create enterprise zones in depressed areas and spur investment in small businesses.
The small-business subsidies are ill-designed and not worth preserving. But the enterprise zones, though modest, are an important symbolic gesture to ailing cities -- the only aid they'll see in the budget package -- and are important to winning support among the Congressional Black Caucus and House liberals.
Tax credits to the working poor and higher food stamp allowances for beleaguered families are more than symbolic. These programs lie at the heart of Mr. Clinton's pledge to lift families with at least one full-time worker above poverty. The House delivered on this pledge by providing large tax credits to low-wage workers, enhanced food stamp allotments and money for innovative programs to help distressed families.
However, the Senate had to reduce or eliminate each of these programs once it cut the House's energy tax by $50 billion. Under the Senate plan, many poor families, for example workers without children, would suffer because they would get no offset to the higher gas tax.
The conferees must decide first the size of the gas tax. If they settle on less than around 8 cents a gallon -- which would raise about $20 billion more than the Senate bill -- then there will not be enough money to elevate the working poor above poverty and fund urban enterprise zones.
Some Western senators oppose gas taxes above the Senate level of 4 cents because, they claim, it hits hard at their rural constituents. They exaggerate. Regional disparities in the gas tax are small and, besides, the income tax hikes hit hard at East Coast cities. Overall, a package with an 8 cent gas tax would be fair.
Congress is moving to hand Mr. Clinton a budget. But if it shortchanges the gas tax or the President's spending initiatives, it won't be a budget that invests in the future and it won't be a victory for those who voted for an economic turnabout.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Looking To the Pacific

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, interviewed while here for meetings with Asian foreign ministers, spoke of "the primacy of Asia" in American foreign policy: a primacy of opportunity.
Did that phrase, I asked, represent a change in America's view of the world? 
 "Yes," he said, "it's a change in American outlook. As a trading partner Asia is one and one-half times as large as Europe. That's not to denigrate in any way our European relationships. There's a primacy -- I wouldn't say in intrinsic importance but in the opportunity for development of new economic and security relationships."
The meetings here reflect the gradual growth of an Asia-Pacific network of relationships and institutions. They center on Asean, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, made up of Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei.
Asean, founded in 1967, for a time seemed a rather lifeless acronym. But its annual meetings have become highly significant, with foreign ministers from many other countries coming to talk after the formal Asean sessions. This year the ministers of China, Russia and Vietnam have come, and Cambodia's is a special guest.
A larger grouping, the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, was formed in 1989. It meets in Seattle this November, and President Clinton has invited all its heads of government there for an informal summit meeting: a symbol of his emphasis on the importance of Asia.
Most of the governments in the region want the U.S. to maintain a strong security role in the Pacific. But touring the area, one hears complaints that America can be too rushed, too demanding on issues like human rights. Asians say they see life as more complicated, more gradual.
Cambodia is a case in point. Asian friends of the United States were unhappy when the U.S. seemingly threatened to withhold aid from the new government there if it let the Khmer Rouge play any role. Mr. Christopher said that was a misunderstanding; we accept that Cambodia must make its own decisions, though in our view the Khmer Rouge should not take part unless it really gives up violence. That clarification could be a response to Asian views.
If the Cambodian peace process continues to work, there will be just one major immediate security problem in the East Asian region. That is the question of North Korea's nuclear weapons development. But Mr. Christopher's meetings here have touched on some tense political problems, notably in relations between the United States and China.
The Chinese Government is unhappy with the Clinton Administration's decision to extend its most-favored-nation trade status on condition that, within a year, it shows significant progress on human rights. But Mr. Christopher said the reality was that Congress would be watching closely to see that the condition was met. Speaking not about China but generally, he said:
"I'm a great believer in raising the human rights issue when we talk with other leaders. They may bat it back. But somewhere in their government someone will read the memorandum of the conversation and find encouragement in the fact that the issue was important to the United States."
The other tense matter that Mr. Christopher is trying, with difficulty, to work out with China is Beijing's reported sale of M-11 missiles to Pakistan: a report that, if true, would call for U.S. sanctions.
"I would emphasize how important our nonproliferation policy is," Mr. Christopher said. "It is the arms-control issue of the post-cold war world."
(That leads to an apology. In a recent column I listed the Secretary of State as among those who recommended against President Clinton's decision to extend the moratorium on nuclear tests. I have since learned -- not from him -- that I was misinformed. He not only supported that course; he urged it on the President.)
Warren Christopher does not give up easily when he tackles an issue. In 1980, as Deputy Secretary, he negotiated with Iran for months to end the hostage crisis.
This trip will take him on to Australia. Then he will go to the Middle East to try to get peace negotiations back on track. Was there a chance of success? I asked. "The planets may get in the right order," he said. "That's what I told myself during the hostage negotiations."

HEADLINE: Another U.S. Jet on Patrol Fires at Iraqi Antiaircraft Battery

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
In the second such incident in a month, a United States warplane fired a missile Saturday at an antiaircraft battery in southern Iraq that was preparing to shoot down the plane, the Pentagon said today.
An Air Force F-4G jet was patrolling the no-flight zone, declared by the United Nations after the Persian Gulf war, when radar at an Iraqi antiaircraft site began tracking it, the Pentagon said. 
 Moments later, about 10:50 P.M. Iraqi time, the pilot replied by firing a missile designed to follow radar beams to their source, the Pentagon statement said. There was no information on whether the antiaircraft site had been hit or destroyed.
 
Missile Launching Reported
 Other United States planes flying over the area immediately afterward reported seeing the launching of a single antiaircraft missile, which did not strike a plane. Pentagon officials said the reported Iraqi missile firing had not been independently confirmed.
Iraq denied that its forces had fired a missile at United States aircraft or that its radar had "locked on" to a plane, Reuters reported from Baghdad. A Government spokesman also denied that the battery had been hit by a United States missile, Reuters said.
On Thursday, Iraq settled its latest impasse with the United Nations over weapons inspections by agreeing to allow surveillance cameras at two missile testing sites. Baghdad's intransigence on this issue had briefly raised the possibility of renewed allied military strikes.
Today, a team of United Nations inspectors arrived in Baghdad to install the cameras at Al Jawn al Azim and at Al Rafa, about 40 miles south of the capital, Reuters reported. The job is expected to take four to seven days.
The incident on Saturday was the latest cat-and-mouse encounter between the allied pilots who patrol the no-flight zone and the Iraqi antiaircraft crews. The Pentagon has said repeatedly that any attempt by radar operators to "lock on" to planes, the first step toward shooting at them, will be considered a hostile act, but Iraq does not accept the no-flight restrictions.
Allied aircraft patrol two zones, in southern Iraq to protect the Shiite Muslim minority, and in northern Iraq to bar attacks on the Kurds.
There were similar incidents in the southern zone on June 29 and in the northern zone on two occasions in April. In late May the Pentagon reported three incidents in which United States planes were fired at by Iraqi antiaircraft in the southern zone but did not respond.
"This is the personality of Hussein," one Administration expert said. "He's going to tweak the giant every chance he gets."
Occasional missile firings, the official said, are intended to shore up domestic public opinion while also testing the resolve of the Administration to keep pressure on Iraq. Previous incidents have been portrayed in the Iraqi press as defense against aggressors.
A United States officer said it was not clear whether the missile firings stemmed from orders drawn up by President Saddam Hussein.
"We think there may be a lot of people who operate independent of his wishes," the officer said. "It's tough to decide whether Saddam is trying to do something or whether someone has acted independently."
Whatever its origins, the antiaircraft activity appears to undermine one of Iraq's chief objectives: obtaining permission to resume oil sales.
The United Nations is weighing whether to allow limited exports, which would ease the effects of the continuing economic embargo and help Iraq earn some badly needed foreign currency.
There was no indication in Washington that the Administration planned any further retaliation for the missile firing. After the last incident, which took place just three days after a cruise missile strike on Baghdad, President Clinton told reporters that he "wouldn't read too much into it."
The cruise missile raid came after the Clinton Administration concluded that Iraq had played a direct role in a reported plot earlier this year to kill George Bush. An Administration official said the antiaircraft missile firings were not of the same magnitude.
"It's like a fly biting an elephant," the official said. "But remember, eventually the elephant's tail kills the fly, sometimes by accident and sometimes by design."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 26 about an American warplane that fired on a missile battery in southern Iraq misidentified the authority that barred Iraqi flights over the area. The ban was imposed by the United States, Britain and France, not the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Clinton Assails G.O.P. Delays In Bitter Tones

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 26

 BODY:
President Clinton accused Congress today of returning to old habits of gridlock and said obstructionism by Republicans there was hurting ordinary Americans, including victims of the Midwestern floods.
The sharp criticism was an unexpected turn to confrontation by a President who has maintained a largely cordial relationship with Capitol Hill. 
 In a speech at a jobs conference here, Mr. Clinton took an angry tone as he complained that Congress now stood in the way of not only flood relief but also a national service plan, and that Republicans had maneuvered in the last two weeks to try to forestall confirmation of his nominee for Surgeon General.
 
'Let's Make Decisions'
 "I don't have to win them all," Mr. Clinton said. "But let's make decisions. This institutionalized delay and gridlock is bad for America."
Mr. Clinton said he did not mean for his criticism to be partisan. But his complaints about filibusters and other parliamentary maneuvers by Republicans were virtually a mirror image of those made last year by President George Bush, who repeatedly attacked the majority Democrats on the same ground during a campaign in which "gridlock" became an epithet.
Mr. Clinton's attack appeared intended in part to pre-empt any effort to delay passage of his economic package, whose final form is being debated by a Congressional conference committee. The President declared that the Government "needs to pass this budget and get on with the rest of its business."
 
Feeling Frustration
 But he was also clearly frustrated by his recent lack of success at winning approval of programs that cause far less dispute. "I mean, you know, this gridlock thing is amazing," he said.
Mr. Clinton said he found particularly inexplicable the filibuster begun by Senate Republicans last Friday to block a vote on his plan to provide grants and loans to students who enlist in a program for national service. The program would cost $394 million in its first year and perhaps $3 billion a year by 1997, and Republican leaders have condemned it as an unnecessary proposal of a tax-and-spend President.
But Mr. Clinton suggested today that the Republicans were engaged in little more than obstruction. "They just want to delay it," he said of the national service plan. "Why? Why shouldn't we send a signal to America's young people that we want you to work in your community to make it a better place?"
Mr. Clinton made his complaints in an address to business and labor leaders attending a conference on the future of the American workplace, a gathering that was sponsored in part by the Departments of Labor and Commerce. He told the group he believed that Washington had changed and that party politics was no longer necessarily an obstacle to action.
But he bitterly cited recent events to suggest that lawmakers remained too slow to shed obstructionist habits.
He complained that the House of Representatives had delayed action on a $3 billion package of flood relief because of a debate about how to pay for it. He also criticized his opponents on a Senate committee who tried last week, although unsuccessfully, to postpone for a second time the confirmation hearings of Surgeon General-designate Joycelyn Elders.
The dispute about flood aid has to do with whether its cost should be covered through cuts in the budget or tax increases, as many Republicans and some Democrats contend, or whether it should be financed by deficit spending.
Mr. Clinton, who favors the latter option, suggested today that he was struck by his opponents' intransigence. "We do not need to raise a tax to pay for flood relief," he said, arguing that the magnitude of the floods, with damage estimates exceeding $10 billion, justified an increase in the deficit.
Although Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said on Sunday that the Administration might seek as much as $5 billion in flood relief, Mr. Clinton gave no hint today that he intended to add to the current request. But White House officials said they would probably seek additional disaster assistance in a second package by the end of the month.
In citing the experience of Dr. Elders, whose confirmation hearing before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee was postponed for a week and then nearly delayed again last Friday, Mr. Clinton complained that her treatment showed "how bad it gets sometimes with Congress."
Efforts to win a second postponement, sought by lawmakers who criticize Dr. Elders's advocacy of condom distribution in high schools and early sex education, was blocked only after Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the committee's chairman, threatened to have the committee meet over the weekend if the hearing did not proceed. The committee is now expected to approve Dr. Elders's nomination when it votes this Friday.
"Maybe there were people who don't agree with her and didn't want to vote for her," Mr. Clinton said of Dr. Elders. Nonetheless, he added, "The country needs a Surgeon General."
Mr. Clinton did not explicitly single out Republicans for criticism today. But it is the Republicans who have blocked the national service plan, it is primarily the Republicans who have delayed a vote on flood relief, and it is the Republicans who have attacked Dr. Elders's nomination. So the examples cited by the President made clear that his complaints had a partisan cast.
The President traveled to Chicago to attend the jobs conference and a political fund-raising event. But the city is also the hometown of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who is under investigation in the House post office scandal, and Mr. Clinton could not escape questions about him.
Asked whether an indictment of Mr. Rostenkowski, a central figure in the conference committee, would imperil the economic package, Mr. Clinton said he could not comment on something that had not happened. But he added, "I have no reason to believe that the conference won't proceed and produce a report and the Congress won't vote on it, no matter what."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

FOR NEW YORK INMATES, CLEMENCY IS RARE
Last December, after almost 11 years in prison on drug charges, Lawrence Snider was one of only two New York State inmates to receive clemency from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The other was Jean Harris, whose conviction for killing her former lover became a cause celebre. Inmate advocates say that while cases like Mrs. Harris's attract attention, prisoners like Mr. Snider -- who developed drug and AIDS awareness programs and organized charity drives in prison -- are more representative of those who deserve to be considered for clemency. But in 11 years, Mr. Cuomo has granted the extraordinary relief only 31 times. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
HIGHWAY ROBBERY IN THE BRONX
Fourteen people on a shuttle bus bound from Washington Heights to Providence, R.I., are robbed on the Major Deegan Expressway by three fellow passengers who produced pistols and forced the driver to pull over at the Van Cortlandt Park exit. The highway bandits took cash and jewelry, then made their escape in a waiting car. B2. 

MAN HURT CUSHIONING FOUR-STORY LEAP
If Marshall Mazeroski had not been there, Letitia Cox might have died. But when a fire sent her leaping from a fourth-floor window, he cushioned her fall, saving her life, but severely injuring his own head and neck. B2.
 
FEAR SPREADS IN A HOUSING DEVELOPMENT
An eerie sense of suspicion, confusion and uncertainty has settled over parents and their children in Starrett City after three young girls were cornered inside stairwells and sexually assaulted in the last seven weeks. B3.
 
IN THE STREETS, CHARITY LIVES ON
As the number of homeless people has increased, some New Yorkers have not let themselves become inured to the misery. Realizing that they cannot afford to help every person, they create a ritual to the daily question: Whom should I give money to, and how much? B3.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bids by Owners Sought for Control of Gucci

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, July 26

 BODY:
Maurizio Gucci, who owns 50 percent of the Gucci luxury-goods businesses, said today that he wanted the Investcorp Group, owner of the other half, to bid against him for full control of the company.
The long-simmering dissension between the two partners burst into public recriminations last week, when Investcorp filed a lawsuit and an arbitration claim against Mr. Gucci to prevent him from selling his stake or pledging it as collateral without first allowing the investment company to bid for it. 
 At a news conference here, Mr. Gucci defended his management of the company, which was founded by his grandfather in 1922. He also said the "group's problems will remain as long as ownership remains 50-50."
 
 
Closed Bids Sought
 He said Investcorp had offered him $50 million for his stake, but that he had rejected that as far too low. He said he had offered to buy Investcorp's stake but had been asked to pay $250 million, despite the stakes having equal size and voting rights.
"What I want are closed bids in envelopes," he said.
Investcorp has contended that Mr. Gucci failed to stem the losses at the group and did not put a strategic plan into effect.
An Investcorp spokesman in New York said that Gucci required additional capital and that Investcorp was prepared to inject that capital, "but only if it sees a change of management." He said that the group had not yet identified who it would like to see manage the Italian company, and that it was not necessarily seeking to take over Mr. Gucci's stake.
The current shareholding structure dates from 1991, when Investcorp completed the purchase of the 50 percent of the company held by cousins of Mr. Gucci.
Gucci lost 24.7 billion lire ($15.4 million) in the year ended Jan. 31, down from 37.8 billion lire the year before. Sales were about steady at 225.4 billion lire.
Mr. Gucci said today that the losses were due primarily to the recession. He also said part of the group's problems stemmed from the independence of Gucci's United States operations, which, he contends, owe 104 billion lire to the manufacturing operations in Italy.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
INVESTCORP'S REACTION
 In New York yesterday, a spokesman for Investcorp refused to comment on remarks made earlier in Milan by Maurizio Gucci, Gucci's 50-percent owner.
"We believe this is not the correct time or forum to respond to Mr. Gucci's inaccurate statements," the spokesman said. "The facts will speak for themselves and the case will be decided on its merits."
Also in New York yesterday, Gucci America Inc. filed a countersuit and contended that as chairman of both the United States and the Italian units, Mr. Gucci had "exercised his power to the detriment of Gucci America."
Guccio Gucci, the Florence-based Gucci unit that designs and sells Gucci products to the other units, has sued Gucci America for $63.9 million, or $58.8 million worth of merchandise plus interest.
While conceding that Gucci America has received merchandise from Guccio Gucci that it has not yet paid for, the suit seeks reimbursement for what it calls inflated prices and says such reimbursement will exceed the amount Gucci America owes the Italian unit. In the court papers, Gucci America contended that Guccio Gucci owed it more than $80 million for inflated prices, extra customs duties paid as a result of the price inflation and the loss of sales the American company suffered because of price inflation.
Gucci America also seeks more than $3 million for items it contends were expenses of Guccio Gucci.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Health Plan Sits in the Waiting Room

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
Remember health care reform? The Clinton Administration's self-imposed 100-day deadline for producing a plan has long since passed, and some experts in the field worry that a rare moment of political opportunity has been lost.
But officials in the White House and the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill say they hope to return quickly to health care once the President's economic plan is passed. They plan to send members of Congress home on their August recess with briefing books on the issue, and the President himself will begin to campaign on health care in mid-August, probably at the National Governors Association meeting, aides say. 
 White House officials say they still expect to have the health plan completed and announced by mid-September. They have already organized a "boiler room" operation to manage lobbying and public relations tactics on the issue, comparable to the one now under way on the economic plan. And on Capitol Hill, Democratic leaders in the House and Senate have been meeting weekly to plot strategy.
 
'The Need to Be Coordinated'
 "We really do want to lay the groundwork, to be ready to go when this thing comes down in final form," said Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and one of the Democrats meeting regularly on health. Democratic leaders, he said, learned from the struggle to pass Mr. Clinton's economic plan "the need to be coordinated before day one."
Mr. Fazio and other Democratic leaders defend the Administration's decision earlier this summer to suspend action on health care until the economic plan is finally approved. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said: "I think it was a wise decision. Rightly or wrongly, Congress is not capable of digesting and dealing with two such large issues at the same time, so it would have been counterproductive to try to do both at the same time."
Mr. Gephardt also contends that while the issue might have slipped off the front pages in recent months, it remains a priority for the public and Congress. "I'm not saying it's easy, but I'm saying there's still a great desire to do it," he said.
 
Months of Wasted Time
 For all of that, the long lull in what had seemed an escalating drive for change has caused some anxiety among experts in the field. Some argue that in retrospect the task force process established by Mr. Clinton's domestic policy adviser, Ira C. Magaziner -- an effort that stretched throughout the spring and ultimately involved more than 500 experts -- was less than efficient.
"As I look back on it now, it seems to me that the process was needlessly complex and drawn out," said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor emeritus of the New England Journal of Medicine and one of the experts called in to review the task force's work.
"I think a smaller number of carefully selected people could have come up with a viable plan much sooner, and it could have been presented to the Congress much earlier," he added. "And if it had, it would have been out in the public arena where it belongs, without this long period of offstage sniping and maneuvering and politicking by the vested interests."
Robert Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health at Harvard, also saw faults in the process. "Usually you use these commissions to bring the public along," he said. "This had the disadvantages of a public commission, which is that it drags on forever, without the advantage of bringing people along -- because it was secret."
And Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said that after all the working group sessions and briefing papers, "What Clinton faces now is the question he faced in December: How do you pay for the damn thing?"
Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Magaziner declined to be interviewed.
 
Clinton Decisions Await
 Indeed, the financing of the health care plan, which is intended to guarantee health coverage to all, still awaits Presidential decisions, White House officials say. An increase in the tax on cigarettes is still expected to be part of the plan, as is some form of tax on employers, officials say.
The President has been holding informal discussions with advisers on these and other health issues, aides say. "I suspect it comes up at the dinner table every now and then," said Jeff Eller, a White House spokesman on health, alluding to Hillary Rodham Clinton's work as chairwoman of the health task force. But Mr. Clinton has yet to resume the more formal meetings aimed at signing off on the plan, officials said.
On Capitol Hill, few underestimate the political task of overhauling one-seventh of the economy; the leadership meetings now under way reflect a recognition of all the structural hurdles, which include not only a gathering army of lobbyists, but also the competing agendas and personalities of several of the most powerful committees in Congress.
Adding to that complicated mix are the difficulties of Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which plays a critical role in health legislation. Mr. Rostenkowski is under investigation in House post office scandal; he denies any wrongdoing.
Moreover, the President's preferred approach to health care has its Congressional critics, including Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health. In a clear dig at the President and his embracing of "managed competition" in the health care industry, Mr. Stark proposed today that every member of Congress be required to enroll in the lowest-bidding health plan in the member's district.
Mr. Stark supports a single-payer approach, in which the Government pays all health bills. He contends that managed competition, which seeks to control costs through a mixture of market forces and regulation, would lead to diminished quality of care.
For all that, Democratic leaders assert that the pressure to produce a major new health plan is strong.
"Everybody in Congress feels the need to address it because of the strength of the feeling back home," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, one of the Democratic leaders meeting on health. "I had a couple of experiences this weekend where people who were inundated by the flood said, 'First, we want to talk to you about health care.' "

HEADLINE: Congress Is Feeling Pressure To Preserve Meal Deduction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
In the last days of politically agonizing negotiations over $500 billion in tax increases and cuts in programs like Medicare, Congress is suddenly having second thoughts this week about a long-settled decision to reduce the huge tax break businesses get for meals and entertainment expenses.
Both the House and Senate voted months ago to reduce the deduction for meals and entertainment from 80 percent of expenses to 50 percent, a move that would raise $15 billion in new tax revenues during the next five years. That roughly equals the amount that would be raised by a proposed increase, to 35 percent from 34 percent, in the corporate income tax. 
 But lobbyists and Congressional aides said today that members of Congress were considering restoring a chunk of the deduction, at a cost of perhaps $7 billion in lost tax revenues, even as they haggle over the size of tax increases and cuts in social programs.
 
Lobbying From Restaurants
 Two factors drive the lawmakers, the aides said. One is that the restaurant industry has mounted a lobbying campaign, centered on television commercials in key states, that is pelting House and Senate negotiators with objections from voters back home.
The second may be the most significant as bargaining over the final version of Mr. Clinton's plan reaches a climax this week. Simply put, Congressional support for Mr. Clinton's package is so thin that negotiators are virtually required to reconsider any part of the bill that draws fire from even a small bloc of legislators.
In this case, 19 representatives sent a letter to the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington State, nine days ago saying they "cannot guarantee a positive vote on final passage" of Mr. Clinton's package unless part of the tax break is restored. The package passed the House in May by only six votes.
"If the bill had passed by 80 votes they would be telling people to go suck wind," said Robert E. Juliano, the chief lobbyist for the Hotel and Restaurant Workers International Union. "Our issue is one that could tilt it over the other the way."
In the Senate, where the economic plan carried last month by a single vote, negotiators are hoping a restored tax break would win over Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, who voted against the plan. Mr. Bryan's state depends heavily on the convention and business-travel trade for jobs and state tax money.
That negotiators are considering multibillion-dollar concessions for the sake of a handful of votes underscores the Wild West character of this budget debate. In effect, every one of the 269 Democrats who voted for some version of the package earlier this year now holds the power to defeat it.
Perhaps coincidentally, it also reflects the political interests of the Congressional powers behind the bargaining. The two chief negotiators, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago, hail from cities where the convention and restaurant businesses are multibillion-dollar industries.
Negotiators said they were optimistic that they could produce a politically palatable compromise by week's end, and that both Houses would pass it before Congress rushes out on its monthlong summer vacation a week from Friday. But they clearly have scant room for mistakes.
For their part, House and Senate aides said, restaurant owners and workers have exploited the negotiators' weakness with a skillful lobbying campaign. When Congress last shaved the meal-and-entertainment deduction to 80 percent from 100 percent in 1986, the tax break was assailed as a write-off for rich businessmen who dined at overpriced restaurants.
 
Lobbying Focuses on Jobs
 This time, the restaurant industry has cast the debate in terms of jobs, not tax breaks. The campaign began in June with a television commercial featuring a small-town waitress who frets that a reduction in the write-off for meals will depress business and cost her her job.
That advertisement was followed two weeks ago by a spot featuring a long-haul trucker, supplied by the American Trucking Associations, who talks about the proposal's impact on drivers who eat almost all their meals on the road.
A spokeswoman for the National Restaurant Association said today that the two commercials had been broadcast in 17 states, most of them rural, and in four large cities, including Mr. Moynihan's and Mr. Rostenkowski's hometowns. Most of the states are represented in Congress by lawmakers who are major players in the economic bargaining.
One Democratic Congressman whose district is targeted, Representative Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii, is the tax expert for an unofficial group of legislators who represent states with large travel and tourism industries. He led the group of 19 representatives who sent Mr. Foley a letter demanding concessions on the issue.
 
Favoring Write-Off of 70%
 His spokesman, Michael Slackman, said today that Mr. Abercrombie was especially worried that a scaled-back deduction for business meals would mean fewer business travelers for Hawaii.
The restaurant industry estimates that the deduction would reduce expenses for meals by $3.8 billion a year and cost 165,000 jobs. But that would be true only if companies and independent business owners cut their own spending on meals enough to recapture every dollar that a reduced write-off would cost them.
The restaurant industry has not said publicly how much of the meals deduction it is seeking to recoup. But Mr. Juliano suggested today that reducing the write-off to 70 percent of expenses, rather than 50 percent, would still generate between $7 billion and $8 billion in new money for the Government in the next five years.
One Congressional aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said legislators considered a write-off of 60 percent or 65 percent to be more realistic. But even that would force the budget negotiators to find $3 billion to $5 billion in offsetting tax increases or new spending cuts.
