HEADLINE: Senate Democrats See Re-election Perils in '94

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
When Senators Charles S. Robb of Virginia and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan appeared on the Senate floor recently to deliver enthusiastic pitches for President Clinton's economic program, they were thinking not just of the President's political fortunes but also of their own.
Both men are atop the list of the most vulnerable Democratic incumbents facing re-election next year. And both, following deliberate strategies, have decided to stick by their President when they comfortably can, but not to hesitate to offer sometime biting public criticism. 
 Defining their relationships with the President is a delicate matter for several Democratic senators who are gearing up their re-election drives. Of the Democratic senators facing re-election in 1994, only Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts have ever had to campaign when their party was in the White House. Thus, the quandary: Do they run against a President who has thus far proved widely unpopular, or do they remain loyal to Mr. Clinton, hoping that a year from now he will have rebounded?
 
Tied to Clinton
 For all the ambivalence in their speeches about Mr. Clinton's budget, most Democratic senators have grudgingly tied their fortunes to his. That is not simply because they want to do Mr. Clinton a favor but because his success, particularly with his economic program, could translate into their own. Now that the Democrats control the White House, there is pressure for these senators to return to their states with a record of accomplishment.
"Their calculation is, 'the best way for me to get re-elected may be to help the President succeed,' " said Samuel Kernell, a professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego. "In the end, that's Clinton's big trump card. They're all tied together because they happen to be called Democrats."
While the economy may improve before the 1994 elections, and Mr. Clinton may have more to show for himself legislatively, history shows that being from the party in the White House often hurts contenders in mid-term elections. The President's party has gained Senate seats only three times since World War II, in 1962, 1970 and 1982.
 
Republican Advantages
 There are other reasons that some Democrats fear that the 1994 elections could be damaging. From the outset, Republicans have the advantage because they have only 13 seats to defend, while the Democrats have 21. (Some Republican incumbents, of course, also face difficult campaigns next year.) While many Democratic officials said that they doubted that the Republicans could pick up the seven seats needed to take over the Senate, they also expected the Democrats to sustain losses.
Understating the challenge ahead, Don Foley, executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said, "There's no question that it has the potential for being a very difficult year."
There are practical reasons for incumbents to cozy up to Mr. Clinton: Even if he is in a political slump, a President is always a big draw at fund-raising events. And many senators fear falling into what Stanley Greenberg, the President's pollster, described as "the Krueger model."
Former Senator Bob Krueger of Texas, a Democrat who was overwhelmingly defeated in a special election last month, based his campaign on emphasizing his disagreements with Mr. Clinton. Brian Lunde, a Democratic political consultant, said the Krueger debacle left Democratic incumbents scrambling in fear for next year. "The Texas results actually set off the 1994 campaign," he said.
 
Inoculating Themselves
 Senators who are linking themselves closely to Mr. Clinton and his economic plan acknowledge that they are putting their hopes in the chance that Mr. Clinton will recover.
"Krueger ran so far away from Bill Clinton that he lost his political base," said Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a loud critic of the President's budget before he ultimately voted for it. "Democrats are jittery because Clinton's asking us to do some things that are controversial and difficult. The only thing that I know how to do is to make sure that where Bill Clinton and I have a shared interest we fight together."
Such was the aim of Senators Robb and Riegle in defending the President on the Senate floor. "Robb is doing something that Bob Krueger did not do," Mr. Foley said. "He will support Clinton when he can. That way, he's kind of inoculating himself from charges that he is in lock step with the President."
But even if Senators Robb and Riegle seek to balance their support by voting against Mr. Clinton on other high-profile issues, like the North American Free Trade Agreement in Mr. Riegle's case, the Republicans are already armed with plenty of material for attacks.
After Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota voted for the deficit-reduction package, his state's Republican Party lashed out at him in a statement. The first sentence was hardly restrained: "Senator Kent Conrad today turned his back on the people of North Dakota and voted with Bill Clinton for the largest tax increase in the history of the world."
 
Trouble in Arizona
 Perhaps fearing such attacks in their own states, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Richard H. Bryan of Nevada voted against the President's package, not wanting to be tarred with unpopular elements like its proposed increase in gasoline taxes.
"There is certainly a risk for DeConcini in opposing the President because primary opposition may develop," said Steve Owens, chairman of the Arizona Democratic Party. "A lot of people in the Democratic Party think elected officials ought to be out there toeing the line on all votes."
But given that Arizona went for President George Bush last year and that Ross Perot drew a large share of the vote, Mr. Owens said Mr. DeConcini's vote may have been the right move. "There's a real sense of change in this state," he said. "People are not quite sure the Democratic Party has all the answers."
Along with Senators Riegle and Robb, Mr. DeConcini is viewed by officials from both parties as probably the most vulnerable Democrats next year. An indication of that is they are the only three Democrats thus far with clear opposition in the primaries.
Mr. DeConcini and Mr. Riegle are dogged by rebukes from the Senate Ethics Committee for their involvement in the influence-peddling scandal involving Charles H. Keating, the owner of a failed savings and loan. And though Mr. Robb avoided a grand jury indictment in a case involving the illegal taping of his longtime rival, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, the controversy and Mr. Wilder's decision to oppose him in the primary, leave his prospects far from assured.
 
Glee From the G.O.P.
 A bit lower down on the list of endangered Democrats, officials in both parties say, are Senators Lautenberg and Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania. Mr. Lautenberg has not been particularly popular in his state and could suffer from the anti-Democrat sentiment prompted by Gov. Jim Florio's pushing through higher taxes in 1990. Republicans also hold distant hopes of unseating Mr. Kennedy and Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin.
While Mr. Wofford's victory in a special election in 1991 was widely viewed as a referendum on the Bush Administration, he is so closely linked to Mr. Clinton -- and to enacting a new health-care system -- that his prospects may hinge on the success of the President's health program.
Republicans react with glee to the Democrats' nervousness over 1994. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said his side would make little distinction next year between Democrats like Mr. Lautenberg, who opposed Mr. Clinton's deficit-reduction package, and those who sided with the President.
"You've got some people like Lautenberg who are trying to distance themselves from Clinton, and you have others like Riegle who are not," Mr. Gramm said. "But the point is that Lautenberg has cast plenty of votes to define who he is and what his position is. There's no way they can run away from Clinton."
Senator Harlan Mathews of Tennessee, who was appointed to the seat vacated by Vice President Al Gore and is reconsidering his vow not to run for a full six-year term, said he was sticking by Mr. Clinton.
"To be honest with you, if I were running tomorrow, I'd have some concerns," Mr. Mathews said. "But I've got to believe that in the long run he's going to be a positive influence on this country, and on the '94 elections."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Softens a Plan to Withdraw Old Ruble Notes

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 26

 BODY:
In the face of growing popular dissatisfaction and loud criticism from the Westernized market-oriented wing of his Government, President Boris N. Yeltsin issued a decree today sharply watering down a drastic currency revision that the Central Bank announced on Saturday.
As Russians stood complaining in long lines from St. Petersburg to Khabarovsk to exchange their suddenly invalid pre-1993 ruble banknotes at state savings banks that had inadequate supplies of new notes, even Mr. Yeltsin's political rival, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the parliamentary speaker, usually an ally of the bank, opposed the change, calling it confiscatory and threatening to reconvene Parliament to overturn it. 
 So Mr. Yeltsin, who was on vacation when the bank made its decision, moved first. In the process he delivered a stinging defeat to the bank and its acting director, Viktor V. Gerashchenko. Mr. Yeltsin generally sided with free-marketers like Finance Minister Boris G. Fyodorov and embarrassed his industrialist Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who approved the bank plans in a quick meeting on Friday to which the Finance Ministry was not invited.
In a decree this evening Mr. Yeltsin ruled that Russians could exchange up to 100,000 old rubles, about $100, for new ones until the end of next month, instead of 35,000 old rubles by Aug. 7. He also decreed that 10,000 ruble banknotes marked 1992 could be exchanged for new ones above and beyond those limits and that banknotes of 10 rubles or less could be used until the end of next month, no matter when issued. Many kiosks and vendors could not function because of the lack of valid small change, with new ruble coins in short supply.
The expanded limits and period for exchange should allow for many times the amount of old notes that were in circulation, economists said today, and remove the sense of panic that many Russians have felt. Originally, the people were obliged to put all old notes above 35,000 rubles into state bank accounts, frozen for six months at a low rate of interest. But given the higher limit and Russians' ability to move money among family members and friends, few people should have difficulty finding ways to exchange their old notes.
Countries of the former Soviet Union that still use the ruble or have large stocks of old rubles for necessary trade with Russia will also find it much easier to cope, Western diplomats and economists said.
Mr. Yeltsin's decision all but kills the Central Bank initiative and is a severe embarrassment for Mr. Gerashchenko, who has been feuding with Mr. Fyodorov. Mr. Fyodorov was on vacation in America when the decision was made, and according to Finance Ministry officials and a senior Government economic adviser, Anders Aslund, neither Mr. Yeltsin nor Mr. Fyodorov was informed of the decision, which was made on Thursday.
Mr. Aslund said Mr. Chernomyrdin did not seem to understand the implications of the decision and called the meeting on Friday to which the Finance Ministry was not invited. There was some dissent, especially from Privatization Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, but participants were unprepared and had seen no documents.
Mr. Chernomyrdin "seemed to have been co-opted into supporting the Central Bank move," Mr. Aslund said.
Mr. Fyodorov was informed on Saturday and lodged an internal protest. But Mr. Chernomyrdin's support complicated the matter for Mr. Yeltsin, officials said. Mr. Fyodorov went public on late Saturday night and today, using a statement to dissociate his ministry from the decision and calling it "a deliberate political provocation aimed at irritating the population and discrediting the President, his Government and their course."
 
Failed Effort at Revision in '91
 In an interview today with a Russian radio station, Mr. Fyodorov said: "Once again, we are making fools of ourselves in the eyes of the world. We are using Bolshevik methods of a Stalinist nature to try to resolve economic problems in the context of a market economy." He plans to return here on Tuesday.
Western diplomats suggested that Mr. Fyodorov would move to seize the fruits of his victory and try once more to remove Mr. Gerashchenko from the bank. Mr. Gerashchenko was also in charge of the bank at the time of the last failed revision, in January 1991, when the Government announced that 50- and 100-ruble notes were invalid.
Mr. Gerashchenko, in brief comments today, was unapologetic. But he said he had coordinated them with Mr. Khasbulatov, contradicting the speaker's statement.
In another sign of Mr. Yeltsin's support for his market-oriented wing, he signed a decree accelerating the turning over of state-owned businesses to private interests. The decree reasserts that 80 percent of enterprise shares have to be bought with vouchers issued free to each citizen last year, that at least 29 percent of the shares have to be sold for vouchers to outsiders who do not work for the company and that at least 3,000 large state-owned enterprises have to be turned over this year.
There was anger across the country as Russians once again found themselves wasting their day in lines. Some formed as early as 6 A.M. At a bank at Karyetny Ryad, 70 people waited outside, mostly older women complaining as one person was allowed in at a time. Anna, on vacation from Tallinn, Estonia, had 50,000 rubles. She had registered as No. 45, arriving at 7 A.M., and ran a few blocks to another bank and took No. 307 on that list.
On Chekhov Street there was pushing among Russians and Azerbaijanis and Armenians as some tried to jump ahead of the line. An old woman leaving the bank was pushed and slipped down the stairs. On the periphery, Regina Alexandrovskaya, 38, a teacher, waited with a book. She had split her money with her son and his friend. "These limits are nothing," she said. "You can't even buy a train ticket and a sausage."
In Khabarovsk in the Far East there was a common and acute shortage of notes. Banks offered to deposit old notes and not exchange them. "The situation caused open discontent among the local population," the Interfax news agency commented.
The original decision of the Central Bank had the stated goals of slowing inflation, seizing counterfeit currency and imposing improved control over the money supply.

HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN PACT IS BACKED BY U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 26

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher affirmed United States support today for a new security pact that would allow the countries of East Asia to head off conflicts as the region becomes increasingly important in the world economy.
Mr. Christopher and United States officials traveling with him say they envision an Asian equivalent of the Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which was established to provide a forum for European countries to work out disputes peacefully. 
 "A new Pacific community must create a new regional balance that promotes stability, regional arms control and the peaceful resolution of disputes," Mr. Christopher said in a speech here today.
The idea of a new East Asian security structure has been promoted by several countries concerned that the end of the Soviet threat and budget problems in the United States may force Washington to reduce its military presence in the area.
While Administration officials say no such withdrawal is contemplated, some countries worry that regional powers like China and Japan would step into any power vacuum.
 
Asia Is Not Europe
 The precise functions of the new body are vague, but would probably evolve into having the members share information about their defenses and discuss territorial disputes that could lead to conflict.
"The purpose is completely different than the purpose you had in Europe during the cold war," said an official traveling with Mr. Christopher. "Here we're not forming blocs against a common enemy. We're having potential enemies, potential antagonists, sitting around the same table talking to each other directly."
As they ended a two-day meeting on Saturday, the foreign ministers of the six countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, endorsed what they termed a Regional Security Forum on political and security issues. The six countries are Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Brunei.
Mr. Christopher is attending an Asean Post-Ministerial Conference, a three-day session that meets every year after the Asean conference and included 11 nations.

HEADLINE: Norwalk Police Find Focus Turns to Them After a Death

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., July 22

 BODY:
A few blocks from brick sidewalks lined with antiques stores and bistros and an extensive array of "shoppes," a dozen of Keith Sumpter's friends were lingering on the chipped pavement near the Carlton Court housing project. It was another restless summer day.
Like many young black men in small cities across the New York region, they said they could not find jobs. So they stood bare-chested in the sun, raging against the local police, who, they insisted, had killed Mr. Sumpter earlier this month for no apparent reason and who routinely harass them. 
 "It's like we're guilty just for being out here," said a 20-year-old who would give only his nickname, "Breeze." "We don't get a chance. We just get laid to the ground with a pistol in our back. That's what brings this anger."
 
Tensions in Smaller Cities
 Tensions between police officers and minority residents are often thought to be confined to volatile neighborhoods in big cities like New York. But law-enforcement experts and community groups say these strains appear to be spreading to the region's increasingly diverse smaller cities, many of which have long prided themselves on their racial calm.
Here in Connecticut, the State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities now sees as its top priority improving relations between local police forces and black and Hispanic residents. The Community Relations Service, an arm of the Federal Justice Department that mediates conflicts in small cities, says it must focus more on police relations in places like Norwalk, Stamford, New Haven and Bridgeport.
Similar troubles are cropping up around the region, from New Rochelle, N.Y., to the New Jersey communities of New Brunswick, Montclair and Teaneck, a Bergen County suburb that was jolted in 1990 when a white police officer shot a black teen-ager to death. The killing touched off violence and months of protest marches. A jury later acquitted the officer of manslaughter.
 
More Incendiary Conflicts
 "This is one of the biggest issues we're facing in policing," said Jack McDevitt, a criminologist at Northeastern University who specializes in teaching small police departments how to improve ties with black and Hispanic residents. "In these smaller cities, these kinds of tensions are becoming more and more significant."
To be sure, such tensions have long existed in some small cities. But law-enforcement experts say they are now more likely to flare into violence or protest.
Norwalk is an example of how recent wrinkles in the social fabric of the region's smaller cities -- from uneven economic development to the growth in drug dealing to the fallout from the Rodney G. King case in Los Angeles -- have frayed relations.
Law-enforcement experts say the most important change is the evolving populations in cities like Norwalk. Seeking to escape urban ills like crime, drugs and unemployment that plague large metropolitan areas, more members of minority groups are moving to small cities. But many white officers in these areas are unfamiliar with the cultures of the new arrivals, these experts say. And many small police forces remain overwhelmingly white, failing to match the ethnic and racial mix of the cities they serve.
In Norwalk, simmering resentment toward the police erupted into violence in the hours after the July 1 death of Mr. Sumpter, 21, who was black. Even though a curfew was imposed in the South Norwalk section, where many blacks live, young men fired guns and threw bottles at officers.
No injuries or arrests were reported, but the self-confidence of this city of 80,000 on Long Island Sound was bruised.
Mr. Sumpter was apparently unemployed and had no police record. He was described as easygoing and witty by friends, who say he was a mainstay of the street life around Carlton Court, cracking jokes and drinking malt liquor to the throbbing beat of rap music.
The police maintain that Mr. Sumpter committed suicide by shooting himself in the head in an alley as he was being taken into custody on charges of stealing two gold chains from a teen-ager. State officials said that a preliminary forensics investigation appeared to confirm the accounts of the arresting officers, who were mostly white.
 
Mindful of Previous Deaths
 But Mr. Sumpter's family and friends, mindful of other questions about police conduct in Norwalk in recent years, contend that the officers killed him and are hiding the truth. They spoke of Ralph Fuller, 27, a black man who was shot to death in 1986 by Norwalk officers responding to a report that he was threatening a relative with a rifle, which, it turned out, was not loaded. The officers were cleared of wrongdoing.
They also recalled the case of a 14-year-old black teen-ager who was used as a human shield by an officer searching a Norwalk home in 1991. The officer was later punished with restricted duty and had to perform community service, but he remains on the force.
"We know it's a cover-up," said Jeanine Van Lierop, 29, a resident of the Carlton Court housing project, referring to Mr. Sumpter's death. "We know he didn't kill himself over some gold chains."
Another youth from the project remarked: "The cops always kill people. That's why it's us versus them."
Despite the disturbances, Norwalk's Police Chief, Carl LaBianca, said relations with black and Hispanic residents were good and he emphasized that in the last decade, he had increased the number of minority officers on the force to 23 percent, from 9 percent. He declined to let his officers be interviewed.
 
City Defends Actions
 "I think there is a silent majority in the minority community that is afraid to voice their dissatisfaction with what is going on in their neighborhoods," said the Chief, who is white and has been with the Norwalk police for almost 40 years.
"Some of the young people you spoke to are going to say things that will make them safe with the drug dealers," he said. "You are not going to get anyone to come out with the contrary -- about how great the police are doing."
The city's Mayor, Frank Esposito, said he had moved quickly to quell the violence by meeting with Mr. Sumpter's family and seeking local and state investigations. "That shows we are trying to do right and to treat everyone fairly," said Mr. Esposito, 65, who is white.
But some members of the minority community, which comprises about 25 percent of the city's population, maintain that local officials have failed to recognize the deep roots of the hostility.
 
Glaring Disparities
 Some complain that they were bypassed by the wealth that surged through Fairfield County in the 1980's, giving rise to sprawling office parks and roadways crowded with luxury cars. For tenants of Carlton Court, a privately owned project that is almost entirely black and Hispanic, a telling sign of that disparity is the waterfront district a short walk away.
Though the city has rejuvenated the district over the last 20 years by wooing art galleries, expensive restaurants and upscale stores, the streets around the project remain rundown. Tenants say they have seen few economic benefits from the gentrification of what is now known as "Historic SoNo," even as the recession has further limited their chances.
"When you live in a place like Carlton Court, there is a lot of wealth and opportunity around you, but you can't partake of it," said Robert Burgess, executive director of Norwalk Economic Opportunity Now, a nonprofit development agency that provides job training and business grants to the city's poor neighborhoods.
As a result, police officers, who are among the most visible symbols of government, are often targets of residents' frustration. "Young people see the police as guardians of the coffers," said Al Robinson, president of Norwalk's N.A.A.C.P. chapter.
The unrest here has also shown that even in a small city 3,000 miles from Los Angeles, the police beating case there still reverberates.
 
Growing Minority Population
 "The King incident had a devastating effect on everyone," said Archie L. Hodge, 30, an AIDS educator at the Norwalk Health Department who is black and has lived in the city all his life. "You feel that you can't trust the law. And if you can't trust it there -- in L.A. -- then you can't trust it here in Norwalk."
And the Sumpter case has thrown a spotlight on how small police forces are adapting to the growing numbers of black and Hispanic people, as well as immigrants, who are settling in the region's smaller cities. The 1990 census, for example, showed that the Hispanic population of Norwalk had nearly doubled in the last decade, to almost 7,400 people.
Leaders of some community groups in the area say that even if small police departments are trying to diversify, many white officers have failed to adjust.
"The police are not getting proper training," said Domingo Isasi, 54, an engineer and member of United Hispanic Action of Norwalk. "The police officer on the beat sees something happening and has to make a snap decision, but he can only judge by his own heritage. That's when the problems start."
 
More Drug Arrests
 Law-enforcement experts say these misunderstandings often ignite conflicts when officers crack down on drug dealing. Many small police forces, they say, rely on strong measures against drugs -- like flooding a block with heavily armed officers -- that have often been discarded by big-city departments as inefficient and too repressive.
Chief LaBianca spoke proudly of the tough actions he had taken against drug dealing, noting that the number of drug arrests in Norwalk had jumped nearly 40 percent in the last decade, to about 400 a year. But some black residents said that while they were eager to rid their streets of drugs, many officers were too harsh.
"In trying to crack down on the drug trade, they have alienated a lot of people," said the Rev. Carl L. Washington Jr., 38, of the Grace Baptist Church, a predominantly black congregation in Norwalk.
For the last few weeks, Mr. Washington has immersed himself in the tensions of this city, speaking about the Sumpter case with hundreds of people -- black and white -- as well as local officials. He is not optimistic.
"When a lot of us were growing up and moving along, we had opportunities that are not there for them," he said, referring the young black residents he meets on street corners. "Small towns, large towns, there's a lot of anger. And honestly and truthfully, if something is not done to help these young people, you are going to have it more and more."

HEADLINE: Keeping It to a Low Roar;
New York City Tries Electronic Muzzles to Zap Bus Noise

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Watch out, Klingons, a new cloaking technology is in the field. It helps hide a city bus.
The technology is an "anti-noise generator," a computer-driven, 220-watt speaker in the tailpipe of a bus that emits sound waves to partially cancel exhaust noise. The New York City Transit Authority is testing the device, also called an electronic muffler, in four buses. 
 It will not turn a 41-seat city bus into a match for the Klingon warships that make themselves invisible on "Star Trek," but it does help eliminate sound, especially the low-frequency sound that travels farthest and rattles windows along the street as buses pass.
With an electronic muffler, a bus "doesn't sound as heavy as the normal bus," said Charles E. Boston, driving a test bus up the East Side of Manhattan yesterday.
 
The Muffler as Mimic
 The Transit Authority's goal for the muffler goes beyond cutting noise. By replacing the conventional muffler, which is a maze of sound-absorbing baffles, the electronic muffler makes it easier for the bus to emit exhaust, thus raising horsepower or increasing fuel economy.
The muffler works by analyzing the sound waves and mimicking them, sending out waves of the same frequency and amplitude, but out of step. The technique is a little like that of a parent who quiets the splashing of a child at one end of a bathtub by making waves at the other end.
The devices being tested in New York were invented by Noise Cancellation Technologies Inc. of Stamford, Conn. They were installed by Walker Noise Cancellation Technologies, a joint venture of the Stamford company and Walker Manufacturing, a division of Tenneco that says it is the world's largest manufacturer of conventional mufflers.
Walker Noise Cancellation says its muffler will cut fuel consumption by 3.5 percent. This may not sound like much, but New York City buses average 2.9 miles per gallon in stop-and-go traffic and travel 30,000 miles a year, meaning a savings of nearly 350 gallons annually. The Transit Authority has 3,700 buses that run on a form of diesel fuel that lately has cost the city 65 to 75 cents a gallon.
 
Wooing Transit Companies
 Walker sold the first four mufflers to the city for $1,100 each, which a company representative said was a generous price to induce New York to get involved. The company's goal is to get enough operating experience to prove that the mufflers work, then persuade bus manufacturers to build them into their designs.
Houston and two transit systems in Southern California have placed small orders for the mufflers, a Walker representative said, and others are negotiating.
The transit systems are generally most interested in the mufflers as a means to save fuel. In New York, Charles Seaton, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, said that "it would be hard to tell with the naked ear" whether the mufflers make buses quieter, and that their main advantage is efficiency.
Scott H. Buehrer, a spokesman for Walker, said the electronic muffler is especially helpful at low frequencies below 500 hertz, a tone roughly equivalent to the B below middle C on the piano. In other words, it lessens the rumble, not the whine.
 The technology is already used in factories to reduce the drone from vacuum or blower fans. Walker says it is also working on a version to use in an airplane to blank out engine noise.
But buses are a harder task, because their speed, and hence the pitch of their engines, keeps changing. "We love fixed r.p.m.," said Ross B. Gordon, the national account manager at Walker.
The first electronic muffler was installed on a New York bus about four months ago, yielding an immediate increase in horsepower of about 4.5 percent, Mr. Buehrer said. But the buses have about 255 horsepower and do not need more, according to the Transit Authority, which would rather take the efficiency gain as fuel savings. So the authority recently installed smaller fuel injectors in the buses with electronic mufflers, restoring the horsepower to the original level and increasing fuel economy.
Measuring the mufflers' effect will take several months, said Andrew S. J. Skabowski, an engineer at the Transit Authority, because fuel economy varies with traffic, temperature, the habits of the bus driver and how many people are aboard.
But Mr. Skabowski said he had high hopes. "If it works without a lot of repairs, we're looking at savings," he said.
With the muffling technology in hand, engineers say they may eventually look at other places to reduce bus noise, including the transmission, drivetrain and fans or air-conditioning compressor.
But then there is that special clunk, rattle and jingle of the bus hitting potholes. The solution for that, experts say, does not lie with the bus.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "NOISE: Lowering Exhaust Rumble"
To reduce noise pollution and save fuel, the New York City Transit Authority is trying out a new noise-cancellation technology in some of its bus mufflers.
 
1. Engine noise is analyzed by an engine sensor and a tailpipe microphone.
 
2. A speaker in the muffler generates sound waves that are the opposite of the engine noise.
 
3. The resulting sound from the vehicle is relatively low in volume.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Pain Ahead in States' Budgets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
After three years of painful and protracted budget battles, most states approved spending plans this spring and summer with relative ease, if not resignation.
But the pain has just begun for many states, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Conference of State Legislatures at its annual meeting in San Diego. 
 The study, which provides the first look at how the states completed the last fiscal year and are beginning the new one, noted that with few exceptions elected officials enacted spending plans that did not address the fastest-growing budget areas: corrections and health care.
Moreover, these two programs will consume nearly 20 percent of all state spending this fiscal year, up from about 14 percent five years ago. And by some dire projections, Medicaid alone could consume a third of state spending by the year 2000.
 
Growing Programs
 "In California, they call a hot, quiet, humid day earthquake weather," said Ronald K. Snell, director of the conference's fiscal program who was the main architect of the study. "That's where the states are: it's quiet, but there is an earthquake building."
Mr. Snell said there were two major opposing forces on the fault line running through state budgets. On one side is the inexorable growth in the cost of punishing criminals and of providing health care for the poor and elderly under the federally subsidized Medicaid program, of which most states pay about 50 percent. On the other side, he said, there is the reluctance of voters to increase taxes for programs like prisons that do not seem to work or have any bearing on their lives.
Fiscal experts say most states have done little to control health care costs because they have been waiting for a national plan. President Clinton postponed making his health care proposal until this fall, saying that Congress was preoccupied with the budget and deficit reduction plan.
"People should have laughed hysterically at that," said Brian M. Roherty, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers in Washington. "It is totally and completely absurd to have a Federal budget that does not address health care, which is the most profound structural problem in Federal and state budgets."
The delay in dealing with health care policy has its most apparent effect on higher education. Since 1990, states have shifted $7.7 billion in costs to public colleges and universities, which have responded by raising tuition and laying off faculty and staff members in most states, according to the American Association of State Colleges and Universities.
"We are entering a situation where there are not enough classes and programs for people to finish degree programs, and the neediest students can't get enough financial aid to go to college," said Dr. James B. Appleberry, president of the association.
State budgets for the 1994 fiscal year, which began on July 1 in most states, were driven more by political pressures than by fiscal ones, which could, at least temporarily, be ignored. Budgets in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut, for example, were passed on time, with no broad tax increases, no significant initiatives and very little debate.
In fact, all states but California and Vermont ended the 1993 fiscal year with balanced budgets, thanks to conservative revenue projections and low inflation.
The conference's fiscal study was based on complete budget information from 38 states and tax information from 46 states. It paints a statistical picture that averages out the stark differences among states, much in the way that a person who has one foot in a fire and one foot on ice is, on average, comfortable.
The study provided this picture of the financial health of the states:
*For the first time, state financing for Medicaid exceeded spending for state colleges and universities in the last last fiscal year. In the 1992 fiscal year, states spent $28.5 billion on higher education and $26.5 billion on Medicaid. In the 1993 fiscal year, spending on higher education declined to $27.5 billion and spending on Medicaid increased to $32 billion. This fiscal year, states plan to spend 24 percent more on Medicaid than on higher education, which used to be states' highest priority after financing primary and secondary education.
*Tennessee, going beyond the reforms adopted in a half-dozen states, boldly scrapped Medicaid and replaced it with a managed care program to try to provide better coverage to nearly twice as many residents at no additional public cost. The Federal Government is expected to approve the program, which would start in January.
*In the Northeast, where most economies are sluggish, budgets for the current fiscal year were balanced with many accounting gimmicks like delaying the payment of bills. In the Midwest, states that are inundated by the Mississippi River reported that it was too soon to calculate the disaster's impact on their budgets. California, which had to cope with a $9 billion shortage in its $52 billion overall budget this fiscal year, is in the worst fiscal shape.
*States expected that their revenues would rise by 2.8 percent on average this year, or less than the estimated 3.3 percent rate of inflation. State forecasts for revenue collections range from a 6.1 percent growth in Idaho, which is thriving with the growth of high-technology industries, to a 7.5 percent decline in Montana, where the economy has stalled.
Sensing the anger of the electorate and the shallowness of their pockets, most states did not enact new taxes. Some states also did raise taxes, most paid by smokers and tobacco companies. New York alone increased taxes on cigarettes by 17 cents a pack to 56 cents. The total new tax revenue expected amounts to $3.8 billion, or just a fraction of the $16.2 billion in taxes enacted in 1991.
 
California Takes Lead
 The budgetary pressures are most intense in California, and state experts look to California for clues on how other states would, sooner or later, deal with similar problems.
California's problems with the rising cost of health care and corrections have been aggravated by years of limits on taxing and waves of immigration and job losses. The state avoided a replay of last year's budget crisis in part by sharing more of the crisis with local governments.
For instance, California reduced its spending on primary and secondary education by $2.6 billion and forced cities and counties to absorb the cost by using local property taxes. The state softened the blow by extending a half-cent sales tax surcharge, which benefits cities and counties. The surcharge, however, will expire in November unless two-thirds of the voters decide to extend it.
In effect, the state is shifting costs to the local level and forcing taxpayers to decide whether they want to pay for the programs.
"This may be startling in 1993," Mr. Snell said, "but in a few years we may look back and see that California was the first of many states to do this."

HEADLINE: Rise Granted On Insurance For Doctors

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 26

 BODY:
With efforts to tame the rapid rise in health-care costs delayed in both Washington and Albany, the State Insurance Superintendent today approved an average 14 percent rise in medical malpractice insurance rates paid by doctors.
The increase, which takes effect on July 30, will be the first rise in malpractice premiums after four years of stable or declining rates. The Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, said in a statement that the change was justified because of an increase in the number of malpractice lawsuits being filed, a rise in the dollar amount of malpractice awards and a decline in interest rates, which has limited insurers' investment income. 
 But officials with groups representing physicians and patients said the increase would only accelerate the rising of health-care costs in a state where medical care is already highly expensive. And they said it would continue the defection of specialists with high insurance premiums, like obstetricians, from fields that already are suffering from dangerously low numbers.
 
Most Expensive Region
 With the latest rise, neurosurgeons practicing on Long Island, the most expensive specialty and region in the state, will pay premiums of $130,532 a year, up from $114,532. In Manhattan and Westchester County, they will pay $101,002, up from $88,599. Obstetricians in Manhattan and Westchester will pay $86,609, while on Long Island they will pay $111,930. General practitioners will pay $11,311 in Manhattan and Westchester and $14,618 on Long Island.
The increase comes as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature have taken a break from negotiations on revamping the state's hospital payment system. Whatever compromise is reached will almost certainly mean at least a modest rise in payments to hospitals and thus in health insurance premiums for most New Yorkers.
This fall, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest and most troubled health insurer, is expected to petition Mr. Curiale for another rate increase. Some legislators and health-care lobbyists have projected that its rate increase request will be at least 20 percent.
In Washington, the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform does not expect to produce a proposal until this fall at the earliest, months later than originally planned. Policy makers in both capitals believe any meaningful change in the health-care system must be accompanied by changes in the medical-malpractice system.
President Clinton's task force has discussed a proposal to relieve individual doctors of legal responsibility for negligence, leaving patients to sue insurance companies and health maintenance organizations instead.
For the last three years, Mr. Cuomo has proposed creating a fund that would compensate the families of newborns injured during birth, regardless of whether malpractice is proved. It would be financed through a $300 fee paid by doctors and hospitals in the birth of each newborn.
In 1985, after malpractice premiums rose more than 50 percent, Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature enacted a series of significant changes aimed at keeping rates down. The law reduced the amount of contingency fees that lawyers could earn in malpractice cases, allowed large malpractice awards to be paid over long periods of time and imposed penalties for frivolous lawsuits, among other measures.
Over the next five years, the number of malpractice cases filed in New York dropped precipitously, from 14,224 in 1986 to 3,410 in 1991, according to figures compiled by the Alliance for Consumer Rights. But last year the number rose to 3,753.
John Calagna, a spokesman for Mr. Curiale, said five insurance companies write policies for virtually all of the 25,000 individually insured physicians in New York. Those companies, he said, submitted actuarial reports showing the need for a rate increase. The largest company, the Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company, which insures 51 percent of the state's doctors, said it deserved a 20 percent increase, he said.
Insurance Department actuaries studied the company reports and recommended an average 14 percent increase to Mr. Curiale. The amount of the increase can vary by specialty, by region and by company.
 
'Just Intolerable'
 Gerard L. Conway, director of government affairs for the New York State Medical Society, said the increase was "just intolerable," particularly since Congress is considering deep cuts in Medicare reimbursement rates for doctors and hospitals. "There's no question that this is going to reduce access for the people who always end up getting the short end of the stick," he said.
A 1990 survey by the New York chapter of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists found that 17 percent of obstetricians and 70 percent of family practitioners who once delivered babies in New York no longer did so. High premium costs for liability insurance were cited as the major reason. Eleven counties had three or fewer obstetricians, and three had none.
Mr. Conway did not question Mr. Curiale's methodology for awarding the increase. But he said the increase highlighted the need for malpractice insurance reform.
Consumer groups, however, criticized Mr. Curiale for awarding the increase without fully auditing the insurance companies to examine whether profits truly were shrinking and, if so, whether the cause might be poor management instead of the growth in malpractice awards.
"You would have thought with this whole Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield thing that we would have learned about going through the paces and granting these requests, but apparently we haven't," said Laura Wittkin, executive director of the New York City-based Center for Patients' Rights.
Blair Horner, the legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, joined Ms. Wittkin in predicting costs would be passed along to patients. "That's where the $10 aspirin comes from," he said.

HEADLINE: Senate Confirms Former Amex Head as S.E.C. Chairman

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Arthur Levitt Jr., President Clinton's selection as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mr. Levitt, the former chairman of the American Stock Exchange, will succeed Richard C. Breeden, who said in February that he would step down as chairman. 
 President Clinton announced the nomination of Mr. Levitt on April 28 after it had been held up by the required review of his finances and a politically sensitive decision to select Mr. Levitt instead of an aide to Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.
The Administration has been trying to appoint members of minority groups and women to more key financial posts, and for some time the front-runner for the S.E.C. post was thought to have been Consuela Washington, a black woman who works for Mr. Dingell on a House committee overseeing the commission's work.
But President Clinton finally turned to Mr. Levitt, who had worked on Wall Street for many years and had substantial backing. He also helped raise millions of dollars for the Clinton campaign.
His predecessor, Mr. Breeden, a Republican who was appointed S.E.C. chairman by President Bush in 1989, had closely allied himself with the Bush Administration.
Though President Clinton had announced his selection of Mr. Levitt as S.E.C. chairman, the Senate technically was considering only his nomination as a commission member. Under the law, the President selects one of the commissioners as chairman.
It is difficult to say what effect Mr. Levitt's selection would have on the agency, which regulates trading in stocks and bonds, but he has had a longtime interest in entrepreneurial companies like some of those traded on the American exchange.
As chairman of the American exchange, Mr. Levitt increased spending on surveillance and regulation of market participants.
Mr. Levitt is chairman of the Levitt Media Company of New York, which publishes Roll Call, a twice-weekly newspaper covering Capitol Hill. He served as Amex chairman from 1978 to 1989. Before that, he ran a securities firm that became part of what is now the Shearson Lehman Brothers unit of American Express.
The Senate also confirmed today the nominations of Alan S. Blinder and Joseph Stiglitz to join President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. All the Senate's confirmations today were unrecorded voice votes.

HEADLINE: In West, Dinkins Promotes Candidacy and Filming

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 26

 BODY:
Battered last week by criticism of his handling of the Crown Heights violence, Mayor David N. Dinkins managed to create some positive moments here, spending the last three days raising money for his re-election campaign and drumming up support for filming in New York City.
Mr. Dinkins met with movie studio executives today, brandishing statistics that he said showed that filming had become less costly and hectic in New York, before he boarded a plane to return home. During the weekend, Mr. Dinkins held a fund-raiser, played tennis and met Barbra Streisand and friends for dinner and movies. They watched "Poetic Justice" and "Cliffhanger."
 
The Political Wars
 But New York's political wars did intrude a bit. Responding to criticism by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, that Mr. Dinkins was masking fund-raising in Los Angeles as an official trip, the Mayor said: "Put this with a long list of things he doesn't understand. Instead of just raising funds I'm spending time doing good government, which is useful to the city." 
 The Mayor said that his trip here underscores the importance of the film industry to New York, where film and television production accounted for $3 billion in economic activity in the late 1980's. That figure has declined considerably in recent years, mainly as a result of a seven-month labor dispute between studios and several unions that ended in 1991 but continued to discourage producers from filming there.
Many producers said they have abandoned filming in New York because of high costs, regulatory restrictions and the logistical problems of working in a city with severe traffic congestion.
Richard Brick, head of New York City's Office of Film, who accompanied the Mayor, said that in the last year the city had seen an increase in filming, citing an increase in the number of film permits to 62 in the first five months of the year, compared with 40 in the same period last year.
Mr. Brick attributed the increase in filming to recent contract agreements with unions that, for the first time, have put the cost of film labor in New York on a par with that of other major cities throughout the country and to agreements with hotels that now offer discounts to production companies. In addition, Mr. Brick said the city's film office had received a small increase in financing that would allow it to expedite requests by production companies for filming and building permits.
Some studio executives said they were impressed with Mr. Dinkins's efforts to make movie-making more convenient and affordable and said they hoped to do more shooting in New York.
"These trips do make a difference because they show a commitment from the top officer of the city to try and alleviate any red tape issues that might exist," said Robert Friedman, a spokesman for Warner Brothers. "Clearly it fosters better relations when you know that you have the ear of the boss and he is making this sort of pilgrimage."
Tom Pollock, chairman of MCA Motion Picture Group, who met with Mr. Dinkins today, said that although logistics and overuse of the city are still drawbacks to filming in New York, production has become easier because the city has given the film office the authority to persuade city agencies to assist producers.
For example, Mr. Pollock said that MCA's current filming of "The Paper," a movie about newspaper wars in New York, was being jeopardized by the need to remove a wall to create a newsroom. "We would have had to wait forever to get the proper permit," Mr. Pollock said. "It helps to have a film office that has been endowed with some power."

	--------------------	 	
 
A PENALTY FOR CUOMO
 In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said he would not be surprised if he pays a political price for ordering the investigation that produced the criticism of Mr. Dinkins's handling of the Crown Heights incident. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat who supports Mr. Dinkins, may run for a fourth four-year term next year and some political analysts and Dinkins allies believe the Governor will be held accountable by black voters if the report contributes to a Giuliani victory.
Mr. Cuomo said he had no choice but to request the investigation. "If you run away from difficult truths and controversial matters because you're afraid somebody's going to misunderstand and vote against you, then you can't govern," he told reporters after delivering a speech in Saratoga Springs. "So it may be that we pay a political price."

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks to Ease Friction in Companies

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 26

 BODY:
With corporate executives and labor leaders gathered here today to give supporting testimony, the Clinton Administration insisted that more jobs would exist in the United States if only management and workers ran their companies together.
The daylong conference, sponsored jointly by the Labor and Commerce Departments, served as a billboard to advertise a keystone of President Clinton's jobs program -- that the friction inherent in traditional labor-management relations undermines efficiency and the competitiveness of American companies in a world market. 
 "The most interesting thing that you said is that what turned out to be good for the company turned out to be good for the employees," said President Clinton, who led one of the sessions after giving the luncheon speech. He had just heard an executive of U S West, the phone company, a U S West employee and a representative of the Communications Workers of America describe cooperative efforts, including the redesigning of some jobs.
The Conference on the Future of the American Workplace was billed as a historic attempt by labor, management and Government to reach agreement on common work practices. "We have spotlighted the best practices," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said. "There are a lot of people out there who don't know they are embracing a new movement."
But the nearly 500 people who were invited to the conference skirted or failed to reach agreement on several major issues, including whether an efficient company, one that enjoys ideal labor-management cooperation, can create many jobs in a weak American economy that fails to generate much demand for many companies' products. "When we proposed this conference after the election, we thought it would be in the context of a much more growth-oriented package of public and private investment," said Derek Shearer, a Clinton economic adviser, referring to the President's public spending stimulus proposals, rejected by Congress.
Whatever the economy's strength, the Clinton Administration considers companies would be more competitive, and thus more likely to create more jobs, if hourly workers were "empowered," to help run their companies, as Mr. Reich put it. This means they must engage in endless skills training, work closely with management in setting production and pay levels and they must take on such tasks as hiring fellow workers, passing on product quality, reorganizaing assembly lines and carrying out other efficiencies even if that lengthens their hours on the job.
The role of unions in achieving this transformation remained unclear at the conference. Unions represented labor in developing partnership arrangements at many of the dozen or so companies represented at the conference. That raised the possibility that the Clinton Administration might encourage union organizing as part of the new cooperation -- perhaps reversing the steady decline in union membership over the last 20 years.
Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called for changes in Federal law to make union organizing easier. But Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said in an interview that they "were not necessary" to the cooperative process, "although they can be an important part of the equation."
 
Issue of Job Cuts
 Several themes came out repeatedly in the sessions. One was job-cutting through layoffs and attrition, a phenomenon at thousands of American companies. Although no one promised this would end, many speakers depicted the cooperative workplace as a method of slowing or halting job shrinkage, or at least making the process more just.
Inland Steel Industries, for example, has a new 10-year labor agreement with the United Steelworkers under which its Indiana Harbor Works, engaged in the new work practices, will nevertheless pare the 9,000 production workers to 7,000. The union has agreed to help the company achieve efficiencies that will cut labor costs and make Inland competitive with other steel companies.
The company has agreed to trim the staff not through layoffs, but through "accelerated attrition" of older workers near retirement, said Robert J. Darnall, chairman of Inland. The rest of the workers, in effect, will have job security.
Then there was pay. Rather than raising hourly wages, the companies at the conference favored profit-sharing or gain-sharing to give workers a share of the improved performance. Gain-sharing is a form of bonus payment based on workers achieving new production goals or some other efficiency. Pay increases based on skills was another favorite, to encourage workers to participate in training.
 
Opportunity for Input
 Asked by Mr. Reich what he considered the most important component of "the high performance work organization," Thomas J. Zidek, a line worker and union leader at the L-S Electro-Galvanizing Company in Cleveland, said: "The opportunity to have input into determining our own pay system, and to set gain-sharing goals."
The conferees recognized that a relatively small number of American companies have attempted to make their workers partners in running the companies. They noted that the process requires costly outlays for reorganizing assembly lines and for training workers, and that many companies preferred instead to take "the low-wage alternative."
There were several proposals to discourage companies from forcing down wages to cut costs, rather than cutting costs through worker-management cooperation. Ray Marshall, secretary of labor in the Carter Administration, called for tax penalties for companies that relocate to low-wage countries. And John T. Joyce, president of the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftsmen, said the Clinton Administration should tighten labor laws to limit "the option that companies have to escape collective bargaining."
But neither Mr. Brown nor Mr. Reich responded to these proposals, many of which are now before an Administration-appointed blue ribbon commission on labor law reform that is to issue its first report next May.

HEADLINE: Jurisdiction Being Sorted Out in Serial Killings

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 26

 BODY:
Prosecutors from nine New York counties met here today to discuss jurisdiction in the case of Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who has admitted to killing 17 women.
The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, said the closed-door talks were about "the problems that arise when various jurisdictions are involved" in a complex murder case like that of Mr. Rifkin's. 
 He said Nassau will continue with plans to prosecute Mr. Rifkin here for the one case in which the victim's body was found in the county.
He declined to comment about whether any of the prosecutors sought to transfer Mr. Rifkin to their jurisdictions to face charges in other murder cases. He said Mr. Rifkin remained at the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow.
The prosecutors were given statements Mr. Rifkin made to the state police after his arrest. Mr. Dillon said it was the first time they had seen the information. Ed Grilli, a spokesman for Mr. Dillon, said the information included locations where Mr. Rifkin told authorities he had committed murders or had disposed of bodies.
"The information turned over to them as part of this meeting will help them to gain insights into the case and to see how his statements to troopers fit into their various jurisdictions," Mr. Grilli said.
The prosecutors discussed a proposal by Robert Sale, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, to consolidate all the cases in Nassau County, Mr. Grilli said.
But Mr. Dillon said some of the prosecutors questioned such an approach for fear a legal error could result in trial reversals.
"Even before the meeting, some of the district attorneys raised questions whether or not that could be legally done," Mr. Dillon said. "Nobody wants to prosecute a case where there are some serious legal problems. So I don't think that's in the cards."
Mr. Rifkin, of East Meadow, was arrested last month after the New York State police discovered a woman's body in the back of his truck. Authorities said he has confessed to killing 17 women and dumping their bodies throughout the region, from Putnam County to the eastern tip of Long Island. As the investigation into the confessions of Mr. Rifkin deepened, law-enforcement agencies from across the region contacted the state police to see whether there might be a link between Mr. Rifkin and other unsolved murders.
Decisions on jurisdiction were complicated, Mr. Dillon said, because cases could be prosecuted either where a body was found or where the murder was committed.
"The discussion involved where it would be best to prosecute," he said.
The nine counties involved in the talks are Nassau, Suffolk, Manhattan, Queens, the Bronx, Westchester, Orange and Putnam.
A public announcement will be made when officials decide the jurisdiction questions, Mr. Dillon said. But he could not say when that would occur.
A state police spokeswoman, Kelly Shonholz, said there were "no further developments" today in the case.

HEADLINE: Science Park Plan Offers Vision of Newark's Center

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 26

 BODY:
An elaborate vision of high-tech offices, homes, parks and shops was put forth today for a desolate 50-acre tract in this city's Central Ward, with Federal, state and community leaders praising the plans as a formula for hope and economic growth during the next 20 years.
Although the proposal, called University Heights Science Park, is little more than a concept at this point, officials at the announcement ceremony in City Hall spoke encouragingly of the collaboration of educational institutions and civic leaders that would lead, they said, to 3,000 permanent jobs and $4 million in property-tax revenue on land that now generates next to nothing.
 
Educated Guesses
 They also acknowledged that the detailed architectural renderings arrayed behind Gov. Jim Florio, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and Representative Donald M. Payne were merely educated guesses as to what might eventually be built. They insisted, however, that their goal of a $250 million development amid the scars left by the 1967 riots was realistic. 
 To underscore faith in the proposal, Everett Shaw, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, pointed to two highly speculative ideas that have recently moved closer to completion and that, with the science park, are considered complementary to the effort to revitalize Newark. The first is the $60 million performing arts center, for which site preparation is under way. The second is the proposed $850 million rail line that would link Newark and Elizabeth to Newark International Airport.
Mr. Shaw, who also serves as president of Renaissance Newark, a business-supported group to encourage commerce and development, acted as host and cheerleader for the event, saying the proposal was on "the cutting edge of how planning will occur in urban centers."
"There's no room for critics," he said. "There's only room for participants to join."
University Heights is a term coined about 15 years ago when four of Newark's major educational institutions -- Rutgers University, Essex County College, New Jersey Institute of Technology and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey -- came together to act as a catalyst for new housing and other civic needs.
Under the plan, students, faculty members and researchers from each institution will work to develop new biomedical products that would attract manufacturing to the park, which has antecedents in Philadelphia and other cities. The state has committed $8.5 million in seed money, and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development provided $1.5 million to buy remaining land and buildings. About half the land is government-owned and off the tax rolls. Most is vacant except for about 110 units of housing and a hodgepodge of vacant or little-used buildings.
 
Olympic-Style Ceremony
 The planners, whose committee includes the presidents of the four institutions, envision one million square feet of commercial space, 150 to 200 homes for low- to moderate-income families, park and recreation space and day care. After the start-up, which includes renovation of an existing building next to New Jersey Institute of Technology for laboratory and office use, officials hope that venture capitalists will underwrite most of the development.
Projections by the Institute of Technology forecast 7,600 construction jobs and 3,000 permanent jobs, with 450 for Newark residents, if the project is completed. The plan also calls for a science high school to attract students from Newark and surrounding communities, as well as job training.
The 90-minute announcement ceremony in the City Hall rotunda concluded with a symbolic torch lighting that featured six flashlights camouflaged as Olympic-style lamps. As Newark's business administrator, Glenn Grant, sounded themes of community, hope and cooperation, Governor Florio and other officials solemnly placed each torch into a frame that resembled an oversize test-tube holder.
Conspicuous by his absence was Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, whose reputation as a civic booster is unrivaled here. A sheaf of news releases included a congratulatory letter from the Mayor dated July 23 but made no mention of missing the ceremony. Some officials cited the mayor's achievements, but none noted his absence.
Later, a city spokeswoman, Andrea Martin, said Mr. James was on a long-planned annual trip with the Sharpe James Civic Association, a group of the Mayor's political supporters. She said he would return to the city next week.

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs by 20.96, to a Record 3,567.70

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average surged to another closing record yesterday, as all leading stock market indicators climbed.
The Dow gained 20.96 points, ending the day at 3,567.70, surpassing its previous closing high of 3,555.40 set last Wednesday. 
 The Dow Jones utilities average also reached a new closing high, riding continued strength in the bond market to finish at 248.88, 1.78 points above its April 16 record of 232.75.
"Today's very encouraging, particularly since the Dow did it for real this time, rather than by a few cents as it did a few days ago," said Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company. He attributed the day's results to some strong second-quarter reports and waning fears of inflation and taxes.
"I think the Street is feeling more reassured that we're not going to get the amount of high taxes relative to cutbacks in spending and so forth -- that Clinton is not going to get the extremes of his program through," he said.
The rally came despite a rise in the price of gold, which investors generally turn to as a hedge against inflation. Gold for August delivery rose $3.10, to $93.10 an ounce. Mr. Seagle attributed that gain in part to speculators trying to manipulate the price of gold by creating fears about inflation.
With many municipal bonds coming due this month, Mr. Seagle noted, there should be plenty of cash to urge the rally along. "If you add all these things together, the factors that created this move in the first place are still there," he said.
 
Other Leading Indicators
 Among other leading indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.99 points, to 449.09, while the Nasdaq composite gained 4.30 points, to 704.54. The American Stock Exchange composite rose 1.71 points, to 433.76.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate at 224.2 million shares, compared with 222.2 million on Friday.
Continuing the trend of recent weeks, stocks rose and fell on reported earnings yesterday, rather than in obedience to some general trend. The Williams Companies gained 2 7/8 yesterday to close at 56 3/8. After Friday's close, the company reported that its second-quarter net income doubled, thanks to improved results from its telecommunications unit. It reported earnings per share of 66 cents, compared with 27 cents last year and expectations of only 39 cents.
At the other end of the spectrum, Cummins Engine led the decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, plunging 6 1/2, to 82 1/2, after issuing a disappointing projection for third-quarter earnings of less than $2 a share.
David M. Garrity, first vice president for research at Mcdonald & Company Securities, said that much of the drop-off in earnings resulted from a slowdown in production of diesel engines for the new Chrysler T-300 pickup. "What happens when you have a product change-over is that production is quite low," he said. "The T-300 promises to be a very successful truck, but you can see investors right now are quite impatient with any company that does not meet expectations."
While he has a hold position on Cummins, Mr. Garrity said, "clearly the selloff represents an opportunity for the long-term investor."
Novell, the software maker, was the most active over-the-counter issue, with almost 11 million shares trading hands after a Goldman, Sachs analyst lowered his earnings projections and investment rating for the company. After hitting a 52-week low of 21, Novell finished down 3 1/2 at 21 1/4.
McDonnell Douglas continued its recent strong performance yesterday, rising 2 1/2 points to close at 87. A week ago, the company reported higher-than-expected second-quarter earnings, thanks to its restructuring. "They've been able to have strong margins in each of their divisions despite lower volume," said David Pizzimenti, an analyst with Nomura Research.
Promus, the casino company, rose 3 points yesterday to close at 56 3/8, possibly on rumors that the company would be selected to run a new casino in Windsor, Ontario.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds End Their String of Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose for the first time in five sessions yesterday as investors adjusted their positions ahead of two important Treasury auctions.
The gains partly reflected a sense that the market may have overreacted to last week's testimony on interest rates by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, some economists said. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose 11/32 point, while its yield fell to 6.67 percent, from 6.70 percent late Friday.
Short-term Treasury issues were unchanged to 1/16 point higher and intermediate maturities were 3/32 to 7/32 higher.
 
Early Gains Overseas
 The gains came in light, choppy trading. Prices opened higher after advancing overseas, where investors sought bargains after last week's four-session tumble during which bond prices fell by more than 2 points.
But the market retreated as concerns crept in about whether there would be enough demand to absorb new Government notes this week, said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc.
The Treasury is scheduled to auction $16 billion in two-year notes today and $11 billion of five-year notes tomorrow.
The market is sensitive about its ability to absorb the new supply after Mr. Greenspan told members of Congress, in no uncertain terms, that the central bank was ready to raise interest rates to control possible future inflation.
Higher rates on new securities would diminish the value of already-sold investments, like bonds and notes, that pay a fixed rate of return.
 
Supply and Demand
 But the market began rising again after results of the Government's sale of new three- and six-month bills showed good demand for supply, Mr. Ricchuito said.
In its regular weekly auction, the Treasury sold $12.3 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.10 percent, for a yield of 3.17 percent. Another $12.3 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.24 percent, for a yield of 3.34 percent.
Some market participants have tempered their initial fear that the Fed would move quickly to push interest rates higher, said Kevin Logan, chief American economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Mr. Logan said that yields in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market for two-year notes were reflecting anticipation of a Fed move to push interest rates higher in about six months. Initially, many investors had interpreted Mr. Greenspan's comments to mean that the Fed would raise rates even if there were no obvious signs of inflation.
"It looks like people will be well rewarded for holding these securities, given the chances of a Fed tightening over the next six months," Mr. Logan said.
 
Housing Report Is Ignored
 The market largely ignored a National Association of Realtors report that sales of previously owned homes rose 1.9 percent in June. The increase was stronger than market expectations but did not have a major effect on prices, said Dan Seto, economist for Nikko Securities Company International.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 1/16 percent, up from 3 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10 18/32, down 3/32 from late Friday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.81 percent.
