HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
As America grows older and grayer, are companies becoming any wiser about their marketing?

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
IF recent advances in medicine and health care are not evidence enough that the passage from middle age to maturity has moved farther along the lifeline, please consider this: Mick Jagger turned 50 yesterday.
That is just one fact that Ken Dychtwald -- gerontologist, psychologist, author and marketing consultant -- uses to demonstrate how corporate America may be misreading the demographics of the country for their advertising and marketing strategies. 
 Here is another fact he is likely to mention during his two-day seminar, which starts today in Manhattan: By the end of the decade, according to the United States Census Bureau, the American population of 50 and older will have increased by more than 12.3 million in 10 years, to 76.1 million, overtaking what will then be 63.5 million adults aged 18 to 34, a decrease of about 6.1 million from 1990.
If youth is wasted on the young, Dr. Dychtwald will be among the loudest to point out that so is marketing. Only in recent years have American businesses begun to recognize the change. And companies are seeking to know more.
A year ago in San Francisco, Dr. Dychtwald's seminar attracted 250 people. The enrollment for this week's event, sponsored by his Emeryville, Calif., consulting firm, Age Wave, nearly totals 650. Many major corporations are expected to attend, including Pepsico, RJR Nabisco Holdings, Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson, Eastman Kodak and Kellogg, as well as representatives from financial service companies, insurance companies, hotels, drug manufacturers and advertising agencies.
His message is a simple one: Marketing efforts in the United States are skewed so heavily toward younger groups that companies are missing the greater and growing buying power of older generations, people living and working longer than ever before.
The older generations have been largely ignored amid a continuing corporate fascination with youth. But a recent study for the Social Security Administration found that the 50-to-54 and 55-to-59 age groups in 1990 had the second- and third-highest median incomes in the country (adjusted to family size), respectively, with $25,983 and $24,884. The leading age group was 45 to 49, at $26,305. The 20-to-24 group was $11,241 and the 25-29 was $17,588.
"Advertising agencies have always targeted the 18- to 49-year-old group, whether it's radio, television or print," said Treesa Drury, the advertising standards director for the American Association of Retired Persons. "That's what they have always looked for," she said. "It's been the largest group, and we have been a youth-oriented country. An older person was somebody you didn't want to be. But all that's beginning to change."
But why has it taken so long?
"Old habits die hard," Dr. Dychtwald said. "Companies still have an extraordinary ability to market to the young because they feel younger people 'look like us,' they're are all over the media and only until the last several years, the image of people over 50 has been that they are frugal and just winding down their lives. But this is the first time there has been a mass population of this age that is comfortable, vigorous and economically powerful."
For the most part, the stereotype is understandable. Many elderly Americans grew out of the Depression era of the 1930's or as children of parents from the era and bore the psychological fears of their generation. They were taught not to spend frivolously and to save always for a rainy day -- an unshakable foundation from which their spending power has grown. Materialism broke through only as a philosophy with the post-World War II baby boomers, whose spending patterns began setting the marketing agendas by the 1970's. Yuppies followed.
Despite the increasing numbers of those 60 years old and all those boomer-buying habits turning 50 in several years, only a small number of companies are mining the older market.
"Four years ago, there were maybe five or six commercials on television aimed at people 50 years and older," Dr. Dychtwald said. "They were for products for dentures, constipation, headaches and hair dye. If older people were in commercials, they were portrayed as buffoons, like Clara Peller asking, 'Where's the beef?' "
A rare exception occurred in 1987, he said, when the Quaker Oats Company began using Wilford Brimley, an actor who looks like everybody's uncle, to sell cereal on television. More recently, Procter & Gamble has used older people in commercials for Scope mouthwash to show they can be as reluctant to offer a good morning kiss before rinsing as yuppie couples.
"And other companies will catch on," said Kenneth G. Manton, a professor of demographic studies at Duke University. "They'll have to."
Dr. Dychtwald has at least been heartened by the apparent demographics of his seminar. The large number of senior company executives expected suggests an older crowd.
"Maybe," he said, "they're starting to get the message."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Ken Dychtwald, a gerontologist, psychologist, author and marketing consultant, believes that companies are missing a large and growing audience with buying power to match: Americans older than 50. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Boeing Net Lower, but Stock Rises

 BODY:
The Boeing Company posted lower second-quarter earnings yesterday, but the results exceeded analysts' expectations and buoyed the company's stock.
Still, the company warned that sales would soften and that results would be weaker in the third and fourth quarters than analysts expected. 
 The Seattle-based aerospace giant, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, earned $426 million, or $1.25 a share, in the quarter, compared with $432 million, or $1.27 a share, a year earlier. Revenues increased slightly, to $7.99 billion from $7.82 billion.
Boeing stock rose 87.5 cents to close at $38.625 in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts had expected earnings of about $1.05 a share.
Boeing said it had a 14 percent loss in military and aerospace sales in the quarter from a year earlier and delivered fewer airplanes -- 109, compared with 121 in the quarter last year.
"You simply had early shipments," said Peter L. Aseritus, a First Boston analyst who had expected 95 deliveries. "You rob Peter to pay Paul a little bit."
But Mr. Aseritus added that the company's 7.3 percent operating profit margin, coming during a severe recession in the airline industry and glutted commercial aircraft market, buoyed appraisals that Boeing's long-term cost cutting measures -- including thousands of layoffs -- have softened the downturn's blows.
Boeing's sales projections for all of 1993 are for about $26 billion, compared with 1992 sales of $30.2 billion.
"The question is: Can Boeing maintain its operating profit even though it is making less deliveries?" said Peter M. Musser, an analyst with Ragen McKenzie in Seattle.
Some analysts expect Boeing's planned production cuts from 40 aircraft a month last year to 21 a month by mid-1994, along with increased customer financings and soft pricing, to erode margins significantly.
But in a statement, Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, emphasized that the company expected to maintain its profit margin as production continued to decrease, excluding research and development costs for new aircraft models.
With an upgraded version of its 737 commercial airliner expected in 1997 and a new 350-seat 777 twin-jet model due in 1995, Boeing is not expected to cut deeply into its research and development budget, which was $1.8 billion last year and is estimated to be $1.7 billion this year, said Russell D. Young, a company spokesman.
Boeing's new-order tally for the first six months of 1993 was $9.3 billion, compared with $9.4 billion for the first half of 1992.
But Steven Binder, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company, said that customers continued to request rescheduling of existing orders, pushing deliveries out farther into the futures.
"Which means the downturn has not troughed yet," Mr. Binder said.
Meanwhile, Boeing and the Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday that they had joined forces to pursue an Air Force and Navy contract for guidance kits for bombs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Gains As German Move Is Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to march higher yesterday as investors fled from European currencies in advance of a German central bank meeting that could decide the future of the continent's exchange-rate system.
The dollar rose half a pfenning against the German mark, trading late in New York at 1.7250 marks. The dollar also edged upward against weaker European currencies that are under attack by speculators. Some investors are betting on a realignment or even collapse of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, which sets narrow bands in which the European currencies trade against each other. 
 "People are fearing the whole system looks so unstable that they'd better stay out of E.R.M. currencies altogether," said Nigel Rendell, an international economist with the James Capel & Company investment house.
Speculators picked the Belgian franc as a target yesterday after betting heavily against the French franc, Spanish peseta, Portuguese escudo and Danish krone last week. The pressure became so intense that Belgium and Portugal raised short-term interest rates yesterday to discourage speculators from borrowing money to bet against their currencies.
 
U.S. Trading Is Light
 In the United States, trading was reported light yesterday as investors waited to see if Germany's central bank would cut interest rates at its meeting Thursday.
If it does not, other European countries will either have to match Germany's relatively high rates or see their currencies -- and in turn the European system -- battered. Lower interest rates in a given country prompt investors to sell that nation's currency, since investments there earn less.
"If they don't cut rates Thursday, the market will definitely try to test the central banks," through dumping weaker currencies and forcing central banks to buy them up to defend their value, said Tom Benfer, a senior market representative at the Bank of Montreal.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 5.8875 French francs, up from 5.8785 francs on Friday. The British pound slipped to $1.5015, from $1.5045 on Friday. And the dollar slipped to 106.65 Japanese yen, from 106.85 yen on Friday.

HEADLINE: Japan Wins U.S. Embassy Work

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
The State Department has selected a Japanese construction company to renovate the residence of the United States Ambassador in Tokyo, even though the American trade representative has found that Japan discriminated against American companies in awarding Government construction contracts.
An American company that wanted the job, Fischbach & Moore International, filed a formal protest Friday contending that the State Department award violated Federal law. 
 The State Department selected the Obayashi Corporation last week to do the renovation because it was the low bidder, according to Susan Edmondson, a department spokeswoman. Obayashi bid $7.1 million, compared with $10.2 million by Fischbach & Moore of Dallas and $10.7 million by the J. A. Jones Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.
The difference in the bids was so great that the American companies could not benefit from a provision that awards contracts to American companies that are within 10 percent of a low bid by a foreign company. In addition, Ms. Edmondson said, Obayashi built the original residence, "an absolutely magnificent historic structure."
President Clinton stayed in the residence during his recent visit to Tokyo to meet with leaders of the seven biggest industrial powers, and it will be the official home of the new Ambassador to Japan, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.
In its protest with the General Accounting Office, Fischbach & Moore noted that the Foreign Service Buildings Act limits foreign bidders to those from countries that give equal access to American bidders for comparable diplomatic and consular building projects. The only exceptions are those required by international agreements, and when the Secretary of State determines such bids are in the interest of bilateral relations or are needed to carry out a construction project.
In a report to Congress on April 30, the Office of the United States Trade Representative identified Japan as discriminating against American companies in the procurement of construction, architectural and engineering services.
On June 30, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, formally identified Japan "as a country that maintains, in Government procurement of construction, architectural and engineering services, a significant and persistent pattern or practice of discrimination against United States products or services that results in identifiable harm to United States businesses."
Mr. Kantor made the finding in accordance with Title VII of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988, which authorizes trade sanctions against countries that discriminate against American companies in their government purchasing policies. Mr. Kantor barred European Community companies this spring from bidding for some Federal contracts in retaliation for the community's new purchasing rules for telecommunications equipment. However, Mr. Kantor postponed putting the sanctions against Japan into effect.
The Office of the Trade Representative had no comment on the Tokyo contract, according to Dianne Wildman, a spokeswoman.
Ms. Edmondson, the State Department spokeswoman, said that Fischbach & Moore should have raised the disqualification issue during the prequalification period last January. "These are guys who know the State Department, who do work for the department in other parts of the world," she said. "If that really was a problem, it should have been raised during the prequalification phase."
But Fischbach & Moore considers her objection a technicality, and notes that the findings of discrimination by Japan were made in April and June, after the prequalification period.
Robert R. Kiley, president of the Fischbach Corporation, parent company of Fischbach & Moore, said that the State Department action was "inconceivable to us." The Fischbach Corporation is in turn a unit of American International Group.
Mr. Kiley, a former chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, suggested that Obayashi could not do the job for the $7.1 million it bid, and that the motive for the low bid was to keep American construction companies out of Japan. "We don't think they could possibly have done it at a better price than we bid and still made any money," Mr. Kiley said."
Similarly, Carl Nagel, estimating manager of J. A. Jones's international division, said, "There's no way we could have gotten down to the price of Obayashi." His company, which had the Mitsui Construction Company of Japan as a silent partner, had no plan to protest the award, Mr. Nagel said.
Ms. Edmondson said that the State Department estimate for the job was $7.5 million.
Clyde Prestowitz -- president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a private trade-research group, and a former trade negotiator -- viewed the action by the State Department as part of its continuing indifference to trade issues.
"These things are read by the Japanese as evidence that the United States is not serious," Mr. Prestowitz said. "When Mickey Kantor goes over there and hammers them to open up their construction markets, and the State Department gives a contract to a Japanese company, it just destroys the trade representative's position. We do this time and time again."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Up Sharply Amid Monetary Turbulence

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Currency turmoil in Europe and Russia drove precious metal futures prices up strongly yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as investors sought a safer place to put their money.
Gold for August delivery jumped $3.10, to $393.10 an ounce, while July silver climbed 12.1 cents, to $5.082 an ounce. 
 The gains more than offset the losses posted last week in both markets. The metals stayed within their recent trading ranges but some analysts were surprised by the strength of the rally in light of the absence of inflationary signals.
"It was a really decisive move," said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Weehawken, N.J.
He credited the gains to "safe harbor" buying as investors and institutions switched assets from foreign currencies to gold and the dollar.
The Belgian franc yesterday became the latest victim of the speculative exchange-rate turmoil sweeping Europe, intensifying skepticism about plans for a single European currency by the end of the decade.
A Russian Central Bank decree eventually making all rubles printed before 1993 invalid for purchases also lifted gold futures, said Peter Cardillo, research director for Westphalia Investments Inc. in New York.
"The thought behind the move was that with the Russian currency in deep trouble here, the people of Russia would turn out and buy more gold," he said.
Mr. Cardillo said the move could prove negative for gold prices in the long run because Russia, a major gold producer, is likely to produce and export even more gold to gain hard currency.
Mr. Savaiko said expectations for a German interest rate cut also buoyed the gold market.
"Every time they cut their rates, it seems to be good for gold," he said. "It fuels fears about future inflation, even though we haven't seen any inflation yet."
On other commodity markets, energy prices rose. Light crude oil for September delivery rose 32 cents, to $18.07 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. August heating oil rose 0.18 cent, to 50.37 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline rose 0.01 cent, to 52.06 cents a gallon, and September natural gas jumped 5.6 cents, to $2.124 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Amy M. Spindler

 BODY:

Micro-Minis Make It Big
The clothes were barely off the haute-couture runways when Barbara Moss, the sales and public relations director for A. B. S. Clothing Collection Inc. of New York, was on the phone touting the news that the company's micro-mini was already heading for Bloomingdale's windows. 
 The biggest winner in the hemline game won't be haute couture, but bridge lines like A. B. S. and Tapemeasure that are made in the United States. A. B. S., which has turn-on-a-dime production capabilities, said it will run an advertisement with Bloomingdale's in August for a micro-mini look.
"For the past two months, we haven't been selling long," said Lloyd Singer, president of A. B. S. "Women, in most cases, didn't accept the long straight skirt. Whether it's a micro or just above the knee, women know they can wear the short skirt."
Mr. Singer said the turnaround time was five days for A. B. S. last year when bell-bottoms became hot. "Nov. 8, we sat down with Kal Ruttenstein of Bloomingdale's," Mr. Singer said. Mr. Ruttenstein, senior vice president of fashion direction at the store, wanted to be the first to have the pants in an ad. "Five days later he had 300 on the floor."
Mr. Singer said his salespeople have been letting stores know that A. B. S. has short skirts. "That's what being first is all about," he said.
Tapemeasure's designer, Marsha Drogan, said: "If you went anywhere in the past year, you saw short skirts, whether it was suits or black tie. I think women picked long skirts up as items.
"In seeing short come back, they won't feel manipulated; they'll believe they won their point."
The best label for the micro-mini, however, may be caveat emptor. Long skirts can be hacked off to fit the mood swings of designers. But there's no place the micro can go. Except in the dustbin.
 
Banned on the Job
 Critics doing their jobs occasionally find themselves banned from the very events they cover. And The International Herald Tribune's Suzy Menkes is doing her job, con brio, as far as two Italian designers are concerned.
She was banned this season from the haute-couture shows of Gianni Versace and Christian Dior, designed by Gianfranco Ferre, because of reviews she's written about the designers' work in the past. While that still left 10 other couture collections for her to cover, the work of Mr. Versace and Mr. Ferre has great impact.
There's no equivalent in other fields of criticism to fashion, where a commercial enterprise offers invitations to a selected few for a one-time showing. The Herald Tribune has a worldwide circulation of 200,000.
"I'm sorry for the readers of The Herald Tribune," said Ms. Menkes, who also writes a monthly column for the Styles of The Times section of The New York Times. "They expect, and they have a right to expect, coverage that takes in all the shows. And I'm sorry for myself. I'm interested in shows, and I like to see the development of designers. If all a fashion critic says is 'bravo, bravo,' what is such empty praise worth?"
 
A Fashionable Trade Show
 Admit it. Someone says trade show and you think of toothy conventioneers with name tags. Blenheim Holdings is on its way to changing all that.
Blenheim is organizing two shows for people in the fashion industry: the International Jeanswear Show, Sept. 11-13 in Miami Beach, and the New York Premier Collections, Sept. 19-21.
For the New York show, Blenheim's chief executive, Marshall Lester, traveled to Paris to sign up Lamine Kouyate, the designer of Xuly-Bet. "He represents the cutting edge of French fashion today," Mr. Lester said. Besides Mr. Kouyate, who will be showing in New York for the first time, the first-ever New York event will feature 200 exhibitors including Anvers, Corine Cobson, Dorothee Bis and Max Mara. "I don't know why no one's ever done this before," Mr. Lester said. "But in the current tough economy, buyers are looking for one-stop shopping."
The jeans show is set in what Mr. Lester deems "America's St.-Tropez." One of the highlights will be a celebrity jeans auction to benefit the People With AIDS Coalition.

HEADLINE: Spain Launches Invasion Of Latin America, to Push For Cultural Preservation

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JESUS, Paraguay

 BODY:
Against a landscape of rolling fields and grazing cows, church columns of pink stone rise unfinished. Work stopped in 1768 when a decree arrived here from King Carlos III of Spain, ordering the expulsion of all Jesuit missionaries from this distant corner of empire.
Now, a new fence protects the ruins from art thieves. Sturdy beams shore up sagging walls. Near a new guard cottage, a billboard heralds the mission's new benefactor: Spain. 
 After two centuries, Spain is returning to Latin America as a regional force for historic preservation.
 
$12 Million a Year
 The reasons for the return have more to do with imperial memory than with imperial conquest. As modern Spain has developed economically, it has become a member of the European Community and acquired a foreign aid program.
"Our motivation for this is to return cultural identity, to retrieve what would be lost," Inocencio Arias, the Secretary of State for International Cooperation and Latin America, asserted recently in Madrid.
Starting small in 1984, Spain's historic restoration aid to Latin America has gradually grown to become a $12 million-a-year program. Working in 17 Latin American nations, Spanish aid has restored about 60 major structures, from forts to theaters to cathedrals. To nurture local interest in historic preservation, Spain has started a school in each of the 17 countries, to teach local apprentices skills needed for restoring colonial-era buildings.
"This is a very powerful force for raising people's awareness about the value of historical houses," said Carlos Colombino, director in Asuncion of Manzana de la Rivera Cultural Center. Facing the presidential palace in Paraguay's capital, this block of 19th-century and colonial-era houses was to be razed for a park. With Spain paying about 60 percent of the $1 million budget, the city was able to buy the houses, refurbish them and turn the complex into a cultural center, complete with library, museum and theater.
"This project is only possible because of the Spanish money," Mr. Colombino said. "It is forcing government people to take a second look at the value of old buildings."
Indeed, with three-quarters of Latin America's population now living in cities, Spain is seeking a wide impact for its limited resources.
Up and down Latin America, projects vary, from restoring 19th- century buildings in the historic center of Ponce, P.R., to restoring a 17th-century Spanish customs building in Portobelo, Panama, to restoring Inca forts in northern Chile and Mayan pyramids in Tikal, Guatemala.
Despite a token project in Portuguese-speaking Brazil -- the restoration of the art nouveau downtown of Joao Pessoa -- all the projects are in Spanish-speaking America. About 80 percent of the projects involve restoring buildings from the Spanish colonial period, an era that ended for most of the region by 1825.
 
Church as Cultural Heritage
 Reflecting the ancient nature of Spanish colonization in Latin America, several projects involve restoring churches built in the 16th century, decades before English settlements began in North America. About half of the projects involve restoring Roman Catholic buildings: cathedrals, churches, monasteries, convents and episcopal palaces.
"Unlike the United States, we have no limitations regarding state money that is used for the restoration of religious buildings and monuments," Mr. Arias said. "We consider these buildings as much a part of a country's cultural heritage as ancient ruins and colonial mansions. Why should we discriminate?"
Here in Jesus, the thick walls and massive columns of the unfinished church were to "compete with the finest churches of America," said one mid-18th century chronicler. While Italians designed most Jesuit missions in South America, three Spanish architects designed the one in Jesus. They drew heavily on Spain's mudejar style, a fusion of Moorish and Christian motifs. The Spanish project, budgeted at $480,000, is to start with archeological escavation, cleaning and a study of structural damage caused by two centuries of abandonment.
In addition to repairing a Jesuit mission virtually covered by forest in Argentina, Spanish restorations of religious buildings include a 16th-century Franciscan church in Popayan, Colombia, damaged by a 1983 earthquake, and an 18th-century Franciscan church in Havana that has suffered from hurricanes, the explosion of a boat in Havana harbor and religious restrictions by the Communist government.
Work restoring secular buildings is often aimed at planting seeds for neighborhood renewal and economic growth. All projects require that the host country contribute to restorations, usually about 40 percent of total costs.
 
No 'Museum Pieces'
 "These projects, when finished, are not going to be museum pieces," said Oscar Centurion, who served as Paraguay's director of cultural properties until May. "They are going to raise the standard of living and provide development."
In Venezuela, Spain is providing financial and technical aid to refurbish parks and balconied buildings of the historic center of Ciudad Bolivar. This interior city is a major departure point for tourists for Angel Falls, the world's highest waterfall.
In Quito, Ecuador, another city with a strong tourism trade, the Spanish aid is helping to refurbish the historic downtown. In Cartagena, a Caribbean city that is Colombia's largest tourist destination, Spanish aid is restoring the Naval Museum, a colonial and neo-classical melange dating back to 1604. In Lima, Peru, Spanish aid is restoring a rococo-style, 18th-century country house that is now engulfed by one of Latin America's largest cities.
Backed by the new money and the old prestige of Spain, Latin America's preservationists hope local politicians and business leaders will see the need to preserve and restore old buildings.
 
'Historic Patrimony'
 Creating a corps of Latin American technicians, the 17 national workshops expect to train 1,200 artisans by 1995: blacksmiths, carpenters, masons, roofers and painters.
"We want to promote among Paraguayans -- and other Latin Americans -- the idea that historic patrimony is important," said Raimundo Espiau, an architect who coordinates Spanish aid in Paraguay. Moving beyond the colonial era, Spain hopes to restore Asuncion's mid-19th-century train station and its late 19th-century city theater.
In a visit steeped in symbolism, King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain stopped at the ruins of Trinidad near here in October 1990. Once one of the grandest of the 30 Jesuit missions, this baroque masterpiece fell to pieces after the expulsion order signed by the current monarch's predecessor, King Carlos III.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
First Olympic Event: Going for the Green

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Olympic and TV executives will square off today over the sale of network rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The networks will try to show how cost-conscious they can be. The International Olympic Committee will push the value of the centennial Olympiad happening live on the East Coast. The Atlanta organizing committee will simply scream for the most money it can get.
The closed-door meetings scheduled for today and tomorrow will need plenty of intrigue to match past Olympic TV negotiations, which have comprised a rather enthralling Olympic event on their own. Most of the fascination grew out of the great competitiveness among the three networks and ABC's position through 1988 as the pre-eminent network of Olympic television. Roone Arledge, the former president of ABC Sports, once said: "Olympic negotiation with the networks is a case of putting scorpions in a bottle." 
 That three-way rivalry has abated as the freewheeling, freespending days of the 1970's and 1980's have given way to today's economics of parsimony.
Bidding used to occur in exotic locales, like Hollywood producer David Wolper's house or Switzerland's Lausanne Palace Hotel. By the time talks for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona rolled around, they were held in the same East Side law firm that will be the site for today's negotiations.
For the rights to the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow, CBS aligned itself with a German impresario named Lothar Bock, who was close to Soviet authorities. ABC was the reigning TV home of the Games, but, according to a source, Bock locked up an agreement for CBS even before talks began. But the deal unraveled, as Soviet authorities started changing the rules of the negotiations. All parties went home. Bock returned to Moscow and secured a contract from the Soviets, but John Backe, the CBS president, refused to sign it. From a phone at P.J. Clarke's in Manhattan, Bock called Carl Lindemann, the president of NBC Sports. "If you want the Olympic Games," Bock said, "fly to Moscow tomorrow." Lindemann flew, and agreed to pay $81 million for the Games that the U.S.A. boycotted.
The night before bidding began on the 1984 Winter Olympics, executives from each network sat in a hotel resturant. A call came for Arthur Watson, the president of NBC Sports. Watson left the table, returned, whispered in his colleagues' ears, and they all left. ABC and CBS were left with a bunch of empty chairs. The next morning, the I.O.C. unsealed the bids in front of both networks, an unusual step, and ABC's $91.5 million won.
ABC won a sour victory in acquiring the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary. Jim Spence, then a senior vice president of ABC Sports, recalled that he was told by Barry Frank, part of the International Olympic Committee's negotiating team then -- and now -- that $275 million would be the winning bid. Sealed bids started with CBS's $182 million, and by the third round, ABC's bid had climbed to $280 million, with NBC $12.5 million behind. CBS was out.
"It went on to round four, and we bid $300 million, $19.5 million ahead of NBC," Spence said. "I later learned that the I.O.C. wanted to stop and finalize with us, but Barry said, 'Let's keep going.' " On Round 5, both networks bid $300 million.
ABC's team, camped in Arledge's suite in Lausanne, thought they had won the bid. But the I.O.C. told them the winning bid would now be decided by an auction. Said Spence: "They told us to come back with another bid later, but Roone refused to go, he was so livid" about the bidding exceeding $275 million. NBC opened with $304 million. ABC's $309 million won.
The networks returned to Lausanne in September 1985, to negotiate for the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. ABC was still stung by the Calgary negotiations. The South Korean organizers wanted $700 million, but would settle for $500 million. ABC would commit to only $225 million.
NBC offered $325 million, but the South Koreans demanded $350 million. NBC refused. Talks broke off. Meanwhile, the South Korean Government authorized its negotiators to take $325 million -- but the Korean organizers in Lausanne wouldn't back down. The talks adjourned for New York, where NBC cut its bid to $300 million. In the end, the Koreans' embarrassment at falling so short of their inflated goal was leavened by NBC's promise to share revenues once ad sales topped $500 million. But no revenues were ever shared.
In advance of the bidding for the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, NBC's Watson tried some gamesmanship. He roundly criticized Neal Pilson, the president of CBS Sports, for outbidding NBC by $68 million to win the rights to the 1992 Winter Games in Albertville, France. Watson called Pilson reckless, then vastly outbid CBS with its $401 million bid for Barcelona. "Not a bad strategy, eh, coach?" Watson said at the time. By 1992, Watson had died, and because of NBC's own overbidding, it lost $100 million on Barcelona.
The memory of such losses -- and losses on football, baseball and other properties -- may make the Atlanta talks very slow, with bids bunched tightly. It is expected to be a three-way struggle involving the networks' stinginess, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games' desire for bigger bucks than the networks wish to pay and the I.O.C. chief negotiator Dick Pound's attempts to squeeze top dollar without risking his long-term ties with the networks.

LENGTH: 634 words

HEADLINE: It's Our Own Genes We Should Worry About

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It seems (despite your own caution against it) you fell for the hype of "Jurassic Park," dwelling on the silliest issues in two editorials. There is no danger that dinosaurs will be brought back, now or ever. It can't be done for the very reasons your first piece carefully spelled out ("Should We Revive the Dinosaurs?," editorial, June 13). But then you turned against your own argument, entertaining the fantasy long enough to conclude that scientists should leave well enough alone.
Worse, when Karl E. Meyer revisited scientific issues in the movie ("The Instant T. Rex," Editorial Notebook, July 18), he examined a "plot hole," whether these creatures could have grown so fast. This is equivalent to publishing a discussion about a cartoon, "The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show," explaining that flying squirrels merely glide, but then quibbling that Rocky actually seems to fly. Remember, this is Steven Spielberg, this is science fiction. 
 The real concerns about manipulating DNA mentioned in your first editorial are not to be found with dinosaur DNA, but with human DNA. Information about human genetics is potentially dangerous. As we acquire more information about the contribution of genetics to behavior, traits and diseases, we simultaneously gain the power to manipulate them.
Perhaps we should leave well enough alone, but instead, everything with a "genetic component" seems fair game for investigation, including things like homosexuality, race and intelligence, alcoholism. A July 18 news article on sexual orientation alludes to the kind of mess we will increasingly find ourselves in. Empowered with genetic information, parents could find justification to abort fetuses carrying a "genetic marker" for homosexuality. Why stop there? As a countermeasure, would-be homosexual parents could abort "normal" fetuses.
Along with social ramifications of genetic information, there are logical economic consequences. For example, it may be cheaper to move or lay off workers with an identifiable "risk factor" than to clean up the workplace. With our current health insurance system, it is in the interests of companies to screen for "healthy" people and discard the rest.
This is not science fiction. In the 1970's, when genetic tests for sickle cell anemia became available, some insurance companies began requiring African-American customers to be tested, and denied coverage to those testing positive or who refused the test. In the absence of an ethical consensus, scientists zeroing in on discrete pieces of DNA just make it easier for others to abuse the data.
However, some actions taken for the most benevolent and humane reasons may also come back to bite us. For example, just months ago, gene replacement therapy was used to treat a child born with severe immunodeficiency ("bubble-boy disease"). When such a person grows up, his children may require gene replacement therapy too -- and their children, and their children. Add to this all other people treated for genetic diseases and their progeny.
By our own hand, we are totally uncoupling ourselves from natural selection, which formerly kept these diseases in low frequency. What are the personal, medical and social costs of maintaining expanding generations of humans like this in a future with finite resources and runaway global population growth?
In our desire to study and manipulate the human genome, we are paving the way for a resurgence of eugenics, which will be more insidious this time because the evidence is better grounded and more sophisticated. We should examine this science fact, not science fiction.
 
LOUIS A. PENA
Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., July 19, 1993
 
The writer, a neuroscientist, is a postdoctoral research fellow at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Overturns Tariffs on Many Steel Imports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Opening huge holes in the protectionist wall that has surrounded the American steel industry for most of three decades, a Federal agency eliminated dozens of steel-import tariffs today, ruling that they were unnecessary.
The six-member International Trade Commission, a bureaucratic oddity that is independent of both the Administration and Congress, wiped out most tariffs on steel used in construction and machinery. But it also made permanent some stiff temporary tariffs on corrosion-resistant steel used for household appliances and for car and truck body panels. 
 The decision is likely to force the domestic industry to further specialize in high-value, corrosion-resistant steel, which is already among its few money makers, industry experts said. At the same time, it could force big American makers to accelerate their long retreat from the markets for lower-price construction and machinery steel.
The unfavorable decision sent the stocks of major producers reeling. Worsening this financial-market pressure, there were signs that the country's largest steelmaker, USX, had had a turbulent quarter.
 
Forced Specialization
 Foreign producers, as well as small American manufacturers that recycle steel from scrap, have already been prospering in the market for lower-price steel. They have done so at the expense of leading domestic companies like LTV, USX and Bethlehem Steel, which make a variety of products from raw iron and coal.
The effect of today's decision on consumers will depend on whether foreign companies begin selling more low-priced products here. Such a move would mean lower costs for the steel used in construction and auto parts, lowering some costs in those industries.
But David H. Hoag, the chairman of the LTV Corporation, warned that American producers would file new unfair-trade cases seeking tariffs on any country that steps up shipments now. "I for one would be very surprised if we see a surge" of imports, he said.
The rulings today were a potential boon for negotiators seeking a global free-trade agreement. Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France had threatened to scuttle the negotiations if the United States did not cancel the tariffs. Today, the duties were canceled on four of five types of steel that France exports to this country.
Asked tonight to comment on the rulings, the French Embassy here declined, but Agence France-Presse reported that an unidentified aide to Mr. Balladur had welcomed the outcome as averting a commercial war.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's trade chief, also praised the rulings. "It is already clear," he said, "that the I.T.C. determinations will help to defuse substantially what had become a very grave trade dispute."
But Japanese steel officials were angry because corrosion-resistant steel accounts for three-quarters of their shipments to the United States.
The six commission members provided several reasons for their votes today on 72 possible tariffs on steel from 20 countries. A common theme was that importers did not serve a large enough part of the American steel market to be responsible for the financial woes of the big American companies, which suffered a combined pretax loss of $1.3 billion last year.
 
A Washington Scorecard
 The American manufacturers lost a total of 40 decisions today, affecting 49 percent of the $4 billion a year in steel imports, and won 32 decisions.
Officials of the American companies said they would appeal the adverse decisions to the Court of International Trade in New York. The appeals process in such disputes typically takes at least a year.
Curtis H. Barnette, the chairman and chief executive of Bethlehem Steel, said the industry would also consider seeking legislation from Congress.
Last year, the domestic manufacturers were encouraged by Bush Administration officials to seek relief from imports through special tariffs to be determined by the Commerce Department. Foreign makers responded with outrage, saying the tariffs would effectively transfer profits gained as a result of previous import quotas to the United States Government.
The Commerce Department elected to assess tariffs averaging 36 percent, and in January it began requiring importers to post bonds for shipments. But before the tariffs could become permanent, American law required that the International Trade Commission rule that the imports were causing "material injury" to the domestic industry.
Today, the commission announced that such injury could not be proved in a little more than half the cases.
The domestic producers had argued that the loss of a single case today could jeopardize their future. They contended that a few currently underutilized mills in one country might expand production, and in doing so, flood the United States with steel unless tariffs were assessed.
Commissioner Carol Crawford discounted that argument, saying that customers now have such precise demands for the hardness, thickness and finish of steel that mills cannot easily replace each other.
 
Taking a Different Approach
 Most of the commissioners are lawyers and economists being rewarded for service as Congressional aides or Administration officials. During much of the 1980's, the commission tended to side with domestic industries, but two Bush Administration appointees, Peter Watson and Janet Nuzum, brought a new emphasis on detailed legal analysis to the commission's determinations.
Mr. Watson, the vice chairman, voted with the majority in all but two cases today and led the rough consensus in favor of protecting corrosion-resistant steel and not the other categories. Don E. Newquist, a Texas farmer and associate of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, the commission chairman, voted for the domestic steel industry in most cases.
The United States has protected its industry in various ways since the late 60's. Steel executives say this is necessary to compensate for heavy subsidies by foreign governments to their manufacturers. They also accuse foreign companies of forming cartels to keep prices high in their markets while dumping excess production in the United States and thereby avoid laying off workers.
Foreign makers deny that they rig their home markets and counter that American steel companies benefit from pension insurance and other Government policies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Ukraine Has Begun Dismantling Nuclear Missiles

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Ukraine has begun dismantling some of its SS-19 long-range nuclear missiles in an effort to address American concerns that it is determined to preserve its nuclear arsenal, Pentagon officials said today.
But while American officials described the move as an important first step, Ukraine has declined to discuss a schedule for dismantling its more modern SS-24 missiles. Nor has Ukraine promised to put the warheads from the SS-19 missiles immediately under international control or ship them back to Russia for dismantling. 
 The Ukrainian move comes against a backdrop of growing concern in Russia and in the West over Ukraine's nuclear weapons.
While the Ukrainian President, Leonid Kravchuk, and Defense Minister, Gen. Konstantin Morozov, have said they are committed to eliminating the arsenal, the Ukrainian Parliament has yet to approve such a move and some Ukrainian nationalists have urged keeping a small nuclear arsenal.
 
U.S. Cooperation Is Lure
 The Clinton Administration has sought to strengthen the hand of the Ukrainian President and Defense Minister by using the lure of economic and military cooperation.
The new Ukrainian move was disclosed by Pentagon officials today after a meeting between General Morozov and Defense Secretary Les Aspin.
Clinton Administration officials said that General Morozov had promised that Ukraine would dismantle all 130 SS-19 missiles. Each missile carries 10 warheads.
In response to the Ukrainian move, the Pentagon said it was planning to provide the Ukraine with $175 million in assistance to dismantle its nuclear weapons.
 
Joint Military Group
 Earlier today, General Morozov and Mr. Aspin signed a military cooperation agreement, providing for an annual exchange of visits. In addition, a joint working group of military officials is being established to expand contacts, and the Pentagon has offered to help the Ukraine transform military industries to civilian use.
Ukraine inherited a potent nuclear arsenal when the Soviet Union broke up. In addition to its SS-19 missiles, it has 46 SS-24 long-range missiles that each carry 10 warheads. It also has long-range cruise missiles with nuclear warheads.
The Pentagon sought to persuade General Morozov to establish a timetable for eliminating its SS-24 missiles. But he declined to agree to a firm schedule. Ukrainian officials have told the Pentagon that they are prepared to dismantle the cruise missiles, which are in storage.
Some officials said a major decision on the Ukrainian arsenal is unlikely before September, when a popular referendum is to be held on the Government.

HEADLINE: Mideast and Bosnia Call Christopher Back to U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
As the situation in Bosnia continues to deteriorate, the Clinton Administration is considering an urgent French request to use air power to punish Serbian attacks against French peacekeeping troops, a senior Administration official said today.
President Clinton summoned Secretary of State Warren Christopher home from a trip to Asia for wide-ranging discussions with other officials at the White House Wednesday on what to do next in Bosnia, including the possible use of American warplanes to enforce United Nations resolutions providing humanitarian measures to ease the suffering in Sarajevo, the official said. 
 Other matters scheduled for discussion at the White House meeting, the official said, include possible economic sanctions against Croatia, which has launched fierce attacks against Bosnian Muslims in recent months.
The French Foreign Ministry in Paris asked the United Nations and NATO today to accelerate plans to protect French peacekeepers operating under the United Nations flag as they came under fire again.
 
Effort to Calm CrisisXx
 When asked by reporters at the White House today why Mr. Christopher was unexpectedly cutting short his trip to Asia, Mr. Clinton indicated that it was part of an effort to calm the mounting crisis in the Middle East, saying, "I thought that in view of the events there, that he ought to come home and we ought to have a conversation about it before he goes to the Middle East."
But other senior Administration officials said a more important reason for Mr. Christopher's return was Bosnia, not the Middle East. The official added that the Bosnian situation was so critical that it could not wait for Mr. Christopher to travel on from Asia to Australia and then to the Middle East. Mr. Christopher's Asian trip will resume after the current talks, officials said.
The abrupt return of Mr. Christopher reflects the quandary facing the Administration as it tries to deal with two increasingly volatile conflicts at the same time.
Bosnia -- and ways to end the fighting there -- will be on the top of the agenda during a regularly scheduled lunch on Wednesday with Mr. Christopher; the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, and Defense Secretary Les Aspin, senior officials said. It is expected to be the main focus of a meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher at a separate meeting at the White House on Wednesday.
 
U.S. Role in Retaliation
 Among the issues that will be discussed are the American role in any retaliation against the Serbs for attacking United Nations troops, the relief crisis in Sarajevo and the possibility of imposing economic sanctions on Croatia, the officials said.
The crisis in Bosnia was discussed at the White House on Monday at a meeting of the so-called deputies' committee, which makes recommendations to members of the National Security Council, other senior officials said, adding that the meeting was not intended to produce recommendations.
At a White House meeting two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton's top national security advisers failed to agree on a plan to rescue Sarajevo. Since then, Serbian forces have advanced closer to the center of the besieged Bosnian capital, while the Clinton Administration has faced intense criticism for its inaction.
As for the Middle East, Mr. Clinton pledged that he would not allow the violence in southern Lebanon, which has left scores of civilians dead and driven tens of thousands from their homes, to derail the American-led initiative to make peace. Indeed, Mr. Christopher, who left Singapore for Washington today, plans to proceed with his trip in an effort to rescue the moribund Arab-Israeli talks. He is scheduled to arrive in Cairo on Sunday.
 
Praise for Syrian Restraint
 In Mr. Clinton's brief remarks on the Middle East, he went out of his way to praise Syria for not intensifying the crisis further. But he made no reference to the fact that Syria provides substantial support for the Party of God, the militant Islamic group that has launched repeated attacks against Israel from bases in southern Lebanon, and has at least some influence on its behavior.
"I think the Syrians have shown commendable restraint so far," Mr. Clinton said, in what senior officials said was a reference to Syria's not striking back against Israel for the death of six Syrian soldiers as a result of Israeli attacks.
But curiously, in the same sentence he blamed the Party of God, also known as Hezbollah, for trying to sabotage the Middle East talks, as if the group had no connection with Syria.
Mr. Clinton's support for Syria illustrates the Administration's dual approach to President Hafez al-Assad: while it castigates him as a sponsor of terrorism, it embraces him as a responsible partner for making peace.
 
Responsibility for Attacks
 The Party of God launched the attacks against Israel that left seven Israeli soldiers dead earlier this month. The State Department's 1992 report on terrorism states that Syria provides sanctuary for several terrorist groups, including the Party of God and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, in areas of the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, under Syrian control.
Both groups have taken responsbility for the attacks that killed the Israeli soldiers.

Bosnian Talks Resume
 GENEVA, July 27 (Special to The New York Times) -- As the three sides in the Bosnian civil war began another round of peace talks today, the Muslim-dominated Government appeared to resist mediators' pressure to accept a partition of Bosnia, insisting on a relatively centralized state of three "federal units" with boundaries not drawn strictly on ethnic lines.
The Bosnian position, hammered out by its collective presidency, offers some concessions to a Serbian-Croatian plan for the ethnic division of the country. But officials close to the mediators, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg, said the Bosnian stand was unacceptable to the Serbs and Croats who now control most of the land.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pearson to Shed Fine China and Oil Units

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, July 27

 BODY:
Pearson P.L.C. said today that it would spin off its fine china company, Royal Doulton, and its oilfield services company so that it could concentrate on its publishing and television operations.
Pearson publishes The Financial Times, owns Thames Television P.L.C. and has a stake in British Sky Broadcasting Ltd., a satellite broadcasting operation also owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. 
 "We believe that concentrating most of our resources now on appropriate sectors in the media industry will benefit shareholders," Pearson's chairman, Lord Blakenham, said in a statement.
Royal Doulton will be split off from Pearson by the end of 1993 and listed on the London Stock Exchange as an independent company, the statement said. Newly created Royal Doulton shares will be given to Pearson shareholders.
Pearson said it would sell its majority stake in the oilfield services company Camco in a public offering on the New York Stock Exchange. The offering is planned for the first half of 1994. Pearson added it would keep a minority stake in Camco for a limited time.
Royal Doulton and Camco accounted for 38 percent of Pearson's $2.4 billion in sales in 1992 and about 7 percent of the $234 million in operating earnings.
Royal Doulton is one of the world's biggest manufacturers of fine bone china. It sells china under its own name and under the brand names Royal Crown Derby, Minton and Royal Albert. More than half of Royal Doulton's sales are outside Britain, mainly in the United States, Canada, Australia, Japan and Continental Europe.
Although china sales have increased in the first half of 1993 amid signs that the worst of the recession is over, profits in the Royal Doulton division have been hurt, Pearson said. Sales were $301.5 million in 1992, little changed from the previous year.
Camco provides specialty drilling products and services like bits and submersible pump systems to the oil and gas industries. Its sales fell 9 percent, to $435 million, in 1992.
Pearson said it planned to expand its existing media interests, including satellite technology.
Pearson has been investing in satellite television in Britain for the last five years. It recently acquired program rights and production capability through the $148.5 million purchase of Thames Television P.L.C., which lost its London broadcast franchise in a Government reorganization of TV licenses.
Pearson also said it would keep its interest in the British arm of the Lazard Freres investment banking house.

HEADLINE: HUD'S CHIEF SEEKS WIDE NEW POWERS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros asked Congress today for broad new powers to deal with what he said was his department's most serious problem: the rapidly growing inventory of Government-owned apartment buildings.
The projects, many of which are in poor condition, have come into the hands of the Department of Housing and Urban Development because of a spate of defaults by private developers on Government-insured mortgages. Government auditors have estimated that as much as $11.9 billion worth of mortgages may not be repaid over the next few years, probably expanding the number of buildings in Government ownership. 
 To ease the sales of the projects the department now owns and manages, Mr. Cisneros is seeking to loosen the restrictions on selling property to private developers or nonprofit groups. He asked Congress today to repeal a 1987 statute that requires the housing department to attach expensive rental subsidies to most of the projects being sold.
 
Seeks Wider Discretion
 That law was intended to preserve the supply of low-income housing in the United States, and Mr. Cisneros wants Congress to give him discretion to use less expensive means to protect existing tenants.
Aides to Mr. Cisneros insisted that none of the tenants now in buildings owned by the housing department would face rent increases when their buildings are sold off. But tenants advocates said that issue is a crucial one, and needs clarification.
The housing department now owns 170 buildings, totaling 29,000 apartments, and that number is expected to more than double by the end of the year. If the department were to follow the law, the General Accounting Office estimates it would need as much as $3 billion in rental subsidies to sell off the buildings already owned by the Government.
"This is the tip of a big iceberg directly in our path which will hurt the department and Administration badly if were not able to get a handle on it," Mr. Cisneros said.
 
Reinventing an Agency?
 The legislative proposals unveiled today, part of Mr. Cisneros's plan to "reinvent" HUD, also includes changes in the law on public housing so tenants who find a job would not be penalized with higher rents. In addition, the housing department wants to expand a $2 billion program to spur economic development. Officials said it would provide low-interest loans to communities hoping to attract businesses that would create new jobs.
In describing his proposals to reporters, however, Mr. Cisneros made it clear that the most pressing problems were posed by the rising inventory of apartment buildings. In 1991, his aides said, the housing agency took over 72 buildings, and sold 11. Last year, it foreclosed on an additional 67 buildings, and sold only 27. The main impediment to selling off the property, HUD officials said, was the lack of subsidy money to meet the requirements of the law.
Mr. Cisneros and other officials acknowledge that HUD has a poor track record of managing apartment buildings it does own. Many of them turn into slums as they wait years for buyers.
Senior aides to Mr. Cisneros said that even if the department wins Congressional approval of he proposed changes, sales of apartment buildings would still require substantial new appropriations. Bruce Katz, Mr. Cisneros's chief of staff, said in an interview that $500 million to $750 million annually will be needed in rental subsidies over the next five years. Last year, Congress appropriated only $93 million for this purpose.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Slips

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Consumers' confidence in the economy slipped in July for the third consecutive month, amid poor employment prospects and slow growth in wages.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index declined to 57.7, from a revised reading of 58.6 in June, the private research organization said today. 
 "With unemployment stuck around 7 percent, jobs remain the public's greatest concern," said Fabian Linden, the director of the New York-based group's consumer research center.
While consumers feel slightly better about current economic conditions, they have grown more pessimistic about the future, the survey of 5,000 households found.
The index of expectations declined, to 65.4, from 69.6 in June. Almost 27 percent of those surveyed expressed concern there would be fewer jobs in the months ahead. That number was up from less than 23 percent last month.
Another report today highlighted consumers' concerns. The Labor Department said wages, salaries and benefits increased a modest nine-tenths of a percent in the second quarter. The gain in the employment cost index, the Government's most comprehensive measure of labor costs, followed a 1 percent advance in the first quarter.
For the 12 months ending in June, the employment cost index rose 3.6 percent, the same increase as a year earlier, the Labor Department said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
When Free Marketers Turn Their Faith Over To Central Planners.

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
FEW would ever argue that Wall Street makes a lot of sense. At a time when some strategists grumble that new taxes and regulations from Washington pose greater risk for American companies' share value, their investment banking colleagues think they have found a place where corporate prospects are just dandy: China.
That excitement for Chinese companies was evident earlier this month, when shares of China Tire Holdings began trading for the first time on the New York Stock Exchange. Demand for the enterprise, a Bermuda holding company that controls two tire manufacturing subsidiaries in China, was intense: The 6.1 million shares in the initial public offering July 15 were priced at $17 each, above the expected range of $13 to $15. 
 The success was predictable. Just a few weeks earlier, the I.P.O. of Ek Chor China Motorcycle had also been oversubscribed, and was priced several dollars above the expected range of $16 to $18 a share. Investors buzzed that China Tire would be another Ek Chor.
Investors were right -- but not in the way they thought. Shares of both companies began a long march downward shortly after their debuts. But China Tire had the distinction of having the worse performance in share price. Shares have slid since the first day after hitting a high of $18.75. The shares closed yesterday at $12.875, down almost 30 percent from their high.
What happened? Some bulls argue that the share price is just under pressure from the flippers, who profit by purchasing pieces of new offerings and flip them back into the public markets once the price goes up. (Of course, the price stopped going up the first day of trading, but never mind that.)
Instead, the trading history of China Tire points up the dangers of what can happen when free marketers turn their faith over to central planners. On July 18, The China Daily, an official Chinese newspaper, reported that the Government had imposed tighter controls on institutional purchases of autos as part of Beijing's new austerity plan.
The result, the newspaper said, was that vehicle prices were declining while inventories were rising rapidly at auto makers, where inventories were up as much as 40 percent at the end of May from a year earlier. A glut of cars usually translates into lower production. And lower production means less demand for tires. In any language, that means that now may not be the best time to hold a tire maker's stock.
Worse, it means that the big customers for China Tire are likely to start experiencing a financial squeeze, and they have been far from eager in the past about paying their bills. In its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, China Tire noted that a collection problem resulted in a significant charge to 1991 earnings.
"Steps by the Chinese Government to control inflation," the company writes in a phrase that describes exactly what China Daily reported, "may increase the liquidity problems of the operating subsidiaries' customers."
And China Tire is not the only company in this giant market. As the Chinese industrial market opens up, more foreign competitors are likely to join the more than 100 tire manufacturers already in the industry.
In fact, so many companies are competing to jump into the tire market that even Communist officials have recognized what seems to have escaped some investors: When lots of companies are producing tires, soon there are too many of them.
"Chinese Government officials have indicated that, as tire producers expand, tire production capacity in China may exceed domestic supply," China Motorcycle says in its S.E.C. filing.
Could it be that the Communist Government understands the rules of production and supply better than Wall Street?

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks More Powers To Stem Illegal Immigration

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
President Clinton asked Congress today for more money and new laws to tighten the borders against illegal immigrants, speed interviews of people seeking political asylum and let the Government have the same tools it uses against organized crime to fight foreign gangs promoting illegal immigration.
The President said his decision to push for this legislation was prompted in part by the World Trade Center bombing, which showed how porous the American immigration system is. But he said it was also an attempt to meet what is likely to be one of the biggest domestic challenges the country will face in the 1990's: how to stem the increasing flow of illegal immigrants while maintaining the fundamental American commitment to legal immigration and legitimate political refugees. 
 "This has nothing to do with our support for keeping the rainbow and the melting pot of America going and growing and enriching and strengthening this country," Mr. Clinton said after unveiling his proposal at the White House to an audience of legislators, with heavy representation from immigrant-heavy states like New York and California.
"But the kinds of practices that are manifest in who can get into this country on an airplane, what kinds of illegal smuggling can go on, and the fact that our borders leak like a sieve: those things cannot be permitted to continue in good conscience.
"It's not good for the American immigrants who are here legally in this country, for the American economy, for the cohesion of our society, or for the rule of law worldwide," he added. "And we're going to try to do better."
 
Pattern of Abuse
 The most controversial aspect of the Clinton plan involves new procedures for on-the-spot administrative hearings to determine whether immigrants seeking political asylum at a point of entry have legitimate claims. This is intended to counter what Administration officials argue is a growing pattern of abuse of American asylum laws by illegal immigrants who do not have credible claims for political asylum but enter the country by air or sea, receive working papers and stay for years while their claims are processed and appealed.
Under the proposed plan, if a traveler claims political asylum, his or her case would be promptly heard at or near the port by a member of the Immigration and Naturalization Service asylum corps, a specially trained group of officers with expertise in interviewing technique and asylum law.
The asylum officer will determine whether an individual has a credible fear of persecution, whether he or she would be likely to qualify for refugee status or whether the person would be in danger if returned to the country of origin.
Under this plan for instant immigration justice, those determined to be bona fide refugees will given protection. Those whose claims are found to be fraudulent will be given the opportunity for a quick, limited appeal to Justice Department officials, and if the immigration service decision is not reversed they will be immediately deported.
Some immigration experts worry, though, that the provisions for quick justice in dealing with applicants for political asylum will be little bit too quick. The legislation limits court review to a technical habeas corpus proceeding, that is, a proceeding that essentially looks only at whether the right person is being deported, not whether the case has merit or whether the immigration officials are following regulations.
 
Some Reservations
 "Our concern is that this limitation would allow the immigration service to operate behind a veil of secrecy by denying constitutional due process and meaningful judicial review to legitimate asylum seekers," said Lucas Guttentag, Director of the American Civil Liberties Union Immigrants Rights Project.
The proposed legislation was pulled together by Vice President Al Gore and was expected to be introduced as a bill sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. But Senator Simpson has decided not to be a co-sponsor for now because he was not satisfied with the review arrangements for those denied political asylum. The differences will have to be negotiated in committee.
The Clinton proposal also seeks to give the immigration authorities the same powers law-enforcement officials have in the anti-racketeering laws that are aimed at organized crime, including wiretaps.
The proposed bill says the Immigration and Naturalization Service "would be authorized to intercept wire, electronic, and oral communications of persons involved in alien smuggling."
The Clinton proposal also seeks an additional $172.5 million for next year's proposed immigration budget to add up to 600 Border Patrol agents, and to give them more high-technology equipment, like sensors and low-light-level televisions. The immigration service budget is already $1.6 billion.
Also in the technology realm, the Clinton bill would promote greater cooperation and communication between the various American Government agencies that deal with immigration, so that people like Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, some of whose supporters have been accused of involvement in the Feb. 26 World Trade Center bombing, will not be able to slip through cracks in the immigration and consular network.
It proposes to do this through a variety of means: upgrading the State Department's ability to issue fraud proof, machine-readable visas; expanding pre-inspection at foreign airports of American-bound passengers; upgrading the consular communications lookout network so that Consular Officers at embassies overseas can immediately share critical information about criminals and suspected terrorists with the immigration service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other agencies; making American passports more secure by digitizing passport photos and installing on-line computer systems to insure that multiple passports are not issued to the same person.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton listening as Attorney General Janet Reno spoke yesterday after Mr. Clinton asked Congress for more money and new laws to stem the increasing flow of illegal immigrants without upsetting the country's commitment to providing asylum for legitimate refugees. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)
