HEADLINE: Wheelchair Warrior Lays Siege to Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
School officials hate to see Gregory Solas coming. But to the handicapped he is a champion -- a wheelchair warrior in the fight to make schools accessible to the disabled.
Mr. Solas is a 40-year-old former construction worker from Warwick, R.I., who has been in a wheelchair since his legs were crushed in an accident on the job seven years ago. Since 1990 he has filed complaints against nearly 2,000 schools, colleges and universities over the absence of ramps for wheelchairs, signs for the visually impaired and other accommodations required by Federal law. 
 Lawyers at the Education Department's regional Office for Civil Rights in Boston say 25 percent of their workload consists of investigating his complaints.
"Some people play golf," Mr. Solas said. "I file complaints."
 
Chorus of Complaint
 Aggressiveness by advocates of for disabled children is nothing new. But in recent years more and more parents and other advocates like Mr. Solas (whose own three children are not handicapped) are filing complaints. The Department of Education has received three times as many complaints in the 1993 fiscal year as it did in 1987.
Of Mr. Solas's nearly 2,000 grievances, many of which have already been resolved, virtually all were filed under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which requires public buildings, public programs and private groups and schools that receive some form of Federal aid to be accessible to the disabled.
The remaining complaints cite the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, which expands protections for the disabled to employment and public services. The Education Department says his complaints are usually upheld and lead to agreements with school systems to upgrade their buildings.
"He is a very accurate advocate," said Norma Cantu, the new Assistant Secretary of Education for Civil Rights. "Is he a thorn in my side? By no means. If anything, he is highlighting the need to inform public schools and colleges and universities about the law."
But at a time when budgets are stretched thin by recession and its aftermath, schools say resolving complaints like Mr. Solas's are forcing them into costly renovations, diverting money from other pressing needs.
 
'Outrageous' Demands
 According to one study, it costs $20,000 to $200,000 to equip a school with ramps, elevators, escalators, barrier-free bathrooms and wider doorways, depending on the age of the school building and the extent of its renovation. Federal disability laws spell out how public buildings should accommodate the disabled, from how far water fountains should be lowered to where signs for the visually impaired should be installed.
"The parents of disabled children are increasing their demands to an outrageous extent," said Gwendolyn Gregory, deputy general counsel for the National School Boards Association. "They are asking for things that parents of nonhandicapped children would have no right to ask for."
School districts say that they are not opposed to serving disabled children, but that parents often demand that a neighborhood school be outfitted to accommodate the handicapped when a school 20 minutes away has the very program a student needs.
Parents say it is a matter of perspective. "Like other minority groups, we get tired of listening to bureaucrats rationalizing what they do to us," said Linda DiCecco, a Warwick mother who is hearing impaired and who has three children with hearing or vision difficulties. "All we want are the same rights that the majority takes for granted." Of Mr. Solas, she said, "At least Greg is getting us into the school buildings."
 
Vow to Help Handicapped
 Mr. Solas, who has long been criticized as a grandstander, shrugs off the criticism. "The law is the law," he said. "If I could, I would make them stand at a chalkboard and write, 'I will not discriminate.' "
Mr. Solas was injured at a construction site seven years ago when a steel beam fell off its wooden piles and pinned him to the ground at the hips. As he lay beneath the beam, he says, his legs crushed, not sure whether he would even live, he vowed, "I'll help the handicapped."
In 1990, he took on the Warwick Public Schools, a system of 28,000 students, 1,800 with physical or learning disabilities. He remembers being unable to negotiate the entrance of an elementary school where the parent-teacher organization meeting was held.
He says he was told to go home; the district would send him a videotape of the meeting. "All of a sudden, I was a guy who was a pain in their behinds," he said.
Mr. Solas said he refused the videotape and instead staged a one-person picket outside the school administration building during a late-winter storm. He ultimately filed a complaint with the Education Department, which forced the school system to renovate its administration building. The parents' group finally moved its meeting to a site more suitable for Mr. Solas's wheelchair.
He took on the district again a year later when his daughter's school held a father-daughter dance in a building that could not accommodate his wheelchair. The school system moved the dance.
And just last month, he filed still another complaint, this time over plans to hold graduations in an auditorium that was not wheelchair-accessible. The district relented and made arrangements to accommodate Mr. Solas.
"The law is the law," he said. "It does not mean you can do it halfheartedly."
 
Expanding His Mission
 Since he first took on the Warwick Public Schools, Mr. Solas, who can walk with a cane but uses a wheelchair most of the time, says he has spent thousands of hours and more than $6,000 of his own money to right the wrongs he sees in schools.
As he has traveled on vacations, he says he has taken pains to look at other schools, maintaining that "if they were violating the law in Warwick then there must be other schools doing the same thing." In other instances, parents of disabled children have called him or he has called schools at random to ask whether they are accessible.
To school administrators, Mr. Solas is equal parts burden and irritant. "He's abrasive and aggressive," said Henry S. Tarlian, who became Superintendent of the Warwick system after Mr. Solas filed the first of his several complaints. "And that causes a society and community to rebel."
Mr. Tarlian said there were ramps at the elementary school where Mr. Solas wanted to attend the parent-teacher meeting, though the Superintendent acknowledged that they were steeper than they should have been.
The Superintendent also says that after one Solas complaint that singled out the aged Warwick School Administration building, the district spent $100,000 last year retrofitting the building, $20,000 of which to comply with Federal disability laws. The system is also renovating six schools to resolve Mr. Solas's complaints.
Although Mr. Tarlian acknowledges that disabled students should be protected to the full extent of the law, he agrees with other education experts that advocates like Mr. Solas have run amok.
He cites one complaint by parents who sought to move their disabled child to a school that did not have a program that could accommodate the youngster. The district wanted to keep the child in the school where he was enrolled, which had a suitable program. The dispute went to a hearing, which the district won. But the school system spent $28,000 defending itself.
"That's like opening a window and throwing out $28,000," said Mr. Tarlian. "There is no question about it. The reason the school has been attacked is because they are the most vulnerable."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gregory Solas vowed to help the handicapped when his legs were crushed in a construction accident. Since then, the complaints he has filed have amounted to 25 percent of the workload at the Education Department's civil rights office in Boston. He was flanked by his twins, Derek and Nicole. (Sarah Putnam for The New York Times)
 
Graph/Photo: "To Overcome Disabilities"
 Outfitting a school to make it accessible to disabled people, in compliance with Federal laws, can cost up to $200,000. Here is how Veterans Memorial High School in Warwick, R.I., was modified after complaints by Gregory Solas. The total cost for the project was $51,850. Information provided by the Warwick Public Schools.
* Fit 260 interior doors with new levers and handles -- $10,400
* Modify restrooms meet the minimum requirements for use by a disabled person -- $10,000
* 300 raised-letter signs for the blind -- $7,500
* New parking area, 80 by 40 feet, with signs -- $7,500
* Provide portable or adaptable equipment for classrooms, including accessible lab tables, language-lab booths and machine-shop equipment -- $3,000
* Extend stair handrails -- $2,800
* Make sinks in the vocational area usable from a wheelchair -- $2,500
* Lower fire alarm boxes -- $2,000
* Install accessible shower stalls in boys' and girls' locker rooms -- $2,000
* Second-floor water fountain usable from a wheelchair -- $1,300
* Lower emergency shut-off buttons and light switches -- $1,000
* Lower the elevator's control panel to 54 inches from the floor and install raised letters and numbers -- $600
* Fire-alarm buzzer and warning light for library -- $600
* Label the main entrance with the international symbol of accessibility and lower the door operating pressure to five pounds -- $500
* Make one public telephone usable from a wheelchair, lower the coin slot to no higher than 54 inches and provide a volume control for the hearing-impaired -- $150

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Legislator to Run For Comptroller Next Year

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 27

 BODY:
Assemblyman John J. Faso of Kinderhook today became the first Republican to announce his candidacy for state comptroller, and in the process provided a preview of his party's 1994 strategy for unseating the Democratic incumbent, H. Carl McCall.
Mr. Faso tied Mr. McCall to both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins, calling them "a double-barreled disaster for the New York State economy and the New York City economy." 
 He also questioned the independence of Mr. McCall, who was elected by a Democratic-controlled vote of the Legislature last spring to fill the unexpired term of the former Comptroller, Edward V. Regan. Mr. Cuomo, a longtime ally of Mr. McCall, led many in the Legislature to believe that he strongly supported Mr. McCall.
"Let's face it," Mr. Faso said while announcing his candidacy in an airport terminal here. "The fact that this Comptroller is attached at one hip to Governor Cuomo means that sometimes he's not going to be independent."
 
Monitor and Auditor
 Mr. McCall said he would counter Republican attacks by demonstrating his independence. "I'm busy doing my job as the independent Comptroller of the State of New York, and I'm not going to be distracted by political carping at this time," he said.
The comptroller serves as the official monitor of the state's fiscal practices and has the power to certify to Wall Street whether New York's budget is balanced. The comptroller also audits state agencies and local governments, and administers the state's $55 billion pension fund.
Mr. Faso, a four-term Assemblyman whose district includes parts of Columbia, Greene, and Albany Counties and all of Schoharie County, said he would run as a fiscal conservative. He said he would use the comptroller's office to "raise the alarm when things are out of control." Thousands of businesses and individuals have fled New York, he said, because of an economy that "has been devastated by high taxes, spiraling spending and burgeoning debt."
More than 15 months before Election Day, the 40-year-old Mr. Faso starts the campaign with little name recognition outside his upstate district. He said he had raised $40,000 -- a July 11 financial disclosure form shows $19,160 -- for a race that he predicts will cost at least $2.5 million to win.
 
Reputation for Eloquence
 His only statewide experience came as campaign manager for Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial nominee who lost a disastrous race in 1990. After several disagreements with Mr. Rinfret, Mr. Faso realized he could neither influence nor control his candidate and left the campaign.
But as a member of the Assembly minority, Mr. Faso has a reputation for being smart, eloquent and aggressive. He helped mount an unsuccessful court challenge against the Assembly Democrats' redistricting plan last year and has criticized Mr. Cuomo for everything from the state's borrowing practices to the Governor's appearance in state tourism advertisements.
Several other Republicans have expressed interest in the comptroller's race, including Suffolk County Comptroller Joseph R. Caputo and State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan. But party leaders predict that if Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato decides to run for governor, any number of Republicans who currently are considering a gubernatorial campaign might drop down to the comptroller's race.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the kickoff of his campaign to gain the Republican candidacy for state comptroller, Assemblyman John J. Faso, right, was greeted by a colleague, Arnold W. Proskin, at the Albany airport. In an election more than a year away, he will seek to unseat the incumbent, H. Carl McCall. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Grants $4.5 Million to Help Military Contractors Shift Focus

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODBURY, L.I., July 27

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came here today to announce that the Federal Government has awarded the state a $4.5 million grant to help Long Island's sagging military industries convert to peacetime pursuits.
"This grant will enable us to do a lot of things, like expanding the state's industrial effectiveness program," Mr. Cuomo said to an audience of about 500 business owners at the Crest Hollow Country Club. "It will fund new training programs for defense workers, expand new market development for defense firms and set aside $2 million as a working capital revolving loan fund to help finance individual diversification programs." 
 The grant is the largest awarded so far under a 2-year-old Federal program intended to help companies reduce their dependence on military contracts, said Wilbur Hawkins, Acting Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Development. Under the program, the state must provide an additional $1.1 million and the private sector must contribute $5.6 million.
 
Dire Need Found
 Uses for the money included helping retrain workers to make products like cellular telephones for the commercial market. The companies make a range of products from landing gear for jets to medical supplies. The money is available immediately for companies that apply.
The size of the grant is based on the area's needs, Mr. Hawkins said. Long Island was deemed to be in dire need because prime military contracts awarded to companies here like Grumman Corporation in Bethpage and the Hazeltine Corporation in Greenlawn were valued at $5.28 billion in 1987, but declined to $2.86 billion in 1992. Between 1985 and 1991, Long Island lost some 15,000 military-related jobs as the Pentagon reduced its weapons procurement programs.
"Our goal is to assist in productivity improvement and make sure we are able to retrain and have a focus on the overall sustainabilty of the economy," Mr. Hawkins said. "This is a major accomplishment."
Several executives at the meeting today said they were pleased with the government's interest in their plight, but said the grant was not enough.
"The Defense Department eliminated a million and a half high-skilled workers," said Martin Bloch, chief executive of Frequency Electronic Inc. of Mitchel Field. The company makes timing devices for aircraft and missiles. "We can put them on the unemployment lines and spend $50 billion keeping them on those lines or try to find them work. That's what they're trying to do and we're pleased."
 
'It's a Demonstration'
 Long Island business owners grew so concerned about the sliding military industry that earlier this year they formed a network of more than 100 Defense Department subcontractors called the Aerospace and Defense Diversification Alliance in Peacetime Transition.
Greg Frisby, chief executive of Frisby Airborne Hydraulics Inc. of Freeport and head of the group of subcontractors, said in June that local companies needed about $200 million in loans to secure about $1 billion in commercial contracts.
"This grant is not enough by itself to help solve our problems, but it's a demonstration by the Federal and state governments that they are interested in helping us," he said.
The state applied for the loan under its diversification program, which was started by Mr. Cuomo in 1991.
"We applaud Commerce Secretary Ron Brown for his support of this economic strategy," Mr. Cuomo said. "Military spending helped to create an advanced high-technology economy for Long Island. In this post-Cold War era, public resources can help defense firms identify the new markets and new technologies they can utilize to compete in the global commercial marketplace."

HEADLINE: Court Sets a 2-Year Limit On Sex-Harassment Suits

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 27

 BODY:
Victims of sexual harassment will have to file suits within two years or lose their right to sue, the New Jersey Supreme Court said today.
The court said the question of the statute of limitations for such claims has been "murky." Sometimes lower courts have treated the cases as economic loss suits, with a six-year limit, and sometimes as personal injury claims, with a two-year limit. 
 In its unanimous opinion today, the court said the two-year limit should apply to claims brought under the state's Law Against Discrimination, which covers sexual harassment cases. The result will be more efficient and uniform prosecutions of such cases, the court said.
Earlier this month the court established standards for claiming job-related sexual harassment -- that it must be so "severe" and "pervasive" that a reasonable woman or man would believe that the work environment had become "hostile" or "abusive."
Justice Stewart G. Pollock, writing for the court in today's ruling, said a quick resolution of harassment claims is fairest to the accused, the accuser and the judicial system, since the outcome often depends on a decision about who is telling the truth.
"Evidence of discrimination, especially proof of sexual discrimination, is vulnerable to the passage of time," Justice Pollock said. "With racial slurs, insults about sexual orientation, or sexually suggestive remarks, the proof generally depends on testimonial evidence.
 
Reasoning for Difference
 "Depending on the memory and availability of witnesses, that testimony can dissipate or even disappear over time."
The New Jersey court said that other jurisdictions, when looking for an appropriate statute of limitations, generally have selected periods of three years or less. "Although they may reach that decision by different analytical paths, those courts concur that civil rights complaints should be timely filed," the court said.
The New Jersey law, first enacted in 1945, provided for the filing of complaints with the Division Against Discrimination, which became the Division on Civil Rights in 1960. The law has been amended several times since then to broaden its scope, , but it has never included its own statute of limitations. The court said the Legislature could still enact its own time limit on suits if it disagreed with today's decision.
In 1977 the law was amended to underscore the state's concern with discrimination based on "race, creed, color, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, liability for service in the armed forces of the United States or nationality." In 1991 the law was amended to protect against discrimination based on "affectional or sexual orientation," and in 1992 another amendment was enacted to prevent discrimination because of "familial status."
The decision today was prompted by a sexual harassment claim filed in 1989 by Jessica Montells, an employee of the American International Adjustment Company. Ms. Montells asserted that her supervisor had made lewd comments and had touched her in sexually suggestive ways in 1987.
When the company took no action in response to her complaints she resigned and was paid through May 13, 1987, according to the facts in the State Supreme Court ruling. She filed her suit on May 23, 1989, and the trial judge ruled that she missed the deadline for filing the suit by a few days. Ms. Montells appealed, pointing to the use of the six-year limit in some earlier discrimination suits.
 
Other Cases
 Although the state's highest court today disagreed with her argument, it did something that the lower courts had refused to do -- it said its ruling applied only to cases that arise after today. It sent Ms. Montells's case back to the lower court for a trial.
Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz and Justices Marie L. Garibaldi, Robert L. Clifford, Alan B. Handler, Daniel J. O'Hern and Gary S. Stein joined in Justice Pollock's opinion.
The court split, 4 to 3 and 5 to 2, on two other rulings dealing with state police searches that found cocaine in the trunks of motorists' cars. The owners of the cars had consented to the searches but the luggage containing the illicit drugs belonged to passengers, leading the court to issue decisions meant to instruct the police on how to conduct such searches.
In one case the passenger told the trooper that he was the owner of a blue canvas bag that turned out to hold drugs. The trooper continued the search without asking the passenger's permission. The passenger later made a motion to suppress the evidence but also pleaded guilty to drug charges and was sentenced to 12 years in prison.
Today the court threw out the conviction, ruling 4 to 3, that a warrantless search of a container in a car based on the consent of the driver is invalid if a passenger asserts ownership of the container.
In the second case the court upheld a search under similar circumstances because the passenger did not claim ownership of the bag with the drugs. The trooper continued to search based on the "objectively reasonable" assumption that the driver's consent covered all the items in the trunk, the court said in a 5 to 2 opinion.
But while it found the search valid, the court threw out the conviction of the passenger on other grounds. Both cases were sent back to lower courts for new trials.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday after the market swallowed $16 billion in new two-year notes, an auction that analysts said drew lukewarm investor response.
However, the auction results were viewed as reasonably favorable considering the bearish tone that has spread through the market as a result of comments by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, last week that inflation was still a concern. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond was down 2/32 point and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, remained unchanged at 6.67 percent.
Breaking a monthlong drought of new intermediate- and long-term issues, the Government's sale of two-year notes was the first in a wave of supply scheduled to reach the market over the next few weeks.
The Treasury sold the notes at a high yield of 4.26 percent, the highest rate since two-year notes sold for 4.28 percent on Jan. 26. Many market participants had expected the notes to yield 4.25 percent, and the higher rate reflected the ability of investors to be somewhat choosier about the returns they will accept.
 
Bid to Cover Ratio
 The bid to cover ratio, a measure of demand that compares the number of bids offered with those accepted, was 2.24 to 1. That was lower than the 2.73-to-1 average over the last 10 auctions of two-year notes.
"It was a little bit soft, but it was a big issue," said David Ader, a market strategist for Technical Data in Boston. "The market cleared the first hurdle of the heavy supply and handled it well."
The market may have a harder time absorbing today's scheduled sale of $11 billion in five-year notes, some economists said. Two-year notes have built-in demand, because banks routinely buy them as a way to store their money at fixed rates of return. Longer-term securities, on the other hand, depend more on demand from portfolio managers and other so-called retail investors.
Next week, the Treasury is scheduled to detail its plans for selling 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities in the second week of August.
Nancy Kimelman, Technical Data's chief economist, said the Treasury is expected to sell $38.5 billion during the refunding -- $16.5 billion in 3-year notes and $11 billion each of 10-year and 30-year securities.
The market's uncertainty about absorbing new supply was compounded last week when Mr. Greenspan testified in Congress that the Fed was ready to raise short-term rates to combat any new signs of inflation.
That depressed prices in the bond market, since higher rates on newly sold securities would erode the value of already sold bonds.
Also hurting the bond market are worries that President Clinton's budget package will not result in substantial deficit reduction, Mr. Ader said.
The market had little response toward fresh economic data that showed sluggishness in the economy. The results were largely expected.
The Labor Department said wages and salaries increased 2.8 percent for the year ending June 30, failing to keep pace with the 3.0 percent inflation rate for the period as measured by the Consumer Price Index.
Also, the Conference Board reported that consumer confidence in the economy fell in July for the third straight month.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.16 percent as the discount edged up 0.01 percentage point, to 3.10 percent. Six-month yields rose to 3.34 percent as the discount increased 0.02 point, to 3.25 percent. One-year yields rose to 3.59 percent as the discount rose 0.01 point, to 3.46 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1016/32 , down 1/16 from late Monday. The average yield to maturity was 5.82 percent, up from 5.81 percent.

HEADLINE: Selling the Shreds of the Cold War

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

 BODY:
In a deal that only the end of the cold war could produce, America's largest munitions maker will soon begin cutting up more than 200,000 tons of surplus Ukrainian ammunition, much of it made for firing at United States troops, and selling it for scrap.
The joint venture between Alliant Techsystems Inc. of Edina, Minn., and the Ukrainian Defense Ministry is believed to be the first between an American company and a former Soviet republic for dismantling such materiel as tank ammunition, artillery shells and mortar rounds. 
 The agreement does not deal with the nuclear weapons that Ukraine inherited from the former Soviet Union. United States officials have urged Kiev to dismantle those weapons.
Alliant and Ukrainian officials estimate that sales of scrap copper, steel, brass and aluminum from the discarded weapons casings and components could generate more than $100 million in revenue in the next five years. The company and the Ukrainian Government would divide the proceeds.
 
A Demilitarization Market
 For Alliant, a leading torpedo and tank-shell maker for the Pentagon, the deal signals an entry into a small but growing international market of demilitarization. Many military contractors in the United States, Germany, Japan and Israel are exploring this market to help offset declining orders for weapons.
For Ukraine, the agreement brings in American capital and technical expertise to reduce huge stockpiles of munitions that date, in some cases, to 1905. In some instances, these arsenals pose safety or environmental hazards.
Toby G. Warson, Alliant's chief executive, and Gen. Konstantin P. Morozov, Ukraine's Defense Minister, are to announce the agreement in Washington today.
For decades, armies around the world have disposed of surplus or obsolete munitions by burning them, burying them, dumping them at sea or blowing them up. But as environmental concerns grow in the United States and elsewhere, these methods are becoming increasingly restricted.
Under the deal, Alliant will set up automated dismantling assembly lines at two ammunition depots in Ukraine. The Ukrainian Government has already started dismantling some munitions at one of the sites, in Icnja, a village 90 miles northeast of Kiev.
At each site, munitions will be taken apart mechanically or by using a high-pressure water jet. Alliant officials said the fine stream of water, under pressure of 50,000 pounds per square inch, could cut through shells without detonating the explosive.
Once the munitions are cut up, rendering them useless, propellants and explosives will be removed and converted into commercial explosives used in mining, construction, synthetic fuels and fertilizers. The scrap metal will be sold on the commercial market.
Alliant is shipping the initial dismantling equipment to Ukraine and is expected to be operating there later this summer. Alliant's initial capital investment is about $15 million, said Larry J. Blagdon, the company's director of ordnance, reclamation and demilitarization.
Eventually, the venture is expected to employ about 100 Ukrainians, mainly civilians who now work at weapons depots.
Industry analysts say that demilitarization is a still a peripheral business for major military contractors, but that broader applications will be possible.
"This part of the industry is still embryonic, but any new business for these guys is good these days," said Byron Callan, a military industry analyst at Prudential Securities in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alliant Techsystems and Ukraine's Defense Ministry have joined forces to dismantle tank ammunition, artillery shells and mortar rounds. High-pressure water jets cut through shells without detonating the explosive. (Alliant Techsystems)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Against Mark But Down in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against European currencies yesterday but fell against the yen as the Japanese currency climbed to a record high against the German mark.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery fell $1.90 an ounce, to $391.20. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $391.00 an ounce, down $1.80 from Monday. 
 The yen was the main beneficiary as investors fled mark-denominated assets on expectations that Germany would cut interest rates to reduce pressure on the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. The yen peaked at 61.46 per mark, breaking Monday's record of 61.55 yen per mark.
Dealers said they were betting that the Bundesbank would cut its key discount rate, currently at 6.75 percent, by a quarter- to half-point at its council meeting tomorrow.
"The Bundesbank will have to ease," said Steven Jury, chief dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. "If it doesn't it will sacrifice the current parities in the E.R.M."
The dollar rose to 1.7271 marks in late New York trading from 1.7245 marks late Monday. But it fell to 106.10 yen from 106.65 yen.
 
Inflation Unlikely to Matter
 Dealers thought it unlikely that German price data would deter the Bundesbank from easing. Annual inflation hit its highest level in three months at 4.3 percent in July, but many economists had forecast an even bigger price rise.
The Bundesbank's weekly open market operations today should lend some clues on monetary policy, dealers said. Most expect Germany's short-term money market rates to decline.
Speculators massed against Spain's peseta and Portugal's escudo. Rumors that Spain would announce alarmingly high unemployment this week helped push its currency to the bottom of its European Rate Mechanism range.
The French and Belgian francs and Danish krone held up better, but few believed the pressure was off for good.
The British pound declined sharply, falling in New York to $1.4890, from 1.5010 Monday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Shape From Nature Helps Curb Noise

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSH

 BODY:
To replace conventional mufflers on trucks and other noisy machines, a Canadian company has developed a "silencer" whose inner workings are shaped like a conch shell.
The developer, Temro of Winnipeg, Manitoba, a subsidiary of the Budd Company of Troy, Mich., contends that the device for diesel engines is up to three times as effective a sound deadener as a conventional muffler and can eliminate 75 percent of the noise from a truck's exhaust pipe. 
 Mufflers work in two ways: by reflecting sound waves back on each other so they cancel out and by using sound-absorbing materials. Temro says its muffler, called the Cowl Silencer, uses both methods.
Stainless steel wool within the walls helps absorb sound while small holes in the spiraling walls allow waves to pass through and cancel others. Because it does not have the baffles and chambers of typical mufflers, the spiral design reduces the back pressure that can limit an engine's performance.
The device is similar in diameter to conventional mufflers, but is only one-third as long. Temro would not specify prices for the mufflers, which are now reaching the market, but did say they were more expensive than conventional mufflers and would probably not be economical for cars. The target markets are buses, air compressors, commercial boats and earth movers.


GRAPHIC: Exhaust from a diesel engine and the accompanying noise enter the cowl muffler and are diverted through a narrow spiraling path. Noise is reduced by the canceling effet of some of the sound passing through the small holes in the path's walls, and by the absorbing effect of the stainless steel wool through which the exhause passes. (Source: Budd Company)

HEADLINE: Unusual Heart Therapy Wins Coverage From Large Insurer

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
In a move that could be a boon to alternative medicine, the nation's largest provider of health insurance for individuals announced yesterday that it would reimburse patients participating in a program that combines diet, meditation, exercise and support groups to reverse heart disease.
The "reversal program," which was developed by Dr. Dean Ornish, director of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute in Sausalito, Calif., is the first non-surgical, non-pharmaceutical therapy for heart disease to qualify for insurance reimbursement, which it was granted yesterday by the Mutual of Omaha Insurance Company. 
 With the exception of chiropractic care, it is the first alternative medical technique, not taught in traditional medical school curriculums, to gain approval by a major insurance carrier. Insurance executives say it will not be the last.
 
'Very Hot Area'
 "Alternative therapies are potentially a very hot area," said Dr. Jeffrey Weiner, senior medical director of U.S. Healthcare, a health-maintenance organization with 1.6 million subscribers, based in Blue Bell, Pa.
Other insurance companies may soon follow Mutual of Omaha's lead. The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Companies of California are "considering Dr. Ornish's plan quite positively and will make a final decision about reimbursement at our next meeting," said Mike Odom, a company spokesman. Similar therapies are being considered for inclusion in the national health-care policy being developed by the White House, according to several physicians who are working with the White House and who asked not to be identified.
Dr. Joseph J. Jacobs, director of alternative medicine at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., said, "I think it's terrific that insurance companies are beginning to acknowlege the value of therapies outside conventional forms." He added that non-traditional therapies could be effective in dealing with chronic problems like heart disease, repetitive stress syndrome, arthritis and back pain and that they were often much less expensive than conventional treatment.
Dr. Ornish's reversal plan, for instance, costs $3,500 a year, about one-tenth the price of conventional coronary care, according to Dr. Richard Collins, director of cardiology at the Immanuel Medical Center in Omaha. Immanuel Medical Center plans to begin offering a reversal program in October; other hospitals offering the program are Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan and Griffin Hospital of Yale University in Derby, Conn.
Patients on Dr. Ornish's program eat a vegetarian diet that gets 10 percent of its calories from fat, practice stress management through meditation and yoga, exercise moderately and participate in a support group to help them adhere to these life style changes.
Jack Weekly, the president of Mutual of Omaha, said that Dr. Ornish's program "is a model for the preventative treatments that are critical for better quality, more economical health care." The company provides health insurance for 10 million people nationwide through individual and group plans.
Dr. William C. Roberts, editor-in-chief of The American Journal of Cardiology in Dallas, agreed. "Americans spent $18 billion dollars last year on coronary-bypass surgery, making it the number-one health bill in the nation," he said. He added that while traditional therapies could retard heart disease, they have not been shown to reverse it.
"More often than not, the patient's cholesterol actually goes up after the traditional interventions," he said. The American Heart Association estimates that if work loss is added to the cost of hospital, surgical and pharmacological intervention, heart disease costs the United States about $117.4 billion a year.
 
Support From Studies
 In three studies financed by private foundations as well as by the National Institutes of Health over a 17-year period, Dr. Ornish has proved that his program not only retards but can reverse heart disease. "In the first year, 82 percent of patients demonstrated overall reversal of coronary artery disease," he said.
Dr. Ornish says his program is an adjunct to traditional therapies, not a replacement for them. Thousands of people have attended his week-long seminars on the program.
In its early years, Dr. Ornish's research struck many conventional cardiologists as a remnant of the feel-good, self-help 1970's.
"There was resistance and disbelief," Dr. Roberts said. "People thought he was a radical." Dr. Ornish said that his colleagues had treated his research as suspect until his findings were published in professional journals like The Lancet and The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Today, he said, few cardiologists doubt that heart disease can be reversed through a stringent, low-fat diet. And in the world of technological coronary care, Dr. Ornish's self-help approach is viewed as a "conservative alternative," Dr. Roberts said.
Dr. Ornish's move from the alternative fringe into the mainstream of American medical practice was predicated on rigorous, well-designed clinical research, according to Dr. Jacobs of the N.I.H. "In order to validate therapies outside the traditional forms, the researcher has to lay a solid groundwork," Dr. Jacobs said.
In addition to his research, Dr. Ornish has written two best-selling books, "Dr. Dean Ornish's Program for Reversing Heart Disease," (Random House, 1990) and "Eat More, Weigh Less," (HarperCollins, 1993). He has also developed a line of frozen vegetarian meals called Life Choice, which is distributed by direct mail through Conagra Inc. based in Omaha.
 
Promoting a Message
 Dr. Ornish said: "It is very threatening to ask people to change what they put in their mouths 21 times a week and to ask them to practice activities that are outside their realm. I figured the more familiar my name became, the less threatening my message would be."
But it may still be threatening to conventionally trained cardiologists. Dr. Roberts said, "It's tough to make a living passing out eating advice." Like conventional heart specialists, Dr. Ornish prescribes heart medicine, but he does not recommend cholesterol-lowering medication for people following his program.
Dr. Ornish's detractors, such as Dr. Adam Drenowski, dean of nutrition at the University of Michigan School of Public Health in Ann Arbor, question whether adherence to a stringent low-fat diet is feasible. "My research has shown that, unless threatened by death, adherence is impossible," Dr. Drenowski said in an interview last winter.
Others, like Dr. Peter Kaufman, director of behavioral medicine at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, say that pulling alternative treatments into mainstream medical practice requires some retraining.
"We are in the early stages of using alternative interventions that rely on behavioral changes in health care," he said. Mutual of Omaha, he said, "is also helping to shape the practice of behavioral medicine, which is in its infancy."
By opening the door to other forms of preventive treatment, insurance reimbursement for the reversal program is also the first step toward changing the way medicine is practiced in the United States, said Dr. Collins of Immanuel Medical Center.
"Physicians have become procedure-providers instead of health-care providers," he said "That's where the money has been."
Dr. Collins plans to do his part to change that when he opens his reversal center in October, using Dr. Ornish's procedures. "We're promising a money-back guarantee," he said. "If reversal doesn't work, we'll deduct its cost from any additional procedure the patient might require."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Dean Ornish, developer of plan for reversing heart disease. (Ed Kashi) (pg. C11)

HEADLINE: Another Generation Lost

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"The Lost Generation," the title of tonight's NBC News special, refers to the many young people who, as Tom Brokaw puts it, have "walked out of high school into a recession." It is no revelation that good jobs are hard to find these days, and this hourlong report tends toward the familiar and repetitious. But the subject is important enough to bear some repeating.
By way of example, Mr. Brokaw visits an Ohio town whose General Motors plant, once its major employer, shut down in 1987. Since then, youngsters who would ordinarily have followed their parents onto the assembly line at union wages have had to settle for minimum-wage jobs in fast-food chains. Instead of rearing families and putting money in the bank, they are scrambling to get by, and prospects are bleak. Interviews bring out their feelings that they have somehow been betrayed, that they will never attain the simple but solid comforts their parents took for granted and they expected. 
 There are also glimpses of young folks who, it is suggested, have been driven to crime or to religion by tough times. The camera keeps busy with all manner of unnecessary tricks, perhaps in an effort to distract viewers from Mr. Brokaw's generally routine comments, which evidence no acquaintance with the long history of generational disaffection.
About halfway through, the program gets into the significant if depressing subject of what the millions of young Americans who are not college bound are being taught. This "Lost Generation," two-thirds of high-school students, is not being prepared for better jobs than dishing out hamburgers. Mr. Brokaw goes on to report on experiments around the country, like apprenticeship arrangements with local businesses, to do something about it. They seem like worthy efforts, but it is hard to get one's hopes up as long as jobs of any sort remain in short supply.
 
'48 Hours'
'On Sunset Boulevard'
CBS, tonight at 10
Tonight's edition of "48 Hours" is all about comings and goings in Los Angeles. Coming in are hundreds of thousands of immigrants, mostly illegal and mostly from Latin America, along with aspiring movie stars and commuters who clog the so-called freeways. Going out are middle-class families, for whom the California dream has been contaminated by crime, pollution and a long economic recession.
Political discontent is signaled by an organization called the Voice of Citizens Together, formed to oppose illegal immigration. Its leaders warn that their city is "exporting jobs and importing poverty." An environmentalist says the future "is as murky as the water."
Given such dire assessments, "On Sunset Boulevard" is a remarkably cheery hour. Hispanic newcomers are seen learning English. A 22-year-old actress is as hopeful of being discovered as young performers always have been while they wait and wait tables, and Lana Turner's picture still hangs at Hollywood High. Surfers continue to surf, although the water keeps getting dirtier. And a man who drives a bus full of neighbors on a two-and-a-half-hour commute and then works nine hours in a Los Angeles bank before driving the bus back home to their distant suburb positively rejoices in his schedule.
But the most cheering moment for New Yorkers comes from a departing woman who says she is returning to New York City. And safety.

The Lost Generation

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
China Needs Time To Deserve the Games

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
IF we all can curb our suicidal instincts for war and pollution, China must surely be an Olympic host for the first time, very early in the next century. But not in the year 2000.
At the point when the decision must be made, in Monaco on Sept. 23, the International Olympic Committee should use the yardstick of preparedness for not choosing Beijing. Then while China is improving its stadiums and hotels, it can work on its observation of human rights, without having been seen as openly criticized. 
For better or for worse, comfort and technology are the major factors in choosing Olympic sites these days. It is a sad fact that most countries will never have a shot at staging the Games, but the emerging nation of China will be a host of them, the sooner the better.
The I.O.C. delegates were not humming "It's a small, small world" when they selected a second-tier American city, Atlanta, to be the host in 1996, only 12 years after Los Angeles.
Telephone lines. Roads. Practical time zones for European and American television. American corporate sponsors. Creature comforts. Can you imagine Carl Lewis and I.O.C. delegates staying in anything but five-star hotels? Having given in to their own top-dog tendencies, the I.O.C. delegates are in perfect position to ask China to wait four years.
Another reason being advanced for delaying China is the violent repression of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in 1989, and wide-scale persecution of dissidents.
"There is no reason to believe that once the Games are awarded, China will be persuaded to loosen the screws," said Richard Dicker, a lawyer with Human Rights Watch, in his testimony before a Senate committee on July 15.
The House of Representatives passed a resolution on Monday urging the I.O.C. to find "another more suitable venue," and many senators also favor a resolution.
They are aiming these resolutions at one former Olympic bronze-medal rower, Anita DeFrantz, the American delegate to the I.O.C. DeFrantz recently told a Senate committee that "respect for human rights, civil rights and human dignity have also been guiding principles in my own moral compass," and she added, "I honor and respect the intent of the resolution." But she has no obligation to any pressure.
She is also a lawyer, a black woman and a resident of Los Angeles, which has seen its share of agony since the so-called Rodney King turmoil. She is not about to say that China is the only country in the world with problems. She lost her second chance to participate in the Summer Games because of President Carter's boycott of the 1980 Games in Moscow following the invasion of Afghanistan.
She was an official in the 1984 Games in Los Angeles, which were diminished to a Disney celebration because most of the Soviet bloc stayed home. Boycotts beget boycotts. Dr. Leroy Walker, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, fears political rejection of China could start a new wave of Olympic power plays.
There are clearly precedents for punishing nations with bad records on human rights. South Africa was barred for 32 years because of its blatant policy of apartheid. In Brazil, off-duty police officers are apparently murdering street children with some overtones of racism, but Brasilia is also a candidate for the 2000 Games. So are Istanbul, Berlin, Sydney and Manchester, England.
There have been religious murders in Turkey, racial murders in Germany, open discrimination against Asians and blacks in the United Kingdom and past repression of aborigines in Australia. Where do people of conscience draw the line?
Fortunately, there is a middle way to send China a message. Twelve Olympic officials have evaluated all six candidate cities, based on 23 factors. The report was supposed to be distributed only to the 94 delegates, but copies became public. Sydney received the highest grades, followed by Manchester and Berlin, while questions were raised about Istanbul, and Brasilia fell far short, and Beijing was particularly criticized for stadium sites and pollution.
"We would also urge you to . . . consider the current economic, political and other factors which may not be covered by the technical evaluation," wrote Gunnar Ericsson of Sweden, the I.O.C. delegate who led the committee.
DeFrantz is much too discreet to tip her hand, but the former Olympic rower did say she always thinks of the conditions for the athletes. "Nobody will ever know how we vote," she said.
China is showing great signs of flexing its economic muscles. It must not be discouraged from even tangential pursuits like sports. Four years to upgrade its infrastructure and take a look at human rights? What are four years to China?

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS VOICING DOUBT ON CHANCES FOR ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Amid rising anxiety among Democratic leaders over the prospects for President Clinton's economic package, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a quarterback in the drive to push the plan through Congress, proclaimed today that he lacked the votes to pass the measure in the Senate next week and was not sure how to get them.
As Mr. Moynihan and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago shuttered themselves in the Capitol today, trying to work out a compromise version of the plan that could pass both houses of Congress, the plan's political woes only seemed to mount. 
 Several lawmakers who had previously supported the plan appeared to be climbing onto the political fence. And a legislative revolt seemed to be brewing against a crucial element of the package, a tax on gasoline and diesel fuel that House and Senate negotiators are counting on to supply at least $5 billion a year.
 
Chicken or Chess?
 But in the feverish atmosphere enshrouding these last days of bargaining over Mr. Clinton's $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts, no one could tell how much of Mr. Moynihan's hand-wringing was genuine and how much was bluff, how much of the gasoline-tax revolt was real and how much was posturing, or how many Democrats would really vote to doom Mr. Clinton's economic plan and their party's political credibility. The negotiators are rushing so the package can be voted on before the monthlong recess that begins on Aug. 6.
Rather, Democrats at both ends of the Capitol were playing a high-stakes game of chicken, warning that they or others could singlehandedly vote the package down unless someone, somewhere bowed to demands that the package be softened, or toughened or left as is.
 
Thinnest of Margins
 "A lot of this is posturing going on now," said Representative Mike Synar of Oklahoma, a Democrat who is a leading supporter of Mr. Clinton's package in a state where outright support is rare. "When it's time to vote, each individual member is going to have to look at themselves and at the future of this country."
Minutes later, Mr. Synar hinted that the proposed gasoline tax was causing even his enthusiasm for the package to wane. "It's not a show-stopper for me," he said of the tax. "But it's sure an intermission."
Such warnings are credible because time is so short, and Mr. Clinton's support is so thin. By most readings, the President's plan will fail if he loses even one supporter in the 100-member Senate, or as few as two or three in the 435-member House.
Mr. Moynihan said this afternoon that the negotiations with the House to produce a compromise bill were going well, even as the politics deteriorated. The talks today, which included Administration aides, produced agreements in spirit, but not number, on most items except the fuel tax, he said.
Lawmakers also said a compromise on that tax seemed near with the House and Senate negotiators reportedly discussing an agreement that would raise the proposed tax from the Senate's 4.3 cents per gallon to between 6 and 7 cents. That tax increase would be added to the current tax of 14.1 cents a gallon.
Still uncertain is whether any compromise can muster support in Congress. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he believed a gasoline tax would be in the final package, but pointedly noted that its fate was an open question among House Democrats.
Mr. Synar and other House members of both parties said the package would probably pass there, but by as a little as one vote. The Senate vote appears to be an even dicier proposition.
"It may be we'll do this thing," Mr. Moynihan said in a telephone interview. "But as of 7 last night, we didn't have the votes." House leaders have told him that they will not schedule a vote on the package until passage in the Senate is assured, he said.
Mr. Moynihan's declaration, which came after what one participant called a "gloomy" meeting Tuesday evening with top Congressional and White House officials, may have been meant as a wake-up call to fellow Democrats. Or it may have been the truth.
The downbeat reading seemed to be affirmed this afternoon, when two Democratic Senators who had earlier supported the economic proposal, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Herb Kohl of Wisconsin, joined Oklahoma's David L. Boren, in expressing new qualms.
That left Mr. Moynihan up to three votes short of the number needed to pass the economic package, with no firm prospects of finding support elsewhere.
Mr. Kohl said he had told Mr. Clinton at a White House meeting today that he felt that the gasoline tax should be dropped from the package to erase the last vestige of taxation on middle- and lower-class families and to deprive Republican critics of a political club in the debate.
 
No Lines Drawn Yet
 Mr. Kerrey told reporters that he had voted for the Senate version of the measure in June to avoid embarrassing Mr. Clinton, as he was headed to Tokyo for his first economic conference with leaders of industrial nations.
Mr. Clinton's backers took some solace in the fact that both men, like Mr. Boren before them, pointedly refused to say that they were definitely opposed to the package.
"I don't want to draw a line in the sand," Mr. Kohl said.
On Tuesday, Mr. Boren had denounced Mr. Clinton's proposal, saying the President should scrap his package, make "significantly more" spending cuts and open negotiations with Republicans to construct an economic plan with bipartisan support. But he had also denounced the Senate version of the economic package before voting for it last month, and negotiators held out hope that he would come around again.
"David Boren has a magical quality about him: he has appeared where you least expected him many times before," said one aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "David Boren is someone on whom you must never give up."
The Senate negotiators and the White House are also not giving up on at least two Democrats who voted against the plan in the Senate last month, Richard Bryan of Nevada and Sam Nunn of Georgia. Mr. Clinton called Mr. Bryan to the White House for a meeting on Sunday, and House and Senate negotiators are considering easing proposed rules on deductions for business meals and entertainment expenses, a big issue for Las Vegas's hotel and convention industry.
Mr. Bryan opened the door a crack today. "He's asked me to keep an open mind until the final package is put together," he said of Mr. Clinton, "and I've agreed to do so."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Merck Will Pay $6 Billion For Giant Drug Discounter

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Heralding the far-reaching changes in the business of health care, Merck & Company, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, announced yesterday that it would spend $6 billion to buy the country's largest mail-order drug company.
The purchase of Medco Containment Services Inc. gives Merck a discount drug distribution arm at a time when prescription drugs, its main business, are coming under increasing price pressure from Washington and employers eager to curtail rising health care costs. 
 The cash-and-stock acquisition is the latest of several moves by large drug companies to try to fit into the emerging world of managed health care, in which consumers' choices are limited and costs are reduced.
Having lost their virtually unrestrained ability to raise prices, many prescription drug makers are striking deals to get their products into other segments of the market in the hopes of keeping sales and profits growing. For instance, the Warner-Lambert Company announced yesterday that it was forming joint ventures with Glaxo P.L.C. and Wellcome P.L.C. to develop versions of two widely used drugs that will soon be available without a doctor's prescription. [Page D5.]
And Marion Merrell Dow Inc. said recently that it would buy Rugby-Darby Group, the biggest maker of low-priced generic versions of drugs whose patent protection has run out.
Merck estimated yesterday that 90 percent of all prescription drugs would be provided free or at reduced prices by government or employer health plans within the next 10 years. About half of prescriptions are financed this way. Medco provides drugs under these plans through its mail-order business and through pharmacy sales to health-plan members who carry a special card.
Medco, based in Montvale, N.J., says it supplies drugs to employer health plans with 33 million members.
In the case of its mail-order business, Medco seeks the lowest-priced drug for each type of illness. Merck had balked until recent years at offering price cuts demanded by Medco and other managed-care buyers.
Companies like Medco and other large drug buyers like health maintenance organizations increasingly influence which drugs are prescribed by giving their members incentives to choose certain drugs.
Analysts said President Clinton's health care program, or whatever version emerges from Congress, probably would accelerate the trend.
But discount drugs are not the only services provided by Medco. It makes telephone calls to customers' physicians to urge them to prescribe selected drugs. It also keeps elaborate electronic records of each patient's drug purchases, and it alerts pharmacists to side effects that might endanger people who take multiple drugs.
 
Offering Advice
 P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, said Merck would study the Medco electronic records to try to show health maintenance organizations and employers that Merck's products would generate large savings for patients who might otherwise need expensive hospital care, which would mean lost days of work.
Citing research findings that 50 percent of patients with chronic ailments stop taking their medicine within 18 months, often without telling their doctor, Dr. Vagelos said Merck hoped to push patients to stay on their regimen. That could not only mean more drug sales for Merck, it could also save billions of dollars in wasted prescriptions, he said.
The acquisition will produce "the first complete vertical integration of a pharmaceutical company from the discovery of drugs to the patient's mouth," Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a pharmaceutical economist at the University of Minnesota, said.
Merck, which is based in White House Station, N.J., said the Federal Trade Commission would review the Medco acquisition for potential problems with antitrust laws. With $9.7 billion in 1992 revenues, Merck has about 10 percent of the fragmented American drug market.
Medco, with $1.8 billion in sales in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1992, has about half of the mail-order drug business and 22 percent of those eligible for employer-financed drug benefits.
"That's a colossus in an industry that is highly fragmented," said Samuel Isaly, an analyst at Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Research. He said Merck executives hope to double their American market share, to 20 percent, in 10 years. But at least for now, he said, the combined Merck and Medco business would not be large enough to be "anticompetitive."
Martin J. Wygod, Medco's chairman, will stay on as head of the business. He said it would be a "free-standing subsidiary of Merck" that would continue to buy products from other drug makers on the basis of cost effectiveness.
But some analysts said some drug companies might shy away from dealing with Medco, fearing their price offers would become known to Merck.
"If another company approaches Medco, Merck can say 'We'll match that price,' " Dr. Schondelmeyer said. "They can never be beat."
Barbara Ryan, a drug securities analyst with Alex. Brown & Company, said other drug manufacturers would now seek to make their own alliances with Medco's competitors. The Merck announcement "caught a lot of other drug companies with their pants down," she said.
Under terms of the agreement signed yesterday morning after an all-night drafting session, Medco shareholders would get $39 in cash, or 1.21401 Merck shares for each Medco share. The cash payments would be limited to 40 percent of the total, to keep the transaction tax free, the companies said.
Merck shares closed at $30.75 yesterday, down $1.375 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Medco gained $4.375 to close at $34.125 in Nasdaq trading.
 
Big Stock Issue Is Set
 Judy C. Lewent, chief financial officer of Merck, said the company would raise $2.4 billion through medium-term and short-term borrowing, taking advantage of low interest rates. It will also issue 112 million shares of common stock. She said the value of Merck stock would be temporarily diluted but the value would be restored by 1996 because of anticipated sales growth.
Mr. Wygod, who acquired Medco 10 years ago, when it was a $20 million-a-year business, said he would convert his personal holdings of two million shares of Medco common stock and 1.2 million Medco stock options to Merck shares. He also plans to buy "$20 million to $40 million worth of Merck stock," he said, "as soon as I get an O.K. from the attorneys."
Two senior Medco executives will convert their holdings to add $10 million to $20 million more in Merck shares, Mr. Wygod added. Kenneth S. Abramowitz of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company said Mr. Wygod had pledged to hold onto the Merck shares for at least three years. The investments are intended to seal the executives' commitment to Merck.

HEADLINE: Cuba Will End Restrictions On Exiles Wanting to Visit

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 28

 BODY:
Accelerating a drive to obtain desperately needed foreign currency, the Cuban Government will announce the lifting of tight restrictions on travel to the island this week for Cuban-American exiles that had forced most to wait for months or even years for visas allowing them to visit their families.
Travel agencies in Miami that specialize in trips to Cuba for Cuban-Americans say Havana has notified them that it will quickly seek a fivefold increase in the number of exiles visiting the island. To accomplish this, the Cuban Government has said it will reduce the processing time for most visa applications to about two weeks. 
 The travel agencies say they have also been told that Cuban-Americans who visit the island may carry an unlimited amount of dollars with them, play host to their relatives in tourist hotels and shops, and return as often as they like.
The relaxation of restrictions on visits by Cuban-Americans is the latest in an increasingly bold series of economic and political gambles that analysts of Cuban affairs say are aimed at buying time for a Government that is nearing financial asphyxiation. This week President Fidel Castro announced that Cubans may legally possess dollars for the first time in three decades,
 
Risks for the Government
 The new measures, broadly hinted at in a speech by Mr. Castro on Monday, were first reported in The Miami Herald today.
Many experts say that while the measures may quickly generate vital new revenues for the island's Communist Government, they also carry incalculable risks.
"This is a gutsy, but really quite dangerous move for the kind of regime they are trying to maintain, with very little political opening," said Jorge Dominguez, a Harvard University specialist in Cuban affairs. "It is dangerous to have all of these free spirits wandering around, none of them with a warm feeling in their hearts for the Government."
Andrew Zimbalist, a professor at Smith College who has made a specialty of studying the Cuban economy, said: "This is really going to open a Pandora's box. You will have a crazier mix of incentives than ever before.
"Blacks will not have access to dollars, party members who are supposed to be relatively better off will have less money than taxi drivers and if the Government doesn't take some other serious steps a lot of people will see no point in working in their 500-pesos-a-month jobs at all."
Relatively few blacks have emigrated from Cuba since Mr. Castro took power in 1959, meaning they would not benefit from remittances sent by relatives abroad.
 
Behind the Mariel Boatlift
 The last time Havana encouraged large-scale tourism by Cuban-Americans, in the late 1970's, the ensuing social ferment, caused in part by the contact with much more affluent and free-speaking visitors, led to the Mariel boatlift of 1980, when over 100,000 Cubans fled their country in a chaotic scramble.
About 100,000 Cuban-Americans visited Cuba in 1979. Since the start-up of Radio Marti, a special United States Government station broadcasting to Cuba, in 1985, travel to Cuba by exiles has been severely limited by a series of restrictions, most of which are now being lifted. On average, about 90 visas a week are granted to Cuban exiles.
That the Cuban Government is carrying out such a policy now, experts say, reflects its dire economic situation.
By Mr. Castro's own most recent estimates, given in a speech on Monday, a lack of foreign exchange has caused the value of imports to fall to $1.7 billion this year, from $2.2 billion last year. In 1989, before the disintegration of the Soviet bloc, which had long provided sustenance to Cuba, total imports valued over $8 billion.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact May Hinge on Border-Bond Plan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
In an effort to win support in Congress for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Clinton Administration plans to create a joint agency with the Mexican Government that would issue $6 billion to $8 billion worth of bonds to pay for the cleanup of the two countries' border, a senior Administration official said today.
"It's a new Mexico-U.S. binational authority," the official, who insisted on anonymity, said. "It would be like the Port Authority in New York -- it would be able to go into the market and float bonds paid for by user fees." 
 The border authority's bonds would be used to build treatment centers for sewage and for drinking water along the Rio Grande and other border-area rivers. Sewerage and water fees from local residents on both sides would be used to repay the bonds.
The border region is one of the most polluted in either country. Hundreds of little-regulated factories have sprung up in Mexico to serve American markets, and many pour sewage and other waste into rivers.
Some counties on the American side are among the poorest in this country, with limited availability of clean water and sewerage.
Environmentalists in the United States, fearing that the trade agreement may result in intensified business activity along the border, have demanded that the Administration assure cleanup of the region as the price for their political support. Such groups have estimated the cleanup costs as high as $30 billion, and it was not clear how they would react to the Administration estimate.
Top American negotiators have begun to discuss the idea with their Mexican counterparts. American deputy Cabinet secretaries and other senior Federal officials involved in the North American trade agreement reached a rough consensus favoring the border authority at a meeting on Tuesday, the senior official added.
The plan was worked out with the help of New York investment bankers who specialize in municipal bonds. But because the Administration has not completed work on the plan's legal details, no investment bank has been chosen to manage any of the bond issues and none will be soon.
Projects that do not generate enough money to repay the bonds will be subsidized in several ways to make up the difference, the Administration official said. Mexico will be able to borrow money from the Inter-American Development Bank, an institution like the World Bank that lends money in this hemisphere to poor countries' public works projects.
The United States is considering the possibility of guaranteeing repayment of the border projects' bonds, which would allow their issue at much lower interest rates than if they were ordinary revenue bonds. A second possibility is that the Federal Government would guarantee the new authority's bonds. A third way would be to set up an arm of the Inter-American Development Bank that would be allowed to lend on the United States side of the border.
The Administration's guiding principle for the new authority, and for other environmental programs, is that Washington would channel private money into the cleanup programs. "A lot of the work that has to be done on the border pays for itself," the Administration official said.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, is to meet here this week on the trade pact with his Mexican and Canadian counterparts. In addition to addressing the accord's costs, these officials will try to resolve disputes concerning pivotal labor and environmental-issue side agreements.
Mr. Kantor and other officials visited members of Congress this week in efforts to gain support for the side agreements, which are intended to prevent any of the three countries from allowing companies to violate their laws as a way of cutting costs.
The touchiest issue now involves whether companies or countries are to be penalized if they allow systematic abuse of labor and environmental laws. A possible compromise, already broached by American officials in talks with the Canadians and Mexicans, calls for initial fines on national governments. Only in cases of severe and persistent abuse, and after several legal proceedings, would more severe sanctions be imposed, like tariffs on imports.

HEADLINE: Party Lines Extra Hard and Fast

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Rarely have the two parties in Congress been so united in opposition to one another. Rarely have the political stakes been so high. And rarely has it been so uncertain which side was gaining the political advantage.
When the final version of President Clinton's economic program comes up for votes in the House of Representatives and the Senate next week, no amendments will be allowed. So the representatives and senators will have no choice but to vote for or against the entire package of tax increases and spending cuts. 
 Almost every Democrat will vote for it. Every single Republican will vote against it. As matters stand now, the measure will pass or fail by the narrowest of margins.
The Republicans are so unified that they make the Democrats appear to be sharply divided. That perception was strengthened Tuesday when Senator David L. Boren, a maverick Democrat from Oklahoma, stepped into the spotlight once more to trash the President's program.
But the fact is, not since World War II have Democrats in Congress been as steadfast as they have been this year.
When the deficit-reduction measure squeaked through the first time around, only 38 Democratic representatives and six Democratic senators voted against the President.
That means that 85 percent of the Democrats in the House and 89 percent of those in the Senate voted with the President, a remarkable show of party loyalty.
According to Congressional Quarterly, 90 percent of the Democrats in Congress have held the line this year on what the service calls party-unity votes, those votes when a majority of Democrats go one way and a majority of Republicans go the other.
By contrast, each year in Jimmy Carter's Presidency, the last time a Democrat was in the White House, fewer than 70 percent of the Democrats in Congress held ranks on such votes.
But on the budget and on several other big issues as well this year, every Republican voted against the President.
"A huge percentage of our people are sticking together," said Representative Vic Fazio of California, a member of the Democratic leadership. "The problem is that without any Republican votes, the cracks in the seams in our party become more evident."
Republicans got their noses out of joint early this year when President Clinton and his Democratic allies in Congress had the hubris to develop their budget plan without the courtesy of consulting any Republicans.
The Republicans gained confidence when they were able to defeat the President's economic stimulus plan with a filibuster in the Senate. It takes 60 votes to break a filibuster. The Democratic majority in the Senate is only 56 to 44. So as long as they stick together, the Republicans realize, they are unbeatable on most issues.
Fortunately for the Democrats, the rules prohibit a filibuster on the budget. But the Democrats' margin is small enough that seven defectors are enough to kill the legislation if Republicans remain solid.
In the House, the Democratic majority is slightly more comfortable, 258 to 176 with one independent, Bernard Sanders of Vermont, who almost always votes with the Democrats. But dozens of Democrats, mainly Southerners, come from very conservative, very Republican districts, and if more than about 40 of them switch sides on any issue, the Democrats lose.
The first time around, with all Republicans in opposition, the deficit-reduction legislation was passed by the House by a mere six votes and by the Senate on the strength of Vice President Al Gore's tie-breaking vote. Congressional scholars have not been able to find a single piece of legislation that became law in recent years when all the members of one party in the House and Senate voted against it.
 
Unifying Principle
 "We're not just trying to scheme and embarrass the President," said Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, a Republican who in years past often operated in a bipartisan fashion. What happened, he said, was that Mr. Clinton has run up against the one principle that unifies Republicans: that the Government is too big and too costly.
Maybe so, but it may be hardball politics, too. Republicans also seem to believe that if they vote solidly against higher taxes at every turn, they can ride that issue back into the White House in 1996 and perhaps into control of the Senate, if not the entire Congress.
For their part, the Democrats are sticking together because they feel they will carry the day if they can show that they can attack the country's problems and govern successfully when they finally control both the White House and Congress.
Which strategy is better in pure political terms is impossible to gauge at this stage.
Former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican, said in an interview the other day that the Republicans might be making a mistake as a policy matter to try to thwart the President at every turn but that it was probably good politics.
Even if the Clinton program is enacted, Mr. Rudman said, the budget deficit will still be over $200 billion in 1996, and Republicans will be able to say that the pain of tax increases and spending cuts had been futile.
Democrats say that if the Republicans remain intransigent, they can be portrayed as guardians of gridlock.
But ultimately, the success or failure of the parties' political strategies will turn on whether the economy strengthens.
If it does, Democrats will probably prevail in the midterm Congressional elections next year and in the Presidential election in 1996. They will be able to take credit for turning the economy around as Ronald Reagan did in 1984.
But if the economy turns sour, the Democrats will be blamed, and that is what the Republicans are banking on. "What's going to happen," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, is that the economy is going to go bad because of defense cuts and higher taxes. Then we can say, 'You should have done it our way.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma speaking to BoyScouts from his home state outside the Capitol. He told them he was receiving about 10,000 letters a day from his constituents about the President's economic plan. Mr. Boren has said he is uncertain whether he could support the compromise version. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
