HEADLINE: Blue Cross Plans a Rate Increase For Individuals by 20% or More

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 28

 BODY:
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey is preparing to raise rates for its 200,000 individual policyholders, possibly by 20 percent or more, a company spokesman said today.
While the spokesman, Fred Hillman, would not say exactly what the increases would be, he said they were necessary to make up for double-digit inflation in health-care costs and the loss of a subsidy the insurer had received from a surcharge on hospital bills. 
 Mr. Hillmann said there was no connection between the rate request being filed soon and the fact that Saturday is the day Blue Cross and Blue Shield and two other companies are scheduled to start selling policies under a revamped insurance law intended to make sure no one can be denied coverage for health reasons.
 
Increases Part of a Strategy
 However, a top aide to Gov. Jim Florio said the rate increases appeared to be part of a strategy to persuade customers to seek coverage in the company's new health maintenance organization policy, HMO Blue, which restricts the doctors and hospitals policyholders can use. Blue Cross and Blue Shield says the managed-care arrangement helps control the costs of health care better than is possible when people are allowed to choose their own doctors.
"The Governor feels if the increases are as rumors indicate, in the 25 to 30 percent range, those are outrageous," said Brenda Bacon, Governor Florio's top health-care adviser. "We think this is a cruel marketing strategy."
Mr. Hillmann said Ms. Bacon was reacting to speculation because nothing had been filed.
He said the Florio administration had been keeping rates low for political purposes.
"You put your head in the sand if you don't acknowledge health care costs inflated in double digits," he said.
He said the increases would take effect in five or six weeks at the earliest, and possibly later when policies come up for renewal.
Under a new health-care law enacted in November, Blue Cross and Blue Shield no longer needs state approval to raise rates, as long as the insurer provides documentation that at least 75 cents of every premium dollar will be paid out in claims. The previous ratio had been in the 90 percent range, so there should be no problem with the increases, Mr. Hillmann said.
Previously, increases had to be granted by the Department of Insurance and could be challenged by the public advocate.
During hearings on the new law, the Blue Cross president, John Petillo, said increases would not exceed inflation. Mr. Hillmann said he was referring to health-care cost inflation, not the consumer price index.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield also announced the price it plans to charge for its Basic Blue insurance policy, which will cover 30 days of hospitalization and 50 percent of the cost of doctor visits.
The plan will cost about $1,300 a year for individuals, $2,400 a year for a parent and child and $3,300 for a family.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Net Surges At Chrysler And Ford

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 28

 BODY:
Providing more evidence of the strong rebound in auto sales, the Ford Motor Company reported today that its earnings had doubled in the second quarter, while the Chrysler Corporation said its profit was nearly four times the level of a year ago.
Ford and Chrysler each benefited from the recovering automotive demand in North America. But Ford, which relies heavily on overseas operations, said it lost money in Europe, where auto sales were off drastically from a year ago. Chrysler, which does not have significant European operations, escaped the negative impact of Europe's weak economy.
 
Earnings Meet Forecasts
 The General Motors Corporation, the largest auto maker in the world, is expected to announce improved earnings on Thursday but, like Ford, will almost certainly be hurt by poor sales in Europe. The three principal nonautomotive subsidiaries of G.M. posted healthy earnings reports today. 
 Both the Ford and Chrysler earnings were in line with analysts' forecasts, but Chrysler stock dropped sharply in heavy trading after the earnings were announced. The stock fell $2, to $42.625, with more than nine million shares traded, making it the second-most-active stock on the New York Stock Exchange.
Neither Chrysler executives nor analysts had a satisfactory explanation for the trading; the latter suggested that traders with short-term perspectives had influenced the selling. Ford shares rose 75 cents, to $52.
The strong showing of the auto industry comes as contract talks continued between the Big Three and the United Automobile Workers union. David N. McCammon, the vice president for finance at Ford, said the latest profit picture should not be viewed by the union as a horn of plenty.
 
'Several Tough Years'
 "We have gone through several tough years," Mr. McCammon said at a news conference. "We have to make money to afford wages and new product programs."
Speaking about the European economy, Harold A. Poling, the chairman of Ford, said in a statement, "I'm not sure we have seen the bottom there yet."
But the domestic automotive operations were a different story. Ford said it had a net profit of $367 million for the quarter, compared with earnings of $42 million for the comparable period a year ago. Overseas automotive operations earned $28 million, down from $61 million.
Ford's financial services group posted $380 million in net profit, compared with $284 million last year. Over all, Ford's net profit was $775 million, or $1.43 a common share, roughly double last year's profit of $387 million, or 70 cents a share.
Ford's revenue was $29.4 billion in the quarter, up 9.7 percent from $26.8 billion in the comparable period a year ago. Worldwide factory sales of vehicles were 1,675,000, up from 1,640,000 a year ago.
Pleased with the increase in sales volume, Mr. McCammon said Ford hoped to maintain its pricing as demand picked up. The auto maker is paying about $750 in incentives per vehicle sold in the United States, he said. He also rebutted criticism from Wall Street that Ford's sales were made up of a great deal of leases, which carry an uncertain future liability.
"These aren't fleet sales; they're retail sales being financed through leases," he said. "We are very conservative in how we value the vehicles at the end of their leases. And we think this gives us a good chance to sell our customers another vehicle when the lease expires."
Chrysler reported second-quarter net income of $685 million, or $1.86 a common share, which included after-tax gains of $71 million from the sale of its stake in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and $39 million from the sale of some plastics operations.
Last year, Chrysler earned $178 million, or 54 cents a share, in the period. Chrysler's revenue for the quarter was $11.03 billion, up 18.5 percent from $9.31 billion in the comparable period a year ago. Worldwide factory sales were 657,050 vehicles, compared with 575,928 vehicles last year.
Robert J. Eaton, the chairman of Chrysler, said the strong results in the quarter were "were marked by tremendous market acceptance of our new products." The auto maker's L/H sedans, mini-vans and Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicle helped boost its share of the new-vehicle market in the United States and Canada to 15.4 percent, up from 13.3 percent a year ago.
 
New Pickup Debuts
 Tuesday, the first new Dodge Ram pickup truck rolled off the assembly line in Warren, Mich. The truck is Chrysler's first new pickup design in 15 years.
The Chrysler Financial Corporation said earnings for the quarter fell to $44 million, from $49 million in the comparable period a year ago.
Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch, said the Chrysler results were on target, but added that some investors were interested in taking profits now because the third quarter is typically weak because of lost production as lines are converted to new models.

HEADLINE: Bienvenidos a los Suburbios;
Increasingly, New York's Outskirts Take On a Latin Accent

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
A rich man once advised Rudy Rodriguez, "Follow the sun and always stay close to where the wealthy people live, because you will find money there."
So after Mr. Rodriguez left Bogota, Colombia, he settled in 1973 in this gritty harbor village on Long Island Sound, sandwiched between two of the nation's most prosperous towns -- Greenwich, Conn., and Rye, N.Y. He took jobs for people in those towns, mowing their lawns, shampooing their carpets, driving their limousines and doing other manual labor. 
 Eventually, Mr. Rodriguez, now 43, earned enough to set up a luncheonette called Rudy's Express, to buy a $300,000 home across the state line in Old Greenwich and to bring in 15 relatives.
"We came here with no papers, no money, no friends, and we make it," said Mr. Rodriguez, who boasts that he once chauffeured George Bush and Sylvester Stallone.
 
Exodus to Suburbia
 In the last decade, thousands of immigrants like Mr. Rodriguez have come from Central and South America to search for opportunities in the New York City suburbs, and their presence has reshaped the cultures and economies of Westchester County, northern New Jersey and southwestern Connecticut.
The distinctly Hispanic accent is apparent not just in industrial cities like Yonkers, Bridgeport or Jersey City, but in more suburban places that still offer a critical mass of cheap housing and nearby jobs.
Even Greenwich saw a doubling of its small Hispanic population during the 1980's, to 2,583, and New Jersey's Somerset County, whose hills are favored by horse riders like Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, experienced a 149 percent surge, to 10,187. The increase in Somerset, says James W. Hughes, a professor of planning at Rutgers University, was attributable to the burgeoning office complexes along Route 287 that drew both white-collar workers and the blue-collar people needed to maintain them.
Many of the Hispanic suburbanites are themselves middle class. They have chosen the suburbs because, like Esmeralda Santiago, whose book "When I Was Puerto Rican," is to be published soon, they prefer greener settings reminiscent of home. In almost-rural villages like Katonah, N.Y., where Ms. Santiago lives, that can also mean isolation from other Hispanic people, however.
"You are here, but not surrounded by people who can celebrate your success," she said. "There is a sense that there is a part of me I can't express."
 
Merengue on Main Street
 Perhaps no place illustrates the fortified Hispanic presence in the New York suburbs better than Port Chester, whose Hispanic population doubled in the 1980's to 7,500, or 30 percent of its 25,000 residents.
The evidence is written across the face of Main Street. A decade ago, its boarded-up storefronts reflected the decay of a village that had lost employers like the Life Savers candy factory. But Main Street has come alive again with Peruvian, Colombian, Mexican and Salvadoran restaurants, two botanicas that sell folk herbs, and a covey of grocery stores, travel agencies and discotecas that cater to Spanish-speakers. Open a door, and the boisterous sounds of merengue and salsa come tumbling out.
Kelly's Taxi Service is owned by a Salvadoran. The Blockbuster Video outlet has a Spanish-language section. The local newspaper, The Westmore News, started a free Spanish monthly edited by a Peruvian journalism student.
"I see new immigrants moving in, then opening up stores, taking over stores originally owned by Italians," said Richard Abel, the publisher of the newspaper and the Spanish monthly, America Latina. "Those immigrant kids will then move up the ladder. It's the same cycle. Ideally, in the long run, this paper will turn English."
This summer saw the start of a Saturday soccer league at Columbus Park, where teams and rooters are sorted by nationalities. The school system, with 43 percent of its 2,953 students bearing Hispanic surnames, has 16 bilingual teachers and, at one school, requires English-speaking students to take 45 minutes of Spanish daily.
Police Chief Carl P. Verrastro, who has hired two Hispanic officers and keeps a Berlitz dictionary at hand, speaks of the "culture shock" his 58 officers go through in a hybrid village, with its mix of ethnic backgrounds and patches of wealth and poverty.
"An officer may go to one call at a $300,000 home that involves a family dispute," he said. "The next minute you're in the other end of town in a situation you might encounter in the South Bronx."
 
Tension and Exploitation
 Along with the cultural effervescence, the Latinization of the suburbs has brought a host of tensions.
The March mayoral campaign here featured a heated debate about the Central American migrants who come for the spring and summer to tend suburban lawns while living illegally in attics and basements, often in the homes of retired couples. Investigators looking into an apparent vendetta murder involving Mexican immigrants stumbled upon a room that held 10 boarders who slept in shifts on mattresses on the floor, paying $150 a week each.
"I've been told that those conditions are better than they were living in back home," said Chief Verrastro. "But this is America and people shouldn't have to live that way."
Mayor John Branca has ordered a crackdown on illegal dwellings. But Luis Andrew Penichet, president of Westchester County's Hispanic Advisory Board -- 10 percent of Westchester's 875,000 people are Hispanic -- has cautioned him to blame exploitative landlords, not the workers.
An informal labor market reminiscent of longshoremen's shape-ups has sprouted on Poningo Street. Men cluster at one corner waiting for gardeners and building contractors driving by in pickup trucks to offer them a day's work, usually in the homes of Rye and Greenwich. These off-the-books jobs may deprive the state of taxes, but the men can be exploited, too, when some bosses renege on pay.
The influx of immigrants has challenged the village to familiarize immigrants with the tacit codes of the suburbs and to acquaint longtime residents with the immigrants' different mores. Chief Verrastro and leaders of a Hispanic group have developed a short flier to tell immigrants what is and is not considered acceptable -- explaining that public drinking is against the law, for example. At the same time, the police have had to remind some residents that outdoor gatherings, common in tropical countries, are not illegal unless they block the street.
 
'We Came Here to Work'
 "We're loud," says Jose Santos, a 41-year-old Dominican who owns two groceries and recently ran for village trustee. "If we play music, we like the whole neighborhood to hear. We like to have a beer like you have a soda. But we have to understand what are the home rules. If you hit your wife in the country, you can't hit your wife here."
At the same time, some immigrants complain that the police are too quick to arrest them. Frank Barcenes, 37, recently opened Rinconcito Salvadoreno, a narrow Main Street restaurant, so the village's Salvadorans could gather in a clean place with familiar foods, like brown sugar wrapped in corn husks. When a crowd gathered outside his store on July 4, Mr. Barcenes said the police were needlessly rough in breaking them up.
"They were trying to clear the sidewalk, but they were treating people like animals," he said.
Some Americans, says Mr. Barcenes, have misconceptions about the immigrants and why they are here. "We came here to work," he said. "We do not have access to welfare. Most of us came illegally, so we have to work. There's no other way to survive."
Port Chester's Hispanic community grew out of a nucleus of Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's rule in the early 1960s and came here to work at a string of waterfront plants. Though many of those plants have closed, Port Chester's economy would wither without Hispanic workers.
The village's cheap commercial rents have made it a haven for restaurant owners who know that customers will drive into the most raffish neighborhoods for good food. Pearl of the Atlantic, in a secluded spot along the Byram River, serves Portuguese paella, but its chef is Peruvian, a waitress is Bolivian, a dishwasher Salvadoran, and a busboy Honduran.
"I can never find Americans to wash dishes," said the owner, Lucia Carlos, whose parents are from Portugal. "Nobody's going to work for $5 or $6 an hour."
 
Success Through Hard Work
 In politics, the Hispanic residents here have so far exerted little weight. In the village election, fewer than 500 of the 3,500 votes were cast by Hispanic voters, Mayor Branca estimates. Mr. Santos, the grocer, lost his bid for trustee. Mr. Penichet, of the county advisory board, guesses that even many of those who are here legally work at two or more jobs daily and don't consider voting a priority.
For some Hispanic residents, success through hard work has translated into conservatism. Now a citizen, Mr. Rodriguez faults America for its welfare policies. "We are creating a dependent society because the incentive to do something is dead," he said. "Why should I work if I can get a check and food stamps? I have to be stupid."
One feeling that never seems to abate is a yearning to return to the homeland, even if the immigrants' memories include tyrannical political leaders and pay scales of $1 a day. "You cannot get an airplane space for Christmas anywhere in South America," said Roberto Portal, a Peruvian who owns New Horizons Travel. "We go to our country and have the greatest time of our lives, and then we go back to reality."
Still, Port Chester has come to grow on him and other Hispanic immigrants.
"Twenty years ago, if you saw a Hispanic person, you held him and said 'I'm Spanish,' " Mr. Portal said with a laugh. "Now, we are so many that if we see a Hispanic, we go across the street."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 12.01 Points in a Mixed Market

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Despite several strong earnings reports, the stock market was mixed yesterday. Most leading market indicators rose slightly, but the Dow Jones industrial average fell further from Monday's record high.
"It's a market that is really very stock-specific," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston. "We're still in that trading range we've been in for so long, with an upward bias." 
 As jumpy investors flee companies that issue soft earnings reports, Mr. Freedman said, long-term investors have an opportunity to buy good stocks at low prices. He cited Novell, which makes software that controls computer networks, as an example of a good value. On Tuesday, Novell's stock hit a 52-week low, at 17 5/8, after the company announced that third-quarter earnings would not meet expectations.
 
 
'Quality Company
 "In the long term, it's a quality company, and should do fairly well," Mr. Freedman said. Yesterday, its stock rose 1 1/8, to 19 1/2, in active trading.
With I.B.M. giving back some of the gains it made on Tuesday, falling 1 5/8, to 44, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 12.01 points to close at 3,553.45. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks fell 1.05 points, to 447.19, but the Nasdaq composite index gained 4.59 points to close at 705.59. Trading was heavy, with 273.1 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 256.8 million shares on Tuesday.
The announcement that Merck would buy Medco Containment Services hurt the Dow but helped the Nasdaq index, as Merck fell 1 3/8, to 30 3/4, and Medco, a Nasdaq issue, gained 4 3/8, to 34 1/8.
After pleasantly surprising investors with improved second-quarter earnings, Eastman Kodak gained 1 3/8, to 52 3/8. MBNA, a credit card issuer, also benefited from a strong second-quarter report. Its stock advanced 2 1/2, to 31.
Du Pont reported that second-quarter profit was up 11 percent, at $537 million, which was below expectations. Its stock slid 1 3/8, to 47 1/4.
But earnings reports did not tell the whole story yesterday. Caterpillar, the manufacturer of construction equipment, fell 1 1/8, to 77 7/8. The stock has declined steadily since its close at 80 1/4 on Friday, as stocks in other companies in the same industry have also fallen. Deere, for example, fell 3/8 yesterday to 64 -- down from 65 1/8 on Friday.
 
 
Earnings Projections Cited
 The reason for the slide in the construction-machinery sector may be because investors have been alarmed by company warnings that there will probably be a decline in third- and fourth-quarter earnings.
Such drops are a normal part of the companies' cycle, because of the seasonal nature of their business, said Karen A. Ubelhart, a senior vice president of Lehman Brothers. This year, the companies were evidently afraid that investors had forgotten that fact.
"They've been worried that people would say, 'There's not going to be a third-quarter slowdown this year because of the economy,' " Ms. Ubelhart said. "And they're saying, 'Oh, yes there will.' "

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Prices at 3-Year Highs As Economic Signs Improve

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Silver prices climbed yesterday to their highest levels in more than three years as solid economic news combined with strong supply and demand.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for September delivery jumped 11 cents, to a new intraday high of $5.195 an ounce, before closing 8.5 cents higher at $5.17. 
 "Investment demand is particularly strong for silver, as well as for the other precious metals," said Fred Demler of Paine Webber, who said prices had not been this high since early 1990.
 
Gold Moves Higher
Gold prices also advanced, partly as a result of a threatened South African miners' strike vote next week. August gold rose $2.20, to $393.40 an ounce.
Mr. Demler said the prices of both metals seemed to have broken out of a consolidation phase, after rising sharply earlier this year on inflation fears.
Most recently, currency turmoil in Europe and Russia had created a rush by investors to the safe haven of gold and silver.
Silver prices have shown particular volatility lately, Mr. Demler said, reflecting more balanced supply and demand for silver and its use by many industries.
The unexpectedly strong 3.8 percent rise in durable goods orders for June, which reflects orders for products that last more than three years, helped silver rally, analysts said.
"Underlying industrial demand for silver looks constructive," Mr. Demler added.
For the second consecutive day, soybean prices plummeted on the improved weather forecasts for the rain-soaked Midwest and the drought-stricken Southeast.
August soybeans declined 14 cents, to $6.88 3/4 a bushel; September corn fell 3.25 cents, to $2.41 1/4, and September wheat dropped 5.75 cents, to $3.1575 a bushel.
Oil prices dropped despite a bullish report showing a decline in domestic stocks of crude oil and strong demand for gasoline.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, September oil declined 19 cents, to $18.23 a barrel; August heating oil eased 0.29 cent, to 51.35 cents a gallon, and August unleaded gas dropped 0.55 cent, to 52.39 cents a gallon. September natural gas rose 3 cents, to $2.14 for a million British thermal units.

HEADLINE: Edward Wilson, 84, Ad Agency Officer And a Civic Leader

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Edward G. Wilson, a retired executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson advertising agency and a civic leader, died at home on Saturday. He was 84 and lived in Sharon, Conn.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Wilson created Thompson's legal department and held numerous posts in the firm as it grew to become the world's largest advertising agency and expanded with the advent of radio and television.
He was general counsel, director, senior vice president, corporate secretary and head of the international division. One assignment, when ad agencies produced broadcast programs, was to preview Walter Winchell's Sunday night radio scripts.
After retiring in 1971, Mr. Wilson devoted much of his time to his alma mater, Earlham College, where he became board chairman.
 
Served on Several Boards
 He was a founding trustee of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists Pension and Welfare Funds, secretary of the Association of Governing Boards of Universities and Colleges and an officer of the International Chamber of Commerce. He also served on the boards of State Charities Aid Association, Manhattan Society for Mental Health and the Common Fund.
Mr. Wilson was born in Richmond, Ind. After graduating from Earlham, he started working at Thompson in 1930. After earning a law degree in night classes at New York University, he worked two years for the Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Lumbard law firm, then returned to Thompson.
In World War II he served in the Office of Strategic Services, where he reached the rank of lieutenant, commanded the agency's Cairo station, worked with Gen. William J. Donovan on Asian affairs, and received the Legion of Merit Award.
His survivors include his wife of 60 years, the former Jane Johnson; a son, Edward F., of Kansas City, Mo., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Big Japanese Railroad's Stock Will Have An Eager, Built-In Clientele.

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
FOR most people who live in Japan's urban areas, the morning-rush-hour ritual involves rail-station employees using fullback-like techniques to squash hapless passengers into cars as the doors squeeze past their errant briefcases, articles of clothing and limbs.
But what the system lacks in comfort, it makes up for as one of the most efficient railroads in the world, which is why the Government's plans to privatize the largest leg of its national rail system in September has drawn a good deal of interest in an otherwise wobbly stock market. 
 After six years of planning and several false starts, Tokyo plans to sell half of the four million shares it owns in the East Japan Railway Company, known as JR East. The first 600,000 shares will be auctioned, and the remaining 1.4 million sold at a fixed price, in one of the largest and most important privatizations in years.
A failure of the JR East offering could badly hurt the overall stock market and damage the Finance Ministry's credibility.
Individual investors driven to the sidelines in the first stages of the stock market's plunge nearly four years ago are expected to be among those purchasing JR East shares.
"If this issue failed, it would be a national crisis," said Jesper Koll, senior economist here with S. G. Warburg Securities. "They are desperate to prove that the Japanese stock market can function in the economic sense, channeling savings to investments."
This is a nation of railroads. Each Japanese travels an average of 1,800 miles a year on the rail, compared with just over 600 miles per Frenchman and 48 miles for each American. Japan's metropolitan regions are remarkably dense, allowing JR East to carry many more passengers than the national railroads of Germany, France, Britain and Switzerland with only a fraction of their employees and far fewer miles of track.
JR East was one of seven systems created when Japan National Railways was broken up in 1987 as it edged toward bankruptcy. It had a long-term debt of 37.2 trillion yen, now equivalent to almost $350 billion.
JR East is the biggest and among the most promising of the new operating units, serving the region from Tokyo north to the top of Honshu, the main island. There are two bullet-train lines, as well as a spider's web of commuter lines running through the Tokyo region.
In the fiscal year that ended on March 31, JR East had pretax profits of 100.9 billion yen, the equivalent of $943 million, and it projects a very small increase this year, to 101.2 billion yen. It also has total long-term debt of more than 5.1 trillion yen -- almost $50 billion.
But the company is heavily regulated, with a virtual monopoly on most routes. The Government can decree its profitability by setting rates.
Robert Rowland, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities here, said that JR East stock could fetch as much as 550,000 yen a share, but that efforts to restrain the price will probably keep it below 400,000 yen. He expects the stock to show solid if unspectacular growth and to benefit from Government support.
The Finance Ministry has already registered its concern for the market's overall health by forcing a number of pension funds it controls to purchase huge numbers of shares of stock.
"It's like buying a utility," Mr. Rowland said. "It's something you buy and hold."
One worry is that the offering may just be too big in a fragile market. It could bring in as much as 600 billion yen, compared with 431 billion yen corporate Japan raised from the issues of all new securities in April, said Jeff Bahrenburg, senior market strategist at Merrill Lynch Japan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Bonds Rise Modestly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Government bond prices rose modestly yesterday in seesaw trading as the market responded to reports that President Clinton was considering an executive order to control entitlement spending.
The news raised expectations for substantial deficit reduction, helping fuel stronger-than-expected investor demand at the Treasury's auction of new five-year notes. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose 13/32 point, or $4.06 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.65 percent from Tuesday's 6.67 percent.
Bond trading got off to a rocky start after the Commerce Department reported that orders to factories for durable goods jumped by a larger-than-expected 3.8 percent in June.
That raised the possibility that the economy was growing at an inflationary pace, a prospect that worried bond investors. Inflation can erode the value of fixed-income securities.
But bond prices recovered as details of the report emerged, economists said. Excluding a 15.1 percent rise in transportation equipment, orders rose just three-tenths of 1 percent in June, following a 1.8 percent decline in May.
Buying picked up further following the late-morning news of Mr. Clinton's support for an executive order to control mandatory spending, known as entitlements.
A substantial reduction in the Federal deficit would bolster the value of existing bonds because the Treasury could pare its sales of new securities, decreasing supply in the secondary market.
 
A Bullish Tone in Auction
 The bullish tone continued into the Government auction. The Treasury sold $11 billion in five-year notes at a yield of 5.25 percent, well within expectations. The bid-to-cover ratio for the five-year note, a measure of demand that compares the number of bids submitted with those accepted, was 2.77 to 1, better than the 2.60 average of the previous 10 auctions.
But prices began to decline again after the White House softened the tone of earlier reports, saying an executive order is just one of several options President Clinton is considering to control the deficit.
Still, the market maintained a strong tone as investors reasoned that even the threat of an executive order could increase chances for passage of the budget package in Congress.
Short-term Treasuries ranged from 1/16 point to 3/32 point higher, while intermediate maturities rose from 3/16 point to 7/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.14 percent as the discount dropped 0.02 percentage point, to 3.08 percent. Six-month yields fell to 3.32 percent as the discount fell 0.02 point, to 3.23 percent. One-year yields dropped to 3.58 percent as the discount fell 0.01 point, to 3.45 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 6/32 , unchanged from late Tuesday. The average yield to maturity held at 5.82 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark And Softens Versus the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against European currencies yesterday after a decline in German money market rates diffused pressure within Europe's Monetary System.
It also softened against the yen as former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, President Clinton's choice as ambassador to Tokyo, expressed concern over the American-Japan trade gap. 
 The dollar weakened despite a Bundesbank move to ease credit by allowing a key money market rate to drop. Dealers said the move by the Bundesbank suggested that it would cut its official discount rate, currently at 6.75 percent, by a half-point when it meets on Thursday for its regular council meeting.
"The Bundesbank is almost forced to cut," said Jeremy Hawkins, senior economic adviser at BankAmerica in London.
Normally, lower German rates would spur dollar purchases by making mark-denominated assets relatively less attractive. But dealers said the German easing led to a waning of European currency tensions, reducing the dollar's status as a safe-haven currency.
 
Late Trading in New York
The dollar closed at 1.7178 marks in New York, down from 1.7271 marks Tuesday. Earlier in London, the dollar finished at 1.7185 marks versus 1.7250 marks Tuesday.
In comments that pushed up the yen, Mr. Mondale cited the importance of cutting the trade gap with Japan at his Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmation hearing for the post of ambassador to Japan. While there was no direct comment on the dollar-yen relationship, his testimony was seen as supportive of a strong yen, which would tend to ease the trade imbalance.
In reaction, the dollar fell as low as 104.85 yen in New York trading -- just above its record low of 104.80 yen. But the dollar later bounced back to 105.80 yen, still below the 106.10-yen level of late Tuesday.
The French franc and Spanish peseta, lately the target of speculators betting these currencies will be devalued, firmed today on news of easier German interest rates. Softer rates in Germany allow other European countries to lower rates without undermining currency parities.
The British pound rose in New York to $1.4950, above $1.4890 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Study in Milken's Name;
Overpaid Executives? Takes One to Know

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Milken Institute for Job and Capital Formation said yesterday that Americans cited "corporate executives being paid too much" as a leading cause of job losses.
The institute, a private, nonprofit research group, may seem an unlikely source for assertions that executives are being paid too much money. It is named for its chairman, Michael R. Milken, who in 1987 alone was paid $550 million in salary and bonuses by his former firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. 
 The Milken Institute says high executive pay remains an "emotionally charged fairness issue that many people fail to look at objectively." It did not elaborate.
The institute describes its aim as "improving economic growth through job creation and capital formation." It released findings yesterday of its second annual jobs survey, which it conducted with Princeton Survey Research.
Mr. Milken transformed the junk bond market in the 1980's. The Government began investigating him in 1986 for possible violations of securities laws.
Mr. Milken pleaded guilty in 1990 to six felonies related to Federal securities law violations. He recently concluded serving a prison sentence in California.
Among other projects, he has talked about starting a cable television network with Michael Jackson, the pop singer.
Mr. Milken hardly needs publicity. He was the subject of at least three books published in the last few years, including "Den of Thieves," a best seller. And Robert De Niro's production company has a movie of Mr. Milken's life in the works, with the Oscar-winning actor talking about playing the lead role.

HEADLINE: ON THE BUS WITH: Merle Haggard;
Under the Growl, a Crooner

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va.

 BODY:
THE Hag is talking apocalypse. "It's like a war zone coming back here," he says.
"Back here" is the East Coast, and Merle Haggard, the country music legend, has descended from his Northern California ranch to cover it by bus, armed with his guitar. 
 The enemies outside the bus windows are many: traffic jams, overpopulation, immigrants -- those he calls "people that can't speak English, and they look like they're starving to death and they'll take anything from you if they could."
Mr. Haggard has been warning of American decline in his blunt, proud, sometimes inflammatory way since at least 1969. That's when he exploded to fame with "Okie From Muskogee," a nationalistic anthem that frowned on marijuana, hippies, love beads and the 60's Zeitgeist in general.
But that chaos "was just the evening of it all," Mr. Haggard says. "I think we're into the dead of night now." A conversation with Mr. Haggard follows this pattern of oblique, often mixed but clearly foreboding metaphor. "The snowball effect I'm talking about is like if you jump out of an airplane," he says, referring to the nation's accumulating problems. "It's just like, compared to the trip down, the ground rush."
He leans forward with a creased, handsome face and stunning blue eyes. "I think you know what I'm talking about," he says.
After three decades of relentless road and studio work, Mr. Haggard has secured his place in country music history. But his position with his creditors is a bit more precarious.
He is 56, $5 million in debt and mired in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy-protection proceeding. He is feuding with his label, Curb Records, and he hasn't had a new release in three years.
So while younger country artists are enjoying unprecedented wealth and popularity, Mr. Haggard is working state fairs and clubs as small as the Birchmere, a 350-seat folk house here. "Forty-one No. 1 records and $5 million down," he says. "How does that compute?"
Almost 400 singers have recorded his 1969 classic, "Today I Started Loving You Again," but tonight his own version will be marred by a waitress five feet from the stage who barks, "Cheeseburger!"
Although Mr. Haggard's 10-member band is known as the Strangers, it is an odd title for a group that includes musicians who have toured with him for 30 years. Indeed, there isn't a stranger in sight.
He is accompanied on stage by Bonnie Owens, one of his four ex-wives. His son Noel is his warm-up act. Dean Holloway, his childhood chum, and Fuzzy Owen, his first manager, are along for the ride.
Playing 100 venues in a typical year, Mr. Haggard lives about half his life out of his customized bus, the Super Chief. The band travels in theChief, an accompanying bus with nine submarine-style sleeping slots and a bag of pretzels splayed open on the kitchen table beside a huge squeeze bottle of French's mustard.
An air of quaint informality prevails, as Ms. Owens powders her face and Noel Haggard unpacks an iron to crease his jeans. Biff Adam, Mr. Haggard's publicist (also his drummer and bus driver), has forgotten about a scheduled interview, so he drafts Ms. Owens as a stand-in until he can rouse the legend. "Bonnie, tell him something about Merle," he says.
Ms. Owens, a sparkling woman with mustard on her shirt, addresses her transition from wife to supporting vocalist. "It's not a touching relationship," she says. "Sometimes he's like my kid; sometimes he's like my brother."
What's clear is that Mr. Haggard's retinue idolizes him.
"One of the best damn singers in the world," says Norm Hamlett, his steel guitarist, who sports a silver belt buckle that says simply "Hag."
"The best singer," Ms. Owens says.
Mr. Haggard has recorded more than 70 albums and has more No. 1 hits than any country singer besides Conway Twitty. He is a very good guitarist, a great songwriter and a singer for the ages. He is also an old-fashioned bandleader (adept at country jazz and country blues) and an utterly unpredictable performer.
Mr. Haggard will start one song, grow bored and suddenly switch to another, forcing the band to scurry along as his nods call forth solos on fiddle or horn, steel or electric guitar.
Someone once called his show "polished." Mr. Haggard was insulted.
The core Haggard collection includes not just "Okie" but songs like "The Fightin' Side of Me," in which Mr. Haggard complains about "some squirrely guy" who won't fight to defend his country, and "Workin' Man Blues," in which he penned a quintessential line of blue-collar resentment:
"Hey, hey, the workin' man, the workin' man like me/I ain't never been on welfare, and that's one place I won't be."
Many critics have lamented his reputation for right-wing populism, arguing that it has obscured dozens of great songs on other themes. Mr. Haggard sings sentimentally of family, mournfully and mischievously of love and enticingly of adventure -- the Jimmie Rodgers, hop-a-freight-train kind.
He will celebrate the virtues of Mama in one track and those of "Make Up and Faded Blue Jeans" in the next. He can be as sentimental as Norman Rockwell, as rebellious as Woody Guthrie or as jaded as the honky-tonks where many of his songs are situated.
What's consistent is the magic of his voice, which growls one moment, yodels the next and distills down to something pure and sweet and sad, a crooner's croon.
"What you hear is real, lower-class struggle," says Bill Ivey, the director of the Country Music Foundation in Nashville. "You just get the sense that all the history he's absorbed, all the hard living, all the personal struggles -- it just gets focused, through a funnel, into his voice."
Mr. Haggard also has what Mr. Ivey calls "an authentic country music biography," meaning that while Mary-Chapin Carpenter attended Brown University, Mr. Haggard attended San Quentin.
His parents were Oklahoma farmers who moved near Bakersfield, Calif., in 1935, two years before his birth. The family lived in a converted railroad boxcar. His father died when Merle was 9. Mr. Haggard hopped his first freight train a year later, and he hasn't slowed much since.
Starting at age 14, he resided at (and escaped from) a series of increasingly tough penal institutions, where he was sent first for truancy and later for car theft and burglary.
Mr. Haggard was behind bars when each of his first two children was born. His ticket to San Quentin got punched one night when he got so drunk he tried to burglarize a nightclub that was still open. He was 23 when he was paroled in 1960, after serving almost three years.
Mr. Haggard calls himself one of the few people prison has straightened out. But his frank autobiography ("Sing Me Back Home," Times Books, 1981) makes clear that this straightening is a relative matter.
There have been bouts of hard drinking and numerous marital infidelities. There have been his legendary failures to appear at his own concerts. (He once walked out on "The Ed Sullivan Show" because he thought the choreographers were making him look effeminate.)
There has also been violence. Mr. Haggard writes that he was once trying to backhand his first wife when she jumped from a car traveling 60 miles an hour. And that wasn't their worst fight.
So while it might be hard for some artists to sing convincingly of hard times while surrounded by wealth and fame, that doesn't seem to have been a problem for Mr. Haggard.
"Being vocal, disgusted and emotionally drained -- all those things lend themselves to good music," he says.
While the critics may fear that Mr. Haggard's politics drown out his music, he does not seem concerned. When he emerges for a half-hour chat, he seems to have a frank and unflattering phrase for almost everyone.
On immigration: "If we don't stop it, then there's not going to be anything here that people want to come to."
On Japanese investors in northern California: "The people we fought in World War II, remember those people? They're taking over that country up there."
Mr. Haggard denounces President Clinton's plans to close military bases and accept homosexuals in the armed services as so much self-evident nonsense, and, perhaps colored by his own unfortunate finances, he is predicting a global depression.
"Some sort of economic tumble has got to be just around the corner," he says. "I'm talking something big, global, you know."
Angry at George Bush for raising taxes, Mr. Haggard said he probably would have voted for Ross Perot if he was the kind of person who voted. But he is not.
Mr. Haggard was similarly dismissive of contemporary country music. "I don't listen to very much of it," he says, arguing that the airwaves are filled with "drugstore music" that calls itself country just to gain play time.
Garth Brooks? "He's a nice enough boy," Mr. Haggard says. "He's not turning my crank."
Mary-Chapin Carpenter? "I don't know much about her," he says. "I like the way she looks." He does like Alan Jackson, John Anderson and Clint Black.
Mr. Haggard is hoping to patch things up with his record company and have an album out by fall, when he is scheduled to marry for the fifth time. The album, he said, ought to rescue him from his debts, which he blames on both his recording drought and his accountants.
Meanwhile, there is the life of prison, adultery and disarray, and the songs of Mama, prayer and patriotic pride. How to reconcile the two?
"There's the guy I'd love to be and the guy I am," he says. "I'm somewhere in between, in deep water, you know, swimming to the other shore."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Being vocal and disgusted and emotionally drained -- those things lend themselves to good music," Merle Haggard says. (pg. C1); Merle Haggard at the Birchmere, a folk-music club in Alexandria, Va. (pg. C8) (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Final Workout Ends in Tragedy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 28

 BODY:
Deo Djossou, the forward for the Northeastern University Huskies, arrived at the Celtics' practice gym shortly after 6 P.M. Tuesday evening for a low-key workout with Reggie Lewis, his friend and mentor.
"We must have missed him by 15 minutes," Djossou said today in a somber voice. 
 Lewis, who was the Huskies' career-leading scorer before he moved on to become captain of the Celtics, was shooting baskets with a few current players from his college team when he collapsed and then died.
For the past two summers he had played informal pickup games with the Huskies. But since Lewis collapsed during a playoff game in April, there had been no practices this summer.
 
Ready to Work Out
 "He said he was ready to work out," said Djossou, who said he spoke to Lewis over the weekend. "This would have been the first time this summer."
So Djossou, along with a few teammates and friends, traveled to the gym where the Celtics practice, at Brandeis University in Waltham. At first, when they did not find Lewis, they thought they were late. Then they heard the news.
Today they tried to talk through their grief.
"Reggie was special," said Djossou, who will be a senior this year. "He was encouraging, telling me what I needed to do to progress my game. I was nervous the first time I played with him, but he made me comfortable."
 
'The Whole City Is Quiet'
 "It hurts now," he said. "The whole city is quiet."
Amir Weiss, a 20-year-old junior at Brandeis majoring in economics, said he was playing ball in the Shapiro Gymnasium with a few friends when he saw Lewis collapse at around 5:05 P.M.
"I was shooting hoops on the court next to him and every once in a while I'd take a look over at him," Weiss said. "He seemed to be doing great. He was kidding around, giving high fives, taking 3-point shots.
"He wasn't even sweating," he said, adding that Lewis had someone else running after rebounds. "He was taking it so easy. He wasn't running.
"Next thing I knew I heard this large slurping sound. I turned around and saw Reggie on the floor, trying to breathe. His arms were shaking at his sides."
 
Stunned Players React
 Stunned players left the other courts to gather around Lewis. Some tried to prop him up while others went to call the Brandeis police.
"After a minute or so he simply stopped breathing," said Weiss.
Joseph C. McDonald Jr., the director of public safety at Brandeis, said that the campus police were first alerted at 5:12 that someone had collapsed. A sergeant who was outside the Gosman Athletic Center, where the Shapiro gym is located, responded to the call.
According to a transcript provided by Brandeis, the sergeant radioed the dispatcher at 5:13. A second officer arrived and began to give Lewis mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. The ambulance got there at 5:19, and emergency medical technicians tried to revive Lewis with electric shocks.
 
Worse and Worse
 But Lewis looked worse and worse. Weiss said his eyes had rolled back.
"He looked more like a rag doll than a person," Weiss said. "I kept saying, 'My God, Reggie's dead.' "
McDonald said the rescue workers continued their attempts to revive Lewis before moving him. Lewis arrived at Waltham-Weston Hospital, about five blocks from the gym, shortly after 5:40 P.M. The Brandeis police blocked traffic along the route to the hospital.
After spending 1 hour 50 minutes trying to resuscitate Lewis, doctors pronounced him dead at 7:30 P.M.
Today, Weiss enrolled in a CPR class at the hospital. "There's no way I'm seeing this again as an observer," he said.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Return of Houdini: He Works for Padres

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Sometimes making players disappear is the most difficult task a general manager has. If Joe McIlvaine, for example, or Al Harazin before him could find a club willing to take Vince Coleman in a trade, he would be a magician of the highest order. Poof, gone is the surly, troublemaking, largely noncontributory left fielder.
Gene Michael, the Yankees' general manager, has earned his magician's wand more than once. A year and a half ago, he traded Steve Sax to the Chicago White Sox when Sax was just beginning a four-year, $12.4 million contract extension. Last August he traded Tim Leary, with one year left on his contract at $1.3 million, to the Seattle Mariners. 
Sometimes the general manager facilitates his disappearing act by agreeing to pay part of the traded player's contract, but it often is a magical feat nonetheless.
The newest prestidigitator among general managers is Randy Smith, at age 30 the youngest at his job in the major leagues. Smith, a rookie general manager as well as a rookie magician, made Bruce Hurst disappear the other day.
Trading a healthy Hurst would have required no sleight of hand. He is a veteran left-hander whom many contending teams would have coveted, indeed did covet, waiting only for him to return to active duty and show that his surgical shoulder was sound.
But Smith didn't wait for Hurst to be healthy. Before a stunned audience of colleagues around the major leagues, he waved his magic wand, and the pitcher instantly disappeared from the San Diego stage and materialized in the Rocky Mountains.
Smith, however, had at least one other trick up his sleeve in performing his act, maybe two.
To induce Smith's former boss, General Manager Bob Gebhard of the Colorado Rockies, to take Hurst, the Padres agreed to continue paying Hurst's salary until he is off the disabled list, where he has been virtually all season. That means the Padres, through today, are responsible for all except $1 million of Hurst's $2.75 million base salary, and their share will continue to grow until he pitches for the Rockies.
Some general managers suspect that Smith used yet another trick. We'll give you Greg Harris, they think he could have told Gebhard, if you take Hurst, too. Harris is the healthy pitcher who was in the five-player trade the teams made Monday.
Healthy or otherwise, Harris and Hurst were the last two high-priced players the Padres wanted to purge from their payroll. They released Kurt Stillwell the next day, but they have to pay the rest of his $1.75 million salary.
So Smith has done the job he was hired to do, the job McIlvaine didn't have the stomach for. Nor the lack of integrity, though that is not to question or malign Smith's integrity because he took the job under different circumstances than McIlvaine.
It is the Padres' owners who should be questioned, no matter what Bud Selig says. Selig, acting head of the major leagues, says Tom Werner is "one of the brightest owners who have come into baseball in years." He also says the Padres' owners can't be faulted for trying to live within their means. Therefore, he said several weeks ago when the team could be salvaged for the fans, he would not even consider taking any action against the Padres to stop them from systematically dismantling their team.
But if Werner is so bright, why did he tell McIlvaine when he hired him less than three years ago he was prepared to do what it took to build a contender? Why did he allow the 1993 media guide to put Gary Sheffield, "Batting Champ," and Fred McGriff, "Home Run King," on the cover? Why did he include in the guide an owners' statement of commitment to make the Padres "contenders for years to come"?
If Werner is so bright, why doesn't he find a buyer for the team who will give San Diego fans what he and his partners have promised but won't -- not can't -- deliver?
The Padres have been able to shed their best players with impunity because the major leagues do not have a commissioner who could have stepped in and halted or at least questioned their actions, as Bowie Kuhn did with Charlie Finley in 1976.
Selig won't act because he himself owns a team in a small market (Milwaukee), he is suffering financially and he feels for the Padres.
Furthermore, the worse the economic situation looks for small-market teams, the stronger their case for getting a greater share of the large-market clubs' revenue. The Pittsburgh Pirates, another small-market club, have done their part in that quest by firing two vice presidents ostensibly because they couldn't afford them. Some baseball people would rather have the examples of the Padres and the Pirates than do anything or criticize them.
The Padres' owners, though, are not without redeeming value. If they sell the team, they could move to Washington and offer their services there. Anybody who can reduce a payroll in less than four months from $24,557,333 to $10,458,333 should be able to do something with the national debt. They're the real magicians.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Wise Decision on Steel

 BODY:
It's tempting to criticize the decision by the International Trade Commission to eliminate many of the tariffs that protect American steel producers from foreign competition. After all, the Commerce Department had ruled that many foreign suppliers were violating U.S. trade laws by selling at prices that did not cover their costs -- an injustice the tariffs were designed to correct.
But the criticism is off target. The commission's decision is a model of professional discretion. It carefully sifted the data to determine, as U.S. law requires, whether foreign subsidies and price cutting had injured the large, integrated steel mills that brought the complaints. What the commission found was that in many cases the foreign imports weren't the villain. 
 The large mills have lost business, and racked up huge losses, primarily because of the explosive growth of other American producers -- the minimills that cut costs by using scrap metal and non-union labor. The commission's staff also showed that imported steel often sold at higher prices than American steel because of its high quality or availability.
The commission came down in favor of one set of domestic producers -- the thousands of manufacturers that use steel -- over another, the large integrated mills that sell steel. That was not only the right legal decision but also the best choice for the economy because it will protect the jobs of thousands of American workers in steel-using industries -- everything from baseball cleats to automobile parts. And by lowering manufacturing costs, the commission's decisions will lead to lower prices for millions of consumers.
The rulings were not all bad news for big steel manufacturers. Where the evidence justified it, the commission slapped heavy tariffs on selected products -- such as rust-resistant steel imported from Japan.
The commission's work (despite the "international" in its title, it's a Federal agency) is governed by laws against unfair foreign exports. These laws are hopelessly biased in favor of the domestic industry that brings a complaint. They find unfair price-cutting and domestic injury where none exist. But the evidence in this case couldn't meet even this easy test. The commission honored itself (and helped the economy) by taking each case separately and making decisions on the merits.
The battle over steel tariffs is far from over. The industry took about three nanoseconds to decide to take its case to Capitol Hill, where it hopes to win with politics what it couldn't with economics. Congress and President Clinton will be lobbied hard for quotas that can only hurt steel-using manufacturers, their workers and millions of consumers.
The commission got it right, and Congress ought to leave matters alone.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Our No. 1 Objective Is to Keep the Yankees in Yankee Stadium;
Let Him Go

 BODY:

To the Editor:
During the John V. Lindsay administration, New York City spent about $75 million to renovate Yankee Stadium. George Steinbrenner now threatens to leave the Bronx because he says the neighborhood is not safe.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposes that the $75 million go down the tubes, the city take over the ballpark, do what with is anybody's guess, and the public foot the bill for a new stadium on Manhattan's West Side. 
 New York City and State are in economic and social crisis. It is not the fault of George Steinbrenner, but neither is he the cure. We should take a cue from San Francisco and San Jose, Calif., which said no when the Giants asked for more.
Richard Sandomir's July 13 sports column points out George Steinbrenner pays New York City nothing from his $486 million cable television deal and has not paid $6.1 million in rent for the last three years and $1.6 million in electricity since 1991. Mr. Steinbrenner thinks the city owes him $2.6 million. The Yankees may be playing world class baseball, but it seems to me George Steinbrenner is a world class freeloader. If he does not want to act like a responsible citizen, let him go.
 
BENJAMIN M. HABER
Flushing, Queens, July 22, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Tandem Reports a $550 Million Deficit in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
Tandem Computers Inc. yesterday reported a $550 million third-quarter loss because of charges for a corporate overhaul that will result in the loss of 1,800 jobs in the next year.
Wall Street analysts and industry experts were surprised at the size of the loss and the depth of the restructuring, even though the company had warned earlier this month that a quarterly loss and dismissals should be expected. 
 "This is not unlike I.B.M. and Apple, which went through similar restructurings," said Tim Bajarin, president of Creative Strategies, a research firm in Santa Clara, Calif. "All these guys were living with the luxury culture of the 1980's," he said, referring to a period of fat profit margins and growing revenue for computer makers.
Tandem said its entire work force of 10,734 would experience a permanent 5 percent cut in pay and benefits. The company's current round of streamlining will also result in consolidation at Tandem offices throughout the nation. The company already consolidated its manufacturing sites in 1991.
Even without the restructuring charges, Tandem had an operating loss of $44 million in the period, which ended June 30. Revenue fell 5 percent in the period.
Tandem, based in Cupertino, Calif, makes fault-tolerant computer systems, which are designed not to fail even under extreme conditions. Like other computer makers, Tandem is being battered by weak economic conditions, particularly in Europe, and steep price-cutting by competitors and the move away from expensive mainframes.
Last week, Tandem belatedly joined the discounting fray with its new Himalaya systems, which the company says are half the price of its old Cyclone systems and twice as powerful.
The company's quarterly results were hurt by customers who held off making purchases in anticipation of the new product.
James G. Treybig, Tandem's president and chief executive, forecast in a statement that streamlining will return the company to profitability within six months, even assuming only 5 percent revenue growth.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET DEBATE;
Clinton Gives His Tax Plan a Homey Touch

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
The flowers were fake, the books borrowed and the stiff poses could have been from "Family Feud." But the faux homey set on a White House stage had a real political purpose: to give a human dimension to President Clinton's fight for an economic plan that is being derided as taxing and spending.
Arrayed in awkward tableaux on sofas, love seats and chairs were three families who described themselves as both working and poor. With coaxing from the President and his wife, Hillary, the families spoke in poignant terms about how a Federal tax credit was helping them escape the depths of poverty. 
 The President has proposed a $28 billion expansion of the earned-income tax credit program, the greatest in more than two decades. A scaled-down version of his proposal now appears almost certain to win favor on Capitol Hill, even while other important elements of his economic plan lie in grave danger.
But the White House also sees the program as carrying the kind of basic appeal that might help to carry the whole plan -- and bitter medicine like higher gasoline taxes -- past its critics. As he stood today with the families from Georgia, Kentucky and Oklahoma, Mr. Clinton said he believed that its intention of lifting every working family with children above the poverty line should be "part of the human creed."
"People who can work, should work," the President said after his guests shared simple stories of using the tax credit to pay overdue bills, buy school clothes and to pay for a used car as transportation to a faraway job. "But if they do work, their families at home shouldn't be poor," he added.
The spectacle today was the most ambitious effort in a new White House campaign using techniques honed by Mr. Clinton in last year's Presidential campaign. But now the talk-show style that helped in selling a candidate are being used in a bid for support for a package whose contents -- like the broad-based energy tax and the earned-income tax credit itself -- are generally known only in arcane terms.
A test of the effort got scant attention on network television news. But the White House, which today released 50 one-page documents in contending that each state would benefit if the tax credit were expanded, appears to be relying even more on its ability to generate favorable local coverage.
 
A Living-Room Setting
 Each of the families had been flown to Washington by the White House, and carpet and upholstered furniture carted in by the General Services Administration transformed a bare wooden stage into the kind of living-room scene used on television interview shows.
The theory, White House officials said, is to win public support for the economic program by trying to tell Americans exactly what it contains.
"People don't know what's in the plan or what it does," one strategist said today in an interview in a "war room" that is being used to coordinate that appeal from the ground floor of an office building across the street from the White House.
As a battle behind closed doors in a Congressional conference committee dwelt on questions like how many more cents Americans should pay for a gallon of gas, the strategist, Ricki Seidman, contended that attention given to those issues had obscured more attractive elements of the economic package.
"This plan will improve people's lives," Ms. Seidman said, expressing a message that Mr. Clinton, top Administration officials and their representatives across the country have repeated in hundreds of interviews, speeches and conversations in recent days as the White House fights to keep the President's economic alive.
Mr. Clinton himself has met individually with at least seven senators and with House Democratic caucuses representing conservative, liberal, black, female and Hispanic lawmakers.
Today's appeal for the plan to expand the earned-income tax credit elaborated on what Mr. Clinton described in his State of the Union Message as a "solemn and simple commitment" to help the millions of Americans who remain in poverty even while holding full-time jobs.
 
House and Senate Versions
 A Clinton proposal approved by the House would provide for a $28.3 billion increase over the next five years in what is now an $11-billion-a-year program to assist the working poor.
The Senate approved an $18 billion version of the plan, which would increase current benefits and expand the number of eligible workers. But White House officials said today that they were confident the Congressional conferees would approve a compromise that would allow the President to fulfill his pledge: that Americans who work 40 hours a week and have a child at home would no longer live in poverty.
For that reason, White House officials conceded today that their purpose in bringing the Risners of Mount Sterling, Ky., the Dorseys of Atlanta and the Dikemans of Tulsa, Okla., to Washington did not reflect any concern about the tax credit's immediate fate.
The officials said instead that they wanted to remind Americans that beyond the abbreviations and acronyms of the budget plan lay a proposal whose billions of dollars in new spending would serve people who worked just as hard as they did but still faced heavy burdens.
As the Clintons listened from a small love seat, Kevin Dorsey, a 31-year-old warehouse manager, said a credit amounting to $800 a year had "opened doors" for his family of four, sitting with him on a couch. And Robin Dikeman, a divorced mother whose son and daughter sat and stood on either side of her armchair, said, "I can honestly say that it is one of the few things that's kept us going."
"This is the real world," Mr. Clinton told the lawmakers and reporters who looked on at the living-room set from seats in the auditorium. "You met it today."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1223 words

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Crusader For Change: Morihiro Hosokawa

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 29

 BODY:
When he was Governor of Kumamoto, a prosperous prefecture on the southern island of Kyushu, Morihiro Hosokawa liked to tell about the time he tried to move a downtown bus stop.
"For an advanced country, this is embarrassing," he told two Americans lingering over coffee in his sunny office one afternoon. "To move the stop a few hundred meters, I had to send a delegation to Tokyo. In Japan, you can't tie your own shoes without official permission." 
 Over the years this story has become a metaphor for his uncommonly harsh critique of his own country. That afternoon he argued that Japan, fattened by wealth and complacency, had surrendered to turf-minded bureaucrats and "politicians who bow at every phone pole rather than think about the broad problems of Japan." What Japan needed, he said, was its own Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a veteran of the system who was willing to shatter it.
This afternoon, in perhaps the oddest twist yet in recent weeks, Mr. Hosokawa was handed that chance. Only 14 months after he started the Japan New Party, he was tapped to become the head of a coalition Government that seems destined to seize power from the Liberal Democratic Party.
By early next month, when Parliament votes, the tall 55-year-old firebrand will be master of every bus stop and telephone pole in the world's second largest economy -- and inheritor of a political system that by his own description has "grown moribund, and out of touch with the realities of the rest of the world."
It is a critique that many Americans will doubtless applaud, and it echoes many of the United States' own complaints. But now that he appears on the verge of coming to power far more quickly that anyone expected, there are already doubts about whether a man who revels in playing the outsider can achieve what he calls the "third opening of Japan."
The first was brought about by the arrival of the American fleet in the 1850's, the second by the Occupation forces, who ran Japan when Mr. Hosokawa was a teen-ager. This one, Mr. Hosokawa says, Japan will have to do on its own.
It will not be easy. Even before Mr. Hosokawa steps into the Prime Minister's residence, many in Tokyo suspect he is being set up to fail. Inexperienced in the ways of the capital, he may prove an easy target for the powerful bureaucrats whom he has lambasted. The party he once belonged to, the Liberal Democrats, will be waiting for his fragile coalition of Socialists and conservatives to splinter, looking for its chance to regain a grip on the nation few thought it would ever lose.
 
An Unknown Quantity
 In a country that warms to predictability, Mr. Hosokawa is an unknown quantity, chosen by the coalition precisely because he appears untainted by an endless stream of corruption and influence-peddling that has tarred most of the other leaders.
The direct descendant of a famous family of shoguns, Morihiro Hosokawa was born on Jan. 14, 1938, in another era of political chaos. At the time his maternal grandfather, Fumimaro Konoe, was Prime Minister, advocating a reduction in the West's influence in Asia and the rise of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.
Historians still argue over whether Mr. Konoe was a moving force behind the invasion of China and the militarist policies that led to Pearl Harbor, or whether he was manipulated by the military. But his name was high on the list of those the United States sought to put on trial as war criminals. He killed himself just before he was supposed to enter custody.
If there is a lesson from his grandfather's experience as Prime Minister, Mr. Hosokawa wrote last year in Japan's leading intellectual magazine, Bungei Shunju, it was simple. "If you raise your voice," he said, "you must raise it clearly."
 
12 Years in Parliament
 In a journalistic and political career that spans 30 years, Mr. Hosokawa has usually followed his own advice -- until recent weeks, when he has said surprisingly little about the political upheaval beneath his feet.
A graduate of Sophia University, he went to work in 1963 for Japan's most liberal newspaper, the Asahi Shimbun. He was a conspicuous presence even then: A friend from that time remembers that Mr. Hosokawa drove a Volkswagen, wore expensive suits, and kept houses in Kyoto and the resort town of Karuizawa, high living for a reporter.
But he soon quit the job for politics, running under the Liberal Democratic flag for the less-powerful upper house of Parliament. He won at age 33, and spent the next 12 years in the Parliament, serving in second-tier posts. He later recalled watching the system at work, with legislators "mere tools of Government agencies, constantly trying to reflect the ideas of bureaucrats in party decisions."
"I was appalled," he concluded.
He returned to Kumamoto, where the Hosokawa daimyo, or fief, had lasted from 1632 to 1868. Elected Governor in 1983, he quickly gained a reputation for energy -- he competed in a nationwide ski contest for the prefecture -- and for economic development. The area's rice fields are now dotted with technology parks and semiconductor plants. But he also found himself constantly at battle with the Government, which he described as "even more reactionary and absolutist than the premodern, feudalistic system of the shoguns."
His big break with the party, however, came last year, after the mounting frustrations of serving on a Government panel charged with streamlining Japan's administrative system. He watched helplessly as the Ministry of Finance watered down a key recommendation to create a Security and Exchange Commission to crack down on stock fraud.
 
Election Successes>
 Soon he decided to create the Japan New Party, vowing to end one-party rule, to bring more women into politics, to clean up corruption and to offer a reasonable alternative to opposition parties like the Socialists that have "addled and grown rigid with age."
He talked vaguely of a new age of relations with the United States, a place he clearly admires. Like many in Japan's elite classes, he has sent his children to the United States for education.
The New Party scored modestly in upper house elections last summer, when he spoke often and fervently, but rarely to very large crowds. That has begun to change. In recent months the party has blossomed, scoring impressively in Tokyo elections and then in the contest on July 18 for the lower house. It won 35 seats, and merged forces with another group of Liberal Democratic Party dissidents. One of the most tireless campaigners was his wife, Kayoko.
Inevitably, Mr. Hosokawa has begun to face criticism along the way. An aide who was forced out of the party recently portrayed him as a minor tyrant, and many have complained that he recruited inexperienced candidates who are bound to lose after the party's novelty wears off. At times he seemed too close to the old-line politicians.
In May he wrote that it would be "tantamount to a suicide" for his party to collaborate with the forces being gathered by former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata and by Ichiro Ozawa, perhaps the country's most powerful politician. But this week, saying it was the only way to bring about a change of government, he announced the collaboration, leading to his selection as the man to stand for the premiership.
