SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1292 words

HEADLINE: COALITION IN JAPAN NAMES NEW LEADER TO BECOME PREMIER

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 29

 BODY:
A conservative populist who has promised to reduce the intrusive role of government in the Japanese economy was all but assured today of becoming the country's first non-Liberal Democratic Prime Minister in 38 years when he was chosen to lead a coalition of opposition parties.
The selection of Morihiro Hosokawa, a descendant of feudal lords who at 55 would be the second-youngest Prime Minister in the postwar era, is expected to be formalized at a special session of Parliament beginning next week. 
 "The leaders of the seven parties have made this decision, so I humbly will comply with this divine mission," said Mr. Hosokawa.
 
Two Months of Change
 Today's decision capped two months of the most drastic change in recent political history and started the industrial world's most conservative country on a slow journey toward a more open economy, greater support for consumers and a more active international role, all goals that the United States has pushed in recent years.
The decision would install a sort of rainbow coalition of conservatives and Socialists whose policy differences have been papered over so they can achieve their principal shared aims -- to unseat the discredited Liberal Democrats and reform the corrupt electoral system.
Beyond those goals there is great uncertainty over the speed of any changes, in particular because some proposed policies are expected to face fierce resistance from bureaucrats.
 
'Beginning of the Beginning'
 "This is the beginning of the beginning of something," said Haruo Shimada, an economics professor at Keio University and an adviser to Mr. Hosokawa's Japan New Party. "It's part of an important learning process for all Japanese. We've chosen to change the power structure. Now we have to think about what we want the new Government to do."
He added: "In the short-term, I don't think there'll be much change. It may take at least 5 or 10 years to tackle some of these problems."
Former Liberal Democrats make up the core of the coalition. Mr. Hosokawa's main rival for the premiership was Tsutomu Hata, who led a wave of defections by three dozen Liberal Democrats last month.
The coalition's composition has prompted some to question how different the group's policies will really be. Mr. Hosokawa's reformist credentials rely on the fact that he took the risk of leaving the Liberal Democrats to mount his challenge 14 months ago, when the party still looked unassailable.
The first two items the new Government is expected to tackle are a budget including a heavy jolt of spending to lift the economy from its stubborn recession, and legislation to end corporate political donations and reshape the electoral districts.
The coalition promised that it would generally preserve current foreign and security policies, but in one highly symbolic departure, said it intended to open a new era in relations with the rest of Asia by confronting the memories of World War II and offering for the first time a full apology for the suffering caused by Japanese aggression.
Beyond that, however, lies great uncertainty. Mr. Hosokawa, a former Governor of prosperous Kumamoto prefecture in southwestern Japan, is a man of modest national political experience who has already reversed his policies several times in his quest for the premiership.
He said earlier that he would lift the ban on rice imports, an issue with great symbolism here, but the coalition opposes that position.
 
Abandoning Past Policies
 He will be leading conservatives who have insisted they will abandon years of favoring big business joined with Socialists who have promised to abandon decades of resistance to Japan's military and its nuclear power plants.
This disparity in basic views has led to widespread expectations that the new government will falter in its attempts to enact some of its major programs and thus will be forced to call new elections within a year.
Many business leaders have supported the nascent two-party system, despite their huge financial support for the Liberal Democrats, and have tacitly approved to the coalition. But they are already indicating that they want results rather than vague statements and too heavy a focus on electoral reform as an end in itself.
"People are talking too much about political reform," said Minoru Murofushi, president of Itochu, one of Japan's largest trading companies. "It is important, but we need economic recovery more."
Until this morning, it looked as if the coalition might be led by Mr. Hata, a former Finance Minister. His defection from the Liberal Democrats last month brought about the downfall of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and eventually resulted in the party's loss of a parliamentary majority.
 
Hata Passed Over
 Mr. Hata, head of the conservative Japan Renewal Party, is expected to have a large voice in the coalition's policies. But he was reportedly passed over for the top post because he and his chief lieutenant, Ichiro Ozawa, are perceived as having been too closely aligned with the most powerful and corrupt faction of the Liberal Democrats.
Mr. Ozawa in particular suffers from a damaging taint because, though he has been charged with no wrongdoing, he was the protege of Shin Kanemaru, the party's former kingmaker, who went on trial for tax evasion last week.
Nonetheless, Mr. Ozawa is expected to play a key, if quiet role, and some credit him with having masterminded the remarkable sequence of events that, in the span of two months, turned Japanese politics on its head.
"It's really up to Ozawa," Mr. Shimada said when asked about the prospects of a tax cut. "He's controlling everything behind the scenes."
The coalition also includes the Clean Government Party, which is affiliated with a Buddhist organization; the Harbinger Party, composed of recent Liberal Democratic defectors, and several small centrist groups.
The coalition has laid out policies that could, over time, have a major impact on the economy and on society.
 
Tax Changes Promised
 In the economic sphere, it said it would introduce a package of government spending programs to stimulate the wobbly economy and consider reducing individual taxes.
It has promised to ease the heavy regulations under which the economy labors and to decentralize the government. And it endorses a major effort to ease trade frictions with the United States, and thus, by implication, to take steps to reduce Japan's huge trade surpluses.
The political reform plan would create a hybrid electoral system in the lower house of the Parliament. Currently, anywhere from three to six representatives are elected from each district, which often pits members of the same party against each other.
Under the proposal, about half of Parliament would be made up of representatives from single-seat constituencies, and the rest elected by proportional representational along party lines.
Equally important, the coalition proposed banning corporate campaign contributions, introducing public election financing and stiffening penalties for violations of election laws. It is believed that this could help build a two-party system and introduce policy debates to election campaigns.
"You have to keep in mind that what we are creating is a framework for political debate," said Kazuo Aichi, a central policymaker in the Japan Renewal Party. "It's not unlike your Democrats and Republicans."

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
After the Deluge, Midwest Lawyers Are Offering Free Ports in a Gathering Legal Storm.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
The lovingly restored law office of F. Coulter de Vries, in what was once a warehouse in Kansas City, Mo., recently sat under several feet of the Kaw River and Turkey Creek, two tributaries of the swollen Missouri River. His files were waterlogged, his furniture floating, his computers saturated with silt and sewage.
"There was brown slime everywhere," he said. "An inch of mud covered the carpeting. And you could tell that everything had floated for a while." 
 Lawyers generally favor either high-rise office buildings or the high ground adjacent to county courthouses or high-rent districts far from flood plains. So Mr. de Vries notwithstanding, they may not have been victimized by the floods in the Midwest in proportion to their numbers. But as the eight states within the newly declared Federal disaster area prepare to dig out and dry out, lawyers there are pitching in.
For the past dozen years, the Young Lawyers Division of the American Bar Association has contracted with the Federal Emergency Management Agency to provide free legal assistance to disaster victims. Through Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco area earthquake in 1989, and during the Los Angeles riots in the spring of 1992, its efforts were modest. But things intensified last August in Florida, when, along with everything else, Hurricane Andrew left a host of legal worries in its wake.
Must one pay rent on a home transformed into a pile of sticks? Must a Miamian pay his bills on time when his checkbook floats somewhere in the Gulf of Mexico? Is a contractor liable when his work fails to withstand acts of God? About 2,000 lawyerscounseled thousands of fellow Floridians on such problems. And now, just as many lawyers in Iowa, Missouri and half a dozen other states are gearing up to do the same thing.
Lest the program degenerate into well-organized ambulance chasing, the rules are clear: All services are free; any fee-generating cases are sent to lawyer referral networks, which farm out clients to lawyers not participating in the program.
It is the kind of effort more likely to excite Charles Kuralt than Jay Leno, whose recent swipes at the bar association led Michael Scanlon, its public relations czar, to complain to the comedian. (He got an apology, plus an invitation to the "Tonight Show."
"No one is making a buck out of this," said Dirk Behrends of the Young Lawyers Division, who is the administrator of the program.
The deeper the water, the more intense the lawyers' efforts.
Martha Fagg, a Des Moines lawyer who is coordinating the disaster program in Iowa, said plans are under way to hold seminars for flood victims in Davenport, Denison, Burlington, Waterloo, Maquoeketa and several other cities, with eight to 10 lawyers participating in each. Many volunteers are in Cedar Rapids today for a seminar on flood-related legal issues, organized by the Legal Services Corporation of Iowa. What they learn will enable them to field questions at FEMA disaster assistance centers and over a toll-free hot line.
The calls are already coming. A riverboat captain unable to ply his trade in the swollen waters wants to know if he is eligible for unemployment benefits. A homeowner wants to know if the city can be stopped from pumping water onto his property. A parent complains that a day care center unable to take her child because of the flood is nonetheless dunning her for its services. There have been 30 such calls so far, fewer than Dennis Groenenboom, executive director of the legal services office, expected.
"In many parts of the state, people are still bailing out," he said. "They haven't got past the point of figuring out where they're going to eat, where they're going to live, where they're going to get water." He expects the legal storm to set in months after the meteorological one has subsided.
In Missouri, lawyers are working at 26 disaster application centers. Their presence, said Rick Morefield of Kansas City, the Young Lawyers representative in the state, will spare Missouri the kind of portable law offices that sprouted up like toadstools amid the detritus in Florida.
One lawyer who will not be participating is Mr. de Vries, who is too busy setting up a new law office -- on higher ground -- and helping paying clients deal with the damage.
At the same time, he is busy salvaging what he can from his old office. He is getting help from one of his clients, American Catastrophe and Environmental Services Inc., which cleaned up the hotels, palaces and government buildings of Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war. Also assisting are his three young daughters, who are squeegeeing soggy files, then blow-drying them.
"We've already gotten everybody tetanus shots, and we're going to have to iron some of the documents," Mr. de Vries said. "But we've got everything saved."

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Official Sees Cuba in Crisis

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
Riven by food shortages and economic hardship, Cuba is suffering its worst political crisis in 30 years, a senior Central Intelligence Agency official said today.
"Castro's Government is in acute distress," the official, Brian Latell, the C.I.A.'s top analyst of Latin American affairs, said at a rare open meeting of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. "The impact of the economic crisis on the populace has been devastating." 
 Cuba's economy is half what it was four years ago, the sugar harvest is the worst since 1963 and next to no money remains to import basic consumer goods, Mr. Latell said. Half the workers lack steady jobs, food shortages are causing malnutrition and disease, fuel shortages leave Havana without power for up to 16 hours a day and public transportation has all but collapsed, he said.
President Fidel Castro legalized the use of United States dollars in Cuba on Monday, intending to provide a measure of economic relief by spurring foreign investment and tourism. But the C.I.A. analyst said that would only aggravate social and political tensions because relatively few Cubans would receive dollars from relatives in the United States.
Quoting Ricardo Alarcon, the President of the Cuban National Assembly, he called such changes "feeding a Trojan horse."
A central question for the United States, which spent considerable energy in the 1960's trying to overthrow the Cuban Government and assassinate Mr. Castro, is whether try to help Cuba, or try to speed Mr. Castro's collapse.
"What is our vision of a post-Castro Cuba?" asked the chairman of the intelligence committee, Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. "What can we do to assist in bringing about a successful transition without violent eruptions and social upheaval?"

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Bonn's Rate Stance Is Blow to Currency Union

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 29

 BODY:
The foundations of European monetary union seemed gravely threatened today after Germany's central bank left a key interest rate unchanged, deciding that defending the mark from domestic inflation was more pressing than trying to help ease the recession in France.
Since France and Germany, the European Community's two strongest economic powers, had hoped to firmly establish the monetary union by the end of the century, it had been expected in Paris and elsewhere that the political importance of the two countries' alliance would outweigh parochial concerns about whether German inflation rose by a fraction. 
 Thus, for more than a week, it had been anticipated that the German bank, the Bundesbank, would lower its discount rate -- even though its leading officials had repeatedly made clear that defending the value of the mark against inflation was their foremost concern.
 
Unchanged at 6.75 Percent
 But late today, the Bundesbank decided to leave the discount rate, the lending rate to Germany's most creditworthy commercial banks, unchanged at 6.75 percent.
Instead, with little public comment after today's meeting -- its last before a month's vacation -- the bank's central council announced that a second interest indicator, the Lombard rate, which acts as a ceiling on money-market rates, would be lowered half a point, to 7.75 percent from 8.25 percent
To some, this seemed akin to throwing a dry bone into a two-week feeding frenzy of speculation against the franc on currency markets. In late trading today in New York, the French currency traded at 3.4237 to the mark, sinking near its established floor of 3.4305 to the mark, in Europe's grid of exchange rates. This was down from 3.4040 francs to the mark before the Bundesbank's announcement.
The weakening franc prompted the Bank of France to buy francs and sell marks to prop up its currency with the aid of other central banks.
The price of gold soared above $400 an ounce yesterday for the first time in about three years as growing concern that the European Monetary System might fall apart sent investors rushing to buy precious metals. In New York, spot gold settled at $397.80 an ounce, up $4.40, after trading as high as $401. [Page D14.]
The German discount rate is critical because it sets a floor on short-term interest rates both at home and in other countries like France whose currencies are closely tied to the mark. Despite step-by-step reductions that have brought this rate down over the last year, the Bundesbank has been reluctant to cut it faster because of a wave of inflation set off by record government and private borrowing to finance the very high costs of rebuilding the formerly Communist eastern part of Germany, which was reunited with the west in 1990.
 
Mechanism in Trouble
 Now, "the odds of a European Exchange Rate Mechanism realignment or collapse have risen sharply," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief analyst for Salomon Brothers International in London.
Other analysts agreed. "The Exchange Rate Mechanism is going to find it incredibly difficult to survive," a Merrill Lynch economist, Darren Williams, said.
Their advice was, in effect, that clients should sell francs and other European currencies tied to the mark and hold marks or still other currencies. The American dollar quickly rose to more than 1.73 marks, its highest level in 22 months, from 1.7185 late Wednesday.
If investors spur a selloff of francs on Friday, the Bundesbank, which has bought billions of francs in recent weeks to try to shore up the French currency, is expected to join the Bank of France in doing so again.
But if the selling continues because people think that the French will be forced to devalue anyway, they may have to accept either a devaluation of the franc against the mark or suspend the franc temporarily from the European Monetary System. The system, a network of closely linked currencies, was designed to be the forerunner to a single European currency.
There was no immediate reaction to today's German decision in Paris, where President Francois Mitterrand and the conservative Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, have vowed to keep the franc strong against the mark.
Confident of support from the Germans, Mr. Balladur said earlier this month that there would be a change of government before there would be a change in the value of the franc, and on Monday in London, Mr. Mitterrand predicted that "in a few years from now, we will have a single currency."
This Government policy led the Bank of France to sharply raise its short-term interest rate last Friday, to 10 percent from 7.75 percent. The move was intended to show currency speculators that Paris would not be bullied into devaluing the franc against the mark, even though higher interest rates were the last thing that it needed in the current European recession.
These steps and the policy itself also symbolized Mr. Mitterrand's determination to press on to monetary union even though most German bankers privately believe that it will not be achieved until sometime in the next century.
 
Looking to Bundesbank
 The Bundesbank's president, Helmut Schlesinger, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl have repeatedly expressed the view that no fundamental economic factors justified a devaluation of the franc, but what the markets were looking for today was to see whether the German central bank would put its money where its mouth was and lower short-term rates by half or even a whole percentage point, to get the franc off the hook.
Instead, it did what it has nearly always done and put the mark first. Now, depending on what happens on the currency markets, the French authorities may have to choose between devaluing their currency against the mark or suspending their membership in the European Monetary System.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET DEBATE;
Fear Is Rife in Capitol As the Tax Figures Fly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
The papers keep writing that a handful of wise and crafty lawmakers are closeted this week in big mahogany-slathered rooms in the Capitol, bifocals on and ties askew, reworking President Clinton's economic package to meet Congress's practical political needs. Literally, this is true.
But something altogether different is also going on. The mahogany doors have been closed for two weeks now without results, and fear is mushrooming among the political animals outside; rumor is riot, and everyone smells the annual August recess, now eight days distant, the way long horns smell water in cattle-drive westerns. 
 And so the deliberative process of producing a budget compromise has lost much of its deliberation, and all its privacy. The whole Congress has elbowed its way in -- at least, all 314 Democrats have -- and the craft of legislation has become equal parts Istanbul bazaar, World Wrestling Federation and London during the blitz, waiting for the bombs to fall.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago, the head of the House budget negotiators, is asked where the Senate negotiators, led by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, stand on the issues.
 
A Temper Restrained
 "I don't know where the Senate is!" he barks, then catches himself. "I mean, physically, I don't know where the Senate is."
He is asked whether the Senate would pass a 6.5-cent increase in the gasoline tax if it was included in the economic package.
"They can't pass anything!" He catches himself again, and pins that opinion on the Senate. "That's what they say. I don't know."
No one knows. That is what has made these talks over Mr. Clinton's proposal to raise $250 billion in new taxes and cut $250 billion in spending over the next five years so wrenchingly difficult, and so dangerous for the President.
Presented with a vacuum in consensus, Democrats of every stripe are rushing to fill it with propositions of their own, based on everything from lengthy analysis to undiluted politics, and frequently in direct conflict.
Delicate alliances, toothpick-and-glue affairs built with months of persuasion, begin to fragment under the weight of anxiety and public pressure.
On the crucial question of a gasoline tax -- a big-ticket money-raiser whose revenue binds the entire economic package together, like mayonnaise in a tuna salad -- the deterioration is almost visible.
When House Democrats approved their version of the package in May, they voted for a broad-based energy tax that included a 7.6-cent-a-gallon tax increase on gasoline and would cost an average family nearly $15 a month.
Today Congress was gossiping about the prospect of a 6.5-cent gas tax increase, costing an average driver perhaps $3.50 a month, and was balking at that.
 
Counting Drivers' Dollars
 Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who is one of the House leadership's most energetic vote-counters, called that figure "saleable."
But Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, who voted for the energy tax in May, now calls the 6.5-cent gas tax a "middle-income tax," and predicts that the House would reject it.
Over in the Senate, Herb Kohl, a first-term Democrat who faces a potentially difficult re-election battle, voted for that chamber's 4.3-cent gas tax in June. Now he looks at 6.5 cents -- an extra buck and a quarter a month, for average drivers -- and blanches. "Above 4.3, I would not be able to vote for it," he says.
Back in the House, Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Maryland Democrat and an influential liberal, strolls into an ornate hallway to promote another idea. He would raise the tax rate on corporate income to 36 percent from 34 percent -- a point above the current proposal -- and use the proceeds to lower the gas tax and finance social programs.
Mr. Rostenkowski hears that and erupts, knowing that would drive conservatives away in droves. "The corporate rate is agreed to!" he snaps, and walks into House Speaker Thomas S. Foley's office.
 
Heavy Courting by Clinton
 So it went all day, one lawmaker floating a tax increase that affronted another lawmaker's stance on the need for balance between taxes and spending, that upset still another lawmaker's political necessities -- all linked, and none alterable without changing everything else.
There are two ways to break this gridlock. Mr. Clinton has been trying one this week, courting recalcitrant lawmakers with private visits in the Oval Office, pledges of future assistance and blandishments from other celebrities in the Administration.
One holdout Democrat, Representative David Minge of Minnesota, said he believes the White House is collaring his local political backers and asking them to lobby on the White House's behalf.
To persuade Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona to switch from "no" to "yes," the President not only dispatched Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt -- a fellow Arizonan and a logical choice -- but Secretary of State Warren Christopher as well.
The other way is being practiced by Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Moynihan, who truly do gather in mahogany-slathered rooms, bifocals on noses, and grind away at the numbers with their cadres of aides.
 
'I Am Not Nervous'
 Mr. Moynihan has been visibly gloomy about the pace of events lately, but today he was mum. Asked whether he was nervous about a Senate defeat, he sniffled, fingered a package of decongestants, and evaded. "I am not nervous," he replied. "I am a man preoccupied with the question of how you get a cold in July. And what the hell is Coricidin D?" With that, he stalked into an elevator.
But Mr. Moynihan and his fellow bargainers are nervous.
"You want to think you're making all the decisions for good policy reasons," said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, an earnest Democrat who is that chamber's chief negotiator on health-care spending. "In fact, decisions are being driven by another reason: mathematics. And some decisions are being driven by another kind of mathematics -- the ratio of spending to spending cuts."
 
'A Few Nicks, That's All'
 Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a fiscally more conservative and even more earnest Democratic Senator, was derisive of the process in a different way. "The mood of the country is to cut expenditures," he said during a ride from the Capitol to his office on one of Congress's toy subway trains. "The leadership tells us we'll have a chance to cut when the appropriations bills come up for a vote. We all know what's going to happen on the appropriations bills -- nothing, a few nicks, that's all."
His argument was that coalitions of politicians are always at the ready to spend more money or protect existing programs, but rarely to cut programs or raise taxes. "They just voted $94 million this week," he said, "for a courthouse I didn't even ask for, in Omaha."
That is a truism, of course. But rarely has it seemed truer than this week, when Messrs. Rostenkowski, Moynihan and Clinton are trying to push, drag and seduce their party into approving what is, by most accounts, the largest tax increase and spending cut in any Government's history.
Can they do it? "Miracles can happen," said Representative William O. Lipinski, like Mr. Rostenkowski a Chicago Democrat from a strongly ethnic neighborhood.
But Mr. Lipinski voted no on the package in May, and so far, he said today, nothing had persuaded him to change his mind.
